[u]Rating[/u]: 8 out of 10 (see remarks below)
[u]Recommendation[/u]: I mainly play battles and skirmishes so am not familiar with how the campaigns are. Despite modeling many effects in real time, the game is not too demanding on your hardware. There are a few minor glitches, but they do not affect tactics that much. It can seem expensive, especially considering its age, so you might want to wait for a promotional sale.

[u]Positives[/u]:
Overall the unit types are modeled quite realistically in terms of their strengths and weaknesses. Examples include spears and pikes, swords, axes, hammers and maces, polearms, bows, crossbows, firearms, javelins, heavy cavalry, light cavalry, elephants, mounted archers and crossbowmen, and siege weapons; some carry shields while others do not. The combat mechanics takes into account factors such as obstacles, concealment, shield coverage, the momentum of cavalry charges, stamina (which recovers more slowly than it is drained, especially for mounts such as horses), armor piercing capabilities, and magazine capacity. Morale is also modeled, where less disciplined troops rout more easily, which can snowball across an army to your advantage or detriment. You may need to balance between quality and quantity, defense and offense, range and melee, field battle and siege performance. Although the game was released more than a decade ago, the graphics is still very much acceptable compared to newer titles, and running it consumes much less computing resources.

[u]Negatives[/u]:
I tried the campaigns a little but found them terribly boring and tedious, like variations on Civilization but with more micromanagement and less focus on economics. There are a few glitches with combat affecting certain units' animation and vulnerability to interruption, but the difference is not that noticeable in my experience. The game manual does not cover every detail of the combat mechanics, such as shield coverage and armor piercing, so you may want to do your own research online. The game might come bundled with expansions and add-ons, including new units and campaigns, and as a consequence be priced somewhat high. If you are not interested in the package deal, then you may want to wait for it to be on sale.

I've always LOVED the Medieval time period (the struggles of Kings & Popes), along with the crusades. This game is built right, with the focus on gameplay and a lovely campaign. Other Total War games just do not have the replay-ability as TWM2. 10/10 would recommend, especially if this is your first Total War game. 

*Do not base your decision off the graphics or date of release. Hike up the graphics settings, and listen to the brilliant voice acting :)

So, I've put a hell of a lot of time into this one, but sadly in hindsight must admit that it's time I half wish that I could get back, as there is enough wrong with this game to make it unlikely that I will play it again. Although, the fact the footwell of my car is full of Mcdonalds' bags and empty bottles of coke attests to the fact my willpower is not the best when addictive crap is involved, so I probably will.
This was actually the first steam review I wrote back in the day, and was effectively a prolonged whining session after I had rage quite the game for the umpteenth time. I owned the game pretty much from release in my early teens, and endured an epic saga simply to get it to run on my Dad's primitive computer, only for the game to fail to import the unit animations (As in, all of them) on multiple installations, so despite owning it I had to buy a second copy when I was 19 and spent a good amount of my summer and first university semester playing it, and have done so on and off ever since. I'm a long term fan of the series, even owning (somewhere) a copy of the very first Shogun total war, and I honestly can't understand why this out of all of them is remembered as the best, but that might be others' childhood nostalgia speaking. 
I think my big issue is that most of the game mechanics are marred by some of the most dimwitted AI ever to grace the screen of my PC. Diplomacy, to put it kindly, simply does not work. Unless you are one of the Iberian three, every single faction that you share a border with will declare war on you with zero provocation, and will refuse every single diplomatic option you have except you handing them a big stack of money, and will maybe offer a very temporary ceasefire if they are on the brink of defeat, but even then this is only to give them enough time to get back on their feet to attack you again. Like in Rome, a faction on the brink of defeat will happily charge right across the map to attack you, even as it's last settlement falls to it's enemies. Alliances are worse than useless, because presumably the game developers understood alliance as "Do nothing and then backstab." Not even at the first opportunity, as that would imply the AI has any tactical sense. The fact you are constantly at war with most of the map would seem to be an issue, but most factions you are fighting will just endlessly send hordes of very weak troops to die against you in sieges. They can sometimes have four or five weak armies attacking you all along the border, where maybe investing that money in one strong one would have ensured that their attacks would actually have a result besides wasting time. Your own settlements need a family member present, or else the auto management will activate, and your settlement will be handed over to a Tory Mp, who immediately sets all the taxes to maximum and spends all available money on making endless stacks of weak infantry and useless siege weapons, which will result in you both likely loosing the settlement to the inevitable rebellion and loosing a lot of money on upkeep for the armies of ballistae that you didn't order. Thankfully you can turn this off just before you start a campaign, but even with it off you seem to have public order issues in settlements without a governor present, so I hope you like finding whichever random settlement your generals and family members spawned in and trekking them across the map. I bring this up as the AI seem to be saddled with this issue too, as they are constantly teetering on the brink of both bankruptcy and mass uprisings. I have heard from a friend (and bear in mind that this is hearsay) that the AI will declare war on you if your economy is outperforming theirs, and if so then their economic management must be truly awful. Also, whilst on the topic of economy, the game has two factions that invade part of the ways through the campaign, the Mongols and Timurids. Besides the utter absurdity of these two factions existing at the same time (As Tamerlane was pretty much Genghis' ultimate fanboy), they, unlike any other faction in the game, are not obligated to pay upkeep, and so can steamroll the entire map by attrition. Other campaign issues include your own army AI, which will march  for a dozen turns to get around an army, and both armies and agents will constantly forget their orders if they run into an unexpected army or agent. Which is constant, so you cannot set them to make long journeys without constant supervision. Also, no matter who you are, or how far away you are, Milan will find and declare war on you.
Now, on the second big issue, which is also AI related. The battlefield AI. Artillery is useless, as it is so inaccurate against anything smaller than a castle wall that it's more worth your money to fill that slot in your army with a unit of peasants, because they have a significantly higher chance of killing something on the enemy side than an entire battery of cannons do. Cavalry units (Besides often feeling far weaker than they should) have very little cohesion, and the amount of times that I have ordered a unit to charge only for most of the models to simply stand there, or even flock off in the opposite direction is nothing short of ludicrous. This was also not an issue in Rome, so I'd really love to know how they messed it up in a game that was basically a reskin of rome. Infantry don't even really need to fight as you can literally click right behind an enemy formation and they will just barge their way through. (Something that is an issue in total war "Troy to get me to use the epic store" at time of writing, but not to my knowledge any of the other games). The Enemy Ai has very little grasp of tactics or formation, and is far far too easy to bait into chokepoints or trap in envelopments. Every battle is Cannae when your enemy cannae defend their flanks. (If I didn't know I was already going to hell for liking Postal 2 I'd be going for that joke. I can now go to super hell, which is more exclusive, and has a salad bar). There are also an alarming amount of glitches, such as infantry with two handed weapons being useless because their attack animations get interrupted and can't get attacks off, top tier units from multiplayer than are inexplicably missing in game, or the game taking a tantrum and often crashing if I dare use alt tab to change my music playlist or take a quick break to apply for more Dole under yet another false name.
There's also quite a few balance issues. The Lack of Koumiss taxation to curb the horse archers has already been mentioned. Elephants are broken, and with the horrible artillery accuracy there seems to be no way to counter them. Firearms are too slow and inaccurate to be of any real use, and a lot of top tier stuff from certain factions gets utterly destroyed by mid tier stuff from weaker factions, but besides the Steppe Tide it's not a gigantic issue. Certain factions also seem to have severe issues with moneymaking. I've played around a little with transplanting factions around the map, and Russia, Byzantium and Poland seem to be poorer than everyone else regardless of where you put them. Finally, the game could really do with a few more islamic factions, as there are only three, and they get terribly bullied by the catholic factions.
If you can set all the issues aside there's a decent enough game here, but I have to admit they are too much for me. Go play Warhammer 2 instead, it has rats with machine guns.

Summary: It's a fun Medieval themed turn-based grand strategy game. It's broken in a lot of ways, but the game somehow manages to remain pretty fun. Just so you know what you're getting yourself into...

Pros: 
- Monster ribualt go brrrrrr (it's 40 guns on a wagon, what could go wrong?)
- Conquer the world as Denmark. Bet they weren't expecting a good old-fashioned Viking raid!
- You can keep assassinating the pope if you don't like him (it's the only way to make that system not work against you)
-  You can troll the AI and sneak around to a far away city by boat, then one-shot them with a bunch of siege artillery. Not so funny now, eh Portugal? 
- You can conquer the Papal States and watch the AI factions lose their minds. 
- Wage religious warfare against your neighbors. Send a bunch of priests/imams over and watch their cities descend into chaos. There are no diplomatic ramifications, so have fun.

Cons: 
- Diplomacy is broken. The AI factions will seemingly randomly declare war on you, then will refuse any reasonable attempt at diplomacy unless you give them all of your money (because they're broke).
- You must bow down to the all-mighty Random Number Generator gods! Seriously, there is so much RNG, and somehow it seems unfair. A 95% success chance fails waaaaay too often to be accurate. 
- Unless you love the RTS part of these games, it can get very tedious. Every battle is largely the same, and you can have 150+ battles in a campaign. On the other hand, the auto-resolve function for battles is subject to the same wonky RNG as other parts of the game. It's a good way to lose a giant army in one battle... I suspect because the AI tries to lead charges with archers or something.
- Naval combat was tacked on. There is only an auto-resolve function and there is no option to retreat, so you will eventually lose an army when pirates attack you while trying to sail somewhere. 
- Crusades are ridiculous. You can request a crusade against any non-catholic faction to include excommunicated factions. I've seen crusades called against cities in the English isles, central Europe, and Italy. 
- Calvary are largely useless, for all factions. Again, the AI doesn't apply strategy when auto-resolving battles, so they're just really expensive sub-standard infantry. 
- The merchant characters are bugged. The AI will ALWAYS win in merchant take-overs, and you will ALWAYS lose. 
- Your generals are a bunch of disloyal flakes. They'll sometimes just randomly decide to join the rebel faction while moving between your settlements, because why not. 
- Speaking of generals, you tend to rack up a decent number of worthless, disloyal ones. Since they're high-stat units that seldom die in combat, I like to band them into makeshift armies and send them out into the countryside to "fight crime" - i.e. hunt down my other idiot generals who decided they wanted to be rebels. 
- The AI flat out cheats. If you assassinate all of their leaders, random high-stat new ones will appear out of nowhere.
- If you're about to wipe out a faction (because you're sick of their bullshit) the pope will step in and threaten to excommunicate you if you attack them for a few turns.
- There are actually only 4 factions in the game: The Northwestern Europeans, the Italians, the Slavs, and the Muslim nations. The flags and starting locations may be different, but the unit rosters are almost all the same.

Total War: Medieval II is often considered to be the best entry in the franchise. And it is, for the time it came out. 

I never grew up with this game, in fact my first introduction to the entire franchise was Empire Total War. I'm not looking at this game with the same nostalgic glasses as some long time players of the franchise are. There is a lot to love about this game but there is also plenty to dislike. 

Let's get the good stuff out of the way first. 

1. The era is fantastic to play in. Starting out in the early 12th century and ending right around the late 15th century, there are so many different events that the player can experience. From the crusades to the hundred years war to reconquista, a lot was happening in those three to four centuries. The player even gets to play with the beginnings of gun powder weapons, advanced siege craft, moving from chain mail to plate armor, there's a lot to do. 

2. The campaign is really fun. Going back to studying a spread sheet for finances, assigning nobles to either lead armies or govern cities, disbanding your army then recalling them back to on another campaign, it's charm and detail that a lot of the newer games are lacking now. It really does feel like you're managing a kingdom or empire, and not just collecting capture points. 

3. For a 2006 game, the visuals are still pleasing. Yeah there are parts where it hasn't aged well, especially when it comes to the models, but the effects, building destruction, and troop movement/combat is still great to look at. 

Now it's time for the bad, and this is where my statement about being great for the time it came out applies. 

1. The game has a certain clunkiness that hasn't gone away and is very awkward now. The camera controls can be very sensitive, I just what to pan to the camera to the left a little and it goes half way across the map. Titling the camera isn't any better either. 

2. This also ties into the clunkiness from before but deserves it's own section. Battles, while fun, can also be frustrating. Not in a I lost frustrating, more of a "attack the f***ing enemy that's right in front of you" frustrating. Every time I'm in a battle, an entire unit can get caught up on one enemy soldier that stray from his battalion, take five minutes to kill him, while ignoring all the other enemies around them. Or, I'll go for a flank attack but the entire unit stops when one or two of their guys strays from the pack and goes for the flank attack on their own. Like this is launch day Total War Rome 2 levels of AI stupidity! It is an absolutely frustrating thing and I can't believe that CA didn't patch this out when the released the definitive edition of this game. 

However, even with all that frustration from before, I still recommend this game because it is the best of the early days of Total War. I don't think it's the best over all, I personally think Shogun 2 is better. But for the time it came out, when comparing it to Rome, Shogun, and Medieval Total War, this game really is the best of the early days of this franchise.

For a while, I didn't understand how people could think that Medieval 2 was the best Total War game. It seemed too dated and clunky for me to ever enjoy. After giving it a fair chance and finishing a campaign I realize now how wrong I was. While it isn't my favorite Total War game, Medieval 2 is undoubtedly the best Total War game I have ever played. I know now how many steps back Creative Assembly have taken, and how much depth the newer games lack compared to this one. 

Coming from the newer Total War games, I never would have guessed how much of a roleplaying element this game has. The "traits" system lets you add personality and complexity to generals, turning them into shining pillars of chivalry, or deplorable, malevolent warmongers, through your actions in war. These extreme poles of morality come with their own effects and bonuses. Dread leads to decreased enemy morale in battle, where as chivalry leads to increased friendly morale in battle as well as extra population growth in settlements. When generals inevitably die, in combat or of old age, it can be emotional, because you were there with them from the start, built them up from nothing, and watched them conquer, only to have to watch them die. This kind of connection to these characters gives such a layer of intricacy to this game that the newer games don't really have, especially Warhammer, as in that game faction leaders and lords are immortal gods of slaughter. 

In Medieval 2, men win wars, not magic tricks. Battles last a long time, soldiers beat each other to a pulp before routing, as opposed to some of the newer games where early routs are commonplace, and battles only last a few minutes. There is much more room for strategy, no dropping down magic spells on giant blobs of enemies. Taking heavy losses takes a toll on the player, units don't magically replenish themselves, and the weight of death can be felt, because you are a human, fighting and killing other humans. At the end of the day, in my opinion, human conflict will always be more interesting and meaningful than the conflict between fantastical races and magical creatures. 

On the campaign side of things, you have diplomacy, which is somewhat complex for a game this old, but still not nearly as complex as Paradox games. You control your own diplomats, in order to initiate diplomacy with another faction, you literally have to move one of your diplomats to one of their cities, as opposed to a few clicks of your mouse in the newer games. Merchants are a way for you to earn a bit of cash on the side, by finding valuable resources to bring back to your capital. Spies are helpful when it comes to waging a successful war, or finding out information about rivals. Assassinations can be attempted on many characters (including the pope) and this adds to the sense of mortality of characters in this game. All of this adds to immersion quite a bit. As the campaign progresses, time moves on, armor and weapons become more advanced, one must adapt and modernize their armies and strategies in order to keep up with the rest of the world. 

Rewrite history, turn heroes into villains, turn despots into saints, or try and follow history as accurately as you can, it's really up to you. This game is a history lover's wet dream come true, any fan of medieval history will probably end up falling in love with this game, and even those who aren't that interested in history can still find something to enjoy in this game. It might seem like I am taking shots at the Total War: Warhammer games, but I still think those games are good, just not nearly as good as this one.

Total War: Medieval 2 is to date the best strategy game, generally, that I've played. The combat is smooth and works well, especially when I use the micro-adjustments to the speed of time, allowing me to play in 1/10th increments of the normal speed of combat (for me, 0.2 or 0.3 usually works the best, allowing for real-time play while also giving me a sense that I am on a par with the computer in terms of seeing things play out, recognizing them, formulating a response, and then executing the orders to my troops). The management of settlements and of military personnel is also very deep, intricate, and fun. I am able to, first of all, micro-manage the degree to which I am able to manage my settlements. For example, if I want to be able to initiate construction projects or soldier recruitment without the presence of a military leader/male member of the royal family, I can toggle that. If I prefer to play hardcore and disallow building or recruitment without the presence of a male member of the royal family present, I can toggle that, instead. Then, I have to manage population growth and financial growth/productivity against public order and religious sentiment on the other. If I push too much toward productivity/wealth, without proper attention to the happiness or well-being of the populace, the people could become so unhappy that they revolt. Within all of these concerns for the wealth of my coffers, I need to also balance military research and construction projects; without them, all that money does me little good. Recruitment not only includes troops, it also includes a host of agents, such as spies, assassins, priests, diplomats, and merchants. Organically, I can also have access to female nobility born to my lineage, which serve as specialized diplomats. Each of these agents perform specialized roles, and they require different skills and approaches on the part of the player to be worth anything at all, let alone powerful in their own rights. Your generals, or the male nobility, have RPG-style personalities, which impact how well they do at various roles they can play, including governing or managing a settlement (influencing trade, taxation, public order, farming output, construction costs, recruitment costs, etc.), traversing the map or marching, and combat (whether attacking or defending, whether attacking or defending walls, whether using siege equipment or not, whether engaging the enemy on preferred terrain or not). These personality traits of your commanders are developed over time depending on what the experience through more or less random events generated by the game code, and depending on actions that you the player take with them, deliberately. What's more, this RPG-style personality and trait system applies not only to your generals, but also to your agents. There are also tech trees that are not visible for many hours into the game, and specialized guilds and specialized military units that you can not have access to for many hours and many turns into the game, and which you will not have access to unless you just so happen to be playing the game according to those guilds' preferences. In addition to all these things are mining, seafaring and ocean-based combat (which is all computer simulated - can't have every detail included in a game), trade, detailed diplomacy, natural disasters, crusades, jihads, rebellions, port blockades, and invasions of vast 'barbarian' hordes. The visuals are solid or outright amazing (see: individually animated troops - thousands of them - on the battlefield). You have to manage troop ammunition - archers and catapult crews can't carry around unlimited supplies. The environmental sound are astounding, and change according to how far zoomed in or out you are: zoom in to hear birds and rustling of foliage along with noises of people present; zoom out to hear only the whistling and roaring of the winds. The music is particular to each human culture you are playing, and is beautiful, engaging, and stays fresh - I find myself humming or singing after I have been playing for a little while. The human speech and 'voice-acting' is all really fun and thorough, as well. Seems like there's something I'm missing ...

I wish there was a way to post both a positive and negative review of this game. For the sake of simplicity, just refer to the mountain of positive reviews for the general stuff. Yeah, this is probably going to anger some people and especially those who deservedly give Medieval II the title of cult status. Back in 2006 this game was incredible. Amazing graphics and one of the best Total War settings ever. Medieval II thankfully has a very few bugs or glitches and at least for me, it was a stable experience. The problem in the game, which is the cause of the negative review is its horrible engine. Allow me to elaborate.
Medieval II uses the same engine as Rome I (TW Engine 2), albiet modified. While this engine offers an enjoyable and fluid experience in Rome I, it just doesn't work all that well for Medieval II. Animations in Medieval II are horribly sluggish and slow, which directly harms a few units, namely the infantry wielding two handed weapons. Archers have it even worse. While their arrows perform well when they shoot straight, if they try to shoot over the walls, the arrows that fly in an arc do as much damage as raindrops. Pikemen have it worst, however. Due to a weird bug which CA never bothered to fix (even though it would have taken them less than an hour), pikemen tend to drop their pikes in the middle of combat and switch to swords which makes them completely useless. There's a few more things like some units being unavailable like the English armored sergeants and HRE dismounted gothic knights. As far as the knights go, their performance is generally underwhelming. Charging into the mass of disorganized infantry rarely goes as planned since charges with couched lances regularly get interrupted by a bunch of routing stragglers rather than barreling and cutting through a disorganized mob of troops like in the modern TWs and Medieval II's predecessor Rome I. Musketeers are also in a pretty bad state. They are forced to completely line up to fire their guns, and if one gets killed by arrows, it can take them ages to reform their ranks a fire a proper volley. 
Multiplayer is another issue alltogether. While it is impressive that a 14-year old game still has a functional and active multiplayer, the game mode is far from impressive. Multiplayer in Medieval II can get very laggy and stuttery, especially siege battles. Knocking down a wall causes a giant lag spike and the balance of troops is awful. Spearmen cost almost as much as the vastly superior dismounted knights for some reason. Knights are a bit problematic beacause the early ones equipped with only chainmail tend to defeat the late knights in plate armor due to the fact armor is mostly meaningless in this game.
The mods for this game deserve a separate review because some of them fix almost all issues the base game has.

[i]Medieval II: Total War[/i] is one of the best Total War games. The game looks amazing, oozes charm, has incredible gameplay, and the best collection of DLC.

Medieval 2 looks absolutely amazing. Even decades later the graphics and art still hold up. The game is colorful, and all of the textures are smooth. The amount of depth behind each unit has yet to be matched. Knights wear personalized crests, and their armor becomes more complex over the course of the game. Plain levies are replaced by late medieval and even renaissance era units with age appropriate clothing for every faction.  

Medieval 2 has alot of minor details that add up to make something special. Build an early game armor building?  The specific units that have been given the upgrades will have leather armor added to their models the battle map. Each historical event and agent action is given a narrated cut scene that gives the game an amazing amount of charm. Even the pre-battle speeches are customized based on the campaign map and tactical map situations. The tension and excitement built up by these speeches works well with the fast-paced action music of Jeff van Dyck. 

The gameplay of Medieval 2 is simply perfect due to its constantly changing balance. Every faction is specialized, and that specialization evolves over the course of the game. The meta of most of the  game is cavalry, but every region of the world uses different kinds of cavalry and has varying dependence on cavalry depending on the era. The whole world sees the slow rise of professional infantry that counters cavalry and armor in different ways. The constantly evolving meta of this game is not seen in many other Total War game, and the fact that nearly every faction is viable is almost never seen. 

The DLC of Medieval 2 adds hundreds of hours of fun gameplay. The Teutonic, and Third Crusade campaigns put the heaviest of knights against armies that rely on lighter units. The Americas and Britannia campaigns put heavy cavalry against armies based around large numbers of  unarmored infantry. Each campaign has several factions, and multiple historical events without straying from being sandbox experiences. 

Thousands of hours can be added to this game by mods. Medieval 2 has one of the best modding communities. Mods such as the Lord of the Rings mod, and Warhammer mod are still played due to the amount of effort that has been put into crafting them.

When people think of Total War, many have their thoughts on Rome 2, Warhammer 2, Empire Total War, Rome Total War. However if I hear someone mention Total War, I immediately think of Medieval 2.
Compared to other Total War titles, Medieval 2 Total War is the most enjoyable in the franchise.

> Not too hard, not too easy: Although I wouldn't say it is "Simple to learn, difficult to master" Medieval 2's overall gameplay is engaging enough to make you want to play more. The Battle mechanics are fair but pathfinding is definitely bothersome during sieges, player or AI. 
> Replayability: Every campaign can be played differently and you'll enjoy every part of it. It all comes down to how you play the game; skillful, challenge yourself with certain rules, historic route - you name it.
> Plenty of Mods! : Medieval 2 is the mastermind when it comes to mods. The most vast out of all Total war games because of the diverse number of mods out there that are game changing or game overhauling.

- If you're looking for your first Total War game, by all means choose Medieval 2 OR Rome Total War. This game has many things done right.

If you like Real Time Strategy and/or Turn Based Strategy Games, you'll love Medieval II: Total War as it combines aspects of both Genres and does it really well. 
You can either choose fighting battles (only Real Time) or playing a campaign (Real Time and Turn Based). 

In campaign mode you can choose one of 5 playable factions (more may be unlocked). Everyting except Battles is handled in Turn Based Mode. You manage cities, build buildings, train troops, forge alliances and move your armies and various agents. Each faction has its own goals. (for example; conquer Rome as Leader of the Holy Roman Empire).

The battles themselves are very engaging. The game features about 300 different types of soldiers which are recruited and controlled as whole unit with multiple soldiers (eg. an English Longbowman unit consists of 48 soldiers, a French Mailed Knight unit of 36 knights).
There are many factors that can decide a battle; Size and quality of you army, strategy, terrain, morale, weather, ...
Land battles also include sieges, where the attacker has to breach the gates/walls of the defenders city/stronghold with siege equipment while the defender enjoys additional protection from their walls and towers. If the attacker doesn't want to risk a siege, they can always try to starve the defenders out.
Sea battles can only be auto-resolved. 

The campaign never gets boring, even if you control multiple large cities and huge armies, historical events like the plague or the invasion of the Huns may foil your plans for world domination.

The game comes with great soundtracks (James Vincent, Jeff van Dyck, Richard Vaughan) and has pretty decent graphics considering its release cate (2006) and the vast number of soldiers.

It's one of the biggest titles in the Total War Franchise and in my opinion a must-play for strategy-fans.

The best (historical) Total War

- 10/10 Soundtracks, which even changes acoording to battle (mobilizing, charging etc.)
- 8/10 Overall Atmosphere
- Realistic Unit collision & behavior
- Good & consequent diplomacy
- Big Campaign lasting from early high middle age to renaissance
- Good Variety of Units
- Useful agents
- Big World Map (even includes America in later stage)
- Perfectly minimalistic Economy
- Cutscenes for most Important Actions
- Historical accurate Events (like Mongol Invasion)
- Escalated Modding Community 
- 10/10 Expansion with 4 Campaigns (Baltic Crusade, Middle East Crusades, Conquest of America & Conflicts on British Isles)
Keep coming back for more 10/10 would recommend! CA needs to make a TWM 3!

Maybe it's because I was pressured into buying this, or maybe it's that I'm not into this kind of game, but I post interest VERY quickly. It's pretty much Civilisation with no city expansion and a heavy focus on war. I tried to play multiplayer with a friend and it required a lot of annoying file shuffling and manual management with plenty of room for abuse. The core game functions well at least. You can select a group of whoever you want and set them to attack the enemy. Although it's fairly lacking in terms of dynamic visuals, it ran well on a slow computer and I have no complaints when it comes to optimisation. I'd say the single player game gets a lot more interesting as time goes on however. I just wish you couldn't mindlessly click and win everything without any strategy... I don't see myself playing this again any time soon.

An absolute classic, a must own for fans of strategy gaming and THE quintessential total war experience.

Admittedly its not the best looking game, but for fifteen years old it doesn't look hideous either and with the plethora of high-quality mods out there the game continues to outlive its natural lifespan. 

You can immerse yourself in a particular historical setting in mods like Broken Crescent or inhabit well-known fantasy universes such as Westeros, Tamriel or Hyrule that are almost fully realised representations of their licensed counterparts.

I would especially recommend the Stainless Steel total conversion mod for a more polished experience than the vanilla campaign and Third Age Total War: Divide and Conquer for a beautiful rendition of Tolkein's world with some really interesting factions and unique mechanics.

Highly recommended. If you have never played it before and you appreciate grand strategy then your in for a treat, if you played it long ago but no longer have the original disc then why not dip back in and enjoy the nostalgia?

I love the time period and the units you get to use to tear your way through the campaign map. However, if you have only ever played Rome total war 1 (not the  crappy Rome 2) then you will find this game to be completely different. You make way less income per turn and your armies seem to cost so much more than they would in Rome 1. Not to mention that units in this game will often times fight to the bitter end, unlike in Rome 1 where units could break very quickly. So just be aware of how different this game is compared to Rome 1, but the cities/castles are gorgeous. The Pope/crusade/jihad mechanics are awesome. The Mongol invasion is a super challenging and enjoyable event in the game. Units are incredibly detailed and look lovely and real. Unlike Rome 1 where every soldier in that unit looked the exact same, there is a lot of variety in the unit models. I would argue that since you make so much less cash in this game compared to Rome 1, a good way to challenge yourself is to try Very hard/Very hard for the campaign to see just how grueling the game can really be. Not to mention that the faction Milan is a DICK and will always declare war on you regardless of where/what factions you happen to be. Also archers in this game are insane and you should invest in them early. Even peasant archers can mess up a body guard unit if they are up on a castle wall. All this said, wait for a sale and play this game as long as you have a nice setup and enjoy the game on high resolution for all the graphic settings and you will have a game where you feel like an evil leader of a genocidal faction, killing all that even try to stand in your way. Have fun my friends.

I first played this game years ago, and not on Steam. I recently bought it again on sale, because I had memories of just how good it was. It still lives up to the hype, and I'd much rather be playing this than most of the modern triple-A titles I've played.

I hesitate to recommend this, as the game has not aged well.

I've probably put a hundred hours into the game between its release and Steam.

The use of agents in M2 is a chore, compared to later entries, the UI is outdated, and the combat AI is clunky. The soundtrack is remains masterful, and the game's aesthetic still shines. While I prefer the medieval setting the most, the gameplay is frankly inferior to the likes of Shogun 2. It's hard to recommend Medieval 2 when there are better options available.

Overall, I'll give Medieval 2 a:
8/10 - [Great]

I originally bought this game as a kid on CDs and got tired of keeping track of my physical copy and Disc Code and all that nonsense half the people on Steam now probably don't even remember. It's been the only Total War game I've ever needed. I tend to boot it up every couple of years and spend a couple dozen hours on a full Grand Campaign. It's real fun.

I'd say if you've never played this type of strategy game before, this is a cool place to start. You've got all of Europe to conquer, and the map stretches all the way to the Holy Land and late game to the Americas. If you don't want to get stressed trying to micromanage where your officer units are and how to keep every city maintained, you can turn off the stipulation that a castle/town needs a governor for you to build things, change taxes, etc. The battle system is fun, with a kind of rock, paper, scissors between cavalry, spearmen, and archers. But it can get way more complex than that when you factor in light vs heavy cavalry, artillery units, armored knights that can shrug off a ton of arrows, etc. It's cool.

If you HAVE played this genre a ton, you'll know more than me. But obviously I've enjoyed this game for years, so the potential for fun is there. And during sales it's like $5, so worth the gamble. If you think you'll like it you probably will.

Oh and final note: personally I think the voice acting is hilarious. There's this Chivalry/Dread system and it means your officers will come across as either pompous dolts or sadistic jerks. Like if your unit can't move any more that turn it'll either be "We must make camp until morning, sire." OR "I'VE TRIED WHIPPING THEM, SIRE! ...but the men are spent."

A solid turn based strategy

It's a simplistic upgrade from the original RTW that I like for the Crusades&Pope/Jihad system. The overarching political system makes for different game play where you aren't just fighting people because they are your most logical conquest - sometimes you have to hold back so you don't anger the Pope and consequently get attacked yourself (sort of a proto-rendition of the modern concept of balance of power). All in all a good game for those who didn't like from Empire Total War and on, while also having really only upgrades from RTW.

Nonetheless, the flaws include a lack of notification system for heretics spawning which means constant vigilance, the clunky crap trait system that produces mediocre people at the start of your game and they slowly turn into hindrances to city management, and a faulty diplomacy system that'll see you offer 10k for map information, get rejected with a counter offer that they just want to give you 9500 no strings attached.

This is a great game.  It was a great game when it was released fourteen years ago and age hasn't wearied it greatly.

   I've played Total War since the first Shogun Total War.  The first two editions (Shogun and the first Medieval) were far more abstract with provinces like chess board squares where only one army can be based.

   This game is the sequel to Rome Total War which changed to the more realistic maps of the present games.

   Firstly this game dates from the Golden Age of the series where when you bought the game you bought the game - rather than now where you buy 75% of it with the rest added as comparatively over priced DLC later.

   What the Total War games did was to satisfy the fantasy of every child (okay - mainly boys) who wanted their toy soldiers to actually march and fight.  So the game balances province management - which buildings to build or upgrade - with strategic - which of your forces to deploy where - and the tactical.

   The tactical matters with weather and terrain having a significant impact on troop performance as well as the presence of  your family member commanders.  The "Gladiator" tactic of softening up the enemy with missiles and artillery, pinning them with a frontal infantry attack and then hitting them from the rear with a heavy cavalry charge holds good here.

   The enemy AI is good enough not to be a total embarrassment but poor enough that you can win battles when heavily outnumbered.

   The scope of the game is huge and by the time you have ten or more provinces managing them all becomes mentally taxing.

   In game the main impediment to your slaughter (as a Catholic nation which in Medieval times was most of Europe) is the Pope.  The Pope generally doesn't like Catholics slaughtering each other when they could be slaughtering Muslims.  Lose enough popularity with the Pope and you will be excommunicated which means you'll lose most trade and every Catholic nation on the map will be able to attack you freely.  Avoid the Pope's displeasure by building chapels, churches, abbeys, and cathedrals.  Also use Priest agents to convert the population to Catholicism and burn witches.  Medieval times were brutal with notions of human rights barely acknowledged and even less adhered to and the game matches that brutality.

   Fourteen years on the game still looks good.  The game's concept and execution are both solid with some of the more irritating aspects of other games (Barbarian factions in a Rome Total War expansion) not present here.

   There are some minor irritations.  Naval combat is a pure numbers game (the video rather cheekily is showing Napoleon Total War not this game) which if you're used to the naval battles of Empire and Shogun 2 is a bit retrograde.  Heading from England by boat Crusade troops still desert even if you are going as fast as you can (which is obviously not in a straight line).  Brothels and inns which help with keeping the population happy and spawn spy and assassin units have transformed my once proud family of holy warriors into a bunch of alcoholic freaks who aren't siring children.

   But these as said are minor irritations.  This is a great game but a massive thief of time.  This is a game that's going to take you upwards of 50 hours to complete one campaign if you fight every battle.  

  And as for price ?  Next week in the Summer sale it will probably cost you 5.00.  It's definitely worth that.

Medieval2 is the worst part of the series. 

If you seen through the nostalgia addled narrative of the fanboys. Factions in Med2 are hardcoded to wage war against the player if he's reached their borders, there's no way around it. You share borders with anyone and they will make war. The Pope will punish you for fighting against invaders and excommunicate you if you don't let them take your lands. Then they can wage war against you without repercussions and even increase their standing with the Pope because they are fighting against "heretics" and no one will make peace and there's a lot of public unrest. You might even get crusades called on you. You can try to get one of your holy men be elected Pope, but it doesn't matter, he'll do the same thing as before. That's why playing as a Christian faction is one of the worst experiences in all of Total War.

PS- That wasn't written by me, but this represent my opinion on this game.
Author -Ephraim_Dalton

A great deal of fun! If you are into strategy, history generally and the medieval era in Europe and Western Asia in particular, you will likely enjoy this. It can be a bit overwhelming at first, especially if you have never played an RTS style battle that is based more on real movement than the unnatural, superhuman motion of most game characters. Initially, moving my cavalry into position to charge and then their doing so seemed to take far too long. I would often abandon such tactics, thinking I had messed them up, because everything didn't happen at once. You have to let your line battle it out and take casualties while you set up such a maneuver. This is natural to a general, less so to a gamer (at least, in my case). Please bear in mind that I am no strategy or RTS expert, and your experience will likely be far smoother if you are.

I am, however, a huge enthusiast of history, and while there are many inaccuracies (necessary perhaps for gameplay's sake in many cases) it still does a wonderful job of creating a medieval battlefield unlike any other I have seen. Seeing the Normans heavy cavalry, Turkish horse archers and Latin knights battling it out alongside hundreds of archers, infantry and other assorted combatants was thrilling just to behold. Managing my nation's growing realms was satisfying, though the bizarre way aging and the passage of time are left unaligned was disappointing. I imagine a mod or fix is available to change it, however, though I have not looked yet.

The best part today, perhaps, is the price. When I bought it on sale I got the 'definitive edition' for under $10, and this sale seems to reappear extremely often. I have played 145 hours thus far, and have not come close to trying all the game has to offer! At such a price, I wholeheartedly recommend it unless you hate the time period, strategy games or RTS-style battles. If you did, though, you probably wouldn't be reading this!

Total War: MEDIEVAL II  Definitive Edition is my favorite total war game. Though from all TW games I played I would rate it 3rd by single player campaign. First is Rome 2 campaign, then Warhammer 2 and finally Med 2. Vanilla Med 2 is good on its own. You unlock new factions to play when you beat them in campaign or edit some shenanigans in the med 2 folder. Then you have the 4 kingdoms expansions. Crusades, Teutonic, Britannia and Americas all which are amazing. If you want a chill campaign play Byzantium in Crusades or Welsh in Britannia. Then you can spice up the game with some fantastic mods like Stainless Steel 6.4, Third age mods, Warcraft Total, Call of Warhammer mod and many other cool and crazy mods like Planet war total mod which is huge you have to try it to have a good laugh. Then multiplayer. People in general are friendly to new comers to the multiplayer scene. Sieges are hell of a way to grind some quality time. You also have people who play the game since its release and day 1 and by now they are Ares reborn in the game. Ofcourse I am talking about clan players.

THIS IS THE STORY OF ALF THE LUCKY, THE WORLDS GREATEST HOBBIT FARMER/GENERAL.

-Starts a new campaign. Decides to play as Bree-land
-Bree-land is basically the town of Bree and a couple of hobbit villages
-Turns out being rural countryfolk makes you poor; can barely field any troops
-Turns out countryfolk also don't make the best troops; basically fielding rag-tag archers and men/hobbits with pitchforks
-Scout the area with my generals (including Brave Sir Alf the Hobbit) and struggling to really do anything, with the Remnants of Angmar encroaching to the north and Duneledings to the south
-Suddenly Alf gets attacked by orcs just south of bree; however allied dunedain rangers are nearby 
-Brave Sir Alf and his small halfling milita make a stand against the orcs whilst waiting for the rangers
-Doesn't work out so well, turns out orcs are a lot stronger than hobbits
-Running on tiny legs, the last remaining halflings leg it in the direction of the rangers
-Turns out orcs are faster than halflings
-The halflings are getting cut down as they flee
-Just a dozen hobbits are left, but the rangers can be seen on the other side of the hill. The remnants of the troop make a last stand so their general can escape
-Brave Sir Alf he ran away
-Bravely ran away, away!
-When danger reared its ugly head, he bravely turned his tail and fled!
-Yes, brave Sir Alf turned about and gallantly he chickened out!
-Bravely taking to his feet, he beat a very brave retreat!
-Bravest of the brave, Sir Alf!
-Alf, now the ONLY hobbit left alive reaches the dunedain rangers
-Turns out rangers are a lot stronger than orcs and turn them into pork pies
-Alf sits quietly in a corner sucking his thumb surrounded by rangers as the battle ends
-With the orcs gone, Alf is awarded the village of Mengalen (it seems the orcs which attacked previously occupied it)
-As such, Alf is dubbed 'Alf the Lucky'. Also turns out Alf is a farmer with a massive pumpkin
-Some 50 turns pass. The Dunedain keep the remnants of Angmar at bay, whilst Breelands ally with the Enedwaith to the south to take on the Duneledings. A slow and painful advance ensues, but eventually both the Breelanders and Enedwaith gain ground, with Bree even taking the Duneleding capital of Dun Larach (with Alf's help).
-Seeing victory imminent, Alf heads a large army (still made up mostly of farmers) from Dun Larach to the east
-The duneledings make a last stand, causing a a full stack of their top tier units to appear north of Alf's farm squad. 
-They immediately siege Dun Larach.
-Dun Larach quickly falls back to the duneledings. It becomes very apparent this Duneleding horde threatens the very exsistence of the Breelands; Alf has the only army of any size and they are mostly bottom-tier troops
-Now completely cut off, there was only one thing to do: 
-Brave Sir Alf he ran away
-Bravely ran away, away!
-The duneleding death army tries to engage Alf's farm squad but they retreat further north, on the bridge just south of the Breelander-occupied town of Tharbad
-The Duneledings engage again, forcing Alf to make a last stand on the bridge
-Alf's angry pitchfork boys desperately hold the bridge whilst archers rain hell on the angry enemy horde
-The town's small garrison arrives as the Duneledings are breaking through, bolstering the defence
-45 minutes of battle ensues. As the archers run out of arrows one by one they join the fray but the Duneledings don't buckle
-With almost all of Bree's forces killed Alf charges in on the Duneleding flank, taking out the enemy general. However, with no arrows left the remaining Breelanders are no match for the duneledings are are slaughtered. Just 27 men make it make to Tharbad. The Duneledings win a phyrric victory, losing 1700 of their 2000 troops, thus losing the ability to retake their lands.

Rest in Peace Alf the Lucky, Conqueror of Mengalen, Planter of Large Pumpkins and Saviour of the Breelands who didn't bravely run away at the battle of Tharbad Bridge. Your luck may have ran out but Bree will live on!

A classic game from the Total War franchise and easily my favorite. The game is well-balanced and offers a challenge to even the most experienced players. A large modding community also means that the game may never become boring.

Medieval Total War II is quite possibly the most addictive turn based strategy game I have ever played. I do love this time of history and all the different historical "Teams" (countries) you can play as.

Bit overpriced for a 12 year old game, I must admit, but you are paying for an outstanding campaign on an Epic scale (similar to WH2's mortal empires in terms of size and unit variety) in which you are compelled to win a campaign in order to unlock the other factions. The multiplayer community is small now, but is still alive and kicking (to my knowledge).
When you're done with all that, there is also a variety of amazing mods that are stable, complete and put together so well I am often surprised I'm not playing a real game. Some good recommendations include:
Stainless Steel for an enhanced version of the base game,
Third Age Total War and/or Divide and Conquer (4.5) for Lord of the Rings
and The Elder Scrolls: Total War for The Elder Scrolls.
Lastly, I haven't got 633 hours, because I've been playing since before it was on steam, so my hour count is probably twice that number or maybe more.

In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#249 out of 558)... it's time for Total War: Medieval 2.

For a very, very long time I considered Medieval 2 to be the best entry in the Total War series. That is no longer the case, but only barely so. (The new king is Shogun 2: Total War, by the way.) Medieval 2 still stands very near the top, with some of the most engaging gameplay in the genre, in both real-time and turn-based modes. In most regards, Medieval 2 has aged very well, and still looks fantastic in 2020, but be aware that certain mechanics feel a bit dated. The camera controls, in particular, come across as fairly clumsy, and the naval mechanics are little more than an afterthought.

While the vanilla campaign is very solid, I would still strongly recommend new players try out the Stainless Steel mod, which improves almost every aspect of the game--most crucially faction AI, unit balance, and the campaign map--which is made much larger and more complex.

Beyond the vanilla campaign there are two particular aspects of Medieval 2 to be aware of.

First: the modding scene is fantastic. There are numerous expansive total conversion mods out there that make Medieval 2 the ultimate Total War sandbox. Some of these, like Stainless Steel, vastly improve the original game, whereas many others completely transform the Medieval 2 into something else, built around various fictional settings like the Lord of the Rings, the Legend of Zelda, Game of Thrones, and so on. Subsequent Total War games would prove much less open to modding, making Medieval 2 the last, best place for awe-inspiring total conversions.

Second: I'd be remiss if I didn't at least mention the "Kingdoms" expansion. It's, uh, it's bad. Really bad. It purports to add the American continent(s) to the campaign map and introduce a number of Native American factions as well. The native representation, such that it is, is problematic in about all of the ways you might expect; the and the added continent at the strategy level is laughably bad. They didn't even try to model the actual geography of the Americas: instead it's only a rough approximation of the "new world," that feels empty and pointless to explore/conquer. Thankfully the original, vanilla game is exceedingly excellent, so it doesn't matter too much. But, still, it bears mentioning.

Note: Also played on PC, sans-Steam.

For example, the best knights in the expansion (ritterbruders) die very quickly to viking axes, while dismount ritterbruders kill the same vikings when outnumbered five to one.

I highly recommend this to anyone looking for a good Medieval Period strategy game or to Total War fans who missed this title. This is basically Rome in Middle Ages with some changes here and there. Historical period spans from 1080 to 1530 with more than a hundred European regions to conquer and a cool little detail like the discovery of a New World.

I like the much simpler map style compared with the newer TW entries. The UI is very straightforward and easy to use. Units have a good variety and a nice visual armor upgrades through better smith buildings. Vast and detailed city and castle settlements on battle maps are a big plus. Excellent modding capabilities. Very pleasing soundtrack. 

Some negative points are the weak and glitchy diplomacy, two-handed weapons bug and not so smart AI. I'd personally prefer the game to gradually remove older period units. It would be nice if the game had at least two different time periods to start the campaign like in Medieval 1 because most people finish playing much earlier than 1530 and never truly use late game units which is a shame. Stability was pretty good for me on Windows 10 and the only bad thing were the fps spikes with structural destruction while playing sieges.

Give this game a try to experience why everyone mentions Medieval II: Total War as the best (or one of) game in the series.

It's such an immersive, authentic and rewarding experience.  It's educational qualities shouldn't be overlooked either.  Often watching Game Of Thrones (yes I now it's not real) with my wife I'd comment with some authority on battles, from siege weapons to the power of horse units based solely on playing this video game.  Watching any number of documentaries about medieval warfare never contradict this games.  Accuracy aside, the key to a strategy game is being rewarded incrementally in stages that lead to learning and progress rather than being some cryptic puzzle (the later versions of Football Manager for example). This game delivers in spades.  A classic of the genre and as computers become more and more powerful, the more beautiful it looks.

Medieval II is usually considered the best Total War game of all time, and in terms of pure freedom and sandbox gameplay, I'd say that's pretty accurate. The campaign is huge, the factions feel extremely diverse, and there's a ton of strategy involved in both the map management and real time battle aspects of the game. However, to be completely honest, the game does kind of show it's age these days, at least without mods. Considering all of its DLC and updates, Total War: Warhammer II is probably the most "complete" Total War game in terms of the sheer amount of content and diversity available. But Medieval II is still great, much cheaper, has a ton of longevity, and will run on pretty much anything these days. If you're a fan of strategy games and haven't played it yet, it's definitely worth a shot.

This review is about Total War II: MEDIEVAL II; as I never play the DLC. Do not judge my review based on the 25 hours played on Steam, but out of hundreds if not thousands of hours played before Steam ever existed. Though, I've never played it on the hardest difficulty.

In my opinion, Medieval 2 is the best game ever brought out of the Total War Series even though the economic system isn't as powerful as it's in the later games but reflects accurately the Medieval era, especially during the hundred years war.

First off, let's start with a trick: If you change a bit one of the .ini files, you'll have the possibility to play nearly every faction, even the Papal States.

Combat is also different from faction to faction as every faction has unique unites which have to be used differently.

The graphic is decent and the accurateness of the historical references and units awesome. There are actually multiple ways to play this game: from being a high warmonger to the sneaky king which loves to assassinate, sabotage and plunder.

Be careful of your choices as every one of them might influence your main characters. They will loose/gain traits, command points, loyalty, piety or chivalry/dread. Every one of this points will influence your city/fortress moral, growth, your troop or enemy moral.

Through merchants, blockades or sieges, religion and units in other countries, you can actually try to accomplish an economy warfare. Those people/units will gender unrest and corruption in foreign countries which can lead to rebellions.

By assassination you can actually delete some factions from the world surface.

Buildings which are damaged or from foreign culture will make people unrest. If you've the finances, repair or destroy them to avoid growing unhappiness.

There is one thing I actually miss from Medieval: Total War. It's the ability to assassinate your generals.

Excellent game, a classic of strategy games and the Total War series. In my opinion, the best medieval strategy game out there, or at least the best one I have ever played...yes, even better than AoE2. Well balanced units, it may be a little bit boring at first when most countries have similar units, but over time each one develops unique military units that will affect your strategy in the battlefield and your expansion plans. 
It also has the best mod a Tolkien fan could wish for: Third Age Total War. This mod totally overhauls the game to make it so you can play as any faction of the Lord of the Rings book and movies, from Gondor to the Dwarves and Easterlings. Best part is that you can reform the Kingdom of Arnor in the North, or the Elven Kingdom... or restore the power of Sauron if you take back the One Ring...

It's an extremely enjoyable game with a lot of factions and variety, especially in multiplayer. If you don't like the base game, there's a lot of mods. I reccomend Stainless Steel, Europa Baraborum 2 and Third Age Reforged.

Absolutely amazing. The height of the Total War series in my opinion. Fixes several issues and bugs from Rome 1 while retaining the weight of two armies slamming into each other, something that I feel was lost with the new engine. Features a tutorial cutscene with graphics I'd consider amazing for the time, an excellent campaign, and several extensive scenarios like the Crusades, Teutonic wars, and colonization of America thanks to the Kingdoms expansion that comes with it for free in the Steam version.

The game begins a little after the Norman invasion of England (which is the tutorial), and goes on until the Age of Discovery, with musketmen and cannons being the final units you unlock. You can play as various nations from the High Middle Ages, from Scotland, France and the Holy Roman Empire all the way to Egypt and the Byzantine Empire. Some nations like Spain and Russia are there because I assume they didn't want them broken up into smaller, less flavorful factions. Every faction and faith has unique units and buildings. England has Yeoman Archers, the HRE has Gothic Knights, and the Byzantines have the Varangian Guard. Western Catholics can build Jousting Fairs while Muslims can build Shisha Bars and Racing Tracks. Spain has Bull Runs and the Byzantine Empire can build Roman style Public Baths and Aqueducts.

The campaign is turn-based, with you moving/training armies and constructing new buildings in your cities every turn. You can build farms courthouses to help your towns grow into sprawling metropolises, which is how you unlock the best buildings in the game, you can focus on building new military facilities to get powerful new units you can train, or build markets and dockyards to help trade and taxation pour money into your treasury. When two or more armies meet, the game shifts into a real-time strategy battle where you command your forces directly. You tell them where to move, when to fire and where to charge. The battles are the highlight of the Total War series, without them I'd bet it'd be an obscure series nowhere near the popularity of Civilization or Crusader Kings. It's the first time I've ever felt like I actually had total control over an army, with thousands of soldiers at my command. Setting up ambushes, taking a hill for your archers to fire from, and directing devastating charges with powerful mounted knights is something other strategy games simply fail to allow you the ability to do.

If everything the game and its expansions has to offer isn't enough for you, there's an almost endless array of free mods, from new factions and mechanics (Stainless Steel 6.4 and Grand Campaign), all the way to a brand new setting or world, like Broken Crescent's focus on the Middle East and Asia, and mods that change the game into a fantasy setting like AGoT, Elder Scrolls or LotR. You're playing the exact same game, but it feels like something completely new, every time.

You could play this game for thousands of hours, honestly. It's well worth the price, and during sales it can dip all the way to ten bucks, which is almost criminal. The Steam version also doesn't come with the strange graphically-caused crashes due to playing on a modern PC, like the disc version does.

You really shouldn't miss this one.

This is an excellent game if, and only if, you don't give a fig about winning. I can't even begin to imagine what horrors await on the two more difficult settings! There are deep flaws in the economic model, the development slope, and, worse still, in the battle simulations. Having played Total War: Rome for many a long hour, I was expecting more, much more. Deeply disappointed.

I don't care how high your IQ is; the game is TOTALLY imbalanced.  Whomever the current/last  game design team was, they TOTALLY and COMPLETELY screwed up any semblance of game balance.  When AI opponents with only a FRACTION of your forces in terms of size and quality KICK YOUR ASS, there's something wrong.
The game is NO LONGER PLAYABLE.

Why are you down here reading reviews?: As of now there are still hundreds of thousands of people playing medieval 2, a 13 year old game. Yes the graphics are shit, yes the game is clunky and yes the AI is retard but i sh*t you not, all of this is irrelevant because Medieval 2 has over 100 mods. 50 of them are TOTAL OVERHAULS!!

The game is the most moddable total war in existence. Lord of the Rings? Witcher? Westeros? Napoleonic Era? Ancient Era? Warhammer? Three kingdoms period? a world where santa claus rides a  T REX? Star fucking wars? These are just SOME of the mods avaible for this game.

No don't get me wrong, vanilla med 2 is still a game worth playing and offers tons of fun, but the strenght of this game is in its incredible modding community. This is worth 100x more than the Steam Price. Before steam i had this game, god knows how many hours i actually have in med 2...

Pros: There are more overhauls mods for the game than games in the Total War Franchise. Voice Over is funny as hell. Everyone can learn and have fun. 

Cons: Historically innacurate, unstable in modern computers and the AI is shit. ALL OF WHICH CAN BE FIXED FOR FREE.

Conclusion: You should buy this game if you are into downloading awesome mods. You should also buy because its incredibly fun even without mods. You should not buy if you're not into mods or is a history buff FANATIC that screams "unrealistic" at every damn movie, TV series and book you read on the middle ages.

Medieval II is the pinnacle of Creative Assembly Total War games. Everything that came afterwards slowly went down hill in both quality of design and execution. The only fault Medieval II has is that the time scaling makes a sea journey take over a decade to go from England to Sicily. The AI makes some silly decisions on easier difficulties, but can be a serious challenge on very hard. With all of the mods available, this game has immense replay value, I keep coming back to it. I have 569 hours at the time of this writing, but own the original DVD and probably played over a thousand hours before I ever had a Steam account.

Medieval II lives up to its reputation, I find the measured pace of developing resources enjoyable and so many strategies to develop! Religious Politics with the Pope, Family Heirarchy to manage your posterity, Economic and natural resource considerations, but most of all: WAR. The combat graphics show the effects of time compared to newer games but damn the strategy of it is pure if you are a history buff of this period. Very smooth commands. All this ensures hundreds of hours of replay and adding the Kingdoms DLC adds up to years of conquering and developing new strategies....Thumbs UP!

Really addictive! I enjoy the unexpected challenges and varied experiences. The battles are immersive and feel authentic (for a video game). Some of my few complaints may be due to my low graphics settings. I feel like the general map is crowded and difficult to read. Total War: Medieval I was easier to read and track the pieces. I'm not sure I need all of the trees, etc., on the map. Also, the settlement ID tags get in the way of the pieces. My biggest complaint is having to watch the moves of each faction. Is there a way to skip this? When Mongolia invades, I have to watch a dozen or more pieces move, which is a pain. If my complaints are due to user error, please let me know. I'm probably missing something. Overall, this is a great game, easy to play for a few minutes, or several hours. The strategy is real.

If you've played newer total war titles, or even if you haven't, this game is still worth playing. The replay-ability is insane, and only made greater by the copious amounts of mods available. Everything from an enhanced medieval experience in Stainless Steel to complete overhaul mods for Warhammer fantasy and Lord of the Rings settings. I can't recommend it enough, I've put 716 recorded hours into this game at the time of writing, which doesn't include the countless hours from a disk version, and I imagine that I'll put several hundred more on at least before I finally grow tired of this absolute treasure of a game.

"managing cities" part , which was very boring and annoying. The game was challenging enough, but i cannot find myself wanting to play again, because i dread managing cities. However i can see how some people would love this admin part of the game, because its realistic: you would need to administrate a city after conquering it. I like fast paced games i guess and this game is to slow for my liking: in the sense that admin part slows down the action of the game. All and all i  still recommend the game, as it caters to its audience who want both the action  and admin of the game, which is very realistic and historical.

An amazingly aged game, Medieval II is the perfect game for avid fans of medieval warfare and the time period. The game itself is extremely immersive and I find myself often losing myself in my campaigns. While not historically accurate in that Spain and Russia are nations in 1080 A.D. (it is supposed to be Castile, Aragon, Novgorod, Muscovy, etc.) the game is the best there is for any medieval enthusiasts. Capable mods, while I've never tried them out, make the game more immersive and add more historical factions, units, and recruitment options (Stainless Steel comes to mind). Medieval II is my favorite Total War game due to its improved graphics from Rome: Total War, and its ability to immerse me as a ruler of antiquated European nations. The game, being $20, is frequently on sale, and its appeal plus the affordability makes it a favorite for me and millions of other players.

[h3]The [b]BEST[/b] Total War game to ever grace a PC and a very hurtful reminder of what is an actual good and enjoyable gameplay mechanic. I couldn't praise it enough even if I spoke 8 languages and I also take this opportunity to recommend 3 of the best mod out there that actually make this game the best of the best :

Rise of Three Kingdoms
Stainless Steel
Third Age[/h3]

My all time favorite computer game.  I have played this game for well over a decade and keep coming back to it.  It tends to capture my imagination completely and I find myself mentally drifting off into my little empire, even when I not playing at the time.  I guess, what I want to say is, that this game offers a total immersion experience for those inclined to get sucked in by their gaming adventures.  You can play a single campaign for weeks or months.  AI works wondrously well, throwing challenges your way and keeping you on your toes continuously.  Save your game frequently, or you get punished - no way back.  While the original game is already a miracle of endless entertainment, there are ways to increase the level of complexity and enhance the game with reworked map material and expanded line-up of factions with help of mods, such as Stainless Steel (highly recommended).
Played as Scotland, burned down London, conquered Egypt, and married my prince to his cousin, 10/10 would do it again.

Yes, this game is fantastic. The vanilla game is well thought out and has DLC to match. While the base game is more of a general overview of medieval Europe and the Middle East, the expansions delve into and focus more on specific times that happen in the base game. Case in point the crusades campaign. The crusades happen in the base game whenever the pope calls one. The vanilla game covers such a big time span though that it cannot properly show all of the crusades or the Crusader kingdoms. For that, we have the Crusades campaign. It fully fleshes out the crusader kingdoms and gives them their own units. The same thing goes for the other expansions. The conquest of the British Aisles kinda happens in the base game, but the map is so big and the time span covered is so vast that it can't really show all the territories in the British Aisles or all the many battles that happened like the Britannia Campaign does. Perfect base game with perfect DLC.

An EXCELLENT entry in the TW series and still high-priced for a reason-- gameplay is, with mods, unmatched. Download Stainless Steel 6.3 and 6.4, and install both in the mods section of your game's Steam directory, then download and install the SHIP mod to Stainless Steel. To run this amazing modset, simply rename one of the other folders ("Americas" is a good one to do this with) to some other name ("Americas old" for instance) and then rename your Stainless Steel mod folder "Americas" and run it through steam, playing MTW2: Americas when prompted.

One of the major selling points for Medieval II, for me personally, is that the pace is far slower than Shogun II, Rome II or Warhammer I. It is not that the game is *slow* but rather one does not feel constantly rushed to power play, or lose. It can also be a very difficult game. One slip up diplomatically, such as a careless excommunication can lead to other kingdoms dog-piling on you. 
Meaning, simplified, the game models the Catholic church as follows: kingdoms vote for a pope, who will come from one of the Catholic countries. The Pope will have favorites, and might pose e.g. ceasefires on warring Catholic factions, with either loss of favor or excommunication as a reward if the ceasefire is broken: excommunicated kingdoms face unrest and possibly Crusades by former Catholic friends. Pretty cool idea, even if the execution is a bit half-baked. 
One major thing for me is also the fact, that ranged units feel *heavy*-- it is not only the number of casualties which longbows or Italian crossbows can cause, but the feel for the weapons. What I disliked about Warhammer was, that archers in that game feel to be shooting pieces of straw. The feedback from hitting the enemy ranks is not there in Warhemmer TW. In Medieval II the sound effects for chain mail being pierced, and the fast moving arrows coming down as a cloud of death are on point. Fire rate is slow, and it makes perfect sense to keep auto fire off, as not to risk friendly fire and e.g. break a cavalry charge with a well timed volley. 
Melee tends to be messy, slow and exhausting, especially for modded, and higher difficulties. Generally, clean victories only come to the side who outmanoeuvres the enemy and gets to charge home to a flank with cavalry, or manages to split the hostile army and deal with the pockets one by one. 

Mods are Great for Medieval II. Highlights are probably Third Age: TW for the LotR theme, and the historical Stainless Steel. I like the very basic Darthmod, as there really is no need for total conversion-- vanilla has all the bits and pieces needed for a classic, just maybe in need for the community to fine tune somewhat. 

The game shows its age in sieges, where it is very difficult to get units off the walls (or on), and the same problem rears at times in field battles, as the unit AI needs some prodding to reform the line after combat. Cavalry sometimes abruptly slows its charge, or halts it entirely. 
Reinforcement mechanics can be irritating, as one needs to replenish units in a city, or a castle, which houses the appropriate production building. Very annoying, if taking an enemy city, and the AI has done very little military building. 

But the good by far outweighs the bad. Probably my preferred TW game, even if dated. Recommended!

I have played over a thousand hours, bought the game and expansion at retail price and then bought this version. 
Years 1080 to 1500 plus. Want to play as Egypt or the Moors? You can do that once you beat that faction. I know, its crazy to release that much content in the base game. But wait, with this edition you get the expansion as well with not one, not two, not three, but four new campaign maps in the areas of Britannia, the Crusader States, the Baltic Crusade, and New World. Yes, you can play as Lithuanian Pagans, Welsh Kings, Mayan Imperials, or control the Krak de Chevaliers. If I only had to take one game onto a desert island with a solar powered lap top this would be the game.

This is still an excellent strategy game despite being nearly a decade and a half old! It holds up very well. The campaign map is fun and interactive. The game is deep enough to support numerous playthroughs without constantly having to repeat the same things over and over again. The game has plenty of variety, with a large number of playable factions (though there are initially only 5 or so). The military battles are fun and fast-paced, and have scaleable difficulty. The combat animations themselves are where the game appears the most-dated, as the troops aren't exactly HD and the cycle of combat animations are somewhat stiff in comparison to a game in 2020. Still, there's enough detail that you can watch individual troops within your army battle others. Overall, this game is still plenty of fun and certainly worth the price, as it holds up admirably against peers that have a decade of technological advancements in their favor.
