Total War: Medieval II is an amazing game. It is more polished than the first Medieval title, and is far more enjoyable. It has many DLCs that I have not played, as the base game alone is fun enough and has so much to offer that I still haven't gotten around to the added content. You do what happens in any Total War title, you build several armies, conquer settlements, and maintain an economy by building different military and civilian buildings at your settlements. Add keeping a small garrison of units there to keep the peace and ward off attackers, and you repeat these steps until you complete your objectives and win the campaign you have chosen. Each faction has a campaign with different objectives to be met. In terms of custom battles, create massive armies and have them fight to the death, literally. If your army is set to defend a fort or larger settlement, they will rout to the settlement center and not off the map. Bodies will stack, morale will wane, and your coffee cup will empty. But they all can be refilled in the next match. I highly recommend this game at it's current price to anyone who loves Total War games or RTS games in general. It may feel overwhelming at first, but sometimes skipping a few turns early in a campaign can allow your economy to bulk up enough to support expansion.

I cant say that i have played much of the campaign if at all but what really makes this game isnt the boardgame side, but the rts element of micromanaging an army to defeat another. The act of sending troops against other troops controlled by another player directly tests your strategic thinking, quick reaction times and control on the battlefield. It is surprisingly invigorating for what a distant glance may suggest is a game made up of just clicking back and forth - i can assure you it is so much more!
Overall, i cannot say much for the board game side but i can say with absolute truth that the online battles cause just as much adrenaline as an fps game. Its especially fun to play against friends. Even though this game is very old, it is still very playable but it may be smarter to buy a slightly newer total war game like rome 2 :)

The golden age of total war.

best strategic map in the series. Everything you do has strategic purpose. move spy to spy. move merchant to profit. send princess to marry. send assassin to kill. send priest to convert. No clunky skill trees destroying the pacing, no stupid diceroll events, no clunky half-baked wannabe-paradox bullshit when you just wanna be fighting battles and roleplaying as a medieval King. Did I mention the loading screens take 2 seconds on an SSD? This game gets you right in the action with no wasted breaths. 
 Become enemies with the Pope and feel the wrath of Christendom as you convert Europe to Islam with a vicious Jihad, or become his sword against the rising menace from the east. But wait, as you're squabbling, the Mongols are coming, so there's that. Yeah, this campaign is nonstop immersive perfection. Watch as your troops in battle actually acquire better armor when you give them armor upgrades on the campaign map.  Watch as your bannermen charge in to battle swinging their flags. Watch your army of shiny cavalry smash a bunch of stupid peasants into oblivion. It's great fun and before you know it, 10 hours have passed.
This game has the best pacing in the series, unhindered by excessive skill trees or diceroll events. Loading screens are quick, everything you do is fun and simple and yet deep and expressive. It has a vision and it perfects it.

I had this and all the expansions on disc and played this game for hundreds and hundreds of hours. In the old days I considered it by far the best game in the series. Since then I have gone on to play most of the newer total war games. Now that the old disc installs dont work I saw this one day and bought it to check it out and see how it compared.

 So....this is still by far the best game in the series. The graphics look a little dated (but by no means unplayable) and a couple features of the game have irritating old mechanics (diplomacy is SO SLOW, and the AI will always have its go-to province it will keep attacking over and over)....but the overall gameplay, design, replayability, unit variety and behavior....all that just blows away all the other games in the series, including the newer ones. I've got 65+ hours in just a couple weeks playing this since I rebought it with no end in sight. It really is that good.

What makes this M2TW great is, not only the essence of the game - be it the kingdoms expansion that quells your lust for mass crusades or the base campaign that (Even though the crashes have annoyed me to the point of uninstalling twice [or more, probably more]) is a spectacular campaign that satiates deep urges for Dark Age European dominance.
The modding community does a fantastic job keeping the community alive, with overhaul mods like Stainless Steel that revamp and upgrade the game. Up to and including mods like Third Age that completely transform the game into Tolkien's beloved fantasy.
Medieval 2 is a staple in Creative Assembly's history that when (If ever) a sequel comes, its base elements will only benefit from drawing inspiration from the Strategy classic that is Medieval 2 Total War

The goods :

- The game has a smooth learning curve where you progressively unlock unit types and are afforded time to familiarize with their strenght and counters.
- Random trait accumulation from your characters make your characters become better at what you use them to do, and worse at what you don't use them to do. This sometimes prompt you to make decisions that are sub-optimal hoping your characters can get an edge for later on.
- Charging an heavy cavalry unit into an ennemy flank and watching foes go flying everywhere never gets old (and I would know, I played 4000 hours of this).
- Good faction variety.
- Excellent mod support.
- Will probably be runnable by your machine.

The bad : 

- Battle UI is decidedly worse than in later titles of the same franchise (but the battle engine itself is better)
- Your favorite characters keep dying of old age (though you might like this)
- Ennemy factions eventually fold easily to your mid-game armies, which might mean you won't get much use of your shiny late-game units (which is fixed by playing any of the Kingdom expansion which make the late-game units appear earlier).
- Getting to the most exciting part of the campaign where you start winning but you aren't just crushing everyone yet takes time and doesn't last very long.

Main campaign is really nothing special, but the Kingdoms DLC has three pretty good ones (Crusades, England, New World). So get the DLC. In main campaign, you don't have to be a modder to change the descr_strat.txt file to lower the turn length (so your leaders don't die before getting good) or changing the readout from which turn it is to which year it is, both simple and useful changes with a text editor. Probably one of the easiest to play without pausing, but mostly because the units are set to react to your commands slowly and the melee takes a while. AI is better than average for the series, generally with good start position/formation choices. If you play at Hard or higher it will sometimes give you a challenging go, but the campaign AI's army unit selection often lets it down. Britain and Turkey have the easiest go on campaign. Family tree management isn't really a thing because you can't control heir selection: just ignore it, it's really not that kind of game.

This game is mediocre at best. It has some decent mechanics don't get me wrong, but it's way to old, boring, without much variety and one dimensional in comparrison to the newer titles. Even whilst those, might not be perfect they offer more to the game then MD II. What MD II lacks is content, difficulty and depth! Whilst you can mod the game, the gameplay itself feels not only very underwhelming but also unsatisfying. Building system and Army recruitment are to put it simply: annoying. There is no fun in it, it feels more like a hinderance than anything really! Battles are bland and outdated, I don't understand the hit-points system in a historical game, makes no sense whatsoever and Auto-Battles are like playing the lottery... you never know how they go! 
At least the timeline is pretty good, that was somewhat enjoyable. 
Maybe if you get the game at a discount you can try it out or if you suffer from nostalgia (which everyone does with certain games) otherwise, there are much better Total War games and strategy games out there!

I remember when I was introduced to M2TW. I was visiting my Aunt and Uncle's house, I was maybe 11 years old and my cousin showed me a game "that will blow your mind". I had played Shogun 1 on a Win95 PC and thought that was dope, so when I played M2TW for the first time my mind was indeed blown. I played it religiously, it was my favourite game for years and so when I bought it again on Steam the nostalgia was intense.

I love this game, warts and all. If you've played any other Total War games and haven't yet experienced M2TW, do yourself a favour and get it. It may be showing its age, it may be buggy and Milan may be a chronic pain in the arse, but this game remains my favourite in the TW series all these years later.

Even though I own all Total War games after this one (except Warhammer 2 and Thrones of Britannia), I still find myself coming back to the great Medieval 2, which also has the most hours put into my collection of Total War games.  The graphics may be dated and horrible unit placement / pathfinding in Towns/Castle but there is something about this older style of the Total War game that makes this one stick out from the rest that come after it.  You also get multiple ages, going from Early Medieval to early gunpowder units with Pike and Shot formations.  This is simply one of the best Total War games out there, that also holds its own after 14+ years.
There are many facets to the game that keep you thinking and planning while the game is in progress.

This still stands the test of time and is the ultimate Total War experience.

The best total war game. The most fun. It's perfectly balanced between fun strategy (ranking up priests to convince the Pope to call a Crusade to trick France into sending one of its armies away so you can take Alsace/Lorraine (as Denmark) to the mindless, stupid fun of watching your general give a unique pre-battle speech based on your faction, the opponent, and his own personality (like creative insults). Also, each agent gets a video for attempting a mission. And also cavalry impact is the best of any total war game.

Reader: Play this Total War game first. It's simple to pick up, the colors are pretty, and it's easy to like.

Caveats/bugs: merchants are underpowered, two-handed weapons don't work, and mod support is not available through Steam. You may find yourself whipping up a 5-minute mod yourself just to tweak some of the bugs and balance issues to your personal preference, but that's part of the charm. The game is so fun that it's worth going out of your way to make it even more fun.

Buy it for your friends too. It's cheap, usually.

1106 AD - A mob of a few hundred English spears and longbowmen slaughters a thousand Viking rebels in Normandy without moving from their starting formation.

1139 AD - The Holy Roman Empire issues an ultimatum, demanding a handful of pocket change from England or they will attack. England complies. The Germans invade England anyway, are promptly pincushioned by longbow arrows, and try to demand more money in exchange for peace.

1292 AD - England captures the Seljuk Sultanate's last holdout by having its longbows stand outside the walls and raining arrows down on the Turks while they stand around in the town square doing nothing. People begin to suspect the longbow may be OP.

1497 AD - At the Battle of Polish Anatolia, a force of English longbowmen massacres the last Mongol horde without moving from their starting formation.

1777 AD - England crushes the Washington Rebellion with a decisive deployment of longbowmen at the Siege of Boston.

1945 AD - England wins World War II by deploying a force of yeomen with scoped compound longbows to capture Tenochtitlan from the People's Aztec Republic.

2973 AD - English longbowmen destroy the Jyrbinian Annihilator in high orbit over Dinthrax VI with a hail of arrows, completing the Kingdom of England's conquest of the Milky Way galaxy.

Honestly the best Total war game made, even 13 years later. Medieval 2 takes the best features from Rome and improves on them, adding more features to improve on the not so great parts of Rome. The campaign is more rewarding when you play it for longer instead of the monotonous routine of Rome, Get strong, Get 10 pop with people, Start civil war, take Rome, take rest of map. Medieval 2 puts more effort into making you think "Do i want to do this yet" based on variables such as the pope and Crusading. The addition Of the horde factions makes it so you don't just conquer a territory and never lose it, providing you to think more about strategy and Consequences. Diplomacy is lacking, which is to be expected with the Earlier total war games which were very battle and army orientated. The graphics are impressive for a game made in 2006 and i would argue better than empire, the game after it in the series. My one big gripe with the game was the Activation of the Americas campaign, which comes much to late, leaving only one faction to take part in this big scramble that CA intended it to be, most of the factions have either been destroyed or are too weak economic wise to send armies to america. If you would like a first experience into a Total war game, i recommend this or Rome 1 , as both games leave you wanting more.

Rome: TW and Medieval 2: TW were milestones for strategy games. Personally, I even think they're better then every Total War game that followed. New in these games was the ability to march your armies and agents through the landscape. Before this, Total War worked much like Risk, where you place and move armies through territories. This makes it possible to raid, or march deep through enemy territory to capture strategic settlements.

The battles were more forgiving then Shogun: TW and possibly Medieval: TW (the first ones). The cultures are diverse and the trade system is a lot of fun, especially employing merchants. All in all, this game is a classic and should be in your library already.

Another piece of classic must own if you love old Total War while waiting for Medieval 3.

It definitely has a learning curve but if you've played other Total War games, you're certainly in for a treat.

The graphics hold up nicely even in 2020 (sure, max zoom can make things look a big low-poly and the textures could use with a little highter res).

Sound is OK. The music is fun but gets old relatively fast. The sound effects show some age but they were highly polished by then's standards and still are relevant and don't get annoying easily.

The interface is a bit clunky and some shortcuts are missing, especially if you are a micromanaging beast like me (the roster that lists your units doesn't allow you to filter, order or do mass-actions and if you deal with one character, you'll have to open it all up again and scroll all over again. Gets tedious late game).

The multiple campaigns with different maps are food for those who crave for more when they're done with the main europe/north africa/middle east region. Americas and Crusades really add good variety and the maps are fun to play. Highly recommended.

This has immense replayability, especially when you realise how powerful diplomats, spies and assassins really are. After all, warfare is not exclusively about troops and siege contraptions! Going for 100% religious unity is also a great challenge for those already accostumed to regular play.

Do yourself a favor and play it on easy and auto-resolve all battles. The real fun in the total war franchise is the empire administration. If you want a truly in-depth troops field management experience, refer to more established RTS's such as Starcraft, Empire Earth and the "Age Of ..." options. This is 4X at its best and definitely one of the most compelling installments of all Total War. The quality of Medieval II far surpasses that of Napoleon and Shogun II.

It's still the best of the older TW games, where the differences between playable factions were more subtle. Lighter on diplomacy and economy than other grand strategy games, preferring to focus on its excellent combat mechanics (despite occasionally wonky AI), but what is there is enough to suck you into each playthrough, as whatever warlord you chose. The 'Medieval' series always delivers satisfying knightly strife, with some swords-and-sandals crusading action between the Arab powers and the more traditional European factions, with the Papacy featuring as a key player.  Good expansions added many more hours to my playtime. I miss its' personality, which is absent in some of the newer entries, even if I am happy for CA to experiment with their formula.

I've played Medieval II: Total War since it was first released, and I keep coming back to this outstanding game. 

Amazing replay ability, and lots of great modding options (Europa Barbarorum 2 and Third Age: Total War in particular). Holds up well for an older game, with good graphics (for the time) and great game play mechanics. 

The vanilla game and the Kingdoms expansions are all excellent (especially the Americas Kingdoms expansion), and can be played through many times. 

The strongest of the Total War games overall. Highly recommend if you enjoy a great grand strategy game. Worth every penny.

This game is one of the most enjoyable experiences I've had, despite its age. It will be 14 years old by the end of the year, but I personally think that this game, with its DLC is one of, if not the best, games ever made. It runs great on computers new and old too, avoiding the problems of Rome: Total War. It has a smaller number of factions then compared to something like Rome 2, but the factions are more varible in this game, in my opinion. It also, in my opinion, can help keep a player engaged for longer times because it has preset goals, and as times move on curcimstances change, from things like the Mongol invasion to the discovering of America in game. It is definetly a bit old, and I will admit that the learning curve can be a bit high and the options a bit overwhelming at first, but it is overall a game well worth the cost, especially since the DLC is now built into the price.

Total War is a franchise that practically sells itself: massive battle lines of hundreds or thousands of soldiers fighting in highly tactical combat with the added bonus of specialized troops, upgrades etc based on your ability as an administrator. But I am going to sell you on Medieval 2, specifically, not Total War in general.
For the first quarter of the game you are an impoverished country pitting your militias against enemy levies of militias in this part of the game bows will sufficiently murder just about anything that is within range, to say nothing of your general's elite heavy cavalry who, at this point in the game, can kill an entire army even when outnumbered 10 to one. 
The next quarter hits you with a twist: the Mongols have arrived to MURDER EVERYTHING. You think you're safe in your castles and cities? Think again. You think you're okay marching your army through the open map? Absolutely not. For hundreds of years the massive and terrifying might of the mongols can hold your entire focus--fighting the mongols in direct combat is as bad or worse than fighting the entire rest of the world. But you learn and you grow. Your elites start to clash with theirs.
Gunpowder rears its head and changes the game dynamic in two major ways: 1) armor is entirely useless against a gunpowder wielding army. Armored units are slow and even steel plate armor doesn't provide adequate protection the thundering might of a gun line. 2) The dominant force of power shifts on its head. Where once your heavily armored elite troops recruited from castles were your mightiest and fiercest soldiers, now the militia trained from your largest cities hold sway over the battlefield. Even the most poorly equipped troops in cities have their uses; if they can hold the enemy in place long enough for your muskets to fire another volley, the militia has more than earned their keep and if even half of your cloth armored, spear holding militia troops die, the cost of training a new unit is dwarfed by the cost of the enemy training new heavily armored sword wielding elite infantry. 
Now that you can recruit gunpowder units you have a huge advantage over your enemies and can bowl over everyone else with superior technology, aye? No. Right around the time where you are able to recruit gunpowder units in earnest from a few of your wealthiest cities, the Black Plague hits and everything goes south. Every unit you have trained starts leaking men as they fall to the horror of contagion. Thousands die, then tens of thousands until you're losing 50,000 citizens in a single turn from the plague and all the while trade suffers and you're suddenly bankrupt and have to slowly rebuild. And if you're lucky, you've rebuilt enough to take on the legacy of Timur the Lame and his war elephants who literally carry cannons on their backs and are incredibly difficult to kill. Medieval 2 uses real crises and events from history to balance the game. You can't ever feel like you're doing too well because there is always going to be something to keep you on your toes or some new horizon to shoot for. Alliances are fickle and end often. Wars more often than not last until one side is completely eradicated. This offers two styles of play: Kill everything with massive armies until no one lives but you and your kingdom, or establishing solid borders in a few key cities and expanding outward in rings of increasing size, simply marching out your men from the cities you've owned for 100 years to garrison your next city. 
Gunpowder is exciting and horrible and seeing its effect makes you long for the simple days of sword to sword combat, but generally this is only when you're on the receiving end. On the offense it's both satisfying and almost disappointing--somber even--to see the elite heavily armored infantry of your enemy falling in scores to your marksmen, or seeing the enemy kings, princes, emperors and their descendants falling one by one to cannon fire. Medieval 2 is a satisfying game with strong design choices that was well thought out and certainly stands the test of time. It is both in setting and overall execution, my favorite of the Total War games not just because it immerses you in the setting, but because it shows you a complete story ripped from the pages of history books without a word of dialogue to explain the developer's stance.

This game has everything. If you like strategy, it's for you. Conquest? Check. City building and technological expansion? Check. Long, complicated, messy battles with thousands of troops and deep elements of proper-war tactics? Yup, bring it on. Quite often, putting everything together can be very risky, as you end up with a title that doesn't really do anything well. And then you have a game like "Total War: MEDIEVAL II" that does everything extremely well. And it just gets better, the more you play it.

I just got Medieval II after my friend nagged me. I get my wallet from the other room, mess with the activation code on my gift card two times. After five minutes of downloads, I load in. My friend tells me to go to Mongols because I usually focus on Cav in Napoleon and Shogun. I go with all the lancers and some bows. We fought on Seine (the river that runs through Paris). I put my car in a block. Then... we begin.

Let me preface this with I am not a stranger to Total War but what I witnessed today... it changed me. 

I charge my men into his pikemen heavy lines, causing me to say "oh shit!" He laughs, thinking he has won. Then, he unleashes his secret weapon: a torrent of flame from his bombards. A dozen Mongols go down. I yell "Oh No! KILL IT!". I target his cannons, hoping to break his pikemen with less than 3/4 losses. Soon, my horses turn to hornets, swishing and swashing left and right faster and faster. I could practically feel the friction piercing my screen. My friend looks on in horror, scream and praying to his God, only to be answered with deaf ears. Soon, droves of pikes lay on the ground as a hoard of hornet like Asians bum tickle his lines deeper and deeper. Like a hot knife through butter, I smash his lines and vanquish his cannons. We cry him out of frustration and myself from pure joy. He had lost over half of his army while I was left with less than a 5th left of my army.

Overall 9/10, controls are a little weird.

The best Total War game out there. The turn based tactical map is very easy for newcomers to learn thanks to it's simple and easy to understand UI while not sacrificing strategic depth like future games. Medieval 2's modding community is also incredible, the amount of masterfully crafted mods for this game puts it up there with Empire at War and Mount and Blade. My personal recommendation is Third Age Total War, It's a faithful recreation of the Middle Earth setting and it's multiplayer community is still alive thanks to it's solid balancing.

My only criticism of the game comes from the Real-Time battles, battles easily become repetitive as siege maps are mostly copy-pasted and the only real winning strategy is just hammer and anvil cav charges, even in sieges. But that's sorta unavoidable in an authentic simulation of pre-modern warfare.

When you think of Medieval II Total War, you think Classic Turn-based Strategy! This game is one of my favourite strategy games of all time despite being released in 2006, it recaptures its nostalgic feel and the reminiscence of playing a Grand Campaign game for many hours on end. I have previously owned the game on a CD (hence why so little game time as I am writing this), and I couldn't be more pleased that it is accessible on Steam! The variety is great with many different factions being composed of numerous units and a game plan that is forged upon these units (e.g. the Faction of Byzantines has a heavy amount of Missile Cavalry or Spain with its early-game skirmishers) Soon, you begin to prefer certain units or Generals over others and forge alliances which decide your preference of friends and foes. Crusades are quite interesting since they allow you to open a new theater as well as new lands for your kingdom and later invasions of many new factions (I'm not going to spoil for those who didn't play it yet) allow for constant immersion and a more interesting challenge. My favourite part of this game are the battles. The very well-known aspect of every Total War game. They are immersive, strategical and decisive (especially on harder difficulties) and a range of tactics and battle plans can be approached within them, some more successful and some less. It is interesting to see the superpowers of the Medieval era to battle it out on the land of a field in the middle of Europe. There are only two disadvantages to Medieval II Total War. Firstly, the more important one, is the price right now on Steam. I bought the game for around 20.00 and that is quite a hefty price for a game released almost 13 years ago (I understand it's a classic)! Secondly, the naval warfare is very boring as there is no real battle simulation to them, only odds (however I do remember it did not work out so well for certain Total War games when this was implemented).

The absolute best of the total war games. It is perfectly strategic and fun. Siege battles feel accurate and have depth. Nothing comes close to this games sieges.  The battles are different every time and are a perfect mix of action and thought. A perfect real time strategy with a nice turn based campaign.
The campaign, while simple, is a nice challenge on the harder difficulties while still feeling fair. 

Normally in a review I would make a pros and cons list, but this game has so, so, so many pros and very few cons. 

This game becomes a different beast with mods. I have spent hours on the Call of Warhammer mod. This games overhaul mods make a game already with possible thousands of hours of content, infinite. 

You will not be disappointed. This game is now cheap, will run on almost any computer (it even works on my crappy laptop). It still looks great. It can still look even though its more than a decade old. 

The only con I can think of is how, no matter how many mods you try. All campaigns (Vanilla and Modded) feel very similar. There isn't much uniqueness (even in the fantasy mods). Even in the different periods its the same thing, it sometimes feels like a grind to recruit units and march them. 

Don't let that distract you from this amazing game. I have put almost 400 hours into this game and only get burned out after days on end of playing. When I first got this game I couldn't put it down, 120 hours in the first month or so.

Any strategy fan should have this no matter what, any total war fan probably already has this. Any big fan of the medieval era or a world that is supported via a mod should have this game. 

Basically if you are interested in this at first glance you'll at least think its cool, at most fall in love like I did.

 If you don't like strategy then maybe it isn't for you. One of the best strategy games ever made is still a strategy game.

Firstly I'd like to start with giving this game a 5/5 even though there is some small things that could have been better. The reason it will still be a 5/5 game in my opinion is because of the games core mechanics and the way it plays and what it has to offer for me to have reached this one thousand hours of playing review/recommend post. Now to some of the minor dislikes that i hope to see addressed in greater depth and detail in future titles. Such as a Medieval 3 anyone. Before I start let me say the developers had a vision they executed it and turned out an endless amount of simulated medieval combat that will keep me entertained for a thousand plus more hours of playing. One, the AI on the campaign (even in great mods like stainless steel) are poorly developed and easy to beat. And that's unfortunate. They suicide charge every pitch battle. You literally have to do nothing but set up a defensive formation and let their soldiers sprint all the way your way and throw themselves on you. Hold fast then swing around your cavalry and done. Then you have the pain of the AI jumping around the map with tiny pathetic forces to pester you and your holdings. If they are going to attack you they should be more strategic and tactful with how they assault the player. If they lay you to siege they never mount the walls. You confront them from within they slink back and you have to chase them. This mechanic could have been more. That's really it on gripes honestly just some poorly designed AI. They could have taken the strategy portion of their idea and actually turned up the dial a bit. Instead of a highly difficult and rewarding campaign that had more depth. I would share my ideas on that but this is getting long enough as is. You get a sandbox build army go destroy every poorly disciplined nation around you without much thought and really quickly and complete the goals of the campaign within set amount of turns. So the strategy here is to go beat face around the map like a madman quickly. The game needs campaign goals but more drawn out. If the game is 1000+ turns in that's cool too. It's really my play style talking here. If people like the run around quickly go for it. I like to watch my kingdom grow become successful and go to war when and where i will. I don't need to take every place i assault. Sometimes i've taken to giving those territories to allies or weak nations, or hell even the pope. I once as England conquered the whole of Italy sacked all of the settlements and gave them to the church. Growing the Papal States into a formidable faction. That was fun try that sometime. And you can do the same thing in the Islamic countries. Anyway to wrap this up it's a fun game giving untold number of hours of entertainment and keeps you playing. Quick battles, Historical "attempts" battles, the campaign itself trying new ways to entertain yourself around some sloppy AI. And still manage to have fun. Mods like Stainless Steel (Especially this one because it's the best that stays to medieval and gives the vanilla a face lift  the developers need to take note from), and any of the themed  mods to spice it up are all what contributes to this being a 5/5 recommended title and franchise to play. And if you are entering this style of game as a first timer start here with this title at a fair and awesome price tag for access to hopefully your newest addiction. Start vanilla then go mod crazy and have fun.

Coming back to it years later, enjoying the rich history and unique gameplay  only to be frustrated and disappointed with diplomacy, pathfinding, general gameplay frustrations utlimately will leave this game on the dustpile.  Maybe, if there was an actual re-release with improved gameplay and enhancements to AI rather than an HD facelift...this might actually be worth purchasing again.

I dont know what can be said about this game. It is in my eyes, a Timeless Classic. Without question. The game in vanilla form is a diverse experience with multiple nations to play as. The expansions offer smaller versions of the same great grand campaign but with a handful of select and new nations. These games are often games that are played with much anticipation but due to such a grand scale, players can often feel as if they're "running out of gas" when playing. Adopting an external mindset of "role playing" can totally help invigorate even the most veteran of players. ( An example would be playing say the "crusader expansion" and adopting ruthless Templar behavior and playing as those individuals would.)  Now if all the vanilla offerings and personal role playing isn't enough, there is sure to be a mod out there for you. From Lord of the Rings to Warhammer and even some Game of Thrones mods (i believe)....there are tons. You may need to utilize google to help with installing such mods, it can be arduous but worth the pay off. A lot of mods even have "sub mods" which add even more content to Total Conversions like the Lord of the Rings mods. The graphics are for the most part dated and key configurations may be dated to some as well... but simply put it is well worth the grand strategy and hands on battles the game has to offer. This can be said for a lot of the Total War games. Regardless of their releases, bugs, lack of content, etc, there exits mods, fixes, solutions for just about anything. At 149 hours in under a year, I have undoubtedly surpassed the time spent playing recently compared to when the game debuted and I fell in love with it back in 05-06. Its simply awesome.

Potentially the best old Total War game where all the good features were made better and no-one had thought of the most controversial features yet, like small villages, navy battles or no general-less garrisons.

Whilst not perfect, it probably has the best Total War pathing and fighting AI for each model in a unit that was somehow lost around Empire, especially for melee combat, and then reworked into the very messy unit blobs of post Rome II Total War that seem to be entirely about unit AI instead of model AI that care more about unit stats than physical formation. [i]This was also the last or one of the last entries to have parting ranks to let a second unit pass through an idle one, yes this is really annoying once you notice it missing in modern Total War.[/i]

The little details like weapon & armour upgrades visually improving a unit or the campaign general speeches reflecting their traits are what makes this a special entry in the series that had more to enjoy than the [i]scissors, paper, stone, I'll just smash my giant army into yours[/i] routine.

And you can always look up total conversion mods if you fancy something like Hyrule, or smaller ones that let you play as the Pope. There is a lot out there.

Summary: TW:ME has a mix of game styles which is refreshing. If you enjoy the Civilization style building that is turn based (changes through seasons, which is a nice touch.) but the intensity of real-time combat, than TW:ME is it. Diplomacy is amazing, lately I've been receiving Alliances w/marriages to Princesses into their bloodlines... really cool touch. Combat and units vary depending on the country you pick but the mechanics are all the same. Heavily fortified cities are much harder to invade than non-fortified. Hence the use of siege units which is a must for castles and their brutal upgrades. Bloodline / Family tree spin is a really cool touch too. Having offspring and everything else makes for very dynamic play thru(s). The religious system is also interesting and acts a lot like the U.N. if you've ever played Civilization. Real-time combat is amazing, well done visually and holds up to todays standards imo. Great for more modern laptops. Additionally it follows events historically, the crusades, mongol invasion, et al. All in all... great game.

TL;DR: If you like real-time strategy/warfare but the building mechanics that make Civilization addictive, then you're going to love TW:ME.

[h1]Medieval 2: Total War - A must buy.[/h1]
     [b]Medieval 2 is one of the best Total War games to date.[/b] Aside from the brilliant 'kingdoms' expansions, it offers a fun campaign spanning Europe [spoiler]and even portions of the new world[/spoiler], a diverse roster of units for each faction, unique agents, the modding community for this game in unrivalled. I would highly recommend this game for anyone new to Total War and unsure as to which game they should try first. Cheap, easy to get to grips with, and not to taxing on low specification machines, Medieval 2 is a masterpiece.

     [b]What's great about Medieval 2?[/b]
- Will run smoothly on older machines, even Macs.
- Easy to understand mechanics.
- Emphasis on fun gameplay over complex, unnecessary features like in newer titles.
- A wealth of great mods to run.
- Good DLC expansions.
- Low price for a Total War game, good starting point for new players.

     [b]What could be improved?[/b]
- Is an older game. Graphics have not aged well.
- Campaign may crash sometimes.
- Unit recruitment is slow and can get tedious in long campaigns.
- Multiplayer on Mac is almost non-existent.
- Limitations of older game engines, etc.

     [b]Who would I recommend this game to?[/b]
1. Newer Total War players who are unsure as to which game to start with.
2. People with low specification systems or Mac users like myself.
3. Any strategy players interested in the medieval period.

     [b]Overall rating: 9/10[/b]

The game that inducted me into strategy games. I haven't played it recently so I can't say how well it's aged, but it's legendary. There are newer games that do the map-level strategy better in my opinion, but even there, you will find intricacies deep into a save and the strategy element is very rewarding if you play smart. Map-play is probably the more engaging out of the two gameplay styles (map-play and battles), which is a feat, because the battles are spectacular. All Total War games have had great battles but Medieval 2 along with a select few like Shogun 2 are the only ones that really nail the strategic map-play. Good classic game to have.

I have a love-hate relationship with ME2. I love it as a student of history and wargaming enthusiast. It is the gold standard of its generation and is responsible in large part for defining the genre in the way we know it today. Although it shows its age in its clunkiness, it chugs along fine by my book. I hate it in that it has slowly drained my life away. The 1500 or so hours I've logged on Steam doesn't account for the double that I have logged in my pre-steam ownership of the title. CA: give me ME3. I want it...I need it...I...must...have it.
It's just a solid strategy game built by competent and passionate designers. Fuck more you want?

I have spent many hours in the Total War series. If I were to total all of them up (not including this, which only shows 61 hours currently), over all the computers I've owned and all the versions I've owned off of Steam, I would easily say that I've probably racked up well over 300-400 hours.

In that time, Medieval 2 has been my favorite. The depth of gameplay, the return of video assassinations, and the historical events, all masterfully done amidst the realistic religious strife...It makes it a complete game.

Become a Catholic nation whose neighbors war with you immediately. Send assassins to Rome to eliminate Popes with whom you have fallen out of favor. Continue your reign of terror until you can place one of your own Cardinals in the Vatican, firmly securing yourself in a position of favor within the Papacy.

Or strike hard and true as the hard-fighting Turks, with their naphtha bomb throwers and their mastery of gunfire weaponry later. Call on your Muslim nations in a Jihad to reclaim lands lost, or to fight the infidels of lands far away.

Watch as your generals grow from young men to battle-hardened veterans, acquiring mercenary entourages as well as slave-women concubines -- until it turns out your general prefers men. Watch as he slips into madness and is cast off as a lunatic, all to see him claim the throne as his father dies of old age and he is next in line for the throne.

Master the art of the longbow or the crossbow, or the art of the heavy cavalry charge. Whatever your faction's strengths are, play them to their fullest and succeed on the field of battle.

Watch your provinces grow from small villages to mighty towns and cities, only to be wiped out by the Black Death. Watch your resources and money plummet as you go into severe debt (along with the rest of Europe and Africa and the Middle East), only to survive the ordeal and to find that, just as you are weak, so now are all your opponents, and you might just have enough strength to assail them in their moment of weakness.

The choice is yours. What kind of kingdom will you run?

One of the best historical titles Creative Assembly has created, this game is still amazing to play after so many hours. Armies that don't need generals so you can send a small scout force or send reinforcements without needing a commander with them, the ability to trade cities and castles for money, crusades(DEUS VULT)/Jihads, and a couple of late game enemies that can provide a challenge when you get to the point where you can steamroll everyone else. Not only that, the mods for this game are insane like the Lord of the Rings mod Third Age: Total War and the submod Divide and Conquer or Stainless Steel 6.4 which adds more variety to the base game. Must get for those who don't care too much about the mid 2000s graphics for a great price!

Good game. DLC is...you know...an actual expansion. Some faction balancing can be an issue. Includes a system that hasn't been used in any other total war game (fortresses and towns) which effect how you look at the world map. AI is competent (for the most part). Can certainly give you a few hundred hours if you like Grandstrategy with a bit of RTS. Only area lacking is in early game unit diversity, which means nothing after turn 30 or 40 if you know what you're doing. Can't comment on the multiplayer. Overall a very fun game.

The good: 
	- factions
		 With a whopping 17 playable factions in the game, medieval 2is one of the most diverse total wars to date., and all these factions are available for freethey are not all available from the start, only 5 are, them being England, France, the holy roman empire, Venice and Spain. You unlock the other factions by destroying them in the campaign, which grants replay ability to the campaign as you unlock all the different factions
	- A lot for your money
		 The only dlc released for this game was the kingdoms dlc, which is a fantastic dlc giving even more replay ability to the game. Instead of locking off content already present in the game, It adds four new mini campaigns with new maps, factions and units added.
	- Slower often more methodical battles
		 If you are a total war player who enjoys the slower more tactical side of things, the battles in medieval 2 are for you. Units generally fight for longer if let to just duke it out, but tactics such as hammer and anvil, standard rear charging, and out flanking can and will send units running fast. The effect cavalry has in these battles really captures the dominance of heavy cavalry during the medieval age.
	- A deeper settlement managed system
		 As the total war series has progressed, the settlement systems especially have generally become much more streamlined and easy to use, with most important effects coming down to if you have enough of one resource; money.This is not the case for medieval 2. in addition to money cities are also constrained by their population, their religion or their culture. You will not be able to recruit knights from a 500 man village and you cannot recruit French soldiers from an English town, however the beauty of this system is that these factors can be changed, an village of 500 can be grown into the military hub of your empire, and any culture can be assimilated
	- The modding
		 The game is one of the most moddable games in total war history, and has an active vibrant modding community to this day, whether you like total conversions, overhauls or aesthetics there is a mod out there for you 

Neither good or bad
	- The AI is simple, but it works, after a while it became very easy to outplay the AI
		 As with most total war games, the AI is not a highpoint, however it does not mean that the AI is incompetent. The AI is aggressive on the attack, defensive on the defence, it attempt to protect its flanks and is generally active on the campaign map. It is however very one-dimensional on how it executes its tactics. If they are attacking they will advance straight at you every time, the cavalry will attempt the same flanking manoeuvre time and time again. The same goes for sieges and when it's on the defence. This means after a while the AI will become quite easy to outplay, outmanoeuvre or even straight up cheese. All in all, it isn't bad, but it is not a positive either.
	- The economy
		 The economy of total war games is something that has become more streamlined over the years, and it's one of those I things that I personally dont mind being more streamlined, because there are many times in medieval where I have been losing or gaining money and I have had no idea exactly where the money was/wasnt coming from. I will not put this as a negative because its a very personal gripe I have with the game.

The bad
	- For players coming from newer games: 
		 Game (especially the battles) can feel very clunky and unresponsive
			 The game is old, and that age comes through, in my opinion, the most during battles, the base controls feel awkward, although these can be changed of course. My main gripe is how unresponsive your units feel, when an order is given it often takes atleast 2-3 seconds before the entire unit is in motion, and orders like running and such aslo feel really delayed and unresponsive. While this might be more "realistic" than the more robotic instant response from units seen in later games, it feel better. Having it reissue an order several time just to get it to run or move is not fun gameplay.
		 research isn't clearly explained and can cause confusion early on
			 As with other total war games your faction will advance scientifically as the game goes on, issue is, at least for new players is that how this process occurs is not immediately obvious to the player.
	- Game tend to become a stomp after the mid game
		 This is an issue with nearly all total war games and strategy games in general, as your faction becomes more powerful, the AI will struggle to keep up, and by the time you have knocked out your initial enemies in the early mid game the main challenge from the game is gone. The game tries to remedy it with the Mongol and Timurid invasion, which helps add some late game challenge, but in my opinion it isn't enough
	
	Conclusion
	Medieval 2 is a solid and classic entry into the total war franchise whose main drawback 13 years later is its age. I want to recommend this to all new fans of total war, however at this time I will not because of a recent price hike on this 13 year old game, this is bad faith by CA, and I cannot recommend this game as long as that remains.

LINUX port review; ignore if you don't use linux
--------------------------------------------------------------
Sorry about the 'don't recommend', it only reflects my view on the linux port; the game is actually good, but steams binary do/don't recommend system forces me to pick the option which is most in line with what I here am writing.

Even though Feral interactive have done a good job porting other total war games to the more elegant operating system for more civilized users (In the case of Empire total war they even somehow managed to make a more stable game than on windows), they have not done a very good job in this case, and I am experiencing a number of issues:

Interestingly, wrong textures are sometimes loaded.

I always find the character portraits (on the family tree) replaced by random pieces of terrain or (whatever texture from the game really) and I have even seen the (entire) ground texture on a countryside battle-map be replaced by cobblestone (not just inside a city or on a road, but all over the countryside, including under the trees in the forest).

Furthermore, as far as I can tell, the game is less stable than the (admittedly not very stable) windows version; sometimes I have experienced simple crashes, but other times the game has frozen and become completely irresponsive to any inputs *even going as far as to ignore 'sudo kill' commands (!)*.

And obviously most mods don't work, as they have not been tested for the linux version; this is of course true for most games, but in the case of this game, the mods is a huge part of its appeal.

In conclusion, while you certainly can download, play and even enjoy this game on linux, you should just play it on a windows environment, either on a dual boot, a windows emulator/virtual machine or a compatability layer (such as Wine) or on a windows machine (as the game is rather old, it is perfectly playable on one of these tiny laptops most of us have lying around anyway). 

Note that I have only tested this game on Windows 10 and Arch-linux through the KDE desktop environment using the runtime version of linux; I have for one thing not tested it on Ubuntu, which the game likely has been playtested for (considering the minimum system requirements)

Game of My Life. I have approx 8'000 hrs of gameplay on this game without a single auto-resolved battle. When I had been playing this game, there was no steam. This is the first game I purchased as a hardcopy. What makes this game unique is the possibilities. The game lets you use your own ideas; there are no patterns you should follow. Watch me kill cavalry with archers, kill spearmen with cavalry, win impossible battles, watch me use merchants (which are called useless by many veterans) to earn money enough to bribe all armies and cities, remain allies with France as England with 3 marriages. The game doesn't shape how you play, it is in your hands.

Some of my achievements I can remember;

* Prevented the Hundred Years' War between France and England
* Made 20k income per turn in 50 turns without invading a single land
* Prevented Osman to build the Ottoman Empire by assassinating him
* Conquer Europe with Orthodox priests as Russia
* Elected as Pope and started crusades
* Stopped Mongols and Crusaders as Egypt without giving a single land.

* Won battles that had 95% chance of losing. Was awarded with many cross-swords in the map, which were nice tokens to remember your efforts.
* Defended a simple castle with 300 hundred militia against 3000 men without having archers or artillery (Did the charge in the movie last samurai with 3 light cavalry units outside the castle. 1 flanked right, another left; disturb the enemy formation, last cavalry unit with triangle formation went out from the front gate and charged directly to enemy general at that open space. Only 3 cavalry reached the general unit, killed the general, the enemy started to flee.
* Killed 3 heavy armored dismounted knight units with 3 Sipahis. Arrows run out, only 1/5 of the enemy was killed, tired the enemy by let them chase sipahis and rest sipahis. After numerous charges, I had 3 sipahis against 5. Was desperate, run up to the hill and hoped the charge down will be enough. It was enough. The battle took 5 hours in real life.

AI might suck but it doesn't prevent you to have fun. I have numerous memories about this game and I still remember them after +10 years. If you are looking for a game to consume in a month don't buy this game. This game is about possibilities and you can't taste them all in a month, or in a year.
Once you get past the dated graphics and the somewhat clunky unit mapping. Then this game will become one of the best grand strategy games that, you will ever have the pleasure of playing.

One of the best total war games there is and still holding its own even in 2019.

The vanilla game is a classic and provides a great sense of epic conquest as you spend countless turns building up your lands and armies before sending them forth to claim the world, or at least the majority of it on the classic vanilla map. The game has its issues and will have newcomers slamming their keyboard when played on higher difficulties (the A.I. gets a lot of bonuses), but with time you'll develop a play style that works for you and your faction in this weirdly well balanced game given its age. 

The definitive edition includes the expansions and though I have far less experience with these, I can say they are worth a go and a welcome addition. I owned this game back when it first came out and can say I easily put months of play into not only the vanilla game and using every faction, difficulty and expansion that was available, but also many of the countless mods that are out there (honourable mentions to the Warhammer, Elder scrolls and Lord of the rings mods in particular).

For new comers to the total war franchise, this is a great place to start, for veterans...well you probably already have this and to those who joined us with the recent additions and are curious what others are always going on about with medieval 2 and Rome. Then if you can get passed the slight change in controls (or remap them, though I enjoy the nostalgia) and old school interface then this game will be an easy purchase and no doubt become a favourite in your library.

played the first installment of this game and loved it. I had high hopes for this one and it did not disappoint me; very addictive.

After all these years, I think Medieval 2 is still the best total war game out there. Sure, Attila is harder, Warhammer is flashier, and Rome 2... exists? But Medieval 2 is still my favorite. On the surface, it's just a battle simulator with a map, but digging deeper reveals more complexity than expected. Sure the AI isn't the greatest, and general's bodyguard is borderline broken, and there's that two-handed glitch, (and diplomacy is sorta messed up), but I still enjoy the game every time I pick it up. Plus, there's a sizable catalog of mods. Everything from stainless steel, which fixes and adds many features, to Santa's Invasion, which changes the Danes into the North Pole (my personal favorite, come at me), to total overhaul mods like Third Age, which turns Medieval 2 into a LotR game. And even if you get bored of all that, there's still the expansion, Kingdoms, which adds 4(?) campaigns at a very cheap price compared to other CA titles.
This game doesn't feel like an odd cacophony of conflicting and unpolished features, and the expansions don't feel like they were designed by penny-pinching cheapskates (go look at Attila's dlc, for example). It feels like a game.

After almost 80 hours invested into the game and finishing the campaign I finally feel that I know the game enough to write a review. I will often compare with Rome total war (RTW, the first one, to be honest I played as of the date of this review only these two titles so I cannot compare the game with any other titles from Total War series).
In general the game uses a very similar system as in RTW in terms of city management, buildings, taxes, squalor and that sort of stuff. There are two types of settlements, either a regular city, usually with almost no decent units to train and then you can have castles. Castles allow you to train elite troops of the time period but the disadvantage is substantially lower income (let's say 50% of a city). The good thing is you can change your cities to be castles and vice versa at any time, however since there are different buildings available in both settlement types, certain (unit training) buildings are not allowed in cities and some in castles, which means if you do not wish to rebuild from scratch you should set your mind at the moment you take the settlement and go with it for the rest of the game. Fortunately for a conqueror like you, factions standing against you will always have at least two or three castles so if you manage to take those, in a few rounds you can start producing troops from there and do not have to march them through half the map.
Let's continue with units. The game offers a wide variety of units and although I did not try many of them, I would say there are at least as many than in RTW if not more. Perhaps a downside to units trainable in a city is that they aren't any good in neither attack nor defense so it does not make sense to train them. While a city full of city troops could stand against a few stacks of castle units, if forced to fight with equal numbers, they would be badly beaten. AI isn't (luckily) as stupid as to train city troops and attack with them (if it has any castles to produce the "real" units, of course). Along with soldiers you can have an array of "standalone" units such as diplomats, spies, assassins (just like in RTW) but they added also princesses and merchants. I confess I did not understand the reason behind using princesses so I did not use them and I did fine without them. The tutorial or the advice panel that pops on the upper left screen if you click on something for the first time tells you something about them but it does not tell you the most important thing, WHEN to use them so it may be as well worthless. Similarly, it tells you how to use merchants but it does not tell you that merchants of all other factions will try to take your merchants away and they will succeed without you being able to do something about it (well, you can run away with your merchants but what is the point of having merchants when you need to run with them constantly?). Of course, you can use assassins to try to kill their merchants but you usually don't have about ten assassins just lying around, waiting for some poor merchant to come. Furthermore, income from one resource is on average somewhere around 30-50 gold per turn and given each one of your merchants costs 550 gold to train, it can be quite expensive to train them (especially at the start) and the profit usually comes after at least 15-20 turns (during which anything can happen to the merchants). And when they are most profitable, earning about 100 or more gold per turn and you are actually glad you invested in them some 30 rounds ago, they just die of old age. I get the premise of not having a 300-year old merchants as the game time goes by but in my opinion, the merchants are not worth it in the long run. Besides these you can train a priest to increase the faith percentage in your towns and regions but once again, I did not use them and I did not have to (even though that my kingdom was a paradise for all heretics and witches).
A few times when playing the game I had the feeling that some things were done to make the game more realistic but at the same time these things ruined the game a little. For example, you attack a city and you built 5 towers to scale the walls. If the defender positioned some basic cheap archer militia on the walls, then you are doomed, as NONE of your towers will survive and all will burn down. I remember that in RTW it happened sometimes that one or two towers were destroyed but never ALL of them. Sadly, the same goes for ram. I get that it would be quite costly to put iron shields in the front of a whole tower (hypothetically speaking) but it could be done to a ram but apparently people were so dumb back then as not to realise that their wooden siege weapons will burn down when used against flaming arrows. So one can picture my relief when finally gunpowder arrives and I could build some basic bombards to smash the gates and give the defenders some real fight. Of course, the tutorial window does not tell you this vital info so you don't have to end the siege just because your siege weapons got destroyed. The only usable and effective "siege weapon" are the ladders but here you have to prepare yourself for the losses you will suffer until your troops reach the top of the walls and start fighting (and not mentioning here another stupidity that the ladders cannot be reused once used so in case of a castle siege with more levels of walls you have to take care not to use all your ladders on the first walls or you automatically lost the battle). It is a little stupid that until there is just one defender unit left on the wall, the towers will fire arrows on your soldiers, which is particularly annoying during longer wall fights. The fighting looks good given the time period when the game was released, of course if you ignore the fact that every soldier dies in just one of two ways. However, it feels very authentic, especially at the beginning of the campaign, to watch your men fight the enemy and to hear their cries, just as you would in a battle. Another realistic thing I like is that when your line clashes with your opponent's, at first you can make out which troops are yours without clicking on them but a few moments later it all just mingles into one giant fighting mass and you can only observe. I don't know if this feature was also in the real medieval battles but it just feels realistic. Of course, you are free to give orders at any time but in this game the pathfinding is worse than in RTW so when you order your unit that is in the middle of it to go left, for example, it will but it will not do it as a whole but some soldiers may be stuck somewhere or the whole group of units may go in the other direction for whatever reason, so you have to be careful when issuing orders to make sure the units are doing what you told them and not some other nonsense that could potentially ruin your battle. I almost forgot, at the beginning of each battle, do not wait for some witty or brave speeches as it was in RTW, it is the middle ages and everybody is serious after all. Contrary to RTW, if you click on some stack of units that don't belong you or even rebels, they will always retort something based on your relationships with their owner. So for example a rebel general may call you a coward for not facing him, a neutral faction general may declare he is not your enemy and your enemies have the best lines going like "my master will reward me for your death, infidel" (the muslims, obviously) or "come and face the might of the reich" (guess who) and the most hilarious retorts are from other princesses: "I will never marry you". That being said, it makes the game a lot more atmospheric.
I did not cover the aspects of ridiculous diplomacy or for example the plague but unfortunately the review has a limited amount of characters and does not allow me to write everything I would like (but then again, noone would read this, not even the few poor souls which suffered until the end).

Possibly the best game in the franchise. The DLCs add a lot of extra hours and fun campaings. Had it in disk format, bought it again on steam. You should try the mods, they add a refreshing flavour to the game, whether they are an extension of the base game or a complete overhaul with new world maps.

This is the 2nd best Total War game to date. It would be the best were it not for the two joint best being Shogun 2 and Warhammer 2.

Ive played every Total War game since Shogun the original back in 2000. I'll start with the positives;

The UI for both the world map and battle maps is unsurpassed. why they changed it to the 'provinces and capitals system' after Shogun 2, I have no idea. Everything is simple to learn for beginners and intuitive.

The Scale is unsurpassed, even by present day standards. You may play through centuries of civilisations, including historically shaping events such as the dawn of the Knight and chivalry, or the Crusades, even discovering the new world, and shamelessly taking advantage of south american native cultures like the Aztecs and the Mayans (gold isnt as precious as you think guys, heres some wool...lets swap..)

So many factions to control (upon completion of campaign) and world domination never gets old, the management of settlements is optional, from micro management down to basically letting AI control your finances (dont let it, it spends like my GF on payday) 
its really engaging, and there is excellent balance between governance and brutal conflict.

The Graphics are excellent for the age of the game, and are still mustard today in my opinion. The sounds of peasent soldiers squabbling, or an English General questioning French sexual orientation are gems, and there is plenty more comedy gold as you scroll over your troops at the start of a battle.

The Soundtrack is great. Not as good as Rome 1 soundtrack, but general very rousing, and theres only so much sound you can get out of a Lute am I right?




The negatives:

Diplomacy is basically toilet, as with 9/10 TW games, It doesnt matter what you do, how loyal or Noble you are, you will be at war with every faction that borders you within a handful of turns. Very irritating. It wont bother you for your first play through, but it'll start getting on your tits after youve completed it a few times, as it really limits your approach to the game. youll find yourself applying the same doctrines to world domination. The way round this is to have a functioning steam workshop to fix the AI diplomacy. Steam however currently doesnt seem to be able to search for this game in the workshop though so dont expect a mod for diplomacy, although im sure they exist.


Doctrine. Youll find yourself approaching each play through with the same mindset. thanks to the above diplomacy, there are few options for a tactical approach, forming close military allegiances, or fiscally starving out opponents are all out of the window in favour of amassing a huge army and clattering any fool who gets in your way. however, this is great fun, and the game would be pointless if it was one big EU friendly SJW utopian wet dream.



Summary;

Get the game its well worth the money and is literally years of enjoyment.

Medieval 2 Total War is entirely worth it- on sale doubly so. I bought it for 5, which is a bit more than you'd get Rome Total War for. I've played Rome 1, Napoleon, Alexander, and a bit of Shogun 2, and this is possibly my favourite or second favourite total war game, and this is as someone who plays a lot of other strategy games like hoi4 and civ v. This game holds it's own against them.

Let me start by saying that this game has an insane amount of content, especially in the definitive edition that is now the default. You can play as England, France, the Holy Roman empire, Milan, and a bunch of others. It starts off in 1066, after the battle of Hastings.
I've begun playing on easy as England, and this game feels like Rome Total War from the sheer fun of the combat, and the scale is much increased. The general's speeches are really nice, and the combat is much improved over previous iterations. 

Sieges are also great, and it feels like I stand a chance against a much larger force. Arrows feel like they do a lot more damage now, but I may be misremembering other games. The fire arrows absolutely obliterate advancing forces- every unit has it's strength in this game, which is awesome.

I truly reocmmend you give it a go. I won't spoil any more content, because there are some cool surprises. Also, treat this game as you forging your own history rather than anything else. Makes it cooler.

A classic! 

Verdict: 9.5/10

Epic" doesn't quite begin to describe the scope and scale of the latest Total War game--there's a lot of strategic depth, with plenty of amazing combat to enjoy.
Like in most strategy games, your goal in Medieval 2 is to try to conquer the known world. And as a ruler of a medieval kingdom, this means you have to rely on knights, men-at-arms, archers, catapults, cannons, and everything else you'd expect out of a movie such as Braveheart or Kingdom of Heaven. That's not all, though; you also have a small array of agents to call upon. Diplomats can negotiate cease-fires (useful when you need some time to rebuild your strength) or alliances; princesses can shore up the loyalty of a general or a neighboring faction through marriage; spies can give you a peek at a fortified city's defenses; assassins can take out enemy agents. Then there are priests, but we'll get to that a bit later.

Since it's a Total War game, Medieval 2 sports two layers. The "big picture" is covered in the turn-based strategic layer, where you can examine a map of Europe and manage your empire. From here, you have command of all your settlements, armies, navies, and agents. You can also construct improvements to enhance the economy or allow you to build the latest in 15th-century military technology. For example, building paved roadways not only increases trade in a province, but it also helps speed along troop movement; improving farmland, furthermore, can help generate more food, and thus more gold.Medieval 2 introduces a few new twists to the established formula of the original game. Settlements come in two flavors now, towns and castles. Basically, towns and cities generate a lot more cash, but castles generate a wider variety of military units and are much harder to capture. It's an interesting idea, and it's not exactly a detriment to the experience that the supercities of the original game are no more, but this does add in a bit more micromanagement as you have to constantly shuttle troops and agents between various settlements. For instance, you might want to send depleted formations back to a castle where they can retrain and upgrade with the latest weapons and equipment.
All of this costs cash, of course, and it's safe to say that you'll be scrimping for every spare gold piece possible, especially early on in the game. The economic game has been bulked up a bit with the addition of merchants and resources. Basically, there are resources such as wheat and wine that are located on the map, and by enlisting a merchant and placing one on a resource, you can tap that resource for gold. However, one merchant can try and "buy out" another merchant sitting on a resource, so you'll be managing merchants while you're also busy maneuvering all the other pieces in the game.Campaigns will last even longer if you choose to fight out each battle in real time, and while you can usually skip over the minor skirmishes by letting the computer instantly generate the results, you'll most likely want to dive into the larger scrums--not only because you don't want to risk losing a major battle with roughly even odds due to a flip of the computer's coin, but because there are plenty of jaw-dropping moments in Medieval 2's combat. The "clone" armies of Rome: Total War are no more, and the brightly colored formations look incredibly detailed and varied. Best of all is that the combat animations are much more fleshed out. In a huge battle with thousands of warriors slamming into one another, you can easily pick up the individual duels going on as your men fight for their lives. You'll see guys getting knocked to the ground and struggling to get back up on their feet when their opponent delivers a finishing blow, as well as other cinematic moments. There are some weird anomalies, like when formations of men get jammed around a ladder, but the awesome spectacle of it all is glorious.Control over all these units is a bit nightmarish, but battles tend to have that effect on command and control, as all plans fall apart once contact with the enemy is made. You're rewarded for using tactics correctly, like not sending knights into the teeth of pikes and maneuvering them to hit the enemy from the flank or the rear. Or you keep your archers safely protected to the rear, where they can inflict the most damage on your enemy. All the decisions that you made during the strategic campaign finally pay off in battle, like the composition of your armies, the upgrades that you've equipped them with, and the generals that you chose to lead them in battle.You'll need a fairly powerful system, though, in order to appreciate the large-scale battles in all their grandeur without any frame rate hits. This is a demanding game, especially when there are thousands of warriors fighting onscreen at once. Our midrange system struggled to keep up, but on a high-end system the visuals were good enough that we could just sit back and soak it all in. And the campaign map looks beautiful, aided by the sense that you're not so much looking at a map but rather at a 3D representation of a living, breathing world. Tiny ships ply the trade routes between cities, caravans haul goods on the road network, and much more. The visuals are also aided by the addition of cool cinematic movies that show the results of various actions, like assassination attempts gone comically awry, royal weddings, and papal elections. Medieval 2 also has excellent audio. The music ranges from pleasing and subtle throughout the campaign map to bombastic and pompous during battle, though the musical cue that we liked the most was the haunting defeat chorus after losing a battle. There's plenty of voice work, too, as most emissaries will talk to you in appropriately accented English depending on their nationality. The prebattle speeches given by your generals are both rousing (in a Shakespearean way) and tactically sound, and you can glean important hints about the upcoming fight.Aside from the single-player campaign, there are a few extra modes in Medieval 2. A single-player skirmish mode lets you create custom battles, so you can pit the Mongols against the Aztecs, for instance, while there are seven historical battles that revisit great moments in world history, such as Agincourt, where Henry V overcame all odds and crushed the French. The multiplayer portion of the game is restricted to battles. Indeed, given the scope and scale of the single-player campaign, we imagine that resolving a multiplayer game would be all but impossible save for the most dedicated of players. Yet one day we'd like to see some kind of small-scale multiplayer campaign that lets you use all those strategic assets against other players. Multiplayer itself features only two modes, last man standing and scored resolution, but the basic idea remains the same in that you want to kill as many of the other guys as possible. Battles support up to eight players, so you can really get a big scrum going on, but the meat of the game is certainly in the single-player campaign.n our version of the Hundred Years' War, England was well on its way to spanking France in record time when those dastardly Danes betrayed our alliance and ruined the fun. About 150 turns later, we found ourselves bogged down in a three-front war against France, Denmark, and a late-to-the-party Spain, though at least those tenacious Scots were finally put down after a lengthy, hard-fought campaign in the north. Still, armies and navies were committed to battle as quickly as they were raised; spies, assassins, priests, diplomats, and merchants scrambled around the map and did their thing; sieges were laid and cities sacked; and battle followed bloody battle. And this is the "short" campaign in Medieval 2: Total War. In a nutshell, that summarizes what is both awesome and somewhat daunting about the latest game in the popular Total War strategy series. With its huge scale, deep gameplay, and beautiful graphics.

Medieval II : Total War is a very good game, buy it during sale, it only cost 9.99$ for hundreds of hours enjoying killing thousands of peoples for one  reason : "Fire and Blood".
Overall an excelent combination between a turn-based strategy game and RTS.

While it can at times get repetitive due to the basic mechanics of M2TW, this is perhaps one of the most unique Total Wars I've played. Basically the last total war to use engine 2 which is less buggier and more creative looking than its successor. No 1v1's that require a "kill move" to fight, units don't look like they're moving like plastic figures, units change their look with every armor upgrade, the challenges that you face in vanilla. We honestly don't this much realism and immersive experience in most of the recent total wars. Not to mention this game doesn't bombard you with overpriced and not well done DLC like Rome 2 and the Warhammers

In addition, there are so many fun overhaul mods you can add on to the game that can improve the experience. Honestly those make up most of the hours I have in comparison to the Vanilla and Kingdoms campaigns. Examples include Third Age, Hyrule, Elder Scrolls, Stainless Steel, Thera, and Planetary.

I will say that the amount of battles and dedication required to finish a campaign is something that's really challenging since it can get boring overtime, but just either play another faction or another campaign/overhaul campaign. It's kept me playing for years and still remains one of my favorite Total Wars
