After all these years, Medieval 2 Total War remains my favorite Total War game (I have played everything up to Rome 2, nothing newer than that). It used to be 2 separate games in the library (regular and Kingdoms) and I believe that some of my time in game wasn't carried over when they merged them, so I am confident I have a few hundred more hours than my profile suggests.

Medieval 2 falls in just the right middle ground of simplicity and potential. It hasn't been streamlined in many of the ways newer Total War games have, and far from suffer from that, I believe it is stronger because of it. The city management, and campaign map aspects of the game just feel right to me. Both Simple on the surface, but also hiding a satisfying amount of depth. And because of the nature of the game, it is EXTREMELY mod friendly.

Although I have certainly played all the campaigns that come with the game, most several times over, the vast majority of my playtime is in the form of overhaul mods (mods that completely overhaul the game experience in one way or another). 100+ hours were in the form of Lord of the Rings overhaul mods, that turned the game into a turn-based/real-time strategy game set in the world of Middle Earth. I have also played multiple mods which simply update and improve the base gameplay, allowing you to play familiar campaigns, but with much more complexity than the regular game can provide. At the moment of writing, I am 50 hours into a Warhammer Fantasy overhaul mod, and loving it.

The game is by no means perfect. Most of the flaws are concentrated in the Real-time strategy portion of the game (battles). The largest flaw is probably the AI. Not only the AI of the enemy, but the AI that governs your own units. Sometimes it takes several attempts to get a unit to properly follow your movement order (although this mostly tends to only happen on city/castle walls). Certain AI interactions also don't work properly; case in point, if you put stakes up inside of a city/castle you are defending, the enemy AI doesn't properly recognize them, and will happily run their cavalry straight through them, causing mass casualties (the issue doesn't really appear on open battlefields though). It is pretty safe to say that most of the biggest flaws seem to occur in the siege portion of the RTS gameplay, where-as open battles seem to work much better. The AI controlling enemy factions on the campaign map can also at times make odd decisions, but it is much less impactful overall (and if you play on the hardest difficulties, you will be thankful for enemy mistakes, not critical of them) 

Obviously this game isn't new, and its age can show at times, but newer isn't always better and I believe Medieval 2 is a great example of this. If you enjoy turn based strategy and real-time strategy, chances are you will enjoy this game too. I certainly will never regret buying it all those years ago.

Relative to other TW titles, Medieval II can sometimes feel quite easy. The reasoning for this is that the AI seldom (if at all; I forget how it behaves on VH/VH) ever cheats, by giving itself free money or troops. For that reason, well into the lategame, you'll tend to face rather low-tier units even against your best-upgraded top-tier armies. In addition, in singleplayer at least, the AI is quite susceptible to battle tactics based around artillery, and strategically speaking, it's quite easy to bully via the diplomacy options. This aside, the game is quite well-crafted, and most of its mechanics stand the test of time quite nicely (I, for one, am a fan of having separate building chains for castles and cities, complete with all the units available in either based on the time period). It's home to some of the more enjoyable campaigns I've played in a TW game (Ireland in Britannia, Byzantium in vanilla and Crusades, Novgorod in Teutonic, and New Spain in Americas), and a title worth picking up even today.

Well, here's a quick summary of the game!

1: It's obviously similar to many games made by Creative Assembly.

10/10 would play again. Apart from this game will take over your life if you're not careful, like " I'll just take this city and destroy this army" 4 hours and many more battles later and you're in full blown emperor mode and then spend the whole weekend conquering the medieval map. 

Battle mechanics and control aren't exactly ideal if you have a large army but for the vast majority of sieges and medieval engagements the system is excellent. Holes show up more in pvp but I'm sure if you took the time reading some guides it's not too large a jump to using hotkeys etc. 

But let's not veer too far off course...The campaign, and it's associated power trip, make up the majority of this game and it's amazing. The start is spent mostly building your economies, allies and killing rebels. Most of your middle campaign will be dying from the plague and watching your allegiances burn as one/two problem nations (not to name names but it's always got something to do with the Milanese - just sayin'). Late game is "Oh no, the Mongols", quickly followed by "Oh no, the Timurids" and then you take the last settlement and there is no more outcry because everyone loves you (lest they openly show their distaste and get assassinated). 

On that point, assassin/spy/general espionage mechanics are a right laugh and if you really want to, you can use these to simply make cities riot to the point your opposing faction gets kicked out. Likewise, the religion mechanic is also pretty cool. It's less cool if you upset the Pope early game and get multiple crusades called open you. Buuuuut, it is super cool when you control the college of cardinals and effectively get given carte blanche to crusade most of the Middle East and Africa (which you'll probably want to do anyway) and get a load of free bonuses. Conversely if your campaign starts in the Islamic East/Africa the Caliphate can be equally rewarding. You're still going to get crusaded and the plague though so don't think you're avoiding that by starting outside of Europe. 

Graphics still hold up for the most part and the soundtrack is, although not overly memorable, certainly immersive and helps suck you in to a half day play through pretty quickly. There is plenty more I could cover but ain't nobody got time for that. Worth a buy but not like super pressing if you value your life outside of medieval murder sims. You're best just picking it up when it's next on sale and having an absolute whale of a time. It's a classic.

Based on the systems of Rome: Total War, Medieval II has all the charm of that game but with a more polished feel and simulation. There is really no reason not to get this game if you are into strategy games but don't necessary need something as complex as a Paradox game.

The game takes place over the course of the entire Medieval Era/Renaissance, but in a way that is compact and manageable in terms of depth vs. breadth in the main campaign. There are smaller campaigns that focus more on the Americas or the Crusades, but these aspects are also represented in the main game.

There are still a lot of quirks with this game that had not been ironed out from Rome. Even at higher difficulties, it is quite easy to roll across the map, the only possible challenges being the addition of the Mongols and Timurids, which spawn giant hordes of units and lay waste across the eastern part of the map. Once you learn to deal with the AI of these factions, they are not difficult to defeat even though they seem ominous at first. 

If I had to rank Total War games in terms of the experience they provide, I would probably place this one close to the top. It may not be as sophisticated or good looking as the newer games, but it has its own charm that balances how easy it can be. Unlike the newer games, which make your units look like greyish brown shapes shooting neon white lines at other greyish brown shapes, this game has a more colorful style that makes the battles seem more epic, even if it is not entirely realistic.

I highly recommend checking out this game if you've never played a Total War game, or if you've only played the newer titles. I wish CA would make a Medieval III that followed closely with the way this game operates but with the depth that Rome II eventually got.

Never thought I'd change my mind on this game but I can't believe what I'm seeing here. I reinstalled the game to play with a friend. I know my steam hours may be deceptive but I've owned this game for almost a decade now. It was one of the big things that ignited my initial love of the Medieval era. My historical field of study has changed but my love for what this game was never did. I spent six years doing a world domination campaign as the Holy Roman Empire in the Stainless Steel mod. Even before that I poured thousands of hours into the vanilla game and its original expansion long before I knew about the modding community. So when I tell you something is different you can't tell me it isn't. I have an old hard-drive lying around from an old computer that hasn't been hooked up to the internet in a few years that has the original copy of the game. So CA can either admit they changed the game or people like me will put the code side-by-side and show that you changed it.

Side note, people getting mad about Kushites and other factions having female generals are being ridiculous. Most of the factions I've heard about do have confirmed historical female generals or warriors, especially the Kushites. Why do people even play the broken mess that is Rome 2, anyway? I hated that game long before they added that in. I don't really care, frankly.

Ballistics are now totally wrong in the base game and it even shows through in mods as well. I've been play-testing several today and range values are different, damages levels are different, and even the AI in battles behaves differently. Diplomacy has been changed so now you can hamfist multiple deals in one diplomacy sitting, taking out all the depth behind each diplomatic interaction every turn and even making it so I can exploit an AI for tribute even on VH/VH. Tons of new features and titles are now in the game that were not there before. Even new bugs have appeared with trade and path-finding! It's utterly absurd and I'm glad I finished my final magnum opus campaign before any of this stuff started.

I didn't buy the new titles because I didn't want them or their problems. Now you're forcing me to accept changes through Steam? What else are you gonna do, CA? This is even worse than what I thought CA would do to mods when they got their hands on a license and wanted 0 competition.

The gaming industry has become one of the most dishonest, backhanded, abrasive, shifty/shady branches of entertainment in the world home to some of the most untrustworthy companies on the planet - considering the kind of stuff we've seen over the last few decades, that is really saying something. I've spent my fair share of time in board rooms and in some of the less reputable ways to make a living and I've seen some stuff that just blows my mind in terms of how greedy and arrogant people can be. But the gaming industry? Updating older titles or outright breaking them to make people buy newer games to get their fix? That's a new low.

This is a great game and personally my favorite game in the Total War series. There's tons of singleplayer content: grand campaign, historical battles, random battles, and the best of all, custom battles, where you can set up any battle you want and play the AI, which is actually not bad. There's even more content if you get into modding. They've got great conversion mods for stuff like Lord Of The Rings, Skyrim, Game Of Thrones, Historical, and more. Good fun to play with your friends too, although beware of heavy cav... And if you don't have any friends who play Med 2, fear not! People still play this online and you should have little trouble finding someone to play with. Basically, if you really like medieval stuff you should check this game out. Plus, they packaged it with all the DLCs recently so that's a huge bonus cuz there also good!

I can play Medieval II on maximum graphical settings with an Intel Pentium(R) 2.8GHz, 4GB RAM with absolutely no performance issues at all. This game is a great classic; it's my first Steam game and Total War game, so I'm a bit biased.

By the numbers:  

Wanted to post a short friendly review for quite some time.

1.  Perhaps the best TW for battles  - including Castle/City defense & assault.  TW games, After MTW II, - include No cities, only small forts to be assaulted.  There exist no population to consider, or exterminate.  A world without people.  Just like computer gaming.  Exception is RTW II - the worst TW, has 'cities' where you cannot build walls, (1 in 3 has walls, and not good walls).  It is pathetic in so many ways!  Not worth further commenting on.

2.  As with ALLLL TWs - NO DIPLOMACY!!!  If they border you, regardless of their weakness, they will Attack!!!

3.  Best artwork & depictions, and landscapes - mountains you can actually fight on.

4.  AI cannot Bridge defend, or attack (in any of the TWs).  Some most important battles in history were fought over - near Bridges, and river fjords.

5.  Vewwwy Important!!!  MTW II was never improved on (by the developers).  Left as half a game.

Conclusion:

1.  Toooo EEEASY!!!!  

2.  Longbows rule.  STAKES!!!  Never seen AI use stakes, bridge defenses.

3.  Best looking,  Did I mention - toooo easy?

4.  Don't mention MODS!  They cannot rescue an unfinished, or poorly programmed game.  *Could JFK save the independence & sovereignty of the USA?  He tried.

5.  MTW II - nice to look at.  Great Castles & Cities.  Step up from RTW artwork/programming.  As with all TWs, NO functional AI.  AI functions at level of American Congress/ & rest of Gov't. (& most every other Gov't).  Apologies for the political comments.  Just ignore them.

I PLAY:

1.  Ultimate General CW,  - with faults, takes real time War simulation to a higher level.

2.  & the Extended Greek Mod for RTW.  RTW - the first, was the best TW effort (obviously my opinion).

The XGM Mod adds some Culture flavor, & expands the Game MAP, and adds more civilizations to the mix.  It cannot Save RTW, but it helps it greatly.  I enjoy flattening the Romans with the Greeks, & Unifying Italy with the Romans.  Still, if they border on you, they will attack!  There is some tacky difficulty added by XGM, & a control that allows you to control the Diplomacy (a bit).

God Bless!

This game sits as my most played game on steam and that doesn't even include the number of hours I spent playing my CD version which are thousands more. This game defined my childhood alongside wc3 and is considered the best total war by both myself and a large number people in the community for a multitude of reasons. 

TLDR: Crusades, merchants, you can assassinate the pope, more crusades, more merchants and you can also assassinate the pope (trust me the pope in this is not a friendly pope)

PROS: 
-Crusades
-Merchants
-You can assassinate the pope
-The graphics are a huge step up from the titles beforehand(Rome is kinda arguable) and haven't aged too badly
-Stainless steel, LOTR, Warhammer and a number of other mods though the base game is still fantastic
-Huge battle map with plenty of room to run down infidels, varied terrains, weather, night and day, and huge cities and fortresses to fight in with designs that can make major strategical differences
-Huge campaign map which is also gorgeous
-AI don't really cheat to make up for lack of skill like later total wars
-Way more build options for cities and castles rather than just some build slots like later installments
-longest historical period covered
-you can get your generals through marriage, adoptions, birth, or leaderless army with a lone captain being a bad*** on the field and getting promoted 
-solid number of factions to choose from

Cons
-who care but I guess I'll name them
-the AI is dumb, they can be cheesed like no ones business because they don't get 10 doom stacks from having one settlement (except for the mongolia and timurid appearance but who picks egypt, russia or the turks anyway) like later installments along with buffs that turn their peasant degenerates into elite units
-Christian factions don't take kindly to Islamic factions moving into Europe, everyone including the pope will declare war on you but they will do that eventually anyway
-the pope will excommunicate you and then declare war on you unless you play as an islamic faction at which point he will just declare war on you
-could be more crusades
-could be more merchants

I'm not the most experienced with Grand Strategy-esque games, but I felt the need for a review based on a lot of criticisms I've seen of the game. I'm also not particularly experienced with effectively summarizing reviews for games and my reviews easily get way too lengthy, but I'll at least say the following.

A lot of players complain about diplomacy, but the only issue I've had are AI diplomat characters going through the animation as if they're going to address you, but it only ever goes through a portion of the time. It's as if the faction is indecisive as to whether or not it wants to declare war on you, strike up relations, etc. but is willing to spam the diplomat on a single settlement repeatedly.

Diplomacy itself, in my opinion, isn't actually broken. Deals, relations, etc. need to be struck up very early and typically not with your expansionist neighbors that are obviously going to betray the alliance at the first opportunity they get. Factions have reputations for a reason- not every faction is meant to be reliable or chivalrous, as not all leaders in the real world are either. It's just another part of the game you need to plan out unless you want to pointlessly frustrate yourself about the game "ganging up" on you like a lot of critics seem to mention.

Good game- just wish the multiplayer included the campaign. Wouldn't care if my friends and I had to repeatedly save and pick the campaign back up from where we left off- it'd be more fun that just the battle scenarios. Also, the automatic resolutions for the battle scenarios in campaigns (as opposed to manually controlling the units in the battle) can be a bit strange. Often had the ratio of power WELL in my favor only to leave me with a stunningly large defeat and very few units left over. Usually forces me to fight manual battles even if I'm not in the mood for them.

Update: 
I have played Shogun 2, another great total war game. There are a lot of things to love about Medieval 2, and in many ways I prefer this game (modded) to Shogun 2, especially in its battles (which is a lot less rock-paper-scissors, with more unit variety too). People love this game and its old engine for a reason. 

All that being said, it's an old game, and it shows. People who've played this game in the past are probably used to it, but if you haven't played it, it's probably more difficult to get into. Bad pathfinding, units getting stuck in awkward melee because one guy is left behind, the simpler campaign map, etc. It also may not work perfectly with modern engines, and you'll have some crashes.

It is still damn fun, so if you're willing to take some risk, buy it when it's on sale and see if you like it. If you do, you'll have quite a number of mods to choose from, and some of them are still being updated to this day.

A Total Classic

A disclaimer before I get to the actual review: I am reviewing Medieval II: Total War NOT Total War: Medieval II - Definitive Edition. This game is nothing more than a cash grab, a definitive edition that changes nothing, fixes nothing and runs terribly on high end computers. What's more, before this "definitive edition" came out, you could buy Medieval II + Kingdoms for 20 $ total as opposed to 25 $ this garbage cost. So in general: Screw you Sega, I hope you choke on that money.

Now to the review of the actual game. I've spend hundreds of hours playing Medieval II back when steam meant water vapor not the biggest digital storefront. I bought this primarily to leave a positive review. It is in my opinion the best TW game. I love the setting, I love how each faction is different and plays differently, I love the cavalry charges and longbowmen laying waste to approaching infantry. 

This is a game made in much better time, when you unlocked new factions by playing the game not by buying them (shame on you CA and Sega). It's a game that, when you've spend 1/3 of original price on the expansion you got FOUR new campaigns with multiple unique races, not one race added to already existing map with four "unique" starting points (who are you trying to fool CA - they all play almost the same).  This is a game where you besieged actual cities and not Helm's deep every freaking time. This is a game where nothing was carved out to sell it as a day one DLC.  This is a damn near perfect strategy game, 

Don't get me wrong, I'm not saying I didn't enjoy later games in TW series, but Medieval II is the game I return to when I want to remind myself what this series once was - a game made with passion and not to stuff the wallets of Sega execs. If you never played TW or only played later installments I highly recommend this game. The graphics look dated but are still pleasant to look upon, especially during battles. Last time I installed this game, I started playing 8 pm and few minutes later it was suddenly 2.30 am. Had this "definitive edition" worked better, same would've probably happen this time.

For those complaining or worrying about the compatibility of this game with Windows 10, when the game downloads fully then go to your steam library>Search for the game>Right click it and then chose the bottom option of properties>Select the third tab next to updates which should say "local files">Select the top option of "browse local files">Within those files should be the icon and game name>Right click it and go to properties>on the second option next to "General" should be "compatibility">Within this, check the box that should be empty and chose the compatibility to be Windows XP SP3>Then select "apply/ok" at the bottom right. Doing this should make the game run really well, with no problems at all. I hope this helped!

One of the greatest, and IMO, the greatest Total War game to date.
I spent thousands of hours on the CD-ROM version of the game only to have to download it again on my MAC.

Fight for the Crusades for the glory of christendom, fight to preserve Byzantium and the true descendants of the Roman Empire, fight for Islam and Holy Caliphate and spread the word of Allah, or become Russia and just fight to have loads and loads of empty space, with barely any resources.

The main campaign has an amazing map, with beautiful detail that is still accessible to everyone - system mechanics work really well and the campaign doesn't get too deep into politics and the awkward building of selected buildings which i found later TW games to have.

The Crusade, Jihad and mission system works great and there is truly nothing quite like murdering your way to the top of the Papacy.

The Kingdoms expansion is the best total war expansion giving you 4 additional campaigns - Britannia and Crusades are incredible, and are worth about 100 hours each on their own.

 If you haven't played this game, i'd honestly say it's worth the 20 price tag, but even better if you wait for the price to drop on sale.

[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review [/h1]

Total War: MEDIEVAL II is a game developed by The Creative Assembly and published by SEGA, it is the sequel to MEDIEVAL: Total War and forms part of the Total War series

The game offers some pleasant graphics and really vibrant colours, although some ugly glitches here and there, it is pleasant all the same

The game does suffer with some repetitiveness at certain areas of the game but a fun game nonetheless

Total War: MEDIEVAL II overall, however, is a fun game to play, yet sometimes flawed, but is a great grand strategy game to play in short bursts!

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

Out of all the Total War games I've played, this is the one I've had the most fun with.

Every faction has a unique playstyle which gives this game extrodinary replayability, both in who you play and whom you wind up fighting.  The music is fantastic and vary's from faction to faction and region to region, which makes the whole world come alive and feel organic.  And every part of the overworld map has been been turned into a unique battle map, meaning there are litterally hundreds of different battle maps you can fight on.  A tall mountain range, a dense forest, a open plain, or behind the walls of your city, choosing your battlefield is very much important in this game.

The game of course is not flawless.  Increasing the difficulty of the game mostly just means that the AI is more agressive and will pick a fight with you more often.  On top of that, when storming a city or a castle, the AI will rarely rely on a strategy beyond "amass or entire army to one side of the city and try to pour through" which can be stupid easy to counter when you know what you're doing.  On top of that, naval combat litterally does not exist beyond auto-resolve.  However in all fairness, with how massive the map selection and unit choice for land is in this game, it can be forgiven for skimping on this aspect.

Overall though I feel this is by far one of, if not THE best Total War games out there, although I know it won't be for everyone.  The graphics are thirteen years old as of this writing plus the lack of naval combat and the highly predictable siege battles will be turn offs for some people.  But the breathtaking amount of different troops to play with, the meticulous eye for historical detail, and near infinite replayabilty makes it more than worth it.

So in short, if you like immersive historical strategy games with a wide range of possible play styles for you to choose from, I'd say give this game a try.  If old games with old graphics and no story (other than what you create) plus hyper agressive AI turns you off, then I'd give this game a pass.

Still my favorite Total War game, having logged hundreds of hours in Steam and probably another 500 hours off steam since it's original release, plus the various mods like Stainless Steel and the Middle Earth mod. If you want the definitive Total War experience Medieval 2 is it. Unlike current Total War games, Medieval 2's gameplay mechanics is extremely complex. From maintaining merchants and diplomats to army management (Example: Maintaining multiple army stacks, totaling 40,000+). Medieval 2 plays more like an empire building simulator.

Battles feel much heavier as units tend to react slower and more realistically to commands. The sense of weight makes battles feel much more organic than Shogun 2, Rome 2 or even Fantasy Warhammer.  

If you do choose to buy this game, be sure to install the mod: Stainless Steel. The mod provides a robust campaign, adding more historical cities for each faction.

Total War: Medieval II is without a doubt a strategic classic. A delightfully engrossing game based around waging war across Europe, North Africa and the Middle East, spanning the period of 1087A.D to 1453A.D. Medieval II does an excellent job of creating intense scenarios which will either show one to be a strategic genius or be crushed by their enemies. After all these years the graphics still hold up, mostly. Obviously this Total War doesn't look as good as some of the later games, but its great use of colour to contrast different areas of the game like the highlands of Scotland to the Rolling dunes of the middle-east in addition to all the colours of medieval troops. Total War: Medieval II is well worth its price tag what that should be.

Total war : Medieval II is quite an old game, and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone who only wants to play with the modern-day graphic possibilities. Having said that, this game is a true masterpiece with a great (and alive) modding community. The base game itself focusses mainly on the high and late medieval era, and has plenty of historical events integrated, which will influence your empire like they have in reality, adding the possibility to roleplay as well. (E.G: Mongol invasion, Black death). 

Although a bit glitchy sometimes as well as a vast amount of exploits available to the player, this game definetely holds up in the modern day gaming environment. The replayability of the game is also good, because the AI randomizes their actions everytime you start a campaign, ensuring that every campaign will forge a new experience. The game also hosts many major mods, and hundreds of minor mods to add to the experience.

Concluding; This game has been a great experience, and if you love strategy games and the medieval time period this game is the way to go.

total war medieval 2 is an amazing game with a lot of depth and replayability but dont let that fool you as the game still has many flaws. let me get the pros out of the way. The game has two different parts, real time battles and a turn based overview campaign map. The battles are a blast and are pretty enthralling as you deploy many different strategies and the tides of battle can be turned around at any moment as soldiers can get scared and rout the army.an army losing 1:10 can catch the enemy by suprise with a stray unit and kill the enemies general which can cause a chain rout on the enemy side. artillery can even be used to launch the carcasses of rotting cows which can rout enemies. There are two different battle types: Normal field battles, and sieges where one force has to defend a city or castle. from the other. Field battles are just battles between two to 6 armies on an open plain which can occur anywhere on the campaign map and each location is a different scene. these are fun battles to have as there is a lot of space for you to use your army and deploy various strategies. siege battles on the other hand are much more linear and require more skill and knowledge to win. Artillery can knock down walls or they can be scaled with ladders and siege towers. In multiplayer siege battles require so much teamwork and communication in 2v2 situations. All of this leads to a very diverse and replayable experience which fun every time. The campaign side of things is also very fun, you have to balance your countries economy, armies and relation with the pope (if your a Catholic country) and other countries. You have to control cities, by building new structures  to keep the population happy and under control, to increase trade or to be able to train a more diverse tree of units for your armies. if you cant keep the population of a city or castle under control  the city can revolt and overthrow the governers and your control of the city. You also have to keep your generals, governers and family happy so they dont betray you and give a location or army to another faction and join the other faction.  the main goal is to gain as many territories as possible (45 to win the game) and for some countries a certain territory. For catholic countries you have to conqueor jerusalem. This is an enthralling experience in its own and is massively replayable as there are many different play styles and countries to choose from. Now lets get on to the cons. The ai in this game is massively outdated and can be easily exploited with calvalry which can detract from the experience during battles. Another thing that is terrible is the diplomacy system. Your country is almost always untrustworthy for no fault of your own and diplomats are near useless as every proposal you make is 99% of the time turned down. Its actually retarded. Alliances are pointless as the faction you are allied with will end up attacking you nonetheless and you will always end up getting gangbanged by every country in the late game. This makes every campaign feel the same as you are just repelling attackers constantly and attqacking other countries and not much else. It would be nice to ask allied countries to assist you in a war against another country and for them to accompany your army or something. Another thing thats dumb is merchants. they are fucking useless. All in all the game is great and i reccomend.

My first total war game and still perhaps my absolute favorite. The game is extremly simple and the factios are brilliantly balanced. Each faction has unique troops and buildings that add flavor to the game. Unlike other later Total War games all factions are portentially playable. You get rewarded for defeating certain factions entirly, you get to play as that faction. When you win the grand campaign all factions are avaliable to you. I love this feature as it allows for nearly endless replayablity. Not only this but the DLC campaigns are stellar. New factions and units that each have the same level of depth as base game factions. 

To add to the general stratagy the game allows for far more strategic depth than newer games. Newer total war games you are limited to very small numbers of armies. In this game however you can deploy as many armies as you have units (each unit can be an "army". This allows you to strategically place troops around to control mountain passes and briges. These armies may become rebel armies if you are not careful so it adds great depth and interesting mechanics. An even better feature that makes this game far superior is the ability to retreat and lose a battle and not have the entire army be whiped out. Modern Total War games cause you to lose your entire army if you retreat and lose a battle, or lose two in a single turn. This means if an ene,y faction beats one of your limited armies you can not recover for quite some time. In this game your armies remain in tact, all be it heavily depleated. This means you can consolidate troops in different locations, forcing you to decide between taking time to retrain your expereinced but weakened units, or just make new ones. 

Get this game. You will not regret it. It is superior to newer total war games in every way.

They have altered the price of the Definitive Edition to be more costly than the old base game + expansion bundle they used to have. It is a price hike masquerading as a gift to the consumer. 

As for the game itself, it is a decent representation of its genre, but it does not overcome its genre's flaws. The flaws mainly have to do with the AI, which is utterly incapable of putting up a fight. This is a single-player game mainly, and the AI is so bad that single player is not a challenge even on the hardest difficulty. A singleplayer campaign is a slog through successive 
fights with AI armies which eat up your time without offering the possibility of defeat. Familiarizing myself with all of the units and mechanics, and witnessing the novelty of mass battles occurring between pixelated miniatures was of mild interest to me. It furnished the early period of my experience with a degree of entertainment sufficient to keep me playing. But eventually the novelty wore off and I was left playing a brokenly easy game with little to no entertainment value. I would not consider it a poor purchase, for the original, cheap price I got it for (5$ Canadian, which is about $4 USD), but it's certainly no gem of a game. It's certainly no masterpiece. It is mediocre.

One of my most treasured moments in my gaming life was my first victory against a larger foe in Medieval: Total War 2. This was because at that time, I thought the game was a realistic simulation of how battles were fought in history. Only after several hours of playing did I realise that the AI had only a few tactics and that you can learn to take advantage of it's dead spots to win outrageous victories, kindof like a Medieval type of circle-strafing. 
Sometimes, though, the AI does it's job and you can have an interesting battle but you have to wait a long time for these to happen. The campaign map is boring and slow, and relies a lot on luck. When you use agents (like assasins or spies) you get lovely cut-scenes that make up a lot. Wonderful! 
The Mongol and Timurid invastions are enormously exciting but they only involve you if you play as an eastern empire. In the west, you might instead go on to invade America but this only takes place at the very end of the campaign and by this time you might already have finished the game, for sure if you play the short game. The long campaign has the trouble of being to easy after the watershed moment halfway through, when you have managed to become the largest empire in you part of the map. The AI players are usually pretty even-keeled so none of them will match your army size. The game becomes too easy and boring at this point. You just want to capture enough castles by that time, a monotonous chore if the enemy will not be able to launch any siginificant counter offensives. 
Another big problem for this game is the prevalence of bugs, especially because they can decide the outcome of battles in a frustratingly unfair way. For example, in mountainous area's, the enemy bowmen may appear on top of an unclimbable rock. They pick off some of your men and you can't approach them. The only thing you can do is give up and the game kills a number of your men as a punishment. Crummy! The other bug that pops up often is the sleepy attacker. It happened a lot when I was defending my cities against the mongols. I managed to knock out their catapults and as a consequence, the Mongol hordes just stood there shouting at me. This gave me two choices, attack them head on (and be killed) or quit the battle (and be killed). Maybe this is how the Mongols were able to conquer the largest land empire in the world?

Anyway, this is just a series of negative points. But you criticize what you love, isn't it? I believe this could have been the best strategy game ever if some of the above points weren't there. 
Definitily play this game until you've defeated a stronger foe in a huge battle. Feel like El Cid or Suleiman and image you celebrate with huge casks of wine (or shisha pipes) with your men afterwards.

This game really stands the test of time. Its old, looks old but the gameplay is still fun its better then the newer historical game in terns of depth but not as deep as crusader king II however but is more freindly to new comer to the these types of games, plus this game has live battles you can fight making for some epic moments.

Story time: I had married my princess to get a epic general with amazing trait that gave his army high moral and himself a high HP pool. however he wasn't able to return to my kingdom because he couldn't move for the first turn and he was just in range of a enemy army.
So i hastle recruited a few mercernary knights and spearmen. I was really scared for losing him and the princess I used to get him first of his line. This man would one day become the King of France.

Right as I expected the enemy force attacked me and I couldn't withdraw and I hadn't saved either. I thought to myself if he is going to die I'll give it all I got.
The enemy out numberd me by 10/1 first thing I did was let the enemy come closer and attack the few spears I had while the cavalry was hidding in the woods. I charged the crossbows units because my frontline had already broken. The enemy cavalry charged and so did I however they didn't stand a chance against my elite bodyguard and with some flank charges with my mercenery cav. However what was left was the enemy general with health stacks of heavy infantry running down my infantry. What happend after that me isolating a single unit and charging them from both sides however I soon lost all my cavalry due to some of them dying on the charge. With only 6 man left of my bodyguard and my general I charged the isolated general still with full hp.
The two generals where facing off mine was already wounded but that didn't stop him. The two generals exchanged blows 1 after the other anyone of these blows could mean the end but then, somehow, my general managed to strike his sword through his armor and droping the horse he was riding on killing him. With only him left now I retreited with the dead generals bodyguard running after me and then my general broke moral and fleed so he didn't die.

A few turns later he was back with a full stack to take his vengance.

-CONS-
AI is pretty bad and can be abused (Hasn't improved much in newer TW Games)
Some units are glitchy and dont work like intended. (Pikemen and Two-handed)
Mongols are annoying to fight and not as epic as hoped.
Seige battles vs AI isn't very good.
Diplomecy is very shallow.

-PROS-
Deep mechanics something that used to be normal in games back in the day.
Traits are fun to mess around with and creating a picture what your King/general would act like.
Easy to learn.
Historical battles are fun and creates unique a challages to overcome.
Can be moded (Strainless Steel, Lord of the Rings).
Sound track is great and fits the situation greatly.

A game that has aged particularly well, looks amazing, still as playable as ever, but the AI in fights can be dopey at times. Grand campaign is brilliant, with in depth politics and diplomacy (not quite rivalling EU4), as well as the classic video events and other little bits that make the game more expansive. Campaign is long enough that it feels worthwhile to put many hours into it.

Brilliant live battles play out seamlessly with good controls, allowing you to control most aspects you would want to for your troops.

Would say anyone interested in total war or strategy games should give it atleast a try. If achievements were added there would be far more replay value for the campaign, but this game is 100% worth the price.

To improve, the game could have more in depth diplomacy as with EU4, better border changes rather than by whole province, and a city-building scheme like with CIV games.

The Crusades were a series of religious wars sanctioned by the Latin Church in the medieval period. The most commonly known Crusades are the campaigns in the Eastern Mediterranean aimed at recovering the Holy Land from Muslim rule, but the term "Crusades" is also applied to other church-sanctioned campaigns. These were fought for a variety of reasons including the suppression of paganism and heresy, the resolution of conflict among rival Roman Catholic groups, or for political and territorial advantage. At the time of the early Crusades the word did not exist, only becoming the leading descriptive term around 1760. 
In 1095, Pope Urban II called for the First Crusade in a sermon at the Council of Clermont. He encouraged military support for the Byzantine Empire and its Emperor, Alexios I, who needed reinforcements for his conflict with westward migrating Turks colonizing Anatolia. One of Urban's aims was to guarantee pilgrims access to the Eastern Mediterranean holy sites that were under Muslim control but scholars disagree as to whether this was the primary motive for Urban or those who heeded his call. Urban's strategy may have been to unite the Eastern and Western branches of Christendom, which had been divided since the EastWest Schism of 1054 and to establish himself as head of the unified Church. The initial success of the Crusade established the first four Crusader states in the Eastern Mediterranean: the County of Edessa, the Principality of Antioch, the Kingdom of Jerusalem and the County of Tripoli. The enthusiastic response to Urban's preaching from all classes in Western Europe established a precedent for other Crusades. Volunteers became Crusaders by taking a public vow and receiving plenary indulgences from the Church. Some were hoping for a mass ascension into heaven at Jerusalem or God's forgiveness for all their sins. Others participated to satisfy feudal obligations, obtain glory and honour or to seek economic and political gain. 
The two-century attempt to recover the Holy Land ended in failure. Following the First Crusade there were six major Crusades and numerous less significant ones. After the last Catholic outposts fell in 1291, there were no more Crusades; but the gains were longer lasting in Northern and Western Europe. The Wendish Crusade and those of the Archbishop of Bremen brought all the North-East Baltic and the tribes of Mecklenburg and Lusatia under Catholic control in the late 12th century. In the early 13th century the Teutonic Order created a Crusader state in Prussia and the French monarchy used the Albigensian Crusade to extend the kingdom to the Mediterranean Sea. The rise of the Ottoman Empire in the late 14th century prompted a Catholic response which led to further defeats at Nicopolis in 1396 and Varna in 1444. Catholic Europe was in chaos and the final pivot of ChristianIslamic relations was marked by two seismic events: the fall of Constantinople to the Ottomans in 1453 and a final conclusive victory for the Spanish over the Moors with the conquest of Granada in 1492. The idea of Crusading continued, not least in the form of the Knights Hospitaller, until the end of the 18th-century but the focus of Western European interest moved to the New World. 
Modern historians hold widely varying opinions of the Crusaders. To some, their conduct was incongruous with the stated aims and implied moral authority of the papacy, as evidenced by the fact that on occasion the Pope excommunicated Crusaders. Crusaders often pillaged as they travelled, and their leaders generally retained control of captured territory instead of returning it to the Byzantines. During the People's Crusade, thousands of Jews were murdered in what is now called the Rhineland massacres. Constantinople was sacked during the Fourth Crusade. However, the Crusades had a profound impact on Western civilisation: Italian city-states gained considerable concessions in return for assisting the Crusaders and established colonies which allowed trade with the eastern markets even in the Ottoman period, allowing Genoa and Venice to flourish; they consolidated the collective identity of the Latin Church under papal leadership; and they constituted a wellspring for accounts of heroism, chivalry, and piety that galvanised medieval romance, philosophy, and literature. The Crusades also reinforced a connection between Western Christendom, feudalism, and militarism.

TLDR: Great TW game and is still my go-to TW game over the newer ones. 

Before I lost my old account, I had another ~200 hours on that one. As far as world mechanics and strategy goes, this has always been my favorite TW. Still, I have a couple gripes that I'll lay out below. 

Pros:

- (Once all unlocked) huge, unique choices for nations spanning across all of Europe and West Africa. Russia is weirdly a full nation here, but other than that most are fairly accurate to their portrayal as far as positioning and power rankings goes. 

- Rewarding in-campaign progression, you feel your armies improve vastly with each unit upgrade. You also see the disipline of your soldiers who are ranked more with battle experience, they tend to stay and fight rather than run away

- The integration of the church is awesome. It's a ass kissing game for who can win the popes praise/favor. And when the Pope dies, a new one gets elected. If your nation is the most religous (has the most priests/catholics in your territory), you get the power to elect one of your own to become the next Pope. The most valuable part of this is that the Pope can biasly call for a Crusade against any nation that is at war with you. Note though, that the vice versa can happen if an enemy nation get's their guy elected as Pope. The Pope also hires Inquisitors that can execute enemy generals for heracy. 

-Siege battles are great, good mix of breaching options including rams, ladders, towers, balistas, catapults, trebuchets, and (very late period) cannons. Huge/max upgraded cities have 3 layers of walls for you to breach, and battles can get bloody and personal.



Mixed/Cons:

-Political system makes literally no sense *sometimes*. Multiple nations feelings towards you would go to "Abysmal" (the worst it can get) after they attacked you first and you beat them, as if somehow this was your fault. Diplomacy at this point is almost non-existant. When you offer a ceasefire to a nation that is clearly not going to win the war, the AI persists on continuing the conflict no matter what you offer. And I mean, NO MATTER WHAT. Example: I just completed a Holy Roman Empire campaign, and tried making peace with Hungary due simply to their pesky raids on one of my border towns. I've offered them 10k, 20k, 30k, 40k, + 1, 2 and even 3 settlements. As well as trade rights, map info etc. Then its just "firmly rejected". And I look at their power rankings and their military is weak and their economy is set to bankrupt. 

-Some generated maps can get really glitchy with large armies, where units won't go where you told them to, or just constantly run back and forth between 2 spots. This though, is rare and also forgivable being the scale of this game at the time it released.


All in all, great TW experience. Desparately waiting for a true Medieval 3 to come out instead of expansions like Britannia.

A marvelous sight and I still treasure the day I received a PC capable of playing this classic. This game deserves so much despite its scruff and aged graphics. Its features, mechanics and role-playing possibilities has earned itself an everlasting legacy of which can't be said for most games.

On to the review:

Best Total War game.

One of the best games in the Total War series, Medieval 2: Total War is all about conquering the map and hoping the pope doesn't excommunicate you, if you are playing a Catholic faction of course. There are plenty of factions to play with unique playstyles. I also used to play this game a lot when it was not on Steam, I can't tell how many hours I played this title. That's how much I like this game. There are very few annoying bugs and glitches in this game, but it is barely noticeable.

If you want to expand your playtime, I would recommend getting some of the mods that are finished for this game, like, Stainless Steel, Third Age: Total War. There are a lot more mods than this to play too, so try them out as well when you get the chance, you may like it.

That being said, I would definetly recommend this game if you like Strategy titles or into Total War games, which im sure you already got it ;)

9/10

It's okay.
No... It's great. One of the best strategy games I've played, actually.

The campaign side requires the player to make some strategic decisions - not many and not that difficult ones, but they do have consequences and, contrary to popular belief, it's possible to lose a campaign (because the AI cheats).
In battle, all units have a direct counter, so it's fairly balanced (Alternative view: cavalry, archers and pikemen are all severely overpowered. That would make most of the units in the game and they all counter each other). The military tactics you end up using tend to be surprisingly historically accurate, unless you exploit the AI, which is quite easy because the game is quite old.
The graphics are decent for a 15-year-old game, not so much now. It's also poorly optimised for modern systems, can only use 2 GB of your RAM and only a single core of your processor - not that much of an issue for the base game and its expansions, however...
This game is extremely moddable, there are many conversion mods, both historical and fantasy. I've spent far more time playing the mods than the base game. These mods tend to upgrade the graphics to the point that the game's poor optimisation can't handle it - some crashes are to be expected then.
The in-game music is well done and fits the atmosphere, both in laid back campaign sections and in action-intensive real time battles. The soundtrack might be worth listening on its own.

All in all, a good old game. I keep coming back to play it again and again.

M2TW remains among the best grand strategy historical games ever created. M1TW and Rome 1 are better in some ways, but M2TW is certainly there with them at the top of the genre. CA was still openly and eagerly assisting modding of their games at this time and the number of mods for M2TW and Rome 1 reflect this fact. CA made modding easy and the modding community over the years helped CA in return.

The above doesn't mean I'm a fan of CA now. See my review of Rome 2 for reference. After M2TW, the quality of the games and the accessibility for modders steadily declined. CA and its parent corporation Sega are different beasts now.  But don't let current practices distract you from the wonderful achievement of Medieval II: Total War and its predeccessors. They are enjoyable in vanilla form and get even better with the many mods available via sites like twcenter.net and others. Don't let those angry with the current state of Creative Assembly put you off trying some of the best games ever made for the PC.

Sit down ye children, and I will spin thee a tale.

The dawn of the Great Milanese Empire was a time rife with war, for there is not a moment of peace within the many centuries that the Milanese were ever at peace, that is, until the end. At first, it was with the disparate Italian states around it, held within the looming vassalage of the Kaiser of Holy Rome. Milan itself was much too influential to be held under the shackles of the Germans, and so they grew in power.

Sicily insulted the Milanese, taking an island that the former had already claimed. In the heat of the moment, the Grand Duke declared war, and quickly took Naples. After several months of intense battle, the Venetians marched onto Milan. The Grand Duke himself led the breakout, leaving only two survivors. Quickly after, Venice was marched upon, and utterly crushed. The populace of the great capital was purged. An act that the venetians have still never forgave. After which, Zagreb was also taken, the armies easily being driven out. The Pope was dissatisfied of the Milanese ways of warfare, and tension grew between the two states. One utterly dwarfing the world. In order to help such relations, the Grand Duke sailed in the Grand Crusade, taking Egypt for himself and God. Although temporary, it eased the tension on Italy.

Then, the world ground against Milan. War after war, slaughter after slaughter, the Milanese became a force that the world could not stop. The mongols were but a small stir in the east. Their grand, continental army but a dwarf to the Milanese crossbowmen and knights. The once powerful state of Holy Rome fell city after city, and the pope had no choice but to excommunicate Milan, only to find Rome under siege, and the next several popes to be put to the blade. Most of Italy was under the Milanese, a self proclaimed 'New Rome'. The southern french, the Occitan and those in Narbonne quickly fell to the blade. Holy Rome split into warring Duchies. Sicily is but a coalition of Islands with hardly any army. The Pope in Rome lies beyond the alps, far from the Peninsula.

Milan marches ever forward, every battle ending the same way. All but several men left, for the Italian empire slew the rest.

For a review purpose, there isn't much to add that hasn't been covered by other gamers here. For me, this is THE Total War game, having played this from 2006 onward. Its gameplay qualities are phenomenal for a strategy game (especially with the added features from the "Kingdoms" add-on) and graphics-wise still holds up to today's standards. With some tweaking and modding, this can easily be mistaken for a 2010 era game, especially with highest graphical setting.

My personal reason to like this game lies in its amazing convertability for different mods. I haven't touched the base game for years (since for my personal expectations it doesn't offer enough variation, it's a wonderful foundation though), the 2100+ hours record has all been spent playing total conversion mods that offer plethora of different campaigns, concepts etc.. These are the reason I return to this game every now and then, wasting hundreds of hours for epic battles, conquest and strategy.

I encourage you search and install any mods that suit your tastes, be it a small scale gameplay improvement mod or total conversion, the modding community of M2:TW will provide. My personal favorites (which I heartily recommend to you) include:

"Third Age Total War" (with "Divide and Conquer" submod) - Lord of the Rings themed conversion
"Stainless Steel" - improves the basis of the original platform, adding new factions, units and such. Unfortunately on hold indefinitely...
"Europa Barbarorum II" - following the original "Rome: Total War" submod, this changes the campaign setting to ancient Europe (ie. Roman era), aiming for historical accuracy. Better than "Rome 2", no question.

This is hands down my favourite game to date, truly sating my needs for strategic faction management and epic warfare. The Total War games that followed became more and more graphically pleasing, that's for sure, but unlike M2:TW they pushed for pointless limitations (restricting the number of buildings per province etc.) or stripped great features. For example, in M2:TW units have a limited pool each that takes a few turns to refresh, elite units doing so more slowly. Thus there is a need to mix peasant armies with elites (in a realistic fashion) until you once again have elites to recruit. Not so much in newer games where once you have access to elites you can just buy them infinitely, thus (unless you roleplay) as long as you have enough money, you can steamroll everything with max stacks of elite knights or whatnot, making lower grade units pointless. This is just one of the features of the game I love and if you ask me, should be implemented in future titles. 

There's so much more to say about this game, so much to love... but you get the idea. In short, the best Total War game, and personally the best strategy game I've yet to play. Highly recommended.

I consider this game one of the better Total War games. The setting is incredible. Europe, North Africa, and the Near East during the High Middle Ages and Early Modern Period provides a depth and variety that few of the other games ever accomplish, despite the limitations imposed by rather simple campaign mechanics. For example, there is not an independent tech tree and all technological advances are made through the building tree much like Rome: TW. Food is not an issue at a faction level as it is in later games and I think the setting would have been enhanced by more campaign level innovations such as a more nuanced and deeper faction quest and Papal quest system (the feudal system of this era could be better represented thus) and the various agents (priests, spies, assassins, and merchants) don't add much added depth as they were probably intended to and could have been better used. For exmaple, perhaps merchants could have been used to influence the politics of another faction.  In a way, the simplicity of the campaign game (moving armies, recruiting soldiers and agents, and building up settlements) keeps the focus on the real-time tactical battles which are excellent. The units are varied and set-piece and siege battles are truly challenging and fun. I personally enjoy the Early Modern era of the game when you begin fielding gunpowder armies. This forces you to change tactics to take advantage of the new units. The graphics are dated and the game definitely shows its age. I think a remaster by Creative Assembly would be a welcome and economical way to diversify their game portfolio for those who are tired of Ancient Rome, are turned off by the limited focus of Thrones of Britannia, and may not be interested in the upcoming Chinese setting of TW: Three Kingdoms. But despite this, the game is still highly playable and the tactical battles are still impressive, especially when watching your Gothic Knights charge with lances down against an isolated unit of Pavise Crossbowman. Buy on sale and enjoy!

All is quiet, 'til suddenly the black banners of the Holy Roman Empire, which now dominates Germany, France, Italy, Denmark, Poland, and the Low Countries, appear on the horizon.  Thousands of knights in heavy plate armor charge up a hill, to certain victory.  Then, arrows blacken the sky, and the Imperials are butchered like rats.  A handful of brave English knights charge downhill, rout the Imperial infantry, then a great counterattack crushes the greatest army in Europe.

20 years later, the heroic Englishmen who crushed the Holy Roman Empire are killed off by the Black Plague.

You will never experience this outside of Medieval II.

Medieval 2 Total war is one of my favorite games of all time, due to several factors that make this game great even without mods. It has truly stested time and has stayed alive even in multiplayer. This can be endless hours of fun and provide an immersive experience that combines titles like CK2 and Hegemony 3 into one game while simplifying the aspects of those games so that the game itself is easy to jump into.

The real thing that makes Total war itself shine is both the massive amount of playable nations and the era that this game resides in. The medieval ages are a dynamic period that has lots of challenging but well timed events like the mongol invasion and the black death, along with technological advances that can flip your plans on it's head if exploited. Every nation feels unique and has a particular feel. The French have awesome cavalry, while the English have great longbowmen and infantry. The germans have a well rounded and unique late game army, and the spaniards have the best navy, and all the units are different in design save for a few standard ones throught the western and eastern worlds.

The campaign feels dynamic and even thrilling at times, whether you fight to the death in your last citidel or lord over a massive and ever expanding empire, the game will not dissapoint. The AI are unpredictable and make bold choices, and wars feel like they matter both logistically and in reality.

The in game economy is complex, but also simple enough for new players to grasp. Trade can be a viable option, while farming and population growth brings more tax. You can reap the spoils of war booty as vikings or outclass foriegn merchants.

I also love how the muslim nations were not ignored, making them completely unique from europe and presenting them with a whole new slew of challenges; and prospective goals! Calling a Jihad never felt so satisfying.

The game as a whole is incredible, and even more so with mods. This is a must buy for fans of real time strategy.

Medieval II: Total War may be outdated, but remains to this day one of the greatest installments of the Franchise's history. This game was created by the early dev team at Creative Assembly, and while mods were not their primary focus, they also didn't go out of the way to make sure you couldn't make good ones. While today's modding community for Total War is essentially just reskins and unit stat sheets that mind you, do look fantastic; The mods from this era are complete overhauls of the base game. Some of the things done today in Warhammer, were ideas instilled into these developers a decade past during this game's existence by way of these mods. It is this game that put in place many of the core principals that make Total War games bearable today. If you want to see where it all started to come together, you came to the right place with Medieval II.

Red Shell
developer_response:
Red Shell is a program we previously used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising  its not spyware.

Its a marketing attribution tool that helps companies determine which of their adverts are most effective. It does this in a similar way to other analytics tools by using cookies to generate a unique token from device information, and comparing that with data taken from marketing campaigns and game activations. In this way, the companies that use it are able to see which adverts are more effective. You can find out more about Red Shell here: https://redshell.io/home

However, while Red Shell was only used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising, we saw that players were clearly concerned about it and that it would be difficult for us to entirely reassure everyone. As such, the implementation of Red Shell was removed from all Total War games that previously used it.

I got the product on sale along with the DLC for 4.74 and what i got was 100% worth the price even the full price. If you buy the complete DLC you get The regular Medieval II plus, Americas expansion,Teutonic War expansion (By far the coolest one) the Britania Expansion and the Crusades. If you ask me that is so much for such a low price even when not on sale. Each of those expansions have multiple factions which you can play a campaign with not to mention you can complete the campaign in short or long mode. Thats a Metric tone content and honestly easy 250+ hours maybe more if you do every faction on the longest campaign and that is only just the single player. The multiplayer is very much still alive and great if you get things like Skyrim mod packs. Now the Graphics for a 2006 game are actually really good. There is a lot of detail put into the soldier on the field and there is no lag even on a Potato PC yeah its not Thrones of Britania facial graphics but its very good. In comparrison to Total war Shogun 2 i feel like this is much more fun and has much more content than that game. As much as i love Shogun 2 this is much better and cheaper and runs on anything. Not to mention its only a few Gig in size.

I HEAR THAT TOTAL WARS HAVE REDSHELL SPYWARE!!!

[h1]DEUS VULT[/h1]

Medieval II Total War was the fourth installation of the Total War series and the sequel to the second installation, Medieval Total War. Riding on the coattails of the huge success that was Rome Total War, MIITW begins in the year 1080 A.D. and is a classic in video game history. It should be noted that my first Total War game was Rome and that I have never played either Shogun or Medieval Total War. With that said, let's get started.

[b]PROS[/b]

+ The campaign map was the largest in Total War history at the time in terms of pure land mass coverage, as they included the eastern coast of the Americas. As I understand, it is still now the fourth largest map by land mass coverage in Total War history behind Empire, Warhammer, and Warhammer II.

+ I believe it still maintains the second largest pool of playable factions (17) behind only Rome II (26). Only the Papal States, Mongols, Timurids, Aztecs, and Rebels are unplayable by default.

+ Offers an excellent selection of short movies throughout the campaign which add an extra level of immersion.

+ Personally my favorite with regards to agents. In addition to diplomats, spies, and assassins (which were available in RTW), religious agents make an appearance. As a Catholic, for instance, recruiting priests is a must in order to please the Pope and maintain religious order throughout your lands. Heretics and witches will sow heresy and must be burned at the stake, and success will improve that agent's ability and standing within the Vatican. Female agents play a vital role here, as princesses can engage in diplomacy and negotiate dynastic marriage alliances.

+ CRUSADES.

+ Home to some of the greatest mods in video game history, including a total overhaul mod called Third Age Total War (I'd recommend just on this fact). Also, back during the 2012 American Presidential race, someone made a mod where two armies consisting entirely of Barack Obama and Mitt Romney fight each other to the bitter, bloody end. It's fantastic.

+ Good news! Nearly all of what follows in the neutrals and cons can be modded-out or altered in the game files!

+ DEUS VULT.


[b]NEUTRALS[/b]

0 While there is a wide range of units from different cultures, most factions have access to the same units. For instance, only England can recruit longbowmen and only Spain can recruit Conquistadors, but both will find that the majority of their army at some point will consist of dismounted feudal knights or levy spearmen or peasant archers, etc. A battle can be extremely colorful, but it can also be extremely dull in regards to unit variety. It all depends.

0 Whether or not you like the battle engine is a matter of preference. Basically what they did was attempt to make the movement of units on the battle map more realistic. When given an order, units don't just turn on a dime, they actually have to receive the order, acknowledge it, turn around, start to run, accelerate, and NOW are finally in full stride. This does result in a more [i]realistic[/i] reaction to orders in comparison to RTW, but to me it just comes accross as clumsy and annoying.

[b]CONS[/b]

- The game begins in 1088 and ends in 1530. Now, you might be thinking to yourself, "Holy shit, that's like 250 years!" And you're right, except that for whatever reason, each turn is two years. Like... what the fuck were they thinking? There's still a summer/winter cycle, but characters still age 1 year per turn... which means that William the Conqueror will be 58 in 1,112 A.D. which is straight-up ludicrous. They were trying to make it so that the characters live for roughly as many turns as they do in Rome, but it just comes off as ridiculous.

- It might be the ugliest Total War ever made. I see what they were trying to do, which I shall elaborate on here: First, they added different stats for different body parts (torso, arms, etc.) which are differently armored and take different damage. However, to visually distinguish this, they totally redid the character models from RTW. Second, to add visual weight, they made weapons and projectiles bulkier, which is mostly successful, but sometimes it just doesn't work. Third, they rounded as many of the blocky corners we saw in RTW as they could. The result is, in my humble opinion, the ugliest Total War game I have ever played. Yes, I think it's even worse than Rome, which looks simply ancient by today's standards, but Medieval II is just... gross. There are mods to change this, of course, and there are parts I do think are at least pretty (like armored knights) but Christ, it can be hard to look at at times.

- They had yet to quite figure out the AI in a lot of ways. The result ranges from hilarious incompetence to unbelievable meanness.

[b]TL;DR/CONCLUSION[/b]

It's Medieval II. You love it or you hate it, or both. Personally, it's both for me.

Each total war game now contains spyware designed to take your info called Red Shell. A link to understand is below if you want to know more.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wF-umETMsSg
developer_response:
Red Shell is a program we previously used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising  its not spyware.

Its a marketing attribution tool that helps companies determine which of their adverts are most effective. It does this in a similar way to other analytics tools by using cookies to generate a unique token from device information, and comparing that with data taken from marketing campaigns and game activations. In this way, the companies that use it are able to see which adverts are more effective. You can find out more about Red Shell here: https://redshell.io/home

However, while Red Shell was only used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising, we saw that players were clearly concerned about it and that it would be difficult for us to entirely reassure everyone. As such, the implementation of Red Shell was removed from all Total War games that previously used it.
