Medieval 2 might be the greatest strategy game ever created. 

This isn't nostalgia speaking. I didn't touch the game until 2015. It's that good. By some miracle, this buggy 2005 sequel with barely functioning AI manages to have grand campaigns and battles with a myriad of depth and replayability. On top of that, there's over a decades worth of mods; some extremely well crafted. It's kind of amazing how the sequel to Rome: Total War (widely considered to be one of the best games of all time) manages to improve on nearly every aspect of Rome while playing differently. 

The campaigns genuinely feel like you're constructing an empire. Rather than a boring "build this to recruit this," there's a broad amount of customization and micromanaging that leeways into specialized areas. Some cities will be used as a trade hub. Some castles will be used to raise knights. Some castles will be used to create professional infantry and level up armour. Ect... If you're engaged with the building system, you end up with hub areas that will affect what units and strategies you'll use on certain fronts. In addition, cities (and the campaign in general) have many systems that are abusable by the player. Don't want to besiege a settlement? Send in spies to create unrest. Don't want the AI repairing damages to its cities? Blockade its port. Don't like the pope pestering you? Start a crusade to take back Jerusalem. Speaking of the Pope, many of the overarching hierarchies in the campaign are what make it so special to this day. One of the problems with Rome 1 was, after the player took the city of Rome, there were no more special elements in place to prevent the player from steamrolling everyone. While the Civil War with 3 other Roman factions was interesting, it pretty much marked the end of any challenge. Medieval 2 has the church you constantly need to deal with in some manner, the other religious which will ally against you if you pose a threat to their existence, the invasion of the Mongols at a dedicated point in time, and constant advancements in technology that change the game. It's kind of overwhelming for a first time play through, but I wouldn't have it any other way. It's great. If you act with the grace of the Roman Empire the whole world will be united under multiple bands knocking on your front door.

In a game where nearly all factions have access to heavy infantry and cavalry, it's marvelous how there is still faction diversity. While not as pronounced as Rome 1's, it's there. Different kingdoms have a general set of identical units, and then access to more special units, and then they're own unique units. This is just enough to make every faction play differently (mostly. There are a couple of redundancies). More importantly is how the battles play, and Medieval 2 has, by a country mile, thee most elements and options of every Total War game to this date. There's archers, crossbowmen, skirmishers, spearmen, heavy infantry, 2-handed units, pikemen/halberdiers, firearms,  cannons, ancient siege equipment, light cavalry, heavy cavalry, and horse archers. Each unit has its own role, and (unlike later Total Wars) they don't exist in a basic rock-paper-scissors format. Rather, a lot of it boils down to the tactics each player employs. It's kind of hard to explain without giving an example, so I'll go over how the knight works. 

Knights are heavily armored, have a powerful charge, can break any unit of infantry in one rear charge, and are highly mobile. The downside is they're expensive, suck when they don't have room to maneuver, and are expensive, meaning they don't trade cost efficiently on a 1 to 1 basis. You would think this means Knights just charge everything, but that really isn't the case. Multiple units have situationally dependent counters. All ranged units will get destroyed by knights, but can trade favorably if they can get enough volleys off in time. Spearmen and Heavy Infantry counter knights well because they get a bonus against cav and have the same melee stats but contain more men per unit, respectively. So infantry can defeat knights, but not if the knights charge from behind. But getting behind an enemy requires some outmaneuvering, which will require other units. Light Cav will straight-up lose to Knights in an honest engagement, but can harass Knights with a charge whenever their back is undefended, while also being able to outrun Knights. Horse archers pretty heavily counter knights, but not if they get cornered. Pikemen chew through cavalry, but are outright useless when hit on a flank.

Do you see why this is so amazing? Knights are about breaking the enemy by plowing right into a unit (preferably from behind). However, they can still charge head on and win, but the trade may not be economical. With that said, it still may create a breakthrough for the rest of the army to capitalize on. Knights are countered by Horse Archers, but that situation can be completely turned around if the Horse Archers are outmaneuvered by the Knights. Instead of "I have X unit therefore I counter Y," Medieval 2 is about "I have X unit in Z situation therefore I can do A, B, and C against Y each with their own pros and cons."

I feel like the multiplayer being active to this day speaks to the quality of the battles. They are a complex mind game about exploiting thee most minor of advantages to completely topple an entire army. Medieval 2 has its flaws (such as the AI being well below mediocre. The micromanaging of settlements in the late game is abhorrently tedious), and it fails at properly communicating a lot of its core mechanics, but it's an absolutely beautiful game.

I would still recommend this game even though i don't particularly like it in a lot of ways, since my opinion is not shared by many.

Many call this the greatest total war game ever made, and whilst it certainly has one of the best single player campaign experiences and certainly the best soundtrack (just listen to "crusaders" and tell me it doesnt), the single thing that draws me to any total war game is the battles, and i'm afraid this game lacks in that department.

It's far from both the worst and best for the battles - it doesn't have the buggy retarded nature of troop movement and combat in Empire, and the latest total war games (with the warscape engine), which look like complete moshpits, but there's nothing particularly stunning about it in my opinion.

Most of the factions work in pretty much the same way: you want to tie your opponent's army down to a nasty position with your infantry so that you can crush them with your cavalry, so as long as you have a good enough army, the battles will basically all be the same. This makes the strategies available in combat limited to me, unlike in Rome: Total war where every faction works completely differently because there are much more restrictions on unit types, eg the Scythians have almost no infantry at all, whereas the romans have almost no cavalry, which makes playing as the different factions much more interesting to me, and that's what keeps me from putting more hours into this game. This problem is not as bad in this game as others like Shogun 2, where all of the factions are literally the same, but it still means that there is not really much to go on when choosing factions for a custom battle.
Also, cavalry in this game seems a little bit overpowered - it almost breaks my immersion to see just a few horses surrounded by at least twice as many infantry soldiers once they have stopped charging, just refusing to die (though I guess I admire their constitution level),

As for the campaign, yes it's probably one of the best campaigns - there's so much more content and strategies available here than in rome: total war. However, if you want a good strategy campaign, you need to stop playing Total War and start playing Paradox strategy games like Europa Universalis 4 - i see no reason to play Medieval 2 for it's campaign given the infinitely more in-depth strategic challenge offered by these games - EU4 for example, which i have invested over 100 hours in and still barely understand many of it's mechanics, so there's still so much more to explore in that game than this.

I think you should play total war games for the battle strategy, and paradox games for the campaign, so this game is really the opposite of what it should be, but i'd be lying if i said i havent enjoyed the little time i have spent in it.

Here is a summary:

Pros:
Excellent soundtrack - you can really get engrossed in the battles with the pounding music in the background, its fun just watching the battle take place and listening to this (albeit it hasnt made me play this game for that long).
Excellent campaign for a total war game.

Cons:
For me at least, doesnt offer anything interesting that i can't get twice as good in another game:
Rome: Total war has battles that are twice as good, Europa Universalis 4 has a campaign that is twice as good.

Would I recommend it: Of course, it seems my opinion is quite unpopular so there's a good chance you'll love this game, especially if you've never heard of "total war". If you can truly love this game and spend 500+ hours in it, I envy you. However, if you've played a total war game before, especially Rome, then there's some chance that you'll only be disappointed for the reasons i've stated above.

I have roughly 2100 hours playing this game with a few popular mods, and have enjoyed every moment of it. 

Here are some reasons why you should try it out:

1. The combat simulation is quite realistic and very immersive. The battlefields and cities are huge, and each battle will vary in weather, terrain, and hour of day. No two battles feel the same, and will demand that you employ different strategies.

2. There's nothing stopping you from playing a campaign exactly how you want to. If you want to sail across the map and pillage random cities, you can do that. If you want to annex you neighbor or backstab an ally, you can do that whenever you want to. If you want to send your king on the frontlines, you can do that. It makes plenty of room for your creativity. 

3. It's very easy to understand. This game doesn't have an elaborate UI, trade system, or diplomacy system like say EU4. Once you're comfortable moving your army around the battle map, there's not much else to wrap your head around.

Also, my favorite mod is Stainless Steel 6.4. I highly recommend downloading it after playing through a few vanilla campaigns.

Medieval II brings the Total War series back to a simpler, more focused vision. Everything you do is designed to build larger armies or a better economy, which in turn means your large armies won't get angry about late payments and plunder your realms as payment. With the satisfying gameplay loop of building up cities to watch the tax roll in, and managing your castles and armies against traitorous bastard AI, it somehow manages to feel like both a relaxing builder game and a tense balancing act of war. 

The agents all feel useful, with diplomats and princesses securing alliances or bribes, assassins and spies providing intel and an easy way to increase your ruler's authority (by murdering half of Europe's generals), and the unique merchants who add some depth and dynamism to the economic war you wage. The RTS battles feel vicious, with the older engine providing better collision than the newer shinier ones. Units act like more of a single blob, which can be both good and bad depending on if it's a highly disciplined footsoldier unit or a rabble of peasants getting stuck on corners and trapped between charging knights. And my god, if lanced knights in this game get a good charge in, you'll see why they were the ultimate killing machine in IRL battles too. This is made harder by the pathfinding though, better than Rome but still wonky. 

And then there's the mods, which range from realistic and depth-adding expansions like Stainless Steel to Planetwar, which defies description and deserves its own review. Overall definitely worth getting even if you have no nostalgia for the series, at least until they make Medieval III (pls).

Well, I guess I'm kinda fed up with medieval Europe. I bought this ages ago because I fondly remembered the original Shogun: Total War, simple as it was. Shogun introduced me to the history of Japan and since many things about it were unknown and foreign to me, it was pretty interesting and a nice game to whittle hours away. Medieval II: Total War seemed busier and it was happening in the ole' Cheeze Peninsula, also known as Europe, and since i'm from there it just seemed kind of uninteresting.

I suppose I'm not the target audience, but then take it this way: The total war formula isn't necessarily appealing to everyone unless the setting itself is exotic or intrigueing enough. Sure, medievalists among my friends might find it fun, but it's a bit too niche to give it a broad recommend.

I'd give it a thumbs down, but you're very likely to get it for not very much, and it has no achievements attached so getting it won't mess up your completion statistics and if you happen to be the target audience you might like it. It's not a bad game by any means, it's just more niche than folks who like it unreservedly might think.

Medieval II: Total War is a fantastic, yet tedious game.

The battles are grand, strategic, and visually stunning for the age of this game. Watching your soldiers charge and clash against enemy armies is truly a remarkable sight. Leading them, setting formations, routing enemy flanks, and finally crushing those that surrender is very satisfying. 

The statecraft is also great. As you build up your nation, you see the land and cities transform with the improvements that you build. When you build roads, you see them; when you build markets and ports, you see carriages trading on the roads you build. I know it is a small detail, but it makes such a large and satisfying difference to see that your improvements change the tangible world and do not merely increase numbers or statistics. 

This is where the game shines. I so deeply enjoyed building markets, roads, and ports to facilitate trade in my land. I enjoyed building beautiful churches to spread and defend the faith. I genuinely felt a sense of accomplishment improving city walls, building towers, exploiting the resources of the land with mines (which also appear in the world), and overall improving the state. I actually enjoyed this more than the war mechanic.

But the game fails in diplomacy. Listen, I understand that the name of the game is Total War, but does that mean that you have to constantly be at war? At times, the AI would attack at random when we had good previous relations, and when they were clearly beaten, they would not surrender. This forces you to forget the deep nation building mechanics of the game to completely concentrate on war and wipe out the enemy entirely because the AI will likely never surrender. It does not make sense. Why waste your time creating complex building mechanics when in the end, you have to focus completely on war? A constant state of war stales the game and gets tiering quick. 

But overall, the game is great and I completely recommend it.

I suppose if you played this when it was released and have some deep-seated nostalgia for it, then you might be able to see past all the game's technical flaws to the gem that supposedly lies beneath. But for me, coming to this instance of the franchise late in the game, it's baffling to me that Medieval II somehow manages to be orders of magnitude uglier AND less functional than both the games before and after it. 

Perhaps the AI is better than Empire, and perhaps the unit and culture rosters are better than Rome, but I wouldn't know because the menu options are so sparse that I can't stop the camera from scooting around the world map at the speed of light, making it frustratingly difficult to centre on any one army and make it do a thing. The tutorial is broken and won't let you move a character that it's asking you to move; archers shoot arrows with glitched animations that weave a serpentine path into the sky like balloons escaping children's hands; peasant farmers obliterate trained spearmen in one-on-one battles; and these are just things I noticed in the first 10 minutes of play. If there's some kind of mod or patch that fixes this, please let me know, but as far as I can tell the game is an utter mess. 

I've false-started a number of times because I keep reading reviews about how great it apparently is, and I always seem to remember feeling that it was 'hard' whenever I tried to play it. But here, now, with a clear perspective, it's just ugly, broken, and unlike any other TW game I've played, not fun to start. I don't know what the deal is here, but this is a waste.

Ah Medieval 2, now a classic. You see that Overwhelmingly positive reception this game achieved, that is the benchmark set by CA for the Total war series. Every total war since has yet to reach that mark again, although i have enjoyed Warhammer. about 145 hours logged on steam version, i cant remember how many hours i logged with the original release CD version (before steam) but lets just say its an ungodly amount of time.

Some of the pros and cons

Pros

- A logical step forward from Rome 1
- Papacy (vote for pope), Jihad, Crusades. Agents
-improved diplomacy over Rome 1
-Settlements are either Economic or Military 
 Economic being towns->City->Metropolis
Military being Castle->Fortress->Citadel
 and you can change a town to a Castle and visa versa, when you want to
-with that in mind you can build up a small village up into a great city (later total wars restricted this to province system)
-agents work well and take time to level up. sort of balances AI agent spam in a way.
-not 60 quid or 40 quid ha
-brings back memories
-plenty of polished mods, the game is still going strong. Has the only working and released LOTR mod, the Third age, that has plenty of submods. 

Cons

well there are obvious ones 
-such as this being an old game  ha
-Graphics are outdated
-no steamworkshop for mods, you have to get mods from MOD DB.com they can be tedious to install but worth it.
-my biggest and perhaps only gripe with playing this nowadays is the lack of unit replenishment, you have to got to settlement or where you can recruit specific unit in order to retrain the unit back to full strenght.

All in all, like age of Empires 2 the conquerors, this is one the greatest strategy games of all time.

Don't let my game time fool you, The countless summers spent at my nans with no internet and playing in offline mode I must have put over 3k hours into ME2. But before I review, let me just say that I have NOT played the base game, or expansions in years. There's a simple reason why I haven't done that, and while it is good, especially the teutonic expansion, I personally find the base game pretty bland and boring.

Now that said... modding is where this game comes alive. I've got over 10 full conversion mods sitting in my ME2 folder, over 120gb worth of content just for ME2.

I have third age total war, with MoS, DaC, and the 1st/2nd/3rd/4th age all in seperate folders so I can play all of them when I want. And DaC in it's current form is by far the best ME2 mod to date, and it's even better than most other TW games simply because it's lotr and it brings ME2 to life. 

BOTET - basically ME2 warhammer. And lo and behold, it's ten times better than WH1/2 TW, and that's the damn truth. ME2 has such a great engine and allows modding that none of the new games allow, why CA stopped the same kind of modding through their kits is a bit of a joke considering the amount of modders for the franchise. Botet may be russian made, but they really have outdone themselves, if you head on over to moddb, or TW heaven you'll find a thread for it, download it and give it a try, it's got EVERY faction, and basically EVERY unit. No more fooling around paying 15 for fucking Tomb Kings and buying a whole NEW game for them. Sure it might not have fancy graphics or magic, but ME2 is still the best TW to date, CA knows it, so does every true TW fan.

Elder scrolls TW - another good addition to the modding scene, really brings a new 'flavour' into ME2, offers a wider range of factions with a very balanced game style. It's elder scrolls, no need to say anymore, it's good.

The game itself is amazing, I do not think the base game is bad, but it is bland. When you experience these mods you will all come to realise how weak the base game is, but it is not CA's fault. these mods have had years of dedication and are still being worked on. DaC and MoS are still being improved and updated, and the latest DaC has improved so much. Once you experience the modding scene of ME2, you'll never touch the base game again.

TL:DR

Mod ME2. Just do it. Don't pay money for the game to only play the base game/expansions. Go to Moddb, go to the TWcenter and you'll find many great mods to give you thousands of hours of enjoyment.

base game may be a good 8/10, but when you experince what the mods have to offer, it's really a 1/10. It's free to install all of these mods, it takes literally no effort other than reading how to install. If you can't get a mod to work, simply delete all the items inside the 'americas' folder, then copy + paste the mod folders content into that, then load up americas and it will run the mod. Some mods can only be ran that way, most like TATW can be ran with the ring.exe once installed.

I've played this game since it came out, from disks that I bought at a local Wal-Mart.  This is undoubtedly one of the best games ever made, and before I ever came to Steam, I probably had thousands of hours on it.  It is immersive, to say the very least, despite it's age.  After downloading, today, I went to the Total War Center, and downloaded the three files for Third Age:Total War, based upon J.R.R. Tolkien's classic works, including the Lord of the Rings.  I started playing as Gondor, which is very weak, at the beginning of the game.

With my new computer, the graphics are set at the absolute maximum settings ... something I was never able to do, before.  The game's graphics ... tweaked by the modders ... came alive.  I'd never seen it look like it does, today.  No, it doesn't look as good as Witcher III, but the graphics take nothing away from the gameplay.

For those who don't know, Medieval II:Total War is a turn-based strategy game, whose origins go way back to Shogun: Total War (note that this was not Shogun II).  I've been hooked on their games, ever since.  The devs have their given games tremendous support, and there is an enormous modding community, out there (though I was surprised not to see one in the Steam Workshop).

There are complete overhauls for the basic game, in the modding community.  Although the basic period is Medieval, overhauls are available that go back to ancient times, to relatively modern times.  There seems to be no limitations to the modders' imaginations, when it comes to this game.

When an army (called a stack) is moved against an enemy army, the game immediately into battle mode, and I like to play with the action as close as possible ... get down and dirty with all the sounds, blood, and gore of the battle.

Today, I led Faramir into a re-taking of East Osgiliath against a much larger force, from Mordor.  My boys sent those orcs screaming into the hills.

If you've never played this game, you need to.

Highly recommended, to say the least.  And the price is right.  Buy the bundle, which includes Kingdoms.  You'll need it, if you intend to download any mods.

P.S.  I love killing orcs ...

Absolute masterpiece- if you are Total War fan than this game is a must-have. It contains of 2 segments- [b]Turn-based grand campaign[/b] and a [b]Battle segment[/b] including land and siege battles. The game covers an era from an early medieval times up to the reneissance so you'll find yourself starting with the use of simplistic swords and light cavalry units and than end up using, first time introduced into Total War series, firearms (rifles, cannons and even elephants armed with that). It gives many, many hours of gameplay and additional mods will deliver much more fresh and new content.

The best grand strategy game I've ever played.  Being a rather dated game, one wouldn't typically expect such replayability.  But i've played way more than my Steam record shows.  I like the game so much, when I lost my physical copy, I happily re-purchased the game on Steam. 

The game mechanics have all been explored in published reviews, so I won't go into a lot of detail.  The diplomacy is ok, could be even more in-depth but is sufficient for the scope of a game like this.  I think the game really shines in the real time combat.  Thousands of soldiers each individually rendered makes directing and watching the combat truly enthralling. The AI is dated, and not particularly difficult even on most difficult level, but is still challenging at times, especially if you are outnumbered.  Graphics are great for the time the game came out.  Sound is great, music appropriate.  

The only con I can think of is the AI.  It could be a lot more difficult and unpredictable, but this seems typical again for the time the game came out.  The AI's diplomacy could be a lot better, but again, it's sufficient for playability and the time period it came out.  If you enjoy medieval type strategy games, this one is a must-have.
I will always contend that this is the best game ever created.

I've tried about all of the Total War games. I keep coming back to this one. I think its the simplicity. (Well, it's not simple, the first time you play it.) Diplomacy actually made you work for it. If you knew an ambassador was going to your enemies to possibly create an alliance, you could send an assassin to kill him. No alliance was made. That was awesome! All the new Total Wars are just instant diplomacy. Click and negotiate. No fun. 

The Medieval period is also my favorite period, especially in Total War. I don't know what it is about it. Moats and castles and trebuchet and cavalry and archers and spearmen. Family trees of inheritence. It's all so fun and immersive. 

And by God, the fucking music is amazing! I don't know what happened going forward, but Medieval 2 (and Shogun 2's for that matter) music are drum-poundingly exciting. Everything about the music puts you in that era, and you feel the battle shake with the drums of war. IT's amazing.

I'd put Medieval 2, Shogun 2, and Warhammer as my top 3 most played Total War games. If the day ever comes when Medieval 3 comes out, and it isn't ass-raped by microtransactions or loot boxes, I will probably love it more than this one.

Medieval II is, in my opinion, one of the best Total War titles, up there with Rome - the first Rome.

The campaign centres around Europe and the Middle East, with emphasis on the internal feudaling in Europe and the Crusades between the caliphates and the Catholic Church. The organised religion of the time has been well represented in the game. If you play as a Catholic country, the Church will launch Holy Crusades against certain Islamic cities. If you play as an Islamic country, a Jihad may be called against Christian cities. The Pope has an opinion on each country, and if you, as a Catholic leader, do things like invade another Catholic country, you will anger the Pope. Anger him enough, and you may be excommunicated and you yourself could be the victim of a crusade.

This additional layer means politics has become a bit more in-depth. If you need help with a particular enemy, even with no allies you can call on the Pope to launch a crusade on your enemy - or call the Islamic world for a Jihad - and half the nations will be compelled to prove their faith by crushing your enemy. Even better, by then caputuring the city you get brownie points with your own religion.

Of course, in addition to this, you have the standard Total War tactics of spies, diplomats and armies. WIth the twin arms of diplomatic subterfuge and military strength, you will expand your borders and crush those who would oppose you. Leading your army from town militas with repurposed farming impliments, to heroic knights all the way to the advent of gunpowder - muskets, cannons and early mortars - you will expand your country into a massive empire, crushing all others beneath you.

How to burn (a fuck ton) of hours:

1) Buy medieval II: Total War. (You'll love it, i guarentee)

2) Download stainless steel 6.4

3) play 20+ campaigns, every time selecting the byzantines, only ever in the early era, never once actually finishing a campaign. (Scotland can be used in place of the byzantines if you've recently seen braveheart)

4) repeat until dead.

Now, a guide to installing SS 6.4 that nobody asked for.

1) download the SS 6.3 and the 6.4 patch from Total war center. 
2) install SS 6.3 into the appropriate directory. (/steamapps/common/medieval2totalwar/mods/SS6.3)
3) install SS 6.4 into the appropriate directory. It should be exactly the same as the SS 6.3 install path.
4) rename the "americas" folder in the "mods" folder of M2TW to "americas_orginal" or whatever the shit you want to call it, really doesn't matter.
5) rename your SS6.3 folder to "americas" exactly as the original folder was once spelt.

To launch your newfound heroin, just choose to play the americas expansion upon launch. Every other option will be vanilla. RIP americas DLC, you kinda sucked so nobody cares

Just a PSA for people who are dumb like me. Do not buy this if you cant get Kingdoms with this. Kingdoms is not a DLC, it is a mandatory patch that unfugs large parts of the vanilla experince. Not to go too into detail lemmie explain one wonderful bug that you'll encounter without Kingdoms:

This bug is caused by Legacy code from Rome 1. In which it had a mechanic where factions could 'raze' settlments, which was (to my knowledge) Barbarian flavour text for exterminate populace. In Medieval, they didn't need it so they tried to remove then disable the code. The issue is that they only removed/disabled the header for it, and the actual effects were still active but didn't have a flag to tell them which button on the "what do you want to do with this settlment" pop-up after taking a settlment. So it defaults to the first value, which in this case happens to be the 'Occupy peacefully' option.

TL;DR, Occuping peacefully in this game will make the AI think you actually just burned a settlment down to the ground and  by the 10th turn you should have a conga line of factions halfway across the world marching to take you down.

Before I go any further, I want to make one thing clear. Medieval II: Total War was released in november of 2006. So if you are not able to play with low-quality graphics, this game might not be for you. 

Medieval II: Total War is, in my opinion as well as the opinion of many others, part of the golden age of Total War which included Medieval II and Rome: Total War. Medieval II might as well be the peak of the entire series, gameplay-wise. 
Medieval II uses very different mechanics compared to the newer Total War games. Arguably more realistic and, as some might say, more immersive. 
The construction system isn't exactly black and white. Construction in Medieval II allows you to build all buildings in every settlement. (I'll assess the castle-city system in a moment.) After the introduction of the Warscape engine in Empire: Total War, one could no longer build all buildings in a settlement due to building slots which limited how many buildings one could build. Now this could be seen as a good thing. Limiting the amount of buildings in your settlements forces the player to make more strategic decisions as to what buildings to build where. However, during late-game campaign, it is not too strategically bad to simply build all the best buildings and ignore the others. Total War: Attila improved this by making buildings more unique to settlement types. What I mean is: In Rome II, you can build top tier recruitment buildings in your minor settlements while just building money-making buildings in your provincial capitals. In Attila, the recruitment buildings for provincial capitals and minor settlements are unique to said settlements. Although it may be seen as "non-strategical" (or something along those lines) to be able to build all buildings in every settlement, eraly game one does not possess the funds to construct all these buildings. One has to make strategic decisions to decide what will be profitable (not necessarily economy-wise). 

Now on to recruitment. In my opinion, recruitment in Medieval II is the height of recruitment in the entire series. Simply because of one feature: Unit pools. When a unit has started recruitment, and that was the last unit in the pool, the unit will not be available until a few turns later at which point one unit will become available. This forces army variation and is a fantastic contrast to the mass conscription of the recent games. Now you cant just spam the best unit through all your armies and dominate the world. Now you must pick up the best that is available. 

In the recent games, generals have been very streamlined. Your general fights battles, he gains XP, he levels up. Now pick a skill. Chose Skill "Strategist". Effects: +1 cunning, +2% Melee Defence skill for all infantry units. This may seem like a good system. And if you want that, I don't blame you. But Medieval II uses another system which is more realistic and (again, in my opinion) overall better. Your general gains traits and retinues depending on how he acts. If he fights battles and mercilessly executes captives and slaughter civilians, he will gain dread. On the other hand, if he is respectful to prisoners and releases them, and he peacefully occupies cities, he will gain respect. Dread and respect are one of four trees that have several levels. There is command, that changes depending on how much and well he wins battles. Traits and retinues can also affect governing. Increased taxes and trade income, increased or decreased public order. 

Despite this game's pros it is not without cons, no matter how small they are. Medieval II has better graphics and animations than Rome I, but the unit response time is useless. (By this I mean when you tell your units to move, it takes them a few seconds to get moving. This is very restricting when you want to pull your cavalry away from charging infantry or pull them out of a melee. And there are of course the graphics and animations. But still, the gameplay itself, can be really immersive and I would definitely recommend it. 

Overall, the game recieves a 9/10 from me.

I bought this game only because I could no longer play the original Meidval: Total War (Steam has a broken version for sale that they apparently refuse to fix but are totally fine to allow people to continue buying it) and thought maybe Medieval II would be comparable. I want so badly to play the original again in a working version and to have my money back for this game.

This is my favorite Total War game to date. A great setting, excellent gameplay, and good mechanics all rolled into one. 

The game has a lot to offer from the unique factions that each have a distinct playstyle (Hungary for example is very cavalry focused, while Milan relies on their crossbow units, and the Moors utilize strong infantry). The graphics also look fairly good for when the game was originally released. The battles are always fun, except when your enemy spams war elephants..... Aside from that the battles are on par with the original Rome Total War, they are fun and require strategy. 

The Kingdoms expansion adds a lot more to the game, allowing you to play campaigns in the Baltic, the British Isles, the Middle East (Crusader States), and even the Americas. 

The game is also highly modable and has a ton of amazing mods you can download which offer so many new experiences. I'd recommend giving the Third Age mod and the Call of Warhammer mod each a try if you love fantasy. For history buffs, check out Europa Barbarorum 2, Invasio Barbarorum 2, Stainless Steel, and Potop Total War. Each is great in their own way.

I highly recommend this game to anyone with an interest in the Middle Ages or strategy games. Really a first class Total War game.
The 2nd best game in TW series after Rome 1. The different types of community mods that are available are a lot of fun.

I cannot remember when I first played this game, but the fact that I still play it after all these years speaks for itself. Everything is great about it: the music, the units, the fascinating middle ages and those badass warrior units like templars, varanguian guards, heavy knights and so on.

There are still  a few annoying things in M2TW.
The diplomatic interface is simple and could be satisfying, it if wasn't more often than not dysfonctional. You may not be able to end a war with a crippled enemy, even if you besiege his last standing city; he will still refuse your offer or demand an exorbitant sum of money to agree, when he really should be the one begging for mercy.
It is also dysfonctional when you always become "unreliable" for an obscure reason and the only way to become reliable is to repeatedly offer money to your neighbours in exchange for their assistance against another faction. It doesn't make sense but it works.
There are many other absurdities like these, but it's still a nice game to play and it gets even better with some of the nice mods available like Broken Crescent, Stainless Steel, etc.

And if you get this game for about five euros during a sale, you can't get any better return on investment as this!

As usual with my reviews, they are relevant to the time of the release of the game. Today, Im reviewing one of my favorite games to play as a kid/teenager. This game, in my opinion, was the first (and potentially largest) leap for the total war series. Previously, total war games felt the same and every problem had very simple solutions. I remember in the original Medieval: Total War, you could basically just build cheap spearman and destroy anybody with the numbers game. In the original Rome: Total War if you had hoplites you could just put those in front of gates and you were 99% guaranteed a win (enemies would just continuously run into them and die, without adjusting). This game is FINALLY when the AI starts to get smart, different times of units start to actually matter more, and a central organization starts to actually make a difference.
	In the past, the central organization would hand out missions with rewards or disappointed messages, but nothing really quite as complex, rewarding, and harmful as the Papcy. This game introduced politics the likes of which were never seen in total war games before hand, with the College of Cardinals. It became INSANELY important to focus on either building lots of priests to rise up in the ranks or lots of assassins to kill your enemies priests so you dont get excommunicated (or, as I do it just to be safe, I do both). This game brought a lot of fresh ideas that even still to this day are enjoyable (though they are FINALLY starting to feel a little dated). Heck, the game even still looks good today, something I cant say the same for Empire: Total War. The story is what you make it like all total war games (though the more recent ones like Warhammer have improved this significantly), so the score will be similar to other total war games here, but overall this was one of the greatest games of its era and certainly the best strategy game.

Chapter 1
Abishag cherishes David in his extreme ageAdonijah aspires to be kingBathsheba and Nathan advise David of Adonijahs plottingDavid names Solomon as king, and he is anointed by ZadokAdonijahs cause fails.

1 Now king David was old and stricken in years; and they covered him with clothes, but he gat no heat.

2 Wherefore his servants said unto him, Let there be sought for my lord the king a young virgin: and let her stand before the king, and let her cherish him, and let her lie in thy bosom, that my lord the king may get heat.

3 So they sought for a fair damsel throughout all the coasts of Israel, and found Abishag a Shunammite, and brought her to the king.

4 And the damsel was very fair, and cherished the king, and ministered to him: but the king knew her not.

5  Then Adonijah the son of Haggith exalted himself, saying, I will be king: and he prepared him chariots and horsemen, and fifty men to run before him.

6 And his father had not displeased him at any time in saying, Why hast thou done so? and he also was a very goodly man; and his mother bare him after Absalom.

7 And he conferred with Joab the son of Zeruiah, and with Abiathar the priest: and they following Adonijah helped him.

8 But Zadok the priest, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and Nathan the prophet, and Shimei, and Rei, and the mighty men which belonged to David, were not with Adonijah.

9 And Adonijah slew sheep and oxen and fat cattle by the stone of Zoheleth, which is by En-rogel, and called all his brethren the kings sons, and all the men of Judah the kings servants:

10 But Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah, and the mighty men, and Solomon his brother, he called not.

11  Wherefore Nathan spake unto Bath-sheba the mother of Solomon, saying, Hast thou not heard that Adonijah the son of Haggith doth reign, and David our lord knoweth it not?

12 Now therefore come, let me, I pray thee, give thee counsel, that thou mayest save thine own life, and the life of thy son Solomon.

13 Go and get thee in unto king David, and say unto him, Didst not thou, my lord, O king, swear unto thine handmaid, saying, Assuredly Solomon thy son shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne? why then doth Adonijah reign?

14 Behold, while thou yet talkest there with the king, I also will come in after thee, and confirm thy words.

15  And Bath-sheba went in unto the king into the chamber: and the king was very old; and Abishag the Shunammite ministered unto the king.

16 And Bath-sheba bowed, and did obeisance unto the king. And the king said, What wouldest thou?

17 And she said unto him, My lord, thou swarest by the Lord thy God unto thine handmaid, saying, Assuredly Solomon thy son shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne.

18 And now, behold, Adonijah reigneth; and now, my lord the king, thou knowest it not:

19 And he hath slain oxen and fat cattle and sheep in abundance, and hath called all the sons of the king, and Abiathar the priest, and Joab the captain of the host: but Solomon thy servant hath he not called.

20 And thou, my lord, O king, the eyes of all Israel are upon thee, that thou shouldest tell them who shall sit on the throne of my lord the king after him.

21 Otherwise it shall come to pass, when my lord the king shall sleep with his fathers, that I and my son Solomon shall be counted offenders.

22  And, lo, while she yet talked with the king, Nathan the prophet also came in.

23 And they told the king, saying, Behold Nathan the prophet. And when he was come in before the king, he bowed himself before the king with his face to the ground.

24 And Nathan said, My lord, O king, hast thou said, Adonijah shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne?

25 For he is gone down this day, and hath slain oxen and fat cattle and sheep in abundance, and hath called all the kings sons, and the captains of the host, and Abiathar the priest; and, behold, they eat and drink before him, and say, God save king Adonijah.

26 But me, even me thy servant, and Zadok the priest, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and thy servant Solomon, hath he not called.

27 Is this thing done by my lord the king, and thou hast not shewed it unto thy servant, who should sit on the throne of my lord the king after him?

28  Then king David answered and said, Call me Bath-sheba. And she came into the kings presence, and stood before the king.

29 And the king sware, and said, As the Lord liveth, that hath redeemed my soul out of all distress,

30 Even as I sware unto thee by the Lord God of Israel, saying, Assuredly Solomon thy son shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne in my stead; even so will I certainly do this day.

31 Then Bath-sheba bowed with her face to the earth, and did reverence to the king, and said, Let my lord king David live for ever.

32  And king David said, Call me Zadok the priest, and Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada. And they came before the king.

33 The king also said unto them, Take with you the servants of your lord, and cause Solomon my son to ride upon mine own mule, and bring him down to Gihon:

34 And let Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet anoint him there king over Israel: and blow ye with the trumpet, and say, God save king Solomon.

35 Then ye shall come up after him, that he may come and sit upon my throne; for he shall be king in my stead: and I have appointed him to be ruler over Israel and over Judah.

36 And Benaiah the son of Jehoiada answered the king, and said, Amen: the Lord God of my lord the king say so too.

37 As the Lord hath been with my lord the king, even so be he with Solomon, and make his throne greater than the throne of my lord king David.

38 So Zadok the priest, and Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and the Cherethites, and the Pelethites, went down, and caused Solomon to ride upon king Davids mule, and brought him to Gihon.

39 And Zadok the priest took an horn of oil out of the tabernacle, and anointed Solomon. And they blew the trumpet; and all the people said, God save king Solomon.

40 And all the people came up after him, and the people piped with pipes, and rejoiced with great joy, so that the earth rent with the sound of them.

41  And Adonijah and all the guests that were with him heard it as they had made an end of eating. And when Joab heard the sound of the trumpet, he said, Wherefore is this noise of the city being in an uproar?

42 And while he yet spake, behold, Jonathan the son of Abiathar the priest came: and Adonijah said unto him, Come in; for thou art a valiant man, and bringest good tidings.

43 And Jonathan answered and said to Adonijah, Verily our lord king David hath made Solomon king.

44 And the king hath sent with him Zadok the priest, and Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and the Cherethites, and the Pelethites, and they have caused him to ride upon the kings mule:

45 And Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet have anointed him king in Gihon: and they are come up from thence rejoicing, so that the city rang again. This is the noise that ye have heard.

46 And also Solomon sitteth on the throne of the kingdom.

47 And moreover the kings servants came to bless our lord king David, saying, God make the name of Solomon better than thy name, and make his throne greater than thy throne. And the king bowed himself upon the bed.

48 And also thus said the king, Blessed be the Lord God of Israel, which hath given one to sit on my throne this day, mine eyes even seeing it.

49 And all the guests that were with Adonijah were afraid, and rose up, and went every man his way.

50  And Adonijah feared because of Solomon, and arose, and went, and caught hold on the horns of the altar.

51 And it was told Solomon, saying, Behold, Adonijah feareth king Solomon: for, lo, he hath caught hold on the horns of the altar, saying, Let king Solomon swear unto me to day that he will not slay his servant with the sword.

There is a problem with this game. When this game came out it was very buggy. However as time went on SEGA released patch after patch after patch to fix. The problem is that STEAM offers you the original buggy version of the game so prepare for a lot of frustration. And even worse STEAM does not offer any support for this product. You cannot even contact them to say hey how about you offer the game and the patches.

I am going to be asking for a refund if I cannot get a hold of Steam in getting these patche installed. They also should note the patches needed etc...before buying the game and whether they offer it or not.

The bugs are very frustrating. Below are just a few examples:

1. CASTLE WALLS - There are too many issues with the walls to really get into but my God this is enough for me to quit.
a. Many Units particularly Nafatuns and Gun Units have a hard time firing while on the walls. Many times they get stuck going throught the motion of firing without firing a single shot. Nafatus for the most part throw explosives at the walls or the floor of the walls rather than over. There was a patch that fixed this.
b. When commanding the units to get off the wall they ofter freeze in place. In battle this is very frustrating. It may take me up to 8 commands to get a unit off the wall. And if the enemy is is firing on the walls, everytime the walls gets it your units on the wall freeze. You reall reall really have to micromanage. A patch has also fixed this.
c. Anytime the wall goes throught the animations of breaking the game slows down signifcantly until the animation has completed. I have an Alienware Desktop from 2017 with all the bells and whistles so not sure why this occurs.
d. Sometimes Archer units below the wall on the ground fire into the wall versus over the wall despite being far enough back.

2. UNIT FORMATIONS - This one is also super frustrating. Especially with cavalry. Lets say you have 50 cavalry. You set the unit to have 10 units wide and 5 lines depth. As soon as you move the unit or set it to attack the enemy it changes its formation to 3 Units Wide and 17 lines deep. So you really only have 3 units in the front of that line charging the enemy versus 10. Super Frustrating. And it really does effect the outcome of that battle. A patch also exists that fixes this.

These two issues are bigger than you  think in game play. 

Unless Steam provides the patches and offers the game with the patches I give this game a thumbs down. Otherwise this is a great game. I wish they make a M3TW.

Wow, where to even start.  I will just say if you are a fan or have any interest in the Medieval time period whatsoever this is the game for you.  Massive epic battles, heroic charges that put the Hollywood movies to shame, dashing heroes who die far before their prime, bloodthirsty tyrants who die of old age and the chastity belts for those wicked princesses who try and steal your best generals away from your kingdom.

I bought this game in 2014 on sale and so I have no nostalgic feelings attached to it.  I sank over 1,000 bloodsoaked hours into this game and though I haven't played it recently (need to take a break and gather my wits for some more holy Crusades) I have enjoyed every single minute of it.  This is as intense as it gets.  

Going after the Mongols and Timurids with my German soldiers, with the Teutonic Knights leading the way has never been more satisfying.  I lied, capturing the Mongol faction leader twice in the same turn and getting over 50,000 florins in ransom money was the best thing I ever did.  We captured him a third time and the Mongols executed their own leader after that.  

There are so many countless battles I could recount but they all now are in the history books.

I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for better than Braveheart battles.  Seriously, this is one of the best games ever made.

Base Game: 9/10     Modded Game: 10/10

A classic Total War, and one of the last ones that didn't involve ridiculous DLC pricing. The game runs on a greatly modified Rome: Total War engine, but runs much more smoothly than RTW in my experience. The game has one of the best soundtracks ever made (even better than RTW), and it's over 4 hours long too. The multiplayer community is still somewhat active. The game's full potential is unlocked with excellent mods, however. Third Age, Stainless Steel, etc. Buy it on sale for like 10 bucks with the Kingdoms DLC, which adds three whole new campaigns, and the ability to mod the game.

Great base game, even better with mods. Third Age Total War and Age of Petty Kings are standouts. Clocked in over 100 hours so far and love dipping back in every now and then.

This is the greatest game of all time. It has aged really well for a twelve year old game, so I wouldn't let that put you off. The graphics arent flashy, but they are remarkably sound, and the combination of a breathtaking soundtrack and impressive game mechanics and features make up for the graphics not blowing you away, because they make the game much more immersive than empty graphics do. More importantly, this game never gets boring. I've had this game for years before I got it on steam, and I never got tired of it. It really hits the sweet spot in my opinion of being easy enough to grasp and get good at while still maintaining depth of features and complexity of gameplay. The only complaint I can think of is that, similar to other Total War games, the AI is pretty unimpressive, and the game can get fairly easy. FOrtunately, I think this gets combatted fairly well by enjoyable aspects of politics, with the pope, crusades and jihads, and public order all being interesting to manage and adding additional challenge. Additionally, unlike some other total war games, it presets a separate and unique late game challenge in the Mongol invasion and the Americas. It is especially impressive in its rolelaying potential as well, as the traits characters can develop are extremely varied and interesting, with the descriptions often making me laugh. The traits are all based off of the lived experiences of the charaters, as well, rather than a generic linear leveling up system. That is to say, to make a character a better commander, you need to win lots of battles, the more difficult the better. It can be personalised as well, as if the character only fights defensive battles, then he will receive traits improving their command rating only during defensive battles. The traits also allow characters to gain either dread or chivalry, which offer separate bonuses and allow the player to actually decide whether they'd prefer their characters to be respected or feared. Would you like your kingdom to have such a terrifying reputation that almost nobody will dare to stand and fight against you? Then do dreadful deeds, like sacking cities, assassinating rivals, and executing prisoners. Alternatively, crusading or jihading, releasing prisoners, or undertaking projects for the public good, like building happiness buildings and maintaining lower tax rates, will allow your charater to gain chivalry, which carries its own benefits. That may seem like an overly long explanation, but it is just indicative of the outstanding depth this game has to offer. Total War is a series like no other, offering an incredible blend of grand strategy and exhilerating RTS elements, and no game in the series really comes close to Medieval 2, in my opinion (Rome 1 and Shogun 2 come closest, but M2TW is in a class of its own).

So, origionally I decided to play cause I saw other people play and it looked intresting. Now I'm more of a 'peaceful' player, preferring to go for allies and such and I just origionally decided to go for a more peaceful victory, knowing I'd eventually have to deal with Scotland and France (given you're only given like...a few choices for your faction at the start and I did wanna play scotland, but that wasn't unlocked.)

Only thirty turns in, I was at war with three factions and wiped out due to being overwhelmed. Tried again, fourty turns in I get wiped out by the Roman empire when I was supposidly allied with them no more than four turns ago. Finally third time I decided to be agressive, took over the british isles, took a good peice of france, acted like the AI usually did.

And I got Excommunicated and had a crusade called agianst me when nearly every game before I ended up getting killed and, even if I had the highest favor with the pope, he'd be little more than like "lol k" with the other factions attacking me with no provoking.

So, I stopped playing and uninstalled until reciently, when I got the urge to play again but had no urge to get attacked. Then, I found out there's a bug in the diplomacy where factions would actually prefer you to sack settlements rather than take them peacefully (Well, as peacefully as you can.) due to the code having three semi-colons. So I thought "Okay, I'll go through unpacking and fix the file" So after finding the three semi-colons and deleting them, along with checking to make sure that the game used the modded files I tried again.

Only to have another faction attack me not even twenty turns in for absolutely no reason.

I give up, I would say "I can't believe that this was allowed to be ignored for such a long time and never fixed." But then I noticed Sega of all things published this. I'm not surprised.

Has great ideas but the game's frankly weak combat and interface ruins most of them. If they did a good mix of this, Attila, and Rome 2 then it'd be far and away better than any total war game ever has been. The city management is great, the multiple levels of walls is great, the unbreakable town centres are utterly infuriating, the variety of units is great, the cavalry is painfully bad and clunky as all heck, and the game looks awful on the battle map. Anyone who isn't nostalgia blinded is going to struggle to enjoy this game if they're into the war part of total war.

Good skirmish function, but shame about how bad the combat is. Put that skirmish function on a DLC for Rome 2 and I'd certainly play that. Defending two flanks and a front is surprisingly fun and would be improved by a better combat engine.

Though most of the content would be in locked content DLC so it might be meh anyway.

Medieval II is my favorite game of all time. The main campaign is fantastic and is always evolving. Between  technology shifting events like gunpowder and the three major endgame superfactions it makes the storytelling of newer total war titles feel downright tiny. It does not miss small details either its great to have a secretly female priest make her way up the collage of cardinals and become Pope or watch as that general who has been away from home for years picks up a mistress. Battles last a long time and units have a real weight to them, the AI isn't too great at sieges but it is still mostly competent. If that isn't enough this game has the largest variety of quality total overhaul mods of any game I've ever played. I have easily played more than 2000 hours between this and its expansion thanks to the sheer variety of worlds people have added to the game. It is not without its flaws and especially fans of newer Total Wars may have a hard time adapting to its building and replenishment systems but overall I can not recommend this game highly enough.

Some great mods to check out
Third Age Total War (Lord of the rings)
Westeros Total War (Game of Thrones/ASOIAF)
Call of Warhammer (Almost as good as the new official Warhammer Total Wars)
Hyrule Total War (Legend of Zelda)
Thera Legacy of the Great Torment (Original creation combining factions from all different time periods and settings like Romans vs. Mammoth riding Native Americans or Uruks vs. Samurai
This has been my favorite game. I was really excited when this released after Medieval Total War.

I put hundreds of hours into this game back when it was new and I had a physical copy.  Now that my disc is all scratched up, I thought it was time to switch to digital.

An excellent title, and my first Total War game.  The base game is great, the expansion is better, the battles are fun, and everything just plays well.  Plus, watching thousands of troops slaughter each other is great fun, especially when you're doing most of the slaughtering.

It's also got a great modding scene:  Third Age: Total War (Lord of the Rings), Westeros: Total War (Game of Thrones), Hyrule: Total War (Legend of Zelda), Call of Warhammer (Warhammer Fantasy, although in this case you should probably get the actual Total War: Warhammer), and many, MANY more.  Lots of these mods have been worked on for years, giving this game a lifespan way longer than its already extensive base content.

There are a few flaws, like the squalor system and rebel system.  The former you can't really control so much as temporarily limit, and if you like long games like me you may find yourself fomenting revolts in your own cities so you can massacre the population to bring squalor back down.  The latter means that you can't get a region to be 100% guaranteed to not rebel, and since the game doesn't alert you when a new rebel army pops up, you have to manually scan your empire each turn for new rebels.  A lot of these flaws would be fixed in later games, but here they're just a minor annoyance and not a deal breaker.

Anyway, this is a must-have for strategy fans.

in short:
Great Campaign, best of all the total war games ever created. The golden standard for how a TW should be.
However, horribly clumsy troop movement on the battlefield.

I also played some hundred hours outside of Steam.

* * * * * * *
(+)
- you buy an actually whole game, no paid unlockable content (ULC)
- Largest unit variety of any TW
- many buildings and no stupid building slots like in succeder TWs
- city management: manage population growth, happiness, religion, squalor, ...; not dumped down like in succeeder TWs
- long campaign, from 1080 with leather armour wearing spearmen and peasant crossbowmen into the early rennaissance with musketeers and lanciers
- agents: spies, priests, assassins, merchants, diplomats; funny event videos
- events: plague, crusades, mongol invasion, gunpowder invented, ...
- characters: many ttraits and ancilliaries, your governers and generals do actually have a personality
- diplomacy: can trade regions
- family tree, form a true dynasty
- the Kingdoms expansion is an example for what an addon/DLC is SUPPOSED to be like
- many mods available and easily moddeable by yourself (just write in the game files)
- command console

(0)

There's not much to say. An old title of the Total War Series, one of the games that forged its own history. For its age, the graphics are decent, the music is -as always- great, the battles are awesome and not 'laggy' and you're free to pick any nation from medieval Europe or the Middle East.
The Expansion, "Kingdoms" is -without a doubt- one of the largest expansions ever released for such a title, consisting of 4 campaigns taking you to a different time period in History. Discover the Americas as the Spanish or push back the invaders as the Aztecs, unify Ireland or establish English rule over the isles, join the Crusades or capture the Holy Land with Saladin's Army, take control of the Teutonic Order and spread Catholicism in the Baltic or bring the peoples of the region under Russian rule.
At this point, I'd like to thank and praise the work of countless nameless individuals who created a large number of mods, regarding all game aspects. Their voluntarily work makes the game even greater.

Like every Total War game, Medieval II is a turn-based strategic game. Whilst playing this game you opt for total world domination. Meaning that you will be taking over cities and wipe out nations with the force of an army. The major factor to fuel this war is 'money', By strategically building cities, paved roads, market places and docks you can recruit merchants to do the trading for you. 

The game is restriced at five nations at the start. Meaning you can only play as: England, France, The Holy Roman Empire, Scotland and France. Upon completion of the campaign you will be unlocking 12 additional factions to play as. 

This game involves a lot of strategic depth. The combat system that comes with this game may be found quite complex at the start. After a few hours into the game and having encountered some battles on the field yourself you will notice that the combat system is quite understandable. 

To sum things up; If you're in the market for a quick or long strategy game in which you can put dozens of hours- this would be the game for you. If you are a casual player, a single quick campaign can last you for a good week of play-time! The long campaign is able to settle you for a staggering two weeks or even a month!

Of all the historical Titles:

Rome is the Grandaddy of the Total War world, the one everybody flocks too for advice and reminiscence,

Empire, the child of the group, brings on new things, but ultimately lacks maturity and direction in the world,

Napoleon is our Young Adult, a more refined child basically,

Shogun 2 is the sleeper Aunt from abroad you dont see too much but have a cracking time with whenever she is over,

Rome 2 is the Uncle who, whenever he shows his face, ends up making everyone uncomfortable in one way or another,

but

Medieval 2 is the Glorious Grandmother that everyone cant help but love. She's more wizened than Rome and in charge too, [even though he acts like he is, (she lets him)]. She is what binds and glues the family together and where the true fans flock for a story or two every few years at the very least. She will live on forever, strong, wise, and absolutely Perfect.

As a long time Total War fan, having played the majority of titles since Rome Total War released back in 2004, I can't recommend this game enough. Creative Assembly got so many things right with this game that I even find it difficult playing other turn-based strategy games without accidentally comparing and eventually returning to this masterpiece.

Everything about it just screams love, care and attention - from the subtly different factions, the variety of maps to fight on, the global events (Mongols ftw anyone!?), the Pope/cardinal mechanic, the Americas being colonisable late game (long past the campaign victory, just for people who have global domination in mind). I have nothing bad to say about this title.

As someone who now spends most of his waking life playing Mortal Empires (in my opinion, the best release since this game), returning to this is admittedly a graphical struggle... but even in the newer titles I long for the mechanics of the old.

This is Golden Age video gaming at its finest, and I doubt we'll see another title as well crafted as this for its time. A definite must have for anyone into ANY strategy gaming, that doesn't mind a bit of blockiness to get that epic feel.

The total war franchise has always been known for its realistic and accurate historical backgrounds.
Medieval 2 is no exception and is possibly the best game of the series,with the exception of the newly released Warhammer. Although the graphics are not mind-blowing(expected as this is an old game), the experience is truly great.
The AI works well enough so that even early on,you can't just throw everything at the walls and see what sticks.
In my opinion what makes it better than Attila or Rome is the fact that not only did those have severe bugs and crashes,the system requirements were pretty unrealistic and very few people actually were happy with it or enjoyed them.
Last,but definitely not least, the modding community is alive and vibrant.
I CANNOT stress this enough, the mods make this game such a joy to play,whether it is the Third Age Total War Lord of The Rings modification which is fabulous or the stainless steel mod which improves the overall play.
Neither the Rome or Attila games have any mods that come near these.
If you can get Warhammer and run it on your PC well,great but otherwise,this is probably the second best game in the series.

The fact that I have 1,000 hrs on record with this game is not surprising considering there are multiple ways to  play and with several different factions involved. The game may look dated, but in some respects it maintains somewhat of an edge in my opinion over its more modern variations. For me, it's the fact that I can utilize any space on the battle map, and it represents it's own unique landscape. There are no naval battles, which are done automatically (they appear in Empire) but there is are seige battles, which are done rather well with the occasional pathfinding issue by some unit sprites. 

There are also some issues with the AI as well as reputation, which is almost near impossible to recover from if you ended up doing something cutthroat like violate a treaty. There are mods that can fix AI issues, update graphics, and other assorted implements which extends the shelf-life of a game like this. However, most of the time spent playing this game was done mod free which only reinforces my belief that it a really fun game and I find myself personally surprised at having put so much time into one game.

The vanilla version is great, but just like all Total War games the mods really make this one of the best strategy games.

Quick highlight: Real time battles mixed with a turn based campaign, you control a country and their ruling family with the goal of building armies and conquering your neighbor countries. The map covers most of Europe with North Africa and the Middle East.

Pros: Battles are very satisfying when you win, timeplan spans hundreds of years, you can follow the members of your royal family as they are born, achieve great victories, and die. There are a lot of mods that greatly enhance the game.

Cons: Very little depth, there isn't much to getting a robust economy other than growing in size; there is very little political intrigue inside your own family (ala Game of Thrones style); and armies can be over simplified. There are only twenty two countries, and the game is called Total War for a reason: allies do not exist.

Overall great game, give it a try if you're looking for a game where you can rewrite history.

I finally have enough hours to make a review on this game..

Medieval 2: Total War is an extremely entretaining game. This is one of the early total wars, dating back to 2005-2006. Unlike newer versions, such as Rome 2 and Warhammer, Medieval 2 has a different battle feeling, which is hard to describe, but if you ask me, is way better than these two newer versions. I myself prefer it to the newer versions.

The game offers you limited amount of factions in the beginning, but once you win with any of them, you will be able to choose any faction you wish, from Scotland to Egypt. Mongols and Timurids, which are invading armies aren't playable (for campaing), though. Maybe with mods.

As for the Kingdoms expansion, it has proven itself worth the money. Adds four new campaigns: Britannia, Americas, Teutonic and Crusades, each of it has it's own unique feeling. This expansion also adds new factors, such as the boiling oil siege defense, which is missing in the normal version and can be really helpful, especially in early game.

The tactics works a little different in here too. In Rome 2, for example, should you surround an enemy, they would break. In here, however, instead of breaking the surrounded unit will fight to death. Cavalry also has more use and diversity here.

Sadly, the naval battles here are fought automatically. General Bodyguards are more useful and are probably by far the best units in game, even though using them would put in risk the general himself. Well used, the general can eliminate even enemy spearmen(Generals are on horse) easily, with few losses. The campaign in general is very different, too. You need to pay refill a damaged unit.

The only lacking points would be the AI, which at times is just plain stupid both in battle and campaign, the pope and the diplomacy. I managed to use a damaged unit with three average heavy infanty soldiers to stand near towers close to the AI's army, and the towers killed over 30% of their army. The pope will annoy you at first, forcing you to make peace with your neighbours that attacked you, for example. As for diplomacy, wars are endless. It usually will only end if you get the lower hand in the dealings, and even if it does, the AI will just attack you after 10 turns max.

So that would be it, Medieval 2: Total War, nice game, with some flaws, but doubtlessly, a masterpiece considering the time it was made. A game enjoyable until this day and one of the best of the series.

Would be my favorite Total War game if just for the sheer mods alone, but sadly, it isn't, because of a few major problems.

1. AI pathfinding, the pathfinding in this game in sieges particularly is pants on head retarded, as exhibited by this video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RF4UPzmMl84. Though playing on smaller unit sizes can help to alleviate this, the problem is still very prevalent, so prevalent that you have to consider yourself lucky to have the siege AI actually attack your fort.

2. Siege AI, the AI is beyond terrible, with a large chance of it just sitting there, allowing you to kill it's men with archers and ballistae while they sit idly, or shuffle between one command and another, never making up their mind, running in circles.

3. Clunky controls, this can be gotten used to, but it will always leave a bad taste in my mouth compared to the modern controls of the newer games.

Now, pros about this game are:

1. Good campaign AI, gone are the days (or yet to come) of diplomats threatening you with horse whippings for attempting to make a trade deal (Empire), gone are the days of AI sitting back and doing nothing all game until you walk over them (Rome II), if you choose very hard on this game you can actually expect a moderate challenge, which is an A+ compared to the pathetic show from Rome II.

2. Family trees, interesting character traits, and generals you actually give a damn about. In Rome II, Attilla, and all the games following Medieval II, there has been a severe lack of fucks about your generals. In Rome II I remember using my general as a vanguard unit, if he happened to die I would just replace him, immediately, without consequence. In Medieval II choosing the right general can make or break a campaign, and losing him would be a big blow to your conquests. Generals/Family members in this game also gain experience based on actions taken in battle, such as if your general refrains from killing an enemy unit for some battles, he may develop cowardice, compared to Rome II which just gives a random trait based on RNG.

3. Better settlement improvement, are you tired of having to use an entire portion of your capital city to build a church in Rome II? Don't worry about that here son, because you can build whatever you want in your cities, provided it has the proper population, which is represented by actual ingame numbers. All the improvements will have a visible effect on the city. For example, if you build a blacksmith, it will show up in the battle for that settlement. Build a grand temple to God? It will show up in the battle. Have a wooden walled settlement and upgrade it to stone walls? You now have actual stone walls. The game is given life in this, so much that if you build up your capital it will look like a real fucking capital when it's sieged, unlike the newer games where all the cities are made by artists, so only Rome/Constantinople have that grand feel.

4. Mods mods mods, mods make this game shine over every other Total War game. Have you ever wanted to journey into the world of J. R.R. Tolkien? To fight against the Aldmeri Dominion as the Cyrodilic Empire? To fight for Skyrim's independence? To journey into the world of Warhammer? There are massive professional mods for each of these things, just waiting to be played. Mods a scope which can never be matched in future games, due to the Creative Assembly's blatant anti Modding policy (to support future games and DLC).

In the end, for all the flaws this game has, it is still one of, if not the best Total Wars around, so go ahead and give it a try.

For an 11 year old game Medieval:Total war still delivers, the graphics have still kept up after 11 years and the gameplay is solid, my only problem with this game is that the battle AI is still quite poor and can easily be baited out in some situations, not as much as Rome:Total wars though. The game also keeps you interested from start to finish with a constant flow of new events which change the way you play the game or your endgame goals. Each faction also feels completely different from one another and encourages different playstyles, for example the French's selection of units encourage a balance between an attack and defense approach, whereas the Byzantine empire encourages a more aggressive playstyle with a focus on picking your enemies off with horse archers before your army assaults. I would deam this game the best in the Total War franchise, although not as developed (strategically) as Shogun:Total war, the game is still great. This game is stilll great after 11 years and I predict it still will be great in the next 11 years.
