Trying my hardest to see this game without any sense of nostalgia. Still, its absolutely amazing! Used to play this maybe hundreds of hours throughout my childhood, and before it the prequel. The game is improved in a lot of ways than the previous Medieval. Better Diplomacy options, more detailed espionage and agent systems, way better graphics both in campaign and in battle, to name a few. A couple of things you may not like about this game however: 

-You can't win without going into war. The only goal is to hold 10-40 regions depending on your campaing length and hold Jerusalem-Constantinople etc. There are no culture-science-diplomatic victories like in the Civilization games.
-The steam version may not be %100 stable. I had a couple of crashes and i hear some people cant even get to run the game. Hope they fix it with a patch soon
-You cant choose the time period you want to start in like in the previous game. No more starting in late period to immediately start kicking some mongolian butt (no offense to mongolians irl)
-As you progress into the later stages of the game, it keeps you waiting in other faction's turns (Milanese spies please stop)

8/10. Would easily give 10/10 if it had less stability issues.

This is the best total war and here are the reasons why:
1. Has only one EXPANSION (not dlc) that costs around the same amount as the age of charlamagne from attila: total war and add FOUR new campaigns not only one.
2. The engine allows modders to make campaign maps which gave us GREAT and I mean it when I say GREAT mods like The third age or Westeros Total war.
3. Still has an active community.
4. You can have blood in the game without paying any money.

TLDR;
Pros:
-Even without expansions the game is a full game (unlike recent TW)
-Awesome and reasonably realistic historical atmosphere
-great strategic gameplay without all the fluff of recent TW games
-Easy to mess with settings in files
-Lots of factions and Units, Expansions rock, hours of fun.
Cons:
-combat can be a little quirky
-dated graphics
This is without a doubt my favorite video game of all time. It's one of the last great TW games. Without any expansions, it is a complete game with a large map, many factions, and a campaign that feels really open ended. The units are fairly diverse and the expansions each add an awesome, unique campaign with great factions. Moreover, it's really simple to mess around with some settings files and unlock all the factions (even the rebels) and mess around with other settings. The game is straight forward, but can be challenging and rewarding, it lacks all the unnecessary fluff added in later TW. It's obvious that this game was developed by people who really had a passion for history and fun historical-strategic gameplay, and not just a bunch of money hungry jerks who want you to pay up to 200 USD for a full, buggy TW game. Honestly, if you don't care about graphics, and just want a fun, engaging, historical strategic experiences, that you'll enjoy for hundreds of hours and numerous play throughs, get this game and the expansions. It's beyond worth it.

Overall i recommend the game but I havent played the DLC and so cant say if that is any good.

Playing as the Kingdom of France....

In the year of 1150 His Holiness the pope declares Crusade on the infidels, in Tunis. As the protector of Christendom I heeded his call, gathered my armies and sailed to Tunis. 
My army, lead by the king, consisting thousand good archers, spearmen, and chivalrious knights, layed siege to their capital. Soon the papal armies arrived and joined the siege. After a wait, we decided to onslaught their citadel. 
My army, with tremendous losses, and with constant asking where the fuck is that dick Papal commander, and his army, slaughtered the entire garrison. With my remainig army (the king and his 20 bodyguard, so yeah it was a hell of a siege) scoured the battlefield after the papal armies. We found them, under the castle, Thousands, upon thousands warriros, and siege engines. And this was the time, when they marched in the city, and claimed for themselves.
I withdrew to France, and now i plan to visit, His Holiness in Rome, with five fully upgraded army behind my back. Christendom will tremble, and the Pope will cry.. Brace yourself, we are coming.

Started my first game as England, and learned through the little tutorial speach bubbles how to play. And I got to tell you, after 25 hours of playtime, I've had a lot of fun. This game let's you do A LOT, so let me give a few examples: If you don't like the Pope, send your best trained assassin after him, and he'll take a crossbow to the Pope's chest, and better yet, when your priests are basicly in control of the college of cardinals, replace the Pope with one of your priests, and in the beggining, it will work well for you, before you just want this Pope to die already as well. I also went on a couple of crusades(I was playing on easy difficulty, as I do for all new games I try out) one of these crusades brought me to the middle east, where I decided to spread the holy word of Jesus to the savage people of Egypt. I sacked their villages, and recruited priests and built churches in the towns, which made many loyal followers of the cross. I own 2 Total War games, This and Attila, and I only got Attila for The AOC DLC. Attila has some great features (manual aiming catapults for one), but Medieval 2 is definitely the better game out of the box. I had to mod the hell out of Attila before I started enjoying it (I still don't really like the Main Campaign). This game does have drawbacks though.

Pros:
-Medieval era, with eventual gunpowder/cannons development
-Runs well even on potatoes
-A few great mods like TATW,MOS,DAC (MOS is probably ~200 of my hours)
-Cavalry is actually useful in battle (rohirrim style charges)
-Spearmen can actually hold the line
-Cool battle maps
-You can actually pick out captains/generals from their units. They're the fancy looking ones (not a big deal, just neat, also very helpful for targeting them to break the enemy's morale)
-Can play as almost any faction without having to pay for them, unlike Attila

Cons:
-Diplomacy flat out sucks in my opinion. There's not really an "affinity" system like in Attila, so you don't really know where you stand with other factions. Also, allies you make may very well turn on you, or each other without warning. Trust no one. Especially the HRE.
-The game is from 2006, so graphics and animations are definitely not up to today's standards.
-No General's abilities apart from rallying horn. They're just heavy cavalry that are vital to morale.
-Artillery is very innacurate. No pinpoint shots like in Attila.
-The Pope is a pain in the ass
-DLC is actually worth paying for. 4 new campaigns for ~$1.50 (on sale) 

I haven't played vanilla in a while, so I may not remember all that 100%, and I may have forgotten to mention a few things. But overall, It's a great game

A strategy game with few peers, Medieval II kicks ass. Considering it was released in 2006 this game not only holds up to scrutiny over a decade later, but I'd say it's still superior to many stategy games on the market today. While the graphics aren't very good by today's standards, the game more than makes up for it with expansive gameplay. You can commit hundreds of hours to a single play-through and still have tons more content to get through. And the quality doesn't diminish with time. Granted, there are glitches galore and the UI for civilization management leaves much to be desired, there are mods for just about everything you want, fixed or otherwise, and excepting Attila, I can't think of a time Total War has topped this rendition.

Medieval 2 Total War is an exciting, action packed tactical game with a habit of always catching the player off gaurd. If your new to Total War games or already an experienced player, I would still reccomend this game to you regardless. Despite the games age it still beats most modern Total War games to date in my opinion. The campaign does a brilliant job of absorbing the player into the game and planting the player into an actual faction leaders shoes in medieval times. it does this by presenting the player with problems such as conquering lands, defending castles from invaders, making strong alliances and trade rights with fellow factions, religion, population and wealth throughout your kingdom. And just as you think you have the game figured out and maybe you are two steps ahead, a curve ball is thrown at you and just like that you are in an entirley different position. 
I highly reccomend this game to anyone interested in Total War games so they might share the same experiences with the game as i have.

I would argue that Medieval II is the best entry into the Total War series. While it's perhaps not as iconic as Rome I or Empire, and it certainly is not as flashy as newer entries like Warhammer, it is arguably the most varied.

On top of not having any faction restrictions (once you beat a campaign once), each faction feels distinct. Everyone starts out with roughly the same units and buildings, but once the mid-game is reached, the factions diverge considerably. Very few factions share castle-built units and the ones that are shared are early-game units.

The mechanics are all straightfoward and easy to learn. There aren't multiple towns in a province to manage, just the main settlement. Settlements only come in two varieties: towns and castle. Towns make money, castles make faction-specfic military units. Taxes are on a settlement-by-settlement basis, so you can tax London to death, but leave Edinbough lightly taxed.

Lastly, the game doesn't pull many punches. Even playing on normal, the AI will backstab you, refuse to cooperate, and handle you roughly.

As with all of the Total War games, you can see a bit of the next game in each preceeding title. Medieval II is a bit of Rome I and a bit of Empire. Plus, the DLC is actually worth getting, giving you new campaigns to play and not just a new faction that should probably have been playable from the start.

Medieval II is not without its flaws, however. The Senate missions from Rome I make a return in the form of Papal Decrees (if you're a Catholic nation) or the occasional Jihad (if you're Muslim nation). The UI isn't nearly as slick as Empire and beyond. Finally, obviously, the graphics show their age.

Overall, Medieval II is my favorite entry in the series, probably the best entry overall, and definitely the best value for money

I own and have played every TW title from Medieval I to Warhammer. Of all these, although I do enjoy them all and play them frequently (except for Medieval I which frankly is too archaic and I can no longer stomach), my favorite is still Medieval II. Although the graphics are of course a bit outdated and it lacks some features we have come to take for granted in later games, such as tech trees, it still can be considered mainstream. You don't feel it to be that different from more modern TW games, which cannot be said about Rome I or Medieval I. On the other hand, Med II has some features that sometimes are missing in later games, such as family lines and royal marriages. Mods such as Stainless Steel further help to keep the game enjoyable and actual. Finally, it is the only TW game covering the Middle Ages period, which for many of us is paradigmatic for the type of warfare depicted in these games.

Overall I give it 4 stars; 5 stars if you dismiss the graphics factor.

This game mind-boggles me. Released all the way back from 2006 and it has better game mechanics and layouts then Attila and WARHAMMER. You can tell this isn't a cash grab like all the other Total Wars becuase, in order to unlock factions, you have to play the game and conquer the faction you want to play as instead of buying them(with the exception of England, France, Venice, Holy Roman Empire, Spain and a few others). For example if your England and you want to play as Scotland all you need to do is march a stack up there and take Edinburgh and the next time you start a campaign you'll see Scotland as playable. Besides graphics, the detail game mechanics wise is the main reason why I love this game. When you recruit units, the city your recruiting from loses some of its population. When you need to refill a unit you have to find a city that can recruit that unit and retrain them there. If you want to trade or sign a non-aggresion pact, you need a diplomat agent and you have to send him to the country you want to talk to and theres plenty more. 
        Sadly there isn't a multiplayer campiagn and there isn't sea battles(weren't mnade till Empire) but there is, of course, normal player v. player battles. Considering the price compared to other Total Wars, and considering that the there is a endless list of mods and almost no DLC (Kingdoms is a must-have if you want to play mods), AND its positive reviews, you should 100% buy this game.

While it's not my favourite of the Total War games (that honour goes to the first ROME: Total War, mainly due to the period in which it's set and, well, Romans!), Medieval II is a near perfect grand turn-based strategy game. It polishes the format established by its predecessors into a slick, easy to use and quite magnificent product. The graphics still stand up well now in 2017, while the gameplay is quite superb. A few niggling irritations such as the frequent "Path Blocked" issues during a long journey on a crusade don't really detract from the whole, while the religion angle is skilfully handled and well integrated. Catholic nations have to be careful to keep the Pope happy (a slight problem for, say, England - surrounded by other Catholic nations where attacking anybody is highly frowned on by the Papacy); Muslim ones have to be always on their guard in case of an incoming swarm of European Crusaders. Diplomacy is quite often ignored by the AI: allies can turn on you without so much as a moment's notice, and the tides of war are such that in the space of a few turns, you can go from swarming across the campaign map, to being driven back into your heartlands with nothing left but a few ragged half-trained armies.

And as if your neighbours aren't enough trouble, wait until the Mongol hordes begin to arrive...

my favorite total war game in the series.  you'll spend hours fighting, conquering and most importantly having fun. the game is  full of tiny details that seem to never make it in contemporary titles. the sound effects and music give a truly medieval feeling and the battles are simply epic, from grand decisive battles with full stacks, to minor skirmishes with small groups of soldiers. this game is the peak of the total war games and combines the best features that were removed along with excellence that inspires players to continue to play the newer titles. if you were a fan of the newer or older games in the total war series, or if you are looking for a fun new game you haven't played before, I highly suggest you pick this up. This game is also highly moddable. There are hundreds of mods that vary from historical to fantasy settings such as the Broken Crescent mod which focuses on the Crusades, Roma Surectum 2 which makes the game into a Roman Empire era mod, Third Age Total War which is a LoTR mod and lastly Beginning of the End Times which is a Warhammer mod.

DEUS VULT

Man, as a fan of real time strategy games that mix in management mechanics here and there, this game really comes off as a masterclass to me. I would argue Rome Total War has a few more loving touches (I guess holdovers of a bygone era in CA) than this game, but Medieval 2 has captivated way more than RTW ever did. It's kinda hard to describe what makes this game so killer. Every good non linear game has a loop. Some cycle that the game follows that constantly delivers the player conflict and resolution in satisfying and diverse ways. This game's cycle is, condensed; raising an empire from a few territories that can muster only a few useless peasants, making mates with some blokes or raiding their settlements for personal gain (you can't argue the game doesn't provide some riveting player choice), accruing a few key settlements you have been eyeing for turns and can now use to turn the tide in a war you have been embroiled in for ages, completely swallowing that once huge empire, and then turning to THEIR former neighbours for potential land. It's...it's not subtle. It's quite blunt, it's silly, and it is goddamn satisfiying as all hell. 


Now, a breif note: as a historian this game is conflicting at best. It does a good job at tossing in events, at getting some level of accuracy on the outfits and architecture, and properly representing more than just the standard lot of European countries. I'm pretty tired of Eurocentrism in the field and it's always refreshing to see Creative Assembly putting equal effort into capturing the Ottomans as they do the Germans. However....oh heavens. Does it get some stuff wrong. I mean what on earth are those strategies? And why on earth does Russia have so many archers? What is with that? Basically, if you have an eye for historical accuracy and are also familar with CA's other stuff, you know your lot. You'll raise your eyebrow, indignantly show off how much "smarter you are than those fools at CA and Sega", and then sink tens of hours into it.
This is the best game ever. of all time.

Englands hold had risen over the lands on the north, and jelusy began to spread. The Holy Roman Empire was one of the few who yearned for the spoils of conquest, that which rich England could provide. And so the war began.
A fortress, holding the old danish peninsula, was the site of a meeting of the great lords of England upon the mainland. There was Ambrose, cousin to King Rufus, apointed high general. There were two Generals, who had shown renown and resolve in the great Denmark invasion. Then there was John, far younger brother to the king, who had recently been apointed command. His wife, newly wed as they were, begged him not to go. But John did, knowing that his country needed him.
While there, the Imperials struck hard and fast, with a large army. They needed the peninsula for any hope of invading the north, and so brought a army that rivaled the entire peninsula's garison in size. Hearing this, John quickly saddled up, and with the assistance of Jeram (one of the generals) they rode out beyond the gates to turn the tides. The enemy, not suspecting of such heroics, marched forth lossly, and with equipment far away from forces. The two untits of brave men, mounted and baring steel, charged forth, first splintering the ladders, then burning the towers, finaly crashing into the backs of the advancing spearmen. By the time the enemy reached the fortress walls, there was little enough to think of, and arrows brought the weary soldiers swift end.
The great victory came at cost however, and Jearam and his band of knights had been slaughtered where they stood, in a final act of compasion for their country. That day, the frankish prisoner's heads rolled upon the ground. John swore an oath in revenge, and an oath to help when he could. The chance came sooner than though, for upon his return, dire news was found. The Holy Roman Emprire marched south, with another levied army. The soldiers there were unprepared and without comander.
John volunteered, and with a parting kiss to his beloved, and a strong drink with his friends, he set off. John Dreadlord was on the path to save his peaople, and to cause his enemies fear. However, on the road, he was beset upon by two whole legions of spearmen. He and his knights used supirior tatics, and with a final blow of the horn and a charge, the Imperials fell. The prisoners soon followed their compaitriots. The men laughed, and cheered for John Dreadlord. The people would be safe yet. Untill the army arived.
Did John and his men cry in dispair? No, Never! The Dreadband was strong, and despite the odds, and despite the gaurentee of death, they rode their horses still. "Forward!" comes the shout and the ranks upon ranks move forward. The knights laugh that laugh, a humor born of grusome thought and spilled blood upon your blade. John Dreadlord looked upon the enemy, and smiled, for his revenge was complete. A young man once, now a vetran general, feared throughout Europe from only a battle. An awnsering "Forward' was procured, and in a deed more brave than all the battles of King William or any man ever after, the lances came down, the voices cried loud, and England lost the strongest fighter the world has ever seen. 72 enemy died, 6 by young John's hand.

In my opinion this is the peak of Total War franchise, with just few a minor issues that are more a minor annoyance than a legit deal-breaker (how towns are split into city for money and castle for troops, merchant management, diplomatic AI being braindead), aaaand that's about it. Other reviews mention dated graphics -- I disagree. This game may be dated on a technical level, but from a purely aesthetic standpoint it perfectly captures what I want to see out of a game about huge medieval-fantasy armies clashing. Yes, I said fantasy, as let's be honest -- the game has frakking CANNON ELEPHANTS and Russian musketeers in 1300s that have better melee stats than a good half of other factions' melee units.

Easily in my top5 fav. games of all time.

Also, no DLC -- just one proper, big expansion. It truly was a better time.

I love this game. I must have over 1000 hrs on the Disc version, since I've been playing it since it first came out. The steam version is nice to own in an era where some of our old PC discs are becoming unsusable and new ones are scarcer and harder to find.

This is classic total war at its peak in my opinion. It uses the older engine, which is far better than the newer one.

There are plenty of factions to play as, though admittedly, a lot feel a bit "samey" aside from a few quirks. Example: The four italian factions all have a very similar roster with only a few key differences. Understandable, since they are all located in the same geographic area, but after 10+ years, you end up wishing there was more variety.

That is where mods come in. To take full advantage of mods, you'll need the Kingdoms expansion pack. However, the Steam version doesnt have good mod support. This title would greatly benefit from a steam workshop of some sort. While some of the greatest mods are compatabile with the Steam version like Third Age: Total War, Stainless Steel, and Rise of Three Kingdoms work with flying colors, others like Custom Campaign 2, Lands to Conquer Gold, and Kingdoms Grand Campaign are seemingly incompatable with the steam version.

I'm aware that this more a responsibility of these mod teams than Steam, but it would be nice to have more integration and have the Steam version be more readily accepting of mods.

And can you people stop it. This is not an RTS! This a turn based strategy and real time tactcis game. This is not a real time strategy game. Enough is enough!

I want to love this game. I really do. I've been looking for a good grand strategy game for awhile, so I jumped on this deal when I learned I had several friends playing this.

I can't exit the game or do a proper shut down when it freezes, so I have to cut the power. My laptop has much better specs than neccesary, and has had no previous problems with other games.

I can't go into to options to try to fix anything. That also freezes it. 
I have 104 minutes logged on this game. Would probably be more counting the freezes. I still haven't actually PLAYED during any of that time. I've wasted 3 day's free time trying to get this to work. Very seriously considering refunding.

I know this game has great reviews and looks great in videos. I'm sure it is great. I just can't experience that, so I can't consider it in my review.

I want to give this game a 10/10. I bet I would if it worked.

 But it doesn't work. It's a 0/10

I love the middle ages and am very intrested in that time. the Crusades, the wars and how each army was used. and how people just interacted. this game is one of the best games ive ever played. 

Pros
-Solid Campaign, will make you want to play every country
-Each Country feels different. countries very similar like egypt and turkey will not have the same units
-managing cities is very fun
-sounds horrific but killing entire cities and making them worship your relgion... yeah lol
-able to create an empire. My Holy roman empire covered all of western europe ( Not spain, they were giving me money not to kill them all ) all the way into Russia, from Norway down to north central africa and even in the New World.
-Battles are amazing. i played as england and fought the mogolians in the Holy Land. I thought using spears would help me but it did not. the Mogols knew i would do this and didnt take the bait, instead kept shooting arrows on my men. i then had my horses attack the Mongol flanks and the horse archers were forced away. i thyen had my longbow men advance behind my spears until the Heavy horses had no choice but to attack my lines. i thought id win and lose a million times until the mongols were beaten. 
- it doesnt feel like rock paper, each until has pros and cons but all arent stupid. archers can fight off heavy cav but is it a good idea, no because youll lose a lot. alot depends on momentum.
- a ton of other stuff that are smaller, in my opinion its the small stuff that makes a game

cons
- mostly limnited to the old engine. but it doesnt matter brcause everything else makes up for it

Your forced to get out of your castle in order to defend it Witch makes no sense. If you lose your General, all your units give up, but if you kill your opponents General they get 0 Morale loss.

I will have to say at this point in time, Medieval 2 is my favorite in the series for sure. I have heard people criticize the campaign AI but I genuinely feel it is some of the best campaign AI in the series. My all-time greatest strategy gaming memories come from this title.

I recall a specific example of the amazing campaign AI when one of my long-time allies thought they had a chance at some of my territory and decided to turn on me and try to cut my empire in half. I immediately decimated their armies and took a third of their territory. They were so terrified at being utterly destroyed that I convinced them to give me another third of their territory in exchange for a truce. The end result was that they lost the vast majority of their empire and nearly all of their military strength. I never had to park troops anywhere near my borders with them again. We made peace and went back to being allies with trading rights and they never even thought about expanding again. For over 100 years they were a lesser power that knew their place under my reign as the dominant European faction.

I could go on with further examples but I won't bore you. The battle AI isn't the best in the series but is as good as the base AI in Rome. The mod community is expansive and the base campaign is incredibly well balanced and fun. I have my complaints but overall the game has significantly more positives than negatives. I can't recommend this title enough.

This is probably one of the best Total War games and it is worth all the money!

[b]PROS:[/b]
+ huge campaign map
+ a LOT of various factions available to play
+ fun & tactical gameplay
+ interesting units
+ town upgrades & logistics
+ TONS of cool mods
+ medieval times atmosphere
+ Kingdoms DLC adds 4 new (separate) campaign maps

[b]Comment:[/b]
Just like RTW I finally bought this game here on Steam so I would have a digital copy of it as my discs are getting old. And it is worth purchasing because it is a phenomenal RTS game and a great addition to the Total War series. The graphics have aged a bit but the game still looks good. Multiplayer is fun but the single-player campaign is what takes the cake. A huge map with many factions to choose from initially, later each defeated nation is unlocked as playable in the campaign. The gameplay is divided into 3 parts just like in RTW - cities management, sea battles and land battles. The management is great but the land battles are what makes this a classic. Most of the units, even siege engines, are nicely done and serve a purpose. The fighting is tactical and fair, although sometimes rather difficult. The AI still has some problems but usually just minor issues. On top of all this are the mods, the INCREDIBLE mods. There are so many it would be hard to write all the good ones but MY personal favourites are Stainless Steel, Europa Babarorum 2 & Third Age Total War. This game is worth your money if you like RTS games and is a great successor to RTW!

What a classic!

It's a great game that makes me reminisce about my childhood. All in all, for modern players who haven't got a PC that can't run a more modern TTW game, curious people who want to play an old TTW title, or people like me who like to reminisce. Plus there is an excellent mod called: The Third Age: Total War, which is basically a Lord of the Rings conversion, which has numerous expansions and an entire campaign, the amount of work gone into the mod is amazing and I highly, HIGHLY recommend it to any LOTR fans. Anyway, back to the base game...

GAMEPLAY:

So like any TTW game, there are two maps, the campaign and the battle map. On the campaign map, you can see all of the main settlements within view and other objects like armies, spies, merchants, diplomats etc... This is where you manage your faction, build structures within your settlements and recruit troops. You move your armies around the map and engage enemy armies or settlements. You can then choose whether to auto-run the battle, or play it yourself on the battle map, where you will move your troops around in real-time, either on an open map or in a siege battle depending on the circumstances. 

You have a family tree which evolves throughout the years, some may die from diesease, others in battles and most from old age. Is basically like Crusader Kings, but a lot less in depth. Your faction will have victory conditions which will need fulfilling to complete the game, which will unlock a lot more playable factions. 

So yeah, it's a classic TTW game.

GRAPHICS AND SOUND:

Well it's not a very demanding game, so you'll be able to run it on most low budget pc systems. But the graphics definitely aren't terrible! There are some graphic overhaul mods out there too for those of you who have better systems.
Sounds are great for the style and age of the game. 

PROS:
- Good in-depth strategy game
- Great battles
- Good amount of unique factions
- Good DLC
- Inexpensive
- Not very demanding in terms of system power
- Awesome mod

CONS:
- Outdated (but still worth playing!)

OVERALL:

It's the perfect game for people who desire a good strategy game for a low-budget system and for those who want to try a classic TTW game too, I also recommend Rome: Total War!

At over ten years old, this game has held up really, really well. It stands up to me as one of the best Total Wars of those I've played (Shogun, Rome I, Rome II, Medieval II, a few mods.) I have spent over 350 hours on it, and so I couldn't possibly not recommend it, certainly in terms of money spent to time played, this is one of the best purchases I have ever made. 

Firstly, the good points: Medieval II builds on all the good ideas in Rome I: the gameplay is solid, and the AI is notably smarter than in Rome (not really saying much to be honest. In Rome II it's notably smarter than in Medi II.) The smaller battles generally feel fun and interesting - watching a cavalry charge send enemy peasants flying as the horses and men collide is satisfying on a basic gut level - and there is genuine satisfaction in causing a huge enemy force to rout and sending your men in to run them down. Your generals are fun to manage and it's great watching them develop traits that are influenced by the battles. (For example a general that gets hurt in combat will develop "scarred" traits, increasing his hit points, and one that executes prisoners and sacks cities will devleop "dreaded" traits making him scarier - maybe if he's a real psycho he'll get his own torturer!

Now the negatives: At times the game feels like a lot of good ideas that weren't tested properly. For example, the Pope will threaten you with excommunication (in game terms this translates to a public order penalty, making your cities more likely to rebel, and the worry that he may even ask other Catholic factions to send huge crusading armies to your cities.) The problem is that seemingly no matter what you do, the Pope is likely to threaten you with excommunication for any war against another Catholic factions. Very well, you may think. You'll only war with non-Catholic factions. However, unfortunately diplomacy in this game is totally broken. Thanks to an unfortunate unfixed bug even staunch allies are likely to stab you in the back. Even if you're the greatest power since the Roman Empire and their 'empire' is a loose collection of wooden castles they'll still eventually gather up a mob of peasants to send at your worst-defended city. And when you defend yourself, no matter how nice you are (releasing the prisoners instead of executing them as any Medieval ruler likely would for such blatant treachery) the Pope will tell you not to retaliate or face excommunication.

The alternative is to play as one of the non-Catholic factions, such as the Orthodox Russians and Byzantines, or the Muslim Turks, Egyptians or Moors. Sadly, this brings me to the second great but flawed idea: the Mongols. The Mongols attack with huge armies with amazing generals you are unlikely to be able to match and cannot hope to be better than. It's a great idea - give you a large and powerful enemy to battle as a real challenge, but while it is possible (albeit difficult) to beat them, it's just not very much fun. Usually it's the same endless slog of holding up in a castle, raining fire on them and then feeding them into the meat grinder of your spears. 

The final minor gripe is the unit selection. Unlike the Roman world where each culture felt quite distinct in terms of its army makeup, most factions, especially in the early game, feel very similar. In the West it's militia, knights and peasants with bows or crossbows, and in the East cavalry archers. Only Scotland and Denmark really feel unique to begin with. 

The Kingdoms expansion really adds more of the same, generally on a smaller and more intimate level. It's four new campaigns and really this is nothing to complain about. In my experience Britannia was a lot of fun to play, while the Crusades and Teutons campaigns were good for one playthrough each. The Americas discovery campaign wasn't great, but might be enjoyable if you want a challenge, either in city management (as the Spanish trying to convert the natives) or on the battlefield (the Aztecs / Mayans, trying to fight a much more advanced military force.)

As much as I've criticised in this review, these minor gripes really can't prevent me from recommending this as one of the best Total War games available, and a must for battlefield strategy fans. Buy this game, you won't regret it (except when you're exhausted at school or work because you stayed up until 3am conquering the Holy Land, because seriously, this game is  a time sink like you would not believe.) As an added bonus, it has a decent modding community who can add real variety to the game.

To me this is the pennicle of the Total War games, this is the best that it has ever gotten as a strategy game. It is easily the most sophisticated as well as difficult Total War games out there, in my opinion. You can use this to your advantage as well against your enemies.
Attacking countries that are Roman Catholic - Byzantines and the Russians, you will not be penalized and the same goes for conquoring the middle east.
Playing as the countries with different religions is also something that gives this game added depth, playing Muslim countries like Egypt, Turkey, the Mongols, and the Moors. The variety in gameplay is fantastic.

I would truly recomend this game for that very reason.

An absolute classic of the Total War series, I would still highly recommend the game to anyone who enjoys historical, strategy games, be that grand strategy or RTS. This edition really put Creative Assembly and the Total War franchise on the map, and drew in many fans for it's rich historical setting, diversity of challenge and sheer depth that means any campaign can take weeks to fully play through.

I highly recommend the Kingdoms expansion, all four of the more story-driven mini-campaigns are highly compelling, as you can fight for power, wealth, religion or just for kicks across the various intricate settings. I do recommend installing mods: particularly the Stainless Steel mod as this expands the campaign map significantly and adds more historical resonance to the gameplay.

Alright, so I've played the Total War series from the original Shogun: Total War, Rome: Total War, the Barbarian Invasion and Alexander Expansions, and when this game came out, I let out a hardy war cry of joy (not really, because people would think I was a bloody lunatic). I even played Empire and Napoleon (but they didn't feel as good to me). But trying to be as unbiased and from a modern perspective, I'm going to make a stab at reviewing this game.

Graphics: The graphics of this game isn't all that bad, but doesn't hold up to more modern titles and can appear a bit dated. Even so the graphics have aged surprisingly well and while not as smooth as some newer titles, it's servicable and really isn't all that bad for a decade-old title. 

Sound Design: The sound effects in this game aren't bad. I thought that the sounds might not hold up all that well, but I was glad to find I was mistaken. Everything from the sounds in the menu to the sounds of a firing cannon, crossbowmen winding up their weapons, or the sounds of a pitched melee, the sound design is still very good.

Music: Perhaps one of the parts of the game that really holds up well. The rendition of Ailein Duinn for the Britannia expanion is very well done. Honestly the OST is something I occasionally listen to from time-to-time. The music is very well composed, even impressive for a game, many of the tracks feel truly timeless and manage to fit in well with the period without being cheesy or feeling jarring. The orchestral work here is well worth a listen.

Gameplay: Don't let the amount of time I played on Steam fool you. I've probably 'wasted' an entire year or so of my life in game-hours on this game's cd version. After I lost the box and CD for a while, I re-purchased the Steam version to get my fix... and it's all because of the gameplay, that beautiful, sweet, delicious gameplay. Controls may be a bit odd for newcomers to the series, but after you get used to them it's like second-nature. Controls in battle are smooth, intuitive, and engaging. This game features both a world-map for grand strategy, but then breaks down into a tactical battlefield map in which you control units attempting to win individual battles with your guile. It's a great mix and I really wish other grand strategy titles would take up a similar formula.

Factions: Holy s*** does this game (and the expansions) have a good selection of factions. The core game only centers around Europe and North-most Africa, but the expansions do include the Americas. 

Mods: A section in its own right. Some modders have done amazing work adding in China, Japan, and the Warhammer fantasy mod on mod DB is freaking fantastic when you consider that the game engine is over a decade old now. Honestly I really wish I knew how they did it.

Overall: I was surprised to find that this game, after all these years, is still a timeless classic that's fun and engaging. For me this game ranks higher for playability and fun-factor than other, more popular titles. While Starcraft 1 and Dark Reign are still solid games nowadays, they feel dated and old when I play them, somehow Medieval II: Total War is immune to being dated. This is the game (that at least for me) sold the series, and has been a cherished title I return to again-and-again after all these years, if that isn't the hallmark of a great game, I don't know what is.

If you are new to Total War games, i would recommend this one above all the others, and i have played all of them other than the 2 latest ones. Atilla seemed to have too many issues,and Warhammer strayed too far from the historical game that Total war always was.

If you are not new to Total war games but you havent played this one, then i highly recommend playing this to see how these games should be made.

Step 1. Launch Crusader Kings II.

This game is fantastic when it comes to gameplay.You can read a ton of positive reviews on here,but I can't recommend this game to you if you want to play multiplayer,because it's simply 0 fun.

The mechanics are there,you can play against players like you can against AI but the performance,to put it frankly,is DREADFUL.

Once you get 3000-4000 units on the battlefield the game shits itself.You can run it at good fps with whatever your specs are,but the units just move for 0.1sec then stop for 0,3 sec and you barely get anything done!

I had the displeasure of playing a siege battle 3vs2 and just destroying the walls and getting our men through took 1h30min , I'm not joking.The whole battlefield looked like a Win 98 trying to run CS GO.
By the time the walls of the Castle were destroyed all fun had crumbled with them and there was immense frustration on both parties,that soon turned into a chat war for the simplest of things .. the game started with friendly attidude and the frustration from the wasted time turned into toxicity in seconds.

As far as I know this is an issue with other Total War titles as well.

Get this game if you want the amazing single player experience.
Do NOT waste your money for this game's multiplayer,because its unplayable. The only matches that work properly are 1v1s with less than 3000-4000 troops on the battlefield.Beyond that it's a spastic freakshow of swordmen,bowmen and pikemen suffering from Parkinsons' ...

This is still my favorite Total War (as of 2017), but I really just wanted to add another shout-out to the "Third Age" total conversion mod. I just repurchased M2TW here on steam, and after following a few community threads to the Third Age mod, I felt compelled to encourage others to try out Third Age : Total War. It's an incredible work of art, and an amazing addition to the TW library of campaigns and settings. Anyone who enjoyed Warhammer at all and still enjoys Medieval 2 should make the Third Age total conversion mod a priority on their to-play list--if you aren't playing it already.

This is the first Total War game I played, and what a title to break into the franchise with. I wish I could write a huge review about all the good things, but it's hard to describe a Total War game without taking too much time to do so. I'll just say that in my opinion it's the best Total War ever made, and it is as close to perfect as any title I have ever played for any game on any system. If you have played another Total War title and are thinking about trying out this one, DO IT! There are literally only two TINY, TINY things that I dislike about this game:

You cannot change the controls, so moving the map around is done by the arrow keys, instead of W A S D.
-0.1

You cannot change or choose heirs on the family tree. So lets say your faction leader has children, but are not of age, and he has adopted a general, that general will become the faction leader instead of following the bloodline. This has lead to lots of time and resources wasted in trying to get these adopted generals killed, so the family tree has to automatically change. Either that or I don't accept any Candidates for Adoption, which is a handicap agaisnt me. Or I suppose I could just let some outsider take over the Kingdom, but that isn't realistic at all.
-0.1

This game gets the most perfect score I have given a Total War game, with a 4.8/5

So I recommend you to give this game a try.

One of my favorite games and, in my opinon, one of the best in its genre and the best of this series. Don't let my hour count fool you. I played this game for aaaages prior to purchasing it via Steam. And over the years, it's always one I come back to. This is an excellent strategy game with a very cool, unique sort of heirarchy. In addition to managing your cities, you also have to consider what effects your actions will have on your general's traits and what effect that will have on their children, your future generals. You can use your princesses as diplomatic weapons to forge alliances or steal away enemy commanders. You have to bribe your way into the heart of the pope and pray (pun intended) that he doesn't hang you for heresy. You can take charge of your troops in battle, send spies and assassins to harass your enemies, and wage economic war with your merchants. And, if you have a daughter born ugly, you can send her out to die tragically at sea or marry her off to someone you don't particularly like. 10/10

This is an absolutely smashing game. It's quite dated but it is so much fun to play, so laid back and enjoyable yet so tense and exciting. It is the beautiful successor to Medieval Total War, and all of us TW veterans have played it for countless hours! Highly recommended to anyone who likes the TW series, or any turn based RTS.
Hands down the best TW to date.

This is an excellent entry in the Total War series, better than its predecessor (Rome) and its next 2 successors (Empire and Napolean). The time period allows for exciting gameplay and lots of variety. The campaign mode fixed a lot of the problems from Rome (late game issues like being unable to deal with large cities and distance from capital). This game also introduced randomization of soldiers, so they all look different instead of being an army of clones. This game has one of the best experiences of building a globe spanning kingdom from 1 or 2 settlements. AI isn't amazing, but smart enough to put you in some tough situations now and again, especially on higher difficulty settings.

DLC campaigns are fun and add interesting scenarios.

All in all, lots of fun, tons of nations to play with, meaningful differences in unit types, and challenging strategy.
This is the type of game I can easily go back to playing after having played newer gens like warhammer. That should be a sufficient review.

Medieval 2 is an absolutely superb game, and a classic PC title. The combat, despite being viewed from a strategic perspective, is visceral and impactful. The aesthetics of the game have aged quite well, and while not the most graphically immpressive it still looks very pretty and even downright gorgeous on occasion. The uniot replenishment and recruitment mechanics esnure that you have to think strategically about lines of retreat and reinforcement and how you will supply soldiers for an extended campaign against your enemy. 

On top of all of this, MMedieval 2 boasts somem of the best mods around, from Third Age to Age of Petty Kings to Stainless Steel. This game will provide endless hours of entertainment for fans of grand startegy and RTS games alike.

[h1]Medieval II: Total War (TRADE MARK) is pretty cool, I guess. [/h1]

If I had to pick my second favorite Total War game it would probably be this one. 

You play as ruler of a nation during the feudal era of Europe and parts of Western and Central Asia. As this ruler it is your job to spread the dominance of your culture and religion across the old world while trading, bartering, negotiating, and fighting with other nations who are more than likely just going to be more heads on the pikes at the end of your campaign. 

It is a time of great uncertainty. The powers of the world won't stop calling one another mean names and every now and then you have to send a priest out to deal with a heretic in what is essentially a bible fight. 
Like Rome, Shogun, Medieval I, and the games after it, Medieval II is split between a campaign map and a battle map that changes depending on what location on the campaign map the battle takes place in. 

You still have the usual things, you build your cities, do diplomacy, move your armies around on the map, command huge armies in battle, things like that. So lets talk about all the neat little things Medieval II adds to the formula.

One, there's an obvious graphical improvement. Medieval II looks miles better than Rome, and adds other improvements such as a change in unit models depending on their weapon and armor levels. If your peasant spearmen are equipped with chainmail then the chainmail will actually show on their models instead of it just being implied to be there. 

Second, the addition of religion and mercantilism adds another level of roleplaying to your campaign as you attempt to convert peoples of other faith or do battle with other merchants for economic resources and business rights. 

Third, new animations and battle damage are added to your armies. So sometimes you get to see a cool little animation where a soldier will beat up an an enemy and call him mean names. There's also blood, while not as gory as later Total War games, your units will get drenched in blood the longer they fight, indicating how long that individual  soldier has before biting it. 

And fourth, the soundtrack is probably the best Total War soundtrack to date. My personal opinion, but my opinion is great. 

There have been also a few events added to the campaign mode. Things such as the Mongol invasion, the black plague, discovering the new world, Crusades, Jihads, the Pope excommunicating you because you're too radical and he's tired of your skateboard phase. etc. 

Wow, all these cool things! So what's wrong?

A few things. 

First, the AI once again doesn't like to cooperate. They're ask for trade rights, map information, and an alliance one turn and then attack you the next. Broken armies of 50 or so people will gladly die to your thousands rather than end the war, and the Pope always seems to demand that you stop a war you're winning even though more than not you didn't start it. He's that kind of school principle. 

[h1]But should you play Medieval II: The one with the armies, not the one with the skeleton guy? [/h1]

When it comes to the mid 2000 Total War games I feel like it comes down to preference. Do you prefer antiquity to feudalism? Or do you like Knights over Legionarries and Hoplites? Either or you can't go wrong with Medieval II. 

The additions to campaign mode are welcomed and there's plenty of meat there if you treat the Total War games more like a roleplaying game than a strategy game. I have about as much time on the physical copy of this one as I do in Rome: total War. 
And if you want, you can still technically play as the Roman Empire in the form of the Byzantines. It's not really the same thing, but hey, they're there. 

Also, the modding scene is friggin astounding. Everything from gameplay tweaks to full out new games.
Two that stand out to me are "Thera: Legacy of The Great Torment" and "Third Age: Total War", the latter being a Lord of the Rings total conversion of the Kingdoms expansion pack.

Medieval II: Total War gets a big number out of a big number.

[i]TL;DR[/i]
[b]I got to execute the Pope, declare a Crusade on the Holy Roman Empire, and conquer the world and spread Milanese Italian fashion under the flag of Duke Bernardo the Mad, son of Duke Giorgio the Cuckold.
9/10[/b]

[h1]A MUST HAVE MEDIEVAL GENOCIDE SIMULATOR[/h1]

[h1]Personal Insights[/h1]
There's a myriad of sources out there that can cover the intricacies of gameplay far better than I could, so I'll try not to waste your time reading my review, when you could be in Medieval II fighting off 8 invading factions simultaneously, and outsmarting every enemy general on the battlefield.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
Outmaneuver enemy armies of better equipped knights and professional crossbowmen and win by epic, narrow margins with your  town militia and peasant archers in the early game, then laugh when you yourself raise armies of knights, and crush peasant armies with K/D ratios of 1:100 in the late game when you have so much excessive gold, you find yourself building Huge Cathedrals and Brothels in every corner of your empire just to drain your bloated treasury.
There is no better feeling than when you've crushed all other factions except Denmark, Russia, Turkey, and Egypt, who then decide to form a super-alliance to prevent you from conquering the 20 remaining territories on the map, which you then do anyway.
Unrest growing in a city? Raise taxes to Very High, move your entire garrison outside the city, and then wait. When the city rebels in 3-5 turns, besiege the city, kill the rebel soldiers, and then exterminate the populace to reestablish peace in your empire.
Tired of using battering rams? Send 5 spies into an enemy castle for guaranteed access to Didney Worl! Laugh as the gates open as your troops surge through, and kill the French King to punish them for their crime of daring to proclaim French cuisine as superior to Italian.
Artillery Elephants.
When your general kills enough prisoners of war and exterminates the populations of enough cities, he can earn the epithet, "The Butcher". With 10 stars of command and 10 skulls of dread, Bindello the Butcher held off the Mongol invaders with little more than armies of Spear Militia and Peasant Crossbowmen. Unfortunately for him, Bindello the Butcher eventually died in an earthquake when I sent him to retire on the Iberian Peninsula.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
Vanilla AI sometimes fails to attack you with large enough armies. 
Vanilla AI sometimes lets you siege their capital for several turns, even though they have a full army nearby that could attack your besieging army, and break the siege.
Executing Prisoners makes your faction "Untrustworthy". Why should enforcing capital punishment have any effect on trust?
Vanilla AI will break a 50+ year old alliance to attack one of your lowest income villages, even though your army, wealth, and territories outnumber theirs by a ratio of 6:1.
Vanilla AI will declare war by blockading one of your ports, and then failing to attack or do anything else for the next 80 years.
Although Battle AI is mostly competent, if not brilliant, there have been a few scenarios in which opposing generals appear brain dead. If you siege a castle, and the AI has external reinforcements, the reinforcements have a decent chance of just camping outside the castle, and letting you slaughter its defenders without trying to aid their own faction.

[h1]Online[/h1]
Online experiences are limited to battles in the base game, although it appears you can run hotseat campaigns in the expansions. My experience with online multiplayer as been extremely limited, as my first online match was this year, more than a decade after this game was released. Nevertheless, I have been extremely satisfied with the handful of matches that I have had. Be warned though; in 2017 and beyond, it will be hard, if not impossible, to join an open match. Join some Medieval II groups, or tell your friends to buy this game if you want the most out of the online battles.

[h1]Mods[/h1]
My recommendations for modding the game? Play the game totally Vanilla for at least one long Grand Campaign, and then think carefully about what you would like changed. I put in over 200 hours in the Vanilla game before deciding to provide some tweaks to add some more options for gameplay. My current mods include Ultimate AI for the Campaign AI, and about 8 changes to the game files. Those changes are:
[olist]
[*]Movement Speed increase for agents (but not armies)
[*]Increasing Age limit for Generals, so my 10 Star Generals stop dying at age 60.
[*]Increased Garrisons (free upkeep slots) for Cities and Castles
[*]Trainable Generals
[*]Stronger Walls/Gates, to make sieges a bigger challenge.
[*]Added Schiltrom (defense formation) to more units
[*]Misc. Diplomacy Fixes (easier Military Access)
[*]Misc. Mission Fixes
[/olist]

[h1]Closing Thoughts[/h1]
My experience with the Total War series actually began with the original Medieval: Total War. Medieval II has proven to be an improvement over nearly every asset of that game, and is actually compatible with modern hardware. If you like any other of the games in the Total War series, fictional Medieval scenarios, RTS's, or Eurocentricism simulators, I strongly recommend this game.

[i]TL;DR[/i]
[b]As Milan, my faction was excommunicated for failing to stop annexing the territories of my Catholic neighbors. The Pope declared a Crusade to take back Rome, which I had annexed from the Papal States several turns earlier. Seeing as I controlled all of Europe except for England at that point, I decided to hunker down at Rome, and let the lone English Crusading army actually reach its intended destination. At Rome, I had a full garrison of high quality Milanese militia, led by three generals. Outside of Rome, I had placed another full army ouside the gates as reinforcements. When the English Crusaders arrived, I was somewhat worried, as the English had brought proper Knights and Armored Swordsmen, whereas I had Spear Militia and Cavalry Militia. Nevertheless, I waited for the English assault. Sure enough, the English began their assault on the walls of Rome with catapults and trebuchets. Yet, they never managed to see Rome's interior. My Cavalry Militia sallied out of the gates, and killed the artillery crew, while my reinforcements attacked the would-be Crusaders from the rear. The English Crusading army was destroyed, and as equal and just retaliation, I annexed the entire British Isles and exterminated their citizens for good measure.
9/10[/b]

Medieval II: Total War 

[h1]Positives:[/h1]

+ Nice music soundtrack which fits the Medieval theme of the game.
+ Great unit variety, with swordsmen, spearmen, archers, cavalry and siege engines like trebuchets and catapults available to use.
+ Many buildings to construct in your towns or castles, such as farms, roads, churches, leather tanneries and so on, each providing different benefits to your kingdom. 
+ Dated graphics but they are still acceptable. Units like templar knights are quite colourful.
+ A really cool religious system. Catholic countries in Europe have a reputation among the Pope which can be improved through completing religious missions or building churches. The higher your reputation the more sway you have with the holy leader, so you can order crusades in Muslim lands for honour and glory. If you play as an Islamic faction, you can order jihads lol.
+ Decent map size extending across Europe and the Middle East.
+ Expansion packs are huge and offer even more gameplay. 
+ Command thousands of troops on screen at once in epic battles.
+ Nice mix of agents on the campaign map, each with different purposes. Priests can convert regions to your religion and denounce witches or heretics, but if they are unsuccessful, could turn to a life of heresy themselves. Assassins are another key unit, skilled in the art of killing enemy generals or family members. Then there's merchants, which can capitalise on trade goods across the world map and send the profits back to your kingdom, but foreign merchants may try to drive you out of business! Diplomats are fairly self explanatory and royal princesses can visit other kingdoms to find a husband, while also acting as a diplomat too. 
+ Hundreds of hours of gameplay here.


[h1]Negatives:[/h1]

- Unit animations on the battlefield aren't very good. They're difficult to see and not that interesting. Later installments of the Total War series improved this. 
- Diplomacy is virtually useless, allies are unreliable and will attack for literally no reason, your relationship with them does not impact the likelihood of whether they will attack you. This is a major problem with the game, mods don't seem to fix anything (I've tried multiple ones.) 
- This game has constant warfare due to the broken diplomacy system. You never do get a break from conquering other kingdoms. Anyone who has played a total war game before knows that it can be quite overwhelming, tiresome and boring fighting turn after turn. It's nice to build your empire in peace sometimes. You don't really get that opportunity in Medieval II: Total War.
- Overpowered Mongol hordes that appear during the late-game can be very irritating. For some unknown reason, Creative Assembly (the developers) like to throw a curve ball at the players in almost every single total war title they release. Total War: Shogun 2 had realm divide, where every Japanese faction declared war on you after you became too powerful, Total War: Rome II had civil wars, where massive armies spawn in your territory to take over. Medieval II: Total War has....the Mongols. All I can say is good luck and be prepared for when they arrive.

Overall Score: 8/10

Even though Medieval II: Total War is an old game which struggles with diplomacy and realism, it has a lot of fun features and micro-management which the more modern total war games seem to neglect. The use of priests to remove witches and heretics, the inquisition trialling your family's characters for blasphemy, the crusades, merchants who fight over resources  - this is all good, interesting gameplay on top of the real time battles. It's an excellent if not exhausting game, due to the AI's constant affinity for wanting to attack you.

This is one of the best Total Wars they ever created.

Don't let the aged graphics fool you. Though the game may seem less polished or action packed than its newer cousins, I still think the combat system and the pace of the battles beat that of any of the newer games.

In Rome 2 (and Attila, to some extent) enemies charging each other sometimes seem to just 'melt together' to some degree. In an instant, a battlefield becomes a confusing, cluttered mess.
In Medieval 2, opposing armies really 'clash' while engaging each other: you can see the troops pushing and shoving with their shields, physically holding back their opponents. This hugely adds to a 'hold the line!'-element in battle experience:
It makes defending a battered gateway, or being outnumbered and squared up in an open field really fun.

Along with Shogun II, Medieval II is tied for being the best Total War game Creative Assembly has ever cranked out. It's rather well balanced, has lots of factions with decent unit variety, at the very least; and the AI doesn't normally run after fighting you for 5 seconds. The AI can be a bit weird at times, does the whole dancing unit thing occasionally, but it seems to do better at pressing an advantage or running away than the AI in more recent Total War games.(Warhammer really comes to mind) 

Once you get tired of the base game, there are numerous mods for this game that are either completed or in development. I'd heard about this game when I got into shogun 2 and I really wanted to like it but after playing shogun 2 it just isn't tolerable.

The camera is painfully clunky and hard to control. It's not intuitive in the slightest and I found myself constantly having to pause just to readjust the camera so I could see what was going on.

The units don't follow your commands very well, especially in seige battles, they won't form up they wander off, they go down ladders despite being set to stand guard. It's like trying to keep track of a small child in a zoo and it's just as frustrating.

In the deployment phase there are areas your men should be able to stand where they simply won't do it. no explanation they just refuse to be placed where you want them. It's especially irritating when one guy of an enemy troop gets past your front line and ALL of your archers in a unit stop shooting just to fight that one guy. Speaking of archers that hand red line from Shogun 2 that tells you when you are in range? yeah that's gone you have no way of knowing just how far archers can fire and I see them constantly shooting into walls and at things they can't hit wasting tons of their ammo and doing nothing.

The enemy AI is dumb as a rock, they ignore gates and funnel themselves into choke points making it really easy to win battles even when outnumbered.

Overall the game feels dated and clunky especially when compared to the newer titles. I really wanted to like this game but at this point I'm 90% sure that this game's reputation comes from a nostalgic fan base and not from any real quality of the game. I'm sure it was good for it's time but considering the improvements in later games it just doesn't hold up well over time.

I have been absolutely obsessed with this game from the day I purchased it, shortly after it came out. This is the one game that I return to over and over again every single year when I'm looking to entertain myself ceaselessly.

The combination of real time strategy and turn based strategy strikes a very unique cord. 

Get ready to plan out your every move, every turn, from developing your political leaders to spreading your merchants around the globe up to sending assassins to take out a foreign enemy.

I got this game for my birthday, back in 2006, its been 10 years latter(2016), and I am still playing it.

The base game is good enough, the expansion(you read that right kiddies, expansion, not this DLC bullshit), adds not 1, nor 2, or 3 games, but 4, and whats even more yet, they all, and yes I mean ALL can be modded. So follow this.

ME2TW can be modded
Expansion 1 game can be modded
Expansion 2 game can be modded
Expansion 3 game can be modded
Expansion 4 game can be modded
All of this at the same time, so thats 5 total mods to the game, all on at once, which means you can explore the Warhammer world, Lord of the Rings world, best damn medieval game every(stainless steel), best damn ancient world game ever(europa barbarorum 2), and keep the basic one for old times sake(or not, and find a 5th mod.)

This is still the best Total War, and will continue to be the best Total War until Creative Assembly dumps the Warscape engine, which has become a serious handicap for every Total War after this one. That, and hiring competent AI programmers so they can stop oversimplifying and removing basic game mechanics just so that AI has less things to fuck up.

Here's a short list of things M2TW does better than the later titles:

-To start, this is by far the most moddable Total War in the series. Everything from units to animations to the campaign and battle maps are completely moddable. Even the AI is moddable to a limited extent.

-Has by far the best recruitment system of any Total War game. Every unit has a limited pool to recruit from that replenishes at variable rates based on the building they're recruited from. Higher quality professional soldiers replenished slower than lower quality militia units, which prevents churning out stacks of elite units in quick order, atleast until you get to the point where you own half of Europe. I'm actually baffled as to why they moved away from this, but it was probably due to Creative Assembly being incapable of making the AI work with it.

-NO LIMITED BUILDING SLOT NONSENSE. And no idiotic food mechanics that further restricted your building choices either. In M2TW's cities/castles, you could pretty much build everything in every city/castle. BUT you can only build one building at a time, so to be optimal you still had to specialize each city/castle for a specific purpose early on. 

-Agents that actually served a strategic purpose, rather than just being a general nuisance or generic regional stat buff.

-Battles that last more than 5 minutes. This is again probably due to CA's AI short comings, as the battle AI throughout the years has yet to evolve beyond "engage front line, flank with any extra cavaly, suicide general". The shorter the battles the are the less this is a problem, but the longer battles go it becomes easier for the player to out manuver and smash the AI.

-Soldiers have actual mass. Heavier units will actually force weaker units backwards in melee. In the later Warscape plagued titles, a few dozen of the weakest unit imaginable can literally prevent hundreds of heavy infantry from moving forwards. 

-Sieges that were, at the very least, fun to defend and attack on. M2TW certainly has the most complicated siege battles, with the highest level castles having 3 sets of walls to overcome. The AI can have a tough time with it, but it usually does okay. Total War AI has always been a little extra special when it comes to siege battles, but other than Shogun 2 the AI has gotten significantly worse at them since M2TW, despite siege battles being significantly simplified.

As superior M2TW undoubtably is, there are a number of things later Total Wars do better:

-Graphics, an obvious one, though the graphics in M2TW still look pretty decent today.

-UI. M2TW's UI is big, ugly, and clunky, and scales poorly on widescreen resolutions. Definitely has not aged well.

-No fuckin diplomats. All diplomacy can be done instantly without the need of an agent running around all of Europe just to die of the plague right when you need him the most.

The gameplay is practical and fun, and the wide variety of factions and units provide greatly differing campaigns, and ensure the game does not become monotonous. Even the loading, while not overly time consuming, provides quotes relating to medieval war. Possibly the only real complaints I have is are number of historical battles, and the fact that you can only play said battles as the side that won. Overall, this is an excellent, fun and accurate battle simulator and medieval strategy game.

Seriously though, this game is still awesome, even after all these years later! In fact, M2:TW just celebrated its 10th birthday, this November 2016! And its still easily one of the best, if not the best, of the Total War series!
Improving upon, and outdoing most everything in the previous M:TW and Rome:TW (whose engine it uses) games, Medieval II was a triumph of RTS when it was first released. And a year later, it only got better with the best Total War expansion to date, Kingdoms. And thats not even considering all the many wonderful fan-made mods this title has available, thus extending its greatness even more so! Even fantasy lands are game! Want to wage war in Middle-Earth? There's a mod for that! Feel like fighting for The Elder Scrolls' Tamriel? There's a mod for that! How about waylaying the Warhammer world? Well, actually, that game was released earlier this year. But..there's still mods that predate that!

Caution: this game is a time consumer! You can EASILY spend 50+ hours on just one campaign alone, and given that there are 17 playable factions available (eventually) in just the base game alone, and that there is NO END DATE for any campaign (only an end to the campaign objectives, but the game still goes on, so you can play a medieval kingdom all the way into the 21st century and beyond, take that modernity! #ProgressIsForSuckers), you can rack up a kingdom's worth of time spent on this game! Rome wasn't built in a day, they say, but it sure was completed faster than this game is!

Whether it be conquering your back-stabbing neighbors (all the italian powers, always!!), managing your empire (where is the govenator when you need him?), retaking the Holy Land from the infidel (ya jerks!), converting the heathen (come on fellas, its "A.D." now, get with the program already!), or making a heroic last stand for all of Christendom against the rapacious onslaught of the Golden Horde (which is what you get when you don't tip the chinese food delivery guy on one too many occasions), yes sir, Medieval II has it all. 
Even the possibility of having one of your generals get so cuckholded by his nakedly adulterous wife, that he loses it, becomes the most shameless man on earth, and shacks up with a tranny, thus bringing eternal shame to your kingdom! As I said, Medieval II has it all. Even things the developers really should have just left alone...*ahem*.

If your a strategy gaming fan, there are certain games in the genre you just have to have played in your lifetime, like Age of Empires II: Age of Kings. This is that kind of game. Don't miss out. 
And here's to hoping that the developers go back on their "we don't make games with the number '3' in their titles" statement, and, once they are done with (the also fantastic, well-worth-your-time) Warhammer: Total War, they start developing Medieval III. 
Deus Vult, Creative Assembly, Deus Vult!

This game made up so much of childhood, it definitely got me to love strategy games. It's a pity that they aren't going to make Medieval III: Total War, it would totally have made them a ton of money and would have been a godsend for so many like myself, fans who've loved this game for most of the last decade. 

This game, along with those developed by Sid Meier, has been one of the reasons turn-based strategy games haven't died off.

After a long period of not playing strategy games (mostly Age of Empires) in my youth after our family desktop died, I received this present as a gift from my parents or my brother (I can't remember which) for Christmas. They probably regretted that act as I proceeded to play the shit out of this game for at least four years, neglecting schoolwork and "real life". This game was totally addicting, and part of the fun was figuring out how the game works. Although the game is really easy once you manage to figure out the games broken AI, it is still fun to build up your Kingdom and clash with others on the battlefield. This is a great game, mostly because of the mods. Especially the total conversions like Third Age: Total War. The vanilla game is enjoyable, but there are plenty of mods out there to change the vanilla experience from what could be considered comparitvely shallow to a game with great depth (Stainless Steel, and the upcomming Dominion of the Sword mod). To be honest, the game itself is sort of a mod of Rome I: Total War, it doesn't really contribute anything gamechanging to the series besides a few engine improvements. It is still definitely an improvement over Rome though, even if not by too much. The extra campaigns added in Kingdoms are good. I personally greatly enjoyed the Teutonic campaign (this is probably the best of the expansion campaigns) and Britannia campaign (both great hotseat campaign experiences with my brother). The Crusades and Americas campaigns being enjoyable (I didn't play too much of the Americas campaign myself). The only thing this game lacks is true online multiplayer campaigns like the most recent installments in the series, which at the time of this writing would be Shogun 2 and Rome II (I beleive Empire had a beta for multiplayer campaigns as well). The reason why that was such an improvement is that it adds the ability to resolve battles between the players using the battle map and not resorting to autoresolve to be fair. All in all I would recommend this game over Rome I, and definitely over all the successors in the series (I never played Medieval I or Shogun I). Of course buying the Kingdoms expansion is a must.

P.S.
Luc, the mods are where its at.

I nominated this one for the "Just 5 More Minutes" award. It could have gone to Civ, but these games edge it for me. The number of times I have clicked the "End Turn" button "for the last time"...   (sigh)

The award could have gone to nearly any Total War game really.

Although this game is by no means perfect, in particular the bland campaign and the ai that does not seem to know what the fuck it's doing, Medieval II is one of the few games who's popularity has managed to survive this long (10 years!) despite the release of 6 more TW games, 7 counting Fall of the Samurai. This is in no small part thanks to the modding opportunities this period offers, of which one of the best is Third Age total war (Lord of the Rings). I recommend this game to all fans of real time tactics and the medieval period, although realism is not one of this game's strong suits *cough cough* color coded peasant uniforms.

Pros
Fun real time battles
Good mods, Third age with Divide and Conquer in particular is great, long live pope Sauron.


Cons
Bland campaign, either takes up too much time for what is essentially setup for the battles or is underdevelopped.
No real effort to represent feudal politics or the way that troops are levied, the campiagn feels like a bad Civ clone with an emphasis on war.
Not many factions (fixed with Stainless Steel mod)
Shit ai, from the the campaign ai not making any logical decision to ai generals charging cav up steep cliffs into pikes to unit ai disobeying simple orders.

As you can see, this game's biggesst issues are in the campaign. If you really want to have fun just play online or custom/quick singleplayer battles.

If you wish to conquer the Easetern world as the Egyptians, you can. If you wish to unite Italy under one banner long before it ever was in the history books, you can.

This is the game you don't play anymore for the vanilla experience. There are so many amazing mods for it that makes this game worth getting 10x over. Everything from the Lord of the Rings mod which should just be its own game to the amazing Stainless Steel mod that improves on the medieval setting and makes the campaign much more enjoyable. Then you have the Hyrule Total War game, because Zelda warfare has never been better. You go your De Bello Mundi mod, a conversion of the Roman era. If you cant run Warhammer total war, you got your End Times mod for Medieval II which now includes all the Warhammer Fantasy factions. If youre looking for a mod that focuses on Crusaders and the Middle East you have the Broken Crescent mod. Oh, and there are a ton of sub-mods for all these mods so you can mod your mod while you mod.

I grew up with this game, form the age of seven. I still play it regulary. I have downloaded tenfolds of mods. This is the pinnacle of Total War. The raw brutality, the strategy adn the epic fights. And the mods. The oh so glorious mods. It says have 544 hrs on record, but with the cd version and the Kingdoms expansion (which got removed after the steam update), I must have played it for several thousand hours. 
The DLC is also great. It is what a DLC is supposed to be. You have the base game, fully fleshed out (Unlike Warhammer etc), and then it adds  not one, not two, but FOUR whole new maps, with new factions and units to play as, for really cheap. That is what a DLC should be. 
The mods are also fantastic, ranging from Warhammer, LOTR, Italy in the 16th century, Japan, even the whole world. Even crazy mods, such as Planetwar, with klingons, aliens v Predator, Shrek and Romans in one group. There is so much to say about the mods, I could spend hours writing about them.
While to community might not be the largest, it's certianly one of the best I've seen. Everyone is friendly, and gives advise. There might be some salt here and there, but that's the exeption that confirms the rule.
If you are interested in strategy, buy this. If you like massive battles, buy this. If you like mods, buy this. If you have a little extra money to spend, this is the game to buy.
