I have been playing this game well before it was put on Steam. I'm actually really happy its on Steam now since I lost my old CD keys, this game is quite a gem. This Total War game is the one I compare every Total War game to and none of them ever come close to this one in terms of fun and replayability. 

The seige battles for both attack and defence in this game feel genuinely better than the ones in future installments. They are satisfying to play, whether you are taking down the walls with catapults/cannons, storming a citadel with seige equipment like rams and ladders, or just defending against invading forces storming your city.

The units in this game matter, but its how you use them that makes for the most interesting battles. Clearly when the professional (late game) units go up against peasants and such, especially in an open field, we know who is ultimately going to lose (in most cases), but with right combination of units, including peasants, and the right kind of placement, you can easily defending a settlement against even the most advanced/elite units. This also depends on difficulty too as the AI can be vicious if given the chance.

I aslo enjoyed the religion system in this game, but mainly for the catholic factions. The Papal states are not a minor faction and they will wreck you with not only their own units (which are pretty powerful) but all of Christendom will come together to crusade your face in should you get excommunicated or if the pope doesn't favor your faction nearly as much as the others (meaning he'll look the other way for a bit). For what it is, it is a complex, but straightforward system that can either be used to your advantage or used against you. 

The modding community for this game is pretty awesome too. Hyrule: Total War and Stainless Steel are both mods I love and they work so well with this game that it gives me endless hours of entertainment even to this day. The game still has a rather active modding community for something of its age, which is great since it just makes a great game even better. 

Finally, the game is just all around fun. How you play this game can easily make for a great time or just a great way to waste time in general all the while being entertained. I wish Sega and the Total War series in general looked back to this game and Rome: Total War (the first one) to see what they got so right about their game series and just put that + whatever improvements and mechanics (like naval battles) into the game. If they were to make a modern day version of this game with everything that made this game great, I would buy it in a heartbeat. But in the meantime, there is this game, so if you are looking to pick it up, do so and enjoy!

The only thing i hate about this game, is that you can't play against horde of AI peasants with a friend(s), yet on the other hand, the AI is so stupid maybe it wouldn't be so freaking cool how we have always imagined it.

This was before the endless torrents of dlc, and when Sega or Creative Assembly decided to release half of the game and piecemeal it to you. By far the best Total War game, although I have yet to play Shogun II or Warhammer. The large armies, cavalry shocks, pike and shot, and cannons make for utterly fantastic battles, and the campaign map gives you a ton of avenues for expansion, not all of which you necessarily have to take. The same goes for the campaign itself - unless you happen to be their first target, you can usually ignore the Mongolian invasion, but it's just /so much fun/ to fight to push them back if you're utterly dominating Europe.

Still good after all these years - I still like Europa Barbarorum better, but this TW stands well on its own. It's CA's last hurrah of good design and no shitty DLC, only expansions that actually add to the game.

If you came here for a game review, you've come to the wrong place.
But if you came here for an outstanding chocolate cake recipe, you've come to the right place.

Chocolate Cake Ingredients:

-3/4 cups butter or margarine, softened
-3 eggs
-2 cups sugar
-2 cups flour
-3/4 cup unsweetened cocoa powder
-1 teaspoon baking soda
-3/4 teaspoon baking powder
-2 teaspoon vanilla
-1 1/2 cup milk

How to make Chocolate Cake:

-Pre-heat oven to 350 degrees.
-Grease and flour three 6" X 1 1/2" round cake pans.
-Mix together flour, cocoa powder, baking powder and baking soda. Set aside.
-In a large bowl, beat butter, eggs and vanilla.
-Gradually add sugar.
-Beat on medium to high speed for about 3-4 minutes until well mixed
-Alternately combine in flour mixture and milk to batter while beating.
-Continue to beat until batter is smooth.
-Pour equal amounts of batter into greased and floured round cake pans.
-Bake 30 to 35 minutes.
-Check with a toothpick to se if it is done. Bake a few minutes more, if needed.
-Remove from oven and allow cakes to cool in pans for a few minutes.
-Place cakes on a wire rack, to them allow to completely cool.

Frosting Cakes:

-Place one round cake on a cake plate.
-Spread frosting on top.
-Repeat this for the third cake.
-Frost top of the third cake.
-Frost the side for the cake.

One of the greatet games I've ever played. The battles are fluid and careful planning and manuevering of troops is well rewarded. Outside the battles you will find a well developed economic system where how you manage your cities will greatly affect your numbers on the battlefield. I've played nearly a hundred hours and still haven't finished my first game, and with over a dozen different factions to choose from before adding any DLC it's easy to see that the amount of material to play with is vast. I bought this game on discount, but after having played it I would say if I had bought it at triple the full price it still would have been a good buy.

I am not a competent or experienced gamer, but even I can appreciate the scope and texture of this game as compared to Rome II. The battle maps are exensive and intuitive when it comes to tactics. The faction rosters are exquisitely detailed. 

One great thing about this game is the extent to which it's as hard as you want it to be. If you feel like getting your backside handed to you, turn all the advice off and jump in at medium difficulty or above. 

If, like me, you're a little more timid, start with low difficulty, start with the advice turned on and, if in doubt, turn to youtube or similar for advice. Swissman15, Pixelatedapollo and many others have huge numbers of instructional and demo videos which can tell you useful things, like how to make enemies rout, how to make the best of itwhen you've got vastly superior or inferior troops in one area, what to do about hills and so forth

You can make this a 40-hours-a-run strategy game, a 20 minute hit-and-run tactics game, an RPG of sorts, go achievement hunting... the choice is yours.

Are you ready to breach and butcher, my lord?  I know I am!  There are many games that allow you to wield a sword or axe or bow, but, really, why do that when you can wield thousands of them?  The beauty of Medieval II, like the rest of the Total War series, is that it does an out-standing job of capturing the tactical nuances of combat from pre-modern eras, as well as doing the strategic piece pretty well also, insofar as you can manage your cities in a variety of different ways as well as control agents.  This is definitely a game for those that like to think and who like a game that rewards them for thinking.  MTW2, like the rest of the TW series, has diplomacy, agents, merchants, assassins, and priests, and captures the dimensions that these bring to the strategy.  However, these elements, like all others, are there, ultimately, as an element related to combat, which is where this series shines.  It is called Total War, after all, not Total Diplomacy, or Total Economic and Cultural dominance.  Additionally, the game events throw at you some unique challenges of the period which really do quite a lot to keep the challenge and pressure on even as your empire becomes more and more mighty.  For the period, the graphics are incredible, and like other TW games, it's a lot of fun to just zoom in and watch your units work.  All in all, this series is unique and indispensible to the PC gaming world.

Probably my second favorite; if not first favorite game in the Total War series apart from Rome II/Attila (I know this review will get some shit on for me saying that, but personally my Rome 1 is super choppy because it was made for a specific rendering processor unfortunately. I can tolerate Rome II and Attila and I understand they arent the greatest as people expected).

It's my grand wish that after perhaps at the writing of this review; the Creative Assembly will release a Total War: Medieval III after Warhammer, because now that like Warhammer's game engine, the developers will most likely use a 64 bit engine rather than a 32 bit for the optimisational parts.

The only pain in the ass part about this game in particular, but acceptable as is would be the cavalry smashes. In Rome: Total War, cavalry had a much bigger impact whereas Feudal Knights/Mailed Knights/Crusader Knights (etc.) give out a rather awkward form of charging and flanking force. I kind of wish they would fix it, but then again, heavily armored men on horses does add a sense of slow movement, and I do not care that one small percent of the game's aspect does not change the astounding 99% percent other than this.

98/100 for me. I strongly recommend it.

Decided to start a game a england. Easy peasy i thought. In a 200 years i was already in control of the British Isles,all of France and even lil Scily. I was also one of the most christian of all the christain kingdoms. I could've called a crusade on ANYONE i didn't like. All was good right. Then the Milanese attacked. See during my entire game these spaghetti eating fucks would constantly antagonize me. Whenever they attacked i would smash through their puny armies and march right up to Milan itself, sometimes taking it and forcing them  to relocate to Venice or Genoa. I've killed more Doges then i could count. But i've never been able to completly rid myself of them. See for some reason that litteraly god only knows, the pope would demand i end my war with them whenever i was about to finish them off. So for about 50 or so years we played this game of mudering each other until the pope forced us, mostly just me, to stop. 

Eventually i just had enough. My kingdom was begining to fall and i could not handle to pay my way out of another war i could have won. The plague was ravaging its way across europe and i feared the french Nobility might have been planing to rebel. So when Milan attacked like they always did i played the game right up to where it always ended. With their remaing forces cowering behind the walls of milan or Venice as my galliant Generals prepared to storm the city and fly the banner of the three Lions from its walls. Like always the pope decided that i had my fun and i should apologize to milan like usual. But not this time, no this time i said Fuck you Pope and took milan, Killing their doge and destroying their entire army. Now you'd think this is where the story would end right? The good guys defying the odds and finally defeating their age old rival right? sadly this isn't the end nor will the end be so Romantic.

See after taking Milan, the Pope excomunicated me for defying him. Which made me public enemy Number 1 to even my closets allies. On top of that the Milanese regrouped in venice and trapped my men in Milan. If they went to take venice then they would lose milan to a greater force but if they stayed in milan then the Milanese would have more the time to rebuild. I was prepared to counter this by sending more forces into italy. But right as my men begin to enter italy from southern france, i get invaded. See my age old ally and undisputed ruler of Iberia, Spain, Decides to launch a full scale invasion over the mountains. Destroying what little resistance remained.

So here i stand. Ruler of a heretical empire that's barely holding together and being betrayed by its closest allies hoping to carve out part of it before it collapses like vulchers circling a dying animal. All becuase the Pope refused to let me have justice.

Today was a good day.

After our victory over the English and the Danish, taking many miles of northern coastline, Scotland was settled as a new, prosperous kingdom. Many alliances, trade agreements, and marriages flourished. But the Pope called a crusade against Jerusalem, and I raised an army for the cause. My noble swordsmen clad in plate embarked for a long voyage through the Bay of Biscay, along the Iberian Coast, and then followed the North African coastline to take Cairo as a staging ground to move armies against Jerusalem. We were successful; my army took Cairo in the name of the Pope. I raised a new army and sent them northeast, deciding to take more land for the Pope. But, to my dismay, I saw that no other nations were joining the crusade. Complicating matters further, the Mongols joined the Turkish and Egyptian cause, and a three nation army destroyed my own in the field. Left with my original crusading army, in Cairo, we withstood one assault after the other. My fleet had returned home, evacuation wouldn't be here in time. After many assaults, my army broke through their coalition lines and we took Alexandira, watching Cairo fall back into enemy hands. There, we raised a fleet and sailed away from our enemies. But they pursed my fleet, and shadowed and raided us at every opportunity. Going back the original way would be too long. France had declared war, so I made the decision to invade southern France. We landed and razed the fortress to the ground. My army was thin, we wouldn't be able to hold it. We burned our ships and pushed north. We fought off raiding Frenchmen several times, and were forced to raze another fortress to the ground. Finally, my army of crusaders, diminished to less than fifteen men per unit, bloodied, muddied, exhuasted from years of combat, arrived in Caen, part of our continental territory. I put them on ships, and sent them home. 

Did that actually happen? Yes. Yes it did. This is the best, most complicated, challenging, and entertaining installment of the Total War series.

Significantly better than Rome 2 in terms of battles, playability, load times, concise campaign experience. Battles are waaaay less infuriating (clicking a unit to move makes them start walking, not immediately running - I had no idea how much this bugged me until now), get a line of units to walk towards the enemy, when they make contact, they start fight IN BATTLE FORMATION - no individually clicking each units specific attack orders. I am fully aware that my boundless love of European history creates an insurmountable wall of bias between me and that which we call objectivity.
That said, play this now.

Decided to play this game again started a campaign as Byzantuim. Start the game and head east taking a few cities off Turks. But then Venice attacks one of the main Byzantine cities Thessalonica and takes it. I turn my attention West towards Venice I retake the city and head West. I reach the west coast and rather than head north, I build a fleet and attack Sicily taking Naples and the island of Sicily itself. Then I head north. You can probably see where this is going. I launch a succesfull attack on Rome and march further north and take Bolonga. By this point my army is highley exprience (some have gold exprience). But then Bolonga and Rome rebel I launch a second attack on rome which is unsuccesful. Rome was the entire objective of the campaign to reclaim Rome for true Romans (not like the Holy 'Roman' Empire). My Veteran army in Bolonga attacks the HRE army but they are reinforced.

HRE - 4100 Troops

Byzantuim - 1050 Troops

This should of been the end of my Italian campaign but the 4100 strong HRE army was actually 3 armies the first army was quickly defeated and then the second came. My horse archers softened the second army up but soon ran out of ammo then the lines of infantry smash into each other my left flank had hidden troops that attacked the left of the HRE army. The HRE'S right broke and then the enemy army got outflanked they fled and we were so close to victory. And then another army came, this time roughly equal to the amount of men I had left but the last army had feudal knights, superior to my infantry who were also Exhausted. I sent every last man in... and then the HRE army completely shattered. After the defeats of the first 2 armies the 3rd army simply broke and ran. On that day 2000 HRE troops were captured and 1500 were killed but the Byzantine army took heavy casualties too. Nearly 50% of there army were killed but regardless they had won.

Yes this really happened. Oh yeah the game yeah like uhhhh 10/10 Ign.

In Summary, a solid game, the graphics and game itself will match your computer, a wide variety of units and play styles and modding adding additional time. easily an 8.5 out of 10

In my opinion, Medieval 2 is far more enjoyable than any Total War game that has come after it (out of the ones I have played, atleast: Empire, Napoleon, Shogun, and Rome 2). You get more of a classic sense immersion from this one. Taking a young lad to lead a meager peasant band to subjugate an independant city, having him gain experiance, a title, special traits and an army that contains hardened veterans aswell as mercenaries recruited from various campaigns all over the Meditarianian and beyond is simply pure fun. Units react more organically and tactics can truely overcome superior units, unlike some situations in newer titles. 

The mod scene really makes this game shine. Warhammer (Rage of the Dark Gods), Lord of the Rings (Third Age), or maybe just an enhanced Medieval experiance (Stainless Steel) add and increase tons more playability and enjoyment to an already very good game.

This is the best game ever.  I have spend thousands of hours on this game with a torrent, and finally purchased it to show support for my favorite game of all time.  I recently got Rome 2 and still jump back to play this one all the time.  The only downfall is once your learn the game it's super easy even on the hardest difficulty.  If you want an unfair advantage turn your castles into towns so you can get higher income.  Create ports in coastal cities to increase income and make everyone want to trade with you.  If you really want an easy game as a catholic nation conquer a series of border settlements and gift them to the papal states (ally them early in game) this will create a border zone that will deter other catholic states from crossing papal lands to attack you.  Fun fun fun.  The DLC's are all worth a play, but the core game is by far the greatest.  Good mod base if you want more.  Buy this game it's amazing.

Our last king restored Hungary to it's rightful place in the Christian church. We must not let it fall!
My western border with The Holy Roman Empire is secured and christianty is almost fully restored, we must restore our eastern front! Many of our greatest builders were sent to build churches, chapels and Abbeys, we trained our greatest priests to become bishops and cleanse our eastern territory from the heretical thought. Our eastern border wasn't protected though, so we had to make alliances, Georgia came to us in request to trade, it was a perfect moment to make a diplomatic action and propose an alliance, gladly they accepted. We both had a common enemy of course, the heretics who call them selves "Byzantines".

They are nothing but a dying empire, after we aided Georgia in their wars and the world was shown the true strengh of Mother Hungary, the Russian and Polish embassies embraced our relations and proposed an alliance. Of course we agreed, now that we have Georgia in the east, Kievan Rus' in the north east and Poland in the north, we can direct our forces to the west!

The Holy Roman Empire is in constant war with our polish allies, but my advisor said that it's best to build up our economy. So we did, in a matter of years Hungary became the richest country in Europe and maybe in the whole world, soon we started buying cities from Poland and Kievan Rus', our borders grew and my kingdom strenghened. Our Polish friends were also getting stronger and our relations were better than ever. But Poland was too concerned with wars than with their own faith! The church has excomunicated them, and I had to declare war on my closest friend. I hasitated but I shudder to think that I could ever betray them...

The church was unpleased with my actions, but I can't betray my own friend, I still think there is hope for him, I just need to meet him once more, have a drink and discuss his issues with the church. But alas I was too late, he has fallen in battle trying to defend his lands, his entire city butchered, women and children.
And now I have to pay for my actions, I have been excomunicated. I am writing now as I'm waiting for the inevitable.

Soon, a crusade will begin.

Europe stands as the heart of monarchy, since the fall of Rome and the establishment of the Kingdoms. The Church determines the fate of all and cries for war upon the Islamic Kingdoms to the east. The year is 1066 and the Duke of Normandy; William (the Conqueor) has been given consent from the Pope to invade England and overthrow the Anglo-Saxon Kingdom. After the victory at Hastings, the Kingdom of England has been born and a new chapter in Medieval Europe has begun. With the Islamic push stopped at the Frankish victory of Tours, the Christian faith now demands retaliation and cries for Muslim blood. With the age of the Crusades now beginning, the world will now watch the world become divided by two religions and the age of Chivarly, Faith, and Conquest has become the objective for any ruler who possess such power and nobility. Despite the church having united Europe to the power of the Pope, rivalries continue to plague Europe with war. Lords use the peasantry as fodder in order to gain both wealth and reputation to become the most powerful ruler Europe shall ever have. Chivarly, Faith, Wealth, Total War...

    This is by far my most favorite Total War game ever, with improved graphics, gameplay, animations, and new weaponry   when compared with Rome: Total War. Watching Knights clash in shiny armor make every soldier a spectacle on the battlefield, watch as massive armies butcher each other leaving literally mountains of dead. This game has captured the brutality and chaotic atomsphere of medieval combat, especially with the aftermath of a battle as you are left speechless at the sight of a sea of dead stretching all over the battlefield. Remember Braveheart? That first battle scene at Stirling Bridge? That is pretty much what you would witness with each battle, as the game captures a more realistic and brutal spectacle compared with the First Rome Total War. Defineitly a must-buy, especially with the Kingdoms DLC, so worth it. Stretching from the wars of independence that ravaged England, to the Crusades in the Holy Land, to the wars between the Christians and the remnants of the religion of Paganism in the Baltic region, to the jungles of Central America as the New World has been discovered. This game plus the Kingdoms DLC is worth every cent and shall always remain as my favorite Total War game.
ONE OF THE BEST OF THE TOTAL WAR FRANCHISE

An excellent game, it surpasses its predecessors. That said it marks a fundamental change  Empire and onwards are significantly different. 

Crank the graphics up to max and it still looks good. The sound variation gets somewhat dull though.

As is par for the series, there are some issues: the AI has pathfinding problems, especially inside cities/castles. Youll see units running back and forth over the same spot, refusing to move onto walls, or refusing to come down from walls, or getting stuck in between  if you need to move units and walls are involved, plan for the movement to take a long time to complete.

Siege/archers will ignore orders, even with fire at will off.

Units have a strong preference to chase routing units, may have to order them several times if you want them to stop. 

The difficulties can cause odd behaviour  on very hard combat difficulty, the auto resolve will almost never favour you, even when you have 10-1 or better numbers. On the campaign, very hard causes the AI to go mad on you  some nations will attack you out of the blue, others will ignore you entirely. 

The late game, due to the map spacing and timeline developments can be a bit of a letdown.
Editing the ini files to change things such as rebel frequency is recommended  its a shame theres no easier way to do so. The vanilla concentrated mod is a fantastic way to keep the core of the game the same, but address some of these issues. 

Overall, these are reasonably minor compared to the full gameplay and I would highly recommend this game and the series as a whole.

A wargame of an exagerated fame. Decent graphics and with the good mechanics of Total Wars series, but thats is all. Maybe its wonderful for multiplayer mode, but in single player mode, the AI is cheater and treacherous: all are against the player; the enemies generate more units per turn, they come from far away left helpless his own territories to attack you, the diplomatic system is expensive, alliances are unstable and unrealistic historically...

If you have played intensively the game and considerate this opinion exagerated, try with Bizantine Empire in normal level, and see what happens after turn 50 or 70...  The game breaks his own rules, and the factions shall attack to you without any diplomatic or strategic logic.

There are many examples: the eastern hordes can ignore nearest, poorest or helpless factions only to search, sack or take your cities; a faction with only have one city, and no allies, can mantain two armies with expensive units, over his economic capacity; a great faction suddenly attacks you with all of his power, and soon collapses because no protect his rearguard, conquered by a lesser faction...

There are a better wargame of historical medieval theme, called Kinights of Honor, that was published years before, with a more honest IA and a deeper mechanics.

The old total war games...when the UI was straightforward, the graphics as good as they need to be, and BUGLESS (Empire Total War is an exception). 
Although Medieval II TW seems like an expansion of Rome TW, with slightly better graphics, more factions (when including the Medieval II TW expansions), it is def worth the relatively cheap Steam price. Although Medieval II TW It does not play like an entirely different game (unlike Empire TW and Napoleon TW since they have guns), the feel is still different given the different time period and the respective time period specific relationships between different countries. Medieval TW is mostly made from the same formula as Rome TW, but it tells completely different stories, keeping the game from feeling like a simple reiteration of Rome TW.  Furthermore, mods like Third Age and Elder Scrolls further increase the replayability and overall value of this game.

Having played this since the original release and recently rebought it on steam, it is still absolutely worth the money and one of the best total war games ever made. 

Combining a blend of economic advancement, diplomatic shenanigans and military conquest, you definetely have room to manouvre with how you play with your faction, whatever your playstyle.

Yes, there are some issues, such as ridiculously OP cavalry charges, scarily buggy battles on mountain terrain-style maps (some units are literally stuck and unreachable), and the AI's diplomatic nature completely unfathomable and changing (Always fun declaring war on the Papal States, conquering Rome then declaring a ceasefire by buying them off and then electing the new pope next turn with your legion of cardinals). 

However, these are miniscual when compared to how many hours you can plug away into this game and still really enjoy it, especially when you only begin to the tap into the mods that are available (Third age total war, Skyrim, Westeros e.t.c.).

For how old this game is it's still one of the best strategy games I've ever played. The game starts in the dark ages and progresses through the Renaissance. You take control of a faction (the Holy Roman Empire, Egypt, England, France to name a few) and run the trade, religion (including joining/launching Jihads and Crusades), family (via marrying into other  royal families or having worthy generals married into yours), exploration (once the technology is available you can lead your faction to settling the new world) and military. When battles occur you can choose to skip them or fight them in real time which is a blast. This game has so much in it and it is so immersive that it is definately worth playing even now.
This game is just so addicting, once you get on you will not get off.

Where have you been all my life?

I purchased Medieval II: Total War when it was on a sale a while back, but never 'opened' it. I bought it because I remember seeing a friend playing it when it first came out, and two things stuck in my mind:

1. WOW! 8 GB on my hard drive?! That's too much space!

2. Man, these battles are huge! And you have to manage the governance? That's insane!

I'm a big fan of the Age of Empires series, so I was very used to a simpler, more combat-focused game series. M2TW's size (legitimately, that wasn't just a joke) as well as the amount of managing you needed to do looked intimidating to me, so I never tried it.

How wrong I was.

This game is absolutely glorious. Managing your nation, commanding your armies, working through all the inner workings of medieval society: this game found a way to make it work together. 

Here's an example: In the short British campaign, you have to conquer both Scotland and France. Scotland has few allies, so they weren't difficult to invade. However, France was a whole different story. France was not only allied with many of my neighbours (The Holy Roman Empire and Milan), but they were highly regarded by the Pope of the Catholic Church. If I tried to invade France, not only did I have to also fight against their allies, but I risked becoming excommunicated. 

I went for the risk, becoming both excommunicated and enemies to nearly all Catholic nations, and that made my French conquest significantly harder. I had to stop playing that campaign because, while my nation was the strongest, my borders were constantly under attack every turn, and I'd rather start a new campaign and learn from my mistakes.

Albeit still a computer program and not reality, Medieval II feels like the closest thing to a simulator of Medieval combat. It's almost as if they intended to create a game series and engine to emulate that!

I have not checked out the other Total War games, but I am going to once I'm done with my campaign on this one. 

So, in conclusion, if you're a fan of Strategy games and haven't tried these games, go for it! It has quickly become one of my favourite games, and I'd recommend it to anyone who's looking for something new.

[b][h1]Medieval II: Total War[/h1][/b]

One of the best Total War titles with probably the best campaign.

Medieval II: Total War throws you into the Middle Ages.You can choose from a good number of states like the Holy Roman Empire,Byzantine Empire,France,England,Scotland and so on.The game has Single Player,Multiplayer,Historical Battles and Custom Battles.You can save replays of your battles.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]

For a game released in 2006,it looks good even to this day.So don't be afraid of the game's age.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Each state has it's own victory conditions.Throughout the game,events like the Mongol Invasion or invention of powder will influence the way you play the game.Religion plays an important role in the game.The Pope can call a crusade while the Muslims can call a Jihad.Aside from generals and armies,you can recruit and use agents such as priests,spies,assassins,merchants and diplomats.Diplomacy in the game is decent,but doesn't have many options.

The Real Time Strategy part of the game is great but it has it's problems.The AI will do weird things sometimes,and the unit pathing in the game is not that great.

[h1]Mods and DLC[/h1]

You can enhance this game by buying the DLC which also offers great campaign stories and other factions.By buying the DLC,you can also install mods.The best and most famous mod is the Stainless Steel mod.It pushes the game to it's maximum capacity,updating graphics,adding more factions,improving AI and more.

Medieval II is an magnificent game that will steal hours if not days from your life. [b] Important note though, [/b] this game has a mix between [u] Turn-Based kingdom management [/u] and [u] Real Time battles [/u] so [i] if you don't like TBS or RTS games i don't think MII is for you. [/i] Vanilla MII is a great game, but i personally suggest that you download either the StainlessSteel or the DarthMod mod conversions which change several game parameter and drastically increases the difficulty and adds tons of new content to the game. Diplomacy is pretty light but it is a forgivable feature due to this being a [b] Total War [/b] game and the whole point is to wage war and conquer everything in sight. Vanilla AI pathfinding i horrible in sieges, but there are some mods that can fix it, although not fully. In conclusion, MII is a unforgettable game that is certainly worth the low price you pay for tons of hours of war and conquest.

without a doubt one of the all time best total wars. 

-Being the last game on the old engine, collision detection actually works and units feel like they have actual mass to them. There is some genuine variety in the factions (although european ones do share lots of the same units) and the game has some surprisingly good rpg elements with your generals and faction leaders.

-The game's full of personality with outrageously stereotypical accents, an awesome soundtrack, and epic scale battles. While not as arcadey as more recent total wars, the game takes a more realistic approach (mostly) leading to slower gameplay (not necessarily a good or bad thing).

-The ridiculous squalor system from rome 1 is gone, and a ton of new features have been added to the main campaign (especially with the kingdoms expansion). These include crusades, the pope, mongol invasions, and so much more.

-And finally, last but not least the mods for this game are spectacular. Whether you want third age (best LOTR game out there imo) Broken crescent, hyrule total war, westereos or my favourite mod stainless steel. Stainless steel in particular solves many of the bugs and balance issues in vanilla (especially the slightly broken two-handed weapon and pikemen glitches)

-so TLDR-if you like total war, especially rome 1, buy this game.

This is probably one of the BEST RTS games out there. It's definitely my favorite Total War game. It is old, but the community is still thriving, and I've spent so many hours on this game just screwing around. Definitely a buy, and if you get into it Medieval II: Kingdoms is an amazing expansion pack.

By far this is one of the best Total War games to date.

What is Total War? Total War is a game where you pick a kingdom to dominate the world with. On the campaign map you will move your agents, and armies, and build upgrades to cities. When two armies meet you will go into a battlefield with thousands of soldiers fighting each other at the same time in an RTS battle.

This game is severely tactics based, so if you aren't good at micromanaging you are going to have a tough time. People with better strategies can win battles that were severely in the opponents favor.

As the game progresses you build your own story. You might raise a huge army to go destroy your enemies in a fit of rage for them killing your favorite general. Or ally with the kingdoms around you and double-team your enemies.

The general's in the game are a part of your royal family. As time progresses, your family will expand and each of these new children will grow up and become generals that you can have govern a town or be at the head of an army.

In the game there are also smaller things that add on to the game such as Crusades, Jihads, the discovery of gunpowder, the discovery of the americas, the mongols, and so on. Those things make the world feel fleshed out and make it feel alive.

Along with diplomacy is The Pope. Now, the pope sort of plays favorites, if you are friends with the papal states and another catholic kingdom declares war on you, the pope may excommunicate them from the catholic church, allowing a crusade to be called against them. When the crusade is called against them, all of Christendom will declare war on said faction and march their armies against them.

Now on to the pros and cons of the game
PROS:
- A large amount of factions with their own culture, units. advisors, and strengths
- Detailed Diplomacy
- Rebellions
- Large Strategic battles
- Jihads
- Catholic church and the pope
- Crusades and world events
- Long Campaign
- Family Trees
- Upgrading Cities
- Personal Stories
- Active modding community
- Multiplayer
- Not many bugs or crashes

CONS:
- Old game, poor graphics
- Animations are wierd sometimes
- Broken tutorial
- Co-op campaigns are done poorly

Overall this game gets a 10/10, Legendary
If you have never played a Total War game before, start with either Medieval 2 or Shogun 2

Example as Milan I am invaded by Venice and The Holy Roman Empire, caught unaware I win 2 Heroic victories, launch a counter attack that captures Venice and besiege Bolonge. Popes responce? Excommunicates me for winning a war I didn't start (which f**** you) and I end up not playing the rest of the campaign (wasted 8 hours). Long story short? Play a non-catholic faction and this is a great game.

Out of all the Total War games, I've liked Medieval II the most, mainly since it has enough mechanics to the gameplay without adding too much complexity that you end up using in the end.  As an example of this, I found the merchant mechanics pointless in Empire Total War when you're going for a conquest victory.  There's also a lot of content here with the new world discovery, and the Kingdoms expansion, which do more than just change the map around, especially with the new world scenario.  The downside is the AI can be very stupid at times, like when you're being sieged you can sallly out, and the enemy will for the most part stand still until you're close.  So for instance, you can use a balista or archers to take them all out if you position them on the flanks of the sieging army and you won't take any casualities.

Aside from that, a really good buy, especially if you can get it on sale.

> Comes to a siege unprepared
> A lot of my men die and break quickly
> Comes down to a few of the enemy's infantry vs archers and artillerymen all out of ammo
> Archers run away; artillerymen kill all of the remaining soldiers

11/10 Would win with artillerymen again

My god this game is epic.
Alright so I was playing as England and I first went and got York, Dublic, ect.
Then i went and declared war on scotland, that war lasted all of about four turns.
Then, and I know I had this game for 63 hours but I actually did not ever complete the game.
I stuck to custom and multiplayer battles. But anyway I went and fought France. Now I did not
do it out of the blue. the French were always threatening to invade me unless I paid a tax, normally like
560 or something. So anyway that was really cool. Massive armies clashing against eachother. Choosing
the better ground, it was like a game of thrones war. I gave my characters backstories and named the battles. 
I will give an example of one at the end. But anyway I was playing a short campaign and when I finished it and 
toppled the final French castle with the Milan and Holy Roman Empire at my side I suddenly get this epic music in ears.
Next thing I know Im in a throne room, like, once again, game of thrones and the Narrator goes on about how epic the
"English Empire" Is and how King Rufus, first of his name, protector of all of Christendom is the "Best king that will ever be. So yeah that was epic. Do I recommend this game? @$% yeah I would! But anyway onto the battle.

King Rufus looks over his men. Wearing their mail coifs and wielding swords of iron and steel. Infront of them stands an army of scots. It was led by a family member, he paused for a moment. He could not remember the mans name. He lined his spearmen in a straight line facing the highlanders and the rabble. Rufus saw the man Edenheart, he thought to himself Edenheart. Rufus ordered his men to fire upon the now charging highland horde. Two hundred arrows filled the sky, near blocking out the sun. Many casualties were theirs. Then the highlanders crashed into a line of iron spears. The line broke. He ordered his border horse to chase down the fleeing enemy. Then the young family member seeing the battle lost, rallied a small portion of men and charged down the hill in which his steed stood upon. Rufus stroked his horses mane. He then road through the line of men and crashed into the unsupecting scots. He met the young man, Edenheart. With one stroke of his blade he cut the man down. He looked at the young man that now lay in the mud, he had no remorse. He jumped down and cut the head of the man. He ordered one of the spear men to stab it unto their spear and march it around like a banner. Edenheart was brother to the king of the scots, the king that had killed his own father. He would have his vengenece no matter how many lives it took. 

Fin
Ps (Sorry for my English :))

Ultimate time sink.

One of the best RTS games ever made.

The Paper-Rock-Scissors-Gameplay works flawlessly, for example, it's very costly to send your cavallery against the enemy spearmen, but the spearmen take heavy losses from archers (if not in proximity) and the archers can't really hurt armored units like knights.
The Turn-Based gameplay between skirmishes is a bit dusted by the oldschool complexity style; but you can automate most of it.

The peak of the gameplay are of course defense of and attacking a castle. Therein, however, also lies the biggest flaw of the game: The AI.

I've won battles against an overwhelming amount of enemies, just by standing on the walls and waiting for the enemy chilling in the arrow fire to perish - nope, they didn't move a finger even though they stood right infront of their ladders which they had built up to seize the walls.

It's just astounding how much the AI can fuck up - for example, all units tend to jam gates and on the strategymap, the AI keeps declaring war and declaring peace every 5 or so turns.

It is to mention that you only have specific (historic) empires to play, which differ mainly on their starting position (duh), leading in significant disadvantages for some to join crusades (playing as England, an entire army deserted while being on a ship (however that works lol), because it took them too long to reach Jerusalem).

However, I've played many RTS games set in the medieval (fantasy) setting, none of which had such thrilling (and hard) combat. Every battle is a new challenge, and that makes this game great.

I haven't played any more recent Total War Games though, so maybe you'll be better off with some better graphics (they tend to tire your eyes quite quickly). 

TL;DR: I can warmly recommend this game to anyone that likes medieval RTS games and seeks a challenge. Don't expect the AI to be too much of a genius, though.

To start off, you should probably buy this game. I say probably, because $20 is a little pricey, but if its on sale for $10 or under get it! It is a great strategy game with two main modes. The campaign map is like an overall strategy game where you try to conquer the world, and the tactical battles are individual battles where you control an army. Although the graphics are outdated, the strategy in this game is priceless. Played a game as Portugal, and first killed Spain. Then fought and made peace with France, then went south and killed the Moors, then kept going east and killed sicily, kept going and am currently about to kill Egypt. I also conquered Rome from Sicily and returned it to the pope, who became my bestie for all of 2 turns until he died. The next pope hated me, but at the moment I am not excommunicated. 

And so,
If you read it through this far you probably should  buy the game.
Just do it.

Bought this game for 2.50 for the mods, play this game with mods exclusively. The base game is kind of meh in my opinion, but its value is in the dozens of full conversion mods that do everything from historical earth to a game that features Shrek vs Gungans. 

Its flawed, its old, its buggy, but its a canvas for new experiences. I've played this game for like 500 hours (this used to be 2 games before they merged the expansion into DLC for the base game) and the ONLY reason why is because of mods. You'll find some truly creative stuff out there, and no other TW game has the extensive modding community after this one.

I remember getting the CD ROM of this game for Christmeas the year it came out, and now I can play it again, without the trouble of keeping a disk.  Just like before, I've decided to only do custom battles because, let's be honest, the battles are the real fun.

UPDATE: Apparently it's now stable even with Steamworks.  The bunch of mods I've tried have worked fine.  Therefore I must change this to a positive review as I actually really enjoy the game, and now that it's no longer busted from bad updates it's playable again, and will likely remain that way as long as Steam doesn't die off.

I have been playing Total War games since a very long time, however my favorite is still Medieval (2), hopefully there'll be a 3rd in the future... The BEST total war followed by Rome 1, Hands down. I put hundreds of hours into this game and Shogun 1, Shogun 2, Rome 1, and Medieval 1, mostly on disk versions before Steam. These games contains my some of my fondest childhood video gaming memories. Medieval 2 in particular was always special to me. The multiple unit textures, the setting, visual armor upgrades, new world conquest, mods it all was great!

PROS
+Great soundtrack, it really lends to the battles
+End of Dark Ages to early Renaissance time period
+Great battle system
+Awesome/funny in game movies
+Beautiful 3D tactical map
+Lots of building depth
+Roughly 20 factions 
+Invasions
+Crusades/Jihads
+New world exploration
+Many units and unique units. New unit types unlock as years progress and some become outdated.
+Multiple textures for units, gone are the days of units filled with clones
+VIsible unit and settlement upgrades (on battlefield, armor/castle/wall upgrades)
+Realistically paced battles that allow you to plan your battles with tactics, so even if you are outnumbered say 1000-3000, you can still win if you take up a good defense (a hill) and perform flanking maneuvers all while pouring arrow hell down on the enemy. Battles don't last 10 minutes like in Shogun, so you have to make sure you have time for a battle!
+Available mods. Too many to name... I usually play Stainless Steel or Custom Campaign. Also, don't like every turn taking up 2 years? Change one line of code in the games notepad code to get 2 turns per year for 400+ turns!!
+Tons of cities to take
+Royal Lineage
+Diverse battle maps (generate from where you are on 3D tactical map)
+Kingdoms Expansion (Essential for some mods)

NEUTRAL
=The diplomacy isn't the greatest thing, heck, the newer Total Wars are probably worse, but it gets the job done for a game that is 10 years old.
=Trade, which can net you tons of extra income if used, is like a reworked version of the assassin mechanic
=Rebels could have had more depth, or even became new countries that would expand

CONS
-AI can be lacking. You can tweak the ai with mods though. Otherwise pump the battle AI to Very hard and put campaign AI to Hard, this will give you a good challenge without mods.
-The AI can sometimes spam massive amounts of units within a short amount of time, even if they have one city. Probably to compensate for AI being dumb at times. 
-Repetitive seige maps
-A couple of silly units (Sherwood archers....). Some mods get rid of them and make the game more realistic.
-No faction reemergences, like they had in Medieval 1, so when a faction is gone, its gone. This makes late game a slugging match between a few factions, instead of multiple factions duking it out still (Like in real life, Knights of Honor or Crusader Kings)
-Bridge battles are kind of one sided, towards you. The AI has a tendency to rush into small places sometimes, getting slaughtered in the process.

Overall Medieval 2 Total War is one of the best in the series and you'll have loads of fun charging cavalry into exposed infantry, seeing knights hack each other to pieces and unloading into Aztecs with gunpowder all while being enamored by the glorious soundtrack! This is just to name a few moments out of the hundreds that this game will give you. If you call your self an Strategy gamer and haven't played this game, you've missed out on a classic!

Total War: Warhammer just came out huh?
Total war: Medieval 2 Warhammer End times just came out as well, all you need is M2TW and Kingdoms, and now you have the entire Warhammer world, instead of just a small patch of it.
Perhaps your not into Warhammer? How about Lord of the Rings? Want to play as the orcs of morder, and bring back the one ring and see what happens?
Perhaps you want to just relive the medieval times as a loyal Crusader, or warmongering Jihadist?
Then Medieval 2: Total war is what you want.

The modding community for this game is INSANE! There are mods which allow you to improve upon the base campaign significantly, to completely overhauling the game. This is something no other Total war in the franchise has nearly achieved. This game's modding community can beat anything CA puts out, the new Medieval 2: Warhammer End times mod that came out roughly around the same time Total War Warhammer came out, proves this.

Buy this game. NOW. (Be sure to buy Kingdoms!)

This is the first game that introduced me to grand strategy, after Stronghold Crusader and that series. I was recommended it by a friend and was not disappointed whatsoever. This is one of only 3 games on steam (so far) that have gotten onto my 'favorites' list. This is one game that hasn't gotten old yet, a classic that will always hold a place in my heart. Sure, it may be a bit outdated, but it is still a wonderful game. The variety of units and factions is staggering, and it's sheer amount of replayability is staggering. Think about this: 26 factions x 25 maps x 12 settlement types... that's 7800 battles, not including weather, allies, or army variants... The possibilities are nearly endless!
In my opinion, this is the best strategy game I've ever played. If you plan on buying it, buy the Kingdoms expansion pack along with it, it just makes the game better than it already is.

One of the best RTS/Turn Based strategy games I have ever played, Medieval II: Total War is a gem within a greatly honored series. Medieval II follows the early portion of the Medieval period (~1080) all the way through the late Medieval period and the discovery of the new world (~1530), this RTS/Turn Based hybrid is a slow paced strategy geared towards domination through war and conquest. 
The game features a diplomacy system and incorporates a grand strategy map with RTS battles. The hybrid allows for players to enjoy one or the other or both systems in their path to ruling Medieval Europe. 
The initial stages of the game are slow going, and patience is a requirement unless one doesn't care about the grand campaign. Other than the grand campaign, one can partake in custom and quick RTS battles or historical RTS battles inspired by actual events. One can play a number of factions including France, England, the Holy Roman Empire, the Moors, the Byzantine Empire, the Danish, and many more, all complete with strengths and weaknesses. The only con is that only about five or six of the factions are playable from the beginning until one completes either the short or long campaign (the difference between those is the amount of regions one must own and the factions one must destroy. For example: England's short campaign requires 15 provinces and the destruction of France, while the Long Campaign requires 50 provinces, including Jerusalem, as well as the destruction of France and Scotland).
Overall, a well made game to pour a large number of hours into as you await your destruction by the Mongols :)

Ok changed my review as rerolled as the turks and it was a bit more challenging. It's not Rome but it's as close as you can get. The timurids while a more challenging faction, if you started in the west then they will just help you by destroying your enemies in the east before meeting them which makes it easy to land grab your enemies, same applies to the monguls. If you started in the east then they just provide an annoinance as your armies will be in the west and they both show up around the time of the plague so for a few turns you will be just shifting armies around towns to make some sort of army to stop them, it basicaly just delays you with your real war with countries in the west.
Biggest ruiner for this game is gunpowder, once this gets invented it becomes real easy mode as the AI is pretty stupid and decides anything that uses gunpowder must be better. There is no use for gunpowder apart from taking a city as soon as you arrive at the walls, 1 canon is needed for this, anymore is just stupid. The AI will create armies full of hand gunners, canons and other siege equipment which stand no chance against cavalery, an army without horse and spear is a dead army. Avoid recruiting any firearm units they are just as likely to blow holes in the back of your men as they are of the enemy.
Other than this it's still pretty enjoyable.

I have roughly 4000 hours total.
I literally had this game since i had a computer. it was the first game i ever got on computer.
And it is perfect.
There are many things wrong with it, but perfection is not flawless, it is the acceptance of ones flaws and shining brighter despite them.
True greatness in gaming comes from innovation, beauty, and passion.
Creative Assembly, Rest their souls, were at the top of their game when they made this beautiful piece of perfection.
There is no story.
Sort of.
The stories are usually crafted by you, the player.
You can be a king. an emperor. a dictator, a peasant. or even a lowly lepor (you heard me.)
there really is no limit to the story you could craft from this game.
Of course, its main feature is the combat.
You play as a tactician giving commands to your armies and organizing them into different formations.
Your army is split into units compramised of 30-400 soldiers. These are usually all one type.
They include: Archers, Spearmen, Swordsmen, Calvary and heavy variants of each.
You then organize them into formations on a randomly generated map fighting against your enemies that are also setting up their formations.
I wont spoil much of the fun, but over time this games graphics have become dated. Obviously, thats to be expected. 
However, I still highly reccomend diehard strategists get this game.

Played this game for over 400 hours and loved every minute. The base game was fantastic and offered a great mix of intellectual organization and also the opprotunity for roleplay elements, the world map being large enough to keep you satisfied with whichever nation you choose as it will always provide a challenge to turn that map one colour.

  The DLC was also some of the best I've played in most likely any of the Total war Series. Each capturing a different period of medieval history while also providing a range of challenges. The America campaign being one of my favorites since it shifts the atmosphere of the game so radically.

  Now as if the base game and DLC wasn't enough. the community has picked every piece of meat from the bone in terms of mods for the game which allow you to play as a lord of the Seven kingdoms of Westeros, the Uruks of Isengard or even just mods that increase realism and immersion.

  This game has captured my attention for over 400 hours, and its been a solid experiance the entire time.

In my opinion, this is the best the Total War series has to offer. Shogun II was good in it's own way but nothing beats Med II. Deep, rich strategy with a wide variety of units, factions and replayability. Best of all, NO CRAPPY DLC FLOOD which robs players by demanding more money for content that should have been in the original release to begin with. This game comes with EVERYTHING at one sticker price and for those who know how to mod file folders you can unlock every faction in the campaign...none of the $7.99 for 3 factions that are nearly identical. 

This game was released when CA cared about producing a quality product and providing the players with a great stand alone game.

Probably the greatest Total War game to ever be released. Shame it didn't get the advertising campaign like Rome: Total War did. Truly an underappreciated masterpiece. My biggest wish is that Creative Assembly can achieve this level of mastery once again. If you can withstand graphics from 2006, I highly suggest playing it. 

As you build your kingdom over the course of 400 years, don't forget to discover America, declare a Crusade/Jihad, assassinate the last 3 heirs of a family line to take over half of their kingdom, use your recently converted christian populace to stir up unrest and rebellion in the local muslim kingdom or vice versa, develop gunpowder, have one of your priests elected pope, get excommunicated, have your merchants systematically take advantage of another nation's trade resources, assassinate your own king, and watch as everything you worked for crumbles when the Black Death hits. This game had it all.

i recently baught this on steam after my many years old hard copy stopped working,

i have played many hours on all the total war games (bar rome 2 but meh) and i have to say this is probably the best of the bunch. it takes the foundations of rome and builds a castle of awesome on top, the units reasonably accurate the visuals are nice for this type of game and the gameplay is intuitive and easy to play in both short and long sessions.

the only downside to this game is it has a fault that is present in every total war game, irrational AI. most gamers will not notice this flaw, but if you are used to much more complicated AI decision making (ie from the paradox series HOI3 and EU IV etc) then the AI will start to bug you somewhat,
in terms of diplomacy just dont bother with anything other than map information, alliances will be broken on a whim (i gave up on aliances after the fith ally in a row attacked me) ceasfires are irrelavant as even if its suicide they will attack you before the ink is dry, these are just a few irrationalities there are many.
the battle AI is a little better but it tends to just go for the zerg rush approach and it doesnt have a  clue how to use reinforcements (it will never try to concentrate its forces the reinforcments will either sit at the map edge or wait till you have defeated the other army before attacking)

while that may seem like a huge issue, if your just looking for an arcady rts then  you most likely wont notice those minor flaws and it still gets my seal of aproval.

final note make sure to get the collection  the extra 4 is well worth it.

I've sunk a lot of hours into playing this game outside of steam, having actually broken the discs from overuse several times. The game is just good enough to buy a replacement!

As a turnbased strategy game based in medieval times from 1088 onward, you'll see your fledgling kingdom emerge from the dark ages, embark on (or defend against!) crusades, weather the ravages of the black death and finally settle into a bustling empire at about a 1500's level of technology, sailing to the new world. Depending on your proclivities, this could be to get some of that sweet aztec chocolate or to teach the natives all about christ or muhammad. Sadly, you can't possibly set sail without the proper late game ships so you'll see no vikings looting aztec gold outside of custom battles.

Holy wars in particular have their own feature, allowing catholics to petition the pope to claim non christian lands (if sufficiently worthy in his eyes) or if you're a muslim ruler, have an imam stir the ummah to march westward. In practice, this causes you and the AI factions of your religion (if they comply) to amass quick and cheap armies who move much faster on the campaign map to reach specific goals such as Jerusalem or hell, why not London? The Orthodox factions of the Byzantine empire and Russia lack this feature for understandable reasons and must simply endure the indignity of foreigners marching through their lands in a religious frenzy.

Religion isn't all about cheap conquests and disgruntled greeks, though. The pope can get very disgruntled on his own and a particulary bellicose, impious king can easily awaken his ire to call a crusade on your sorry royal backside. Muslim factions should consider this as the pope will always be pissed at you, all the time for being muslim. Even if you court the christian kingdoms with gold, pope AI is likely to randomly declare a massive war on his best muslim buddy! 

Furthermore, failing to maintain your particular religion in your far flung provinces will cause heresy to rise. Once that gets particularly bad, heretics units pop up, acting as priests of a new religion you'll have to squash to avoid rebellion. If catholic, sufficiently heretical provinces will have the papal states send inquisitors. These hardasses aren't particularly concerned if the agent spreading faith in the province is a heretic or your very own frickin' cardinal. Don't let divergent ways take root. Beware the heretic, the Emperor protects.

At the start, you only have a few factions unlocked. England in its freshly conquered Norman suit with its classic longbowmen, the French with their legendary knights, the holy roman empire (amusingly beset by heresy), Spain or rather a version of Castile at the onset of the reconquista and the republic of Venice (don't worry, you still get crowned emperor at the end). 

As you conquer other factions, you actually unlock them for future playthroughs with the exception of the timed event invasions of mongols and timurids so if you ache really badly to play Scots and don't want to mod the game, swallow your pride and march the English north for a quick, new faction. Pick your kingdom and get crackin' because destiny awaits!

Aside from the basic features, the developers put a lot of effort into the little things which adds a lot to the experience of your campaign. Sending a spy to peek on an enemy army or an assassin to deal with enemy nobles and even the pope(!) will trigger its own video sequence. In addition, as your nobles age and aquire various traits, it can and will, especially in the case of the English and French, cause their real time battle speeches to take on hints of their personalities. A noble leading an army tends to have entertainingly scathing remarks about the rival nations even if they aren't particularly awkward, alcoholic or frothing mad.

Furthermore, Jeff van Dyck contributes with some pretty breathtaking pieces of atmospheric music that'll set the mood for your battles. It's some pretty exceptional stuff that I've yet to see other total war games top almost 10 years later.

All's not sunshine, however and the game is plagued by the same basic empire management and faction flaws that hampered Rome: Total War. Specifically, squalor can and will cause unguarded cities to rebel and there's little to be done about it. On the plus side, a rebel city counts as heretical which allows you to call a crusade or jihad to claim it from the obviously ungodly rebels. 

As for other issues, given how the autoresolving of battles works with unit statistics, AI fighting AI will tumble easily to high hitpoint cavalry. In Rome it was chariots, in Medieval 2 it's the elephants. Where this meant Egypt would usually consume all of the middle east in Rome: Total War unless you personally stopped them, this now applies to the late game Timurid hordes. 

The problem with both mongol and timurid invasion is that these factions don't need to pay any upkeep for some of their units, allowing the situation to snowball fast and turning the late game into an endless slog. I've ended up fighting back a massive mongol empire that held all of russia and poland well into the 1700's using English longbowmen!

Additionally, the timescale of the base game runs on two years per turn while your royal family only ages one year. This is an oversight but is easily modded out by subtle edits to a file that even a modding halfwit like myself could figure out without breaking the game.

Overall, it's a nice, relatively polished game of compelling history and strategy. If this appeals, get it now.

I know this game recieves high grades in steam but for the life of me I don't understand why. most of the battle mechanics are basically broken: archers can't fire effectively when on walls, cavalry don't charge most of the time, skirmishers usually get lost or caught, pathfinding of units in cities and especially on walls is atrocious and many other small things. 

Some of the things are fixed by mods but most aren't and mods bring an element of instability to the game. For me the game (when modded) tends to crash after large siege battles. Also, as usual, the AI is clueless leaving you with either playing against a really handicapped opponent (normal difficulty) or letting it "cheat" (hard mod and above). Also broken is diplomacy (unless modded and even so is extremely limited). I'm a long time total war player but this game is mostly frustrating and annoying. I get that the cartoonish new style is a turn off in the new total wars games but at least things work so I really don't get the huge difference in opinion between this game and the ones that follow.
Maybe it took people time to realize that the total war series is in decline?  In any case while fun can be had in this game, if you're expecting the same level of gameplay as in previous titles I'd recommend you stay away from this.

While the campaing and the solo playing games are very nice, it needs some fixing in the multiplayer area. when playing with your friends in local area, you cant fill the game with computer players, which really sucks. 
Another aspect of the multiplayer game is that there are almost no games in the lobby list, and many games are not viable to be joined. Other than that it's a good game. Requires a beffy computer sometimes.
Some people say, there are broken civs but I don't believe it's a big deal, I haven't got any problems with any civilization in custom game mode.

Favourite Total War so far.

-Try to take over a town but get rekt.
-Blame the game at first but decide to try again taking a different approach.
-Instead of sending your entire force into this massive blob you place small amounts of them in three positions around the city you have Center Force, Right Force, And Back Force.
-Harass the defenders with arrows baiting them out of the city so they can be cut down by your infantry.
-They send some of their forces to attack your Right Force.
-Wait for them to get outside of the town and then trap them in a bubble of soldiers.
-Send Back Force to attack their archers who are all inside the town center.
-They send some pikes to stop you.
-Take out their pikes with the help of your javelins.
-They send spears to slow you down.
-Meanwhile the forces they sent after Right Force earlier are all routing back to the town center.
-Your archers are out of ammo in your Center Force.
-Same with Right Force.
-You charge Center Force into the town square.
-Send the rest of your Right Force to support Back Force.
-Center Force taking heavy losses from the archers.
-Back force breaks through the spears.
-The combined force of Back Force, and Right Force charge into the exposed backs of the enemy's within the town square.
-Noone is spared.


Then you realise that was just for one town...and you have like 45 more to conquer... Hooooo-boy.

Medieval 2 is one of the best games in the Total War series, the graphics might be a little dated, but the gameplay is as good as ever. Thanks to the publisher and Feral Interactive it is now out on linux, hopefully other older TW games will follow. If you're a fan of the Total War games this is a must buy. As someone who loves the Medieval Era, and everything around it, this game is pretty awesome.
As someone who loves the TW series, this game is pretty awesome as well.
I came into this game off play the original Rome:TW, and I quickly learned that the gamestyle is a lot different. Instead of having a big professional army, you have an army of peasants, and then expensive units of lords and knights. Instead of conquering the heck out of your neighbors, you need to (if you're playing a Christian kingdom) consider the political and spritual (i.e. if the Pope will like it or not) ramifications of starting a war, thanks to chivalry.
As a TW fan, I love this game. As a history buff, I love this game. As a person, I love this game.

Final Thoughts:
Did/do I have fun? Yes
Does it have issues? The AI seems a bit wonky at times. Units seems to push off against one another like there was a force-field around them. 
Should you buy it? Probably. I dunno, man. I don't know you.
Can you go on a Crusade against the enemies of Christendom? Yes. Papa bless.

I've played Empire, Napolean, and Shogun 2 (played Rome 2 for a couple hours but the graphics were shit on my computer and I couldn't play it).
Here are the pros and cons:

Pros:
-Each faction has a greater variety for its playing style. (spain relies on cav, venice relies on militia...etc. whereas shogun 2, empire and napolean, the faction differences are basically moot and don't change too much).
-two types of towns that require strategic use of each in order to win. Castles produce good units, Cities produce income. Without cities you're broke but without castles you'll be overrun be stronger units
-Population growth system (one of the few things that I'm upset wasn't included in shogun 2)
-You MUST use the layout of the map strategically during a siege if you want to win
-MERCENARIES (I love this and I wish napoleon, empire, and shogun did it)
-ranged units on walls are balanced so they aren't op
-population growth adds an interesting twist. Populations in cities will always become a problem at some point and will threaten with throwing you out (aka squalor)

Cons:
-Most agents are worthless. The only agent you need are priests/imams to convert people to your religion. You only need one diplomat at the beginning to establish contact at the beginning of the game, after that they are uselss. Assissin's are kinda useless. Merchants are useless initially (because they always get bought out by the enemy).
-balancing problems. Missile cavalry are stupidly op (especially early on). Crossbows are better than archers even though peasants of both costs the same.
-It's super difficult to get morale boosting traits for generals
-like every total war game, once you get to a certain point, no matter which difficulty, the game stops being a challenge and you just steam roll everyone else
-bad AI (generals always charge in front during sieges and get killed)

>Take a bunch of cities
>Cities revolt, lose them
>Nothing you can do about it
>Enemy takes these cities immediately
>Enemy moves troops through your territory
>You can't do anything about it
>Instantly take your capital
>Try taking it back
>Pope threatens you to not attack them
>Take back your capital = excommunicated by Pope
>Everyone attacks you
>WTF...

This could have been a great game... indeed many contend that it is. I disagree however, because my criteria for a great game includes controls that are not broken.

Go on the internet and you will see legions of fanboys jumping through hoops to defend the obvious lazy programming and lack of anything even resembling QA testing that has resulted in controls so broken that even the simplest of maneuvers can reduce even normally patient gamers to shouting, fist-pounding emotional wrecks as they watch what should have been a gimme battle devolve into an embarrassing defeat simply due to the fact that it is next to impossible to get your troops to do as they are told.

Fanboys respond to this by saying "you just have to learn how to micro it properly", or "maybe if you learned to do it properly..." blah blah blah, ad nauseum. I call shenanigans. I'm not talking about advanced maneuvers. Not even the cavalry charges. I'm talking about "you three units, go over here and stand in a line". Ten minutes later, they are still milling around where they were before, apparently totally defeated by the entrance to a city street. And now you're out of position, and your strategy collapses as your longbowmen are outflanked by the cavalry your spearmen were supposed to be defending against. There is no excuse for this. And if it isn't getting stuck on each other and milling around, it's running *past* the spot where you told them to go, triggering a battle you're not ready for and resulting in units routing and strategies failing. No excuse. 

Cavalry is similarly broken. You cannot have more than one unit of cavalry at a time, because one unit requires constant micromanagement just to charge properly. They have to be lined up *just so*, the enemy has to be clicked on *just so*, they have to be watched all the way to their target lest they encounter a tree or a slight rise and begin milling around in confusion, and they have to be told to retreat the instant they hit, or even the lowliest of peasants will begin to bowl them over like ninepins. If you can have more than one unit of cavalry in this game; never play it again because you can click fast enough to make money playing Starcraft professionally.

This is the only review I've ever written for a game on Steam. After playing Medieval 2, Rome, Empire, and Rome 2, I can safely say that Medieval is still my favorite in the series. Yes, the later iterations ARE prettier. This game was released in 2006 after all. However, in my opinion, you can't beat the game engine they used. The Warscape engine that is utilized by the newer games (empire onwards) has taken a loooooong time to reach the same level of melee combat satisfaction that I got from M2. Sure, there are no fancy one v one animations. BUT, those animations also wrecked havoc with how many battles played out. I don't think I ever saw two soldiers gang up on one soldier in any game other than M2 and Rome 1. Battles are played out more by training stats, upgrades, and tactics vs. a boat ton of special abilities and badas* animations. I know there are plenty of people who won't agree, but it's just my experience. 

The biggest reason why I always come back to this game is the modding community. I had the game running on a virtual version of windows on my mac (years before the mac version was released) JUST so I could play Third Age Total War. Not to mention all the unit mods, engine and animation tweaks, etc. This is still probably the most mod friendy total war game out there. I spent dozens of hours over the last 8-9 years compiling units and tweaks to get my game just right, enduring hundreds of coding errors and game re-installs. Little by little (and somehow without taking over my life) Medieval 2 became a near-perfect game. And this is a guy with little to no mod creation or coding experience whatsoever. 

All in all, it's a wonderful game that won't be surpassed until they potentialy do a new Total War in the Medieval setting. It's perfectly fine without mods, but if you're like me and discovered just how awesome the modding community is, it's the best Total War game to mod in my opinion.

What I am trying to say is:
+ Tactics are the core of this game, a smart commander can win with nearly any competent force composition as opposed to just buying top tier unit spam.
+ Great Political/Kingdom Management System outside of battles.
+ Ungodly 22 factions, each with their own nuances and tactics to master, but still realistic.
+Beautifully done melee and archery combat, the fights are fully animated with their own brutal kills and flying corpses, which is kind of a must for a medieval RTS

- Learning Curve is not for the faint of heart
- Games take a very long time, especially when good players can fight each other to a stand still
- Sometimes its unclear how quickly your units break, especially in some circumstances where they seem like they will win, but the AI is generally very good and this along with a few smattering of bugs (Not on Rome TW2 Level) make up a small portion of the Game Overall.

An older game that I had before it was available on Steam. Spent an embarrasing amount of time playing it. The vanilla is good, but with the Stainless Steel mod, it really shines. Even with as old as it is, it's still a fun game to play and the graphics have held up pretty well. The last Total war game that was good. The newer ones are prettier but don't play as well and aren't as much fun.

[h1]The Good:[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Great graphics (for its time but still hold up today)
    [*]Diverse choice of factions. From the northern Kingdom of Denmark to the Byzantine Empire
    [*]Excellent replayability
    [*]A wide variety of choices on how to grow your kingdom or empire. Through diplomacy, war, or even treachery.
    [*]Massive mod support. Medieval II easily sports some of the best mods in the Total War franchise. Find them here: http://www.twcenter.net/forums/forumdisplay.php?3-Medieval-II-Total-War
    [*]Large-scale battles that require quick thinking
    [*]An enormous campaign map that allows you to strategise as if you were a true king!
[/list]

[h1]The Bad:[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Horrible optimization. To this day, running this on max settings on a GTX 960 GPU is still not enough to run it smoothly.
    [*]Occasional glitches such as armies not moving, a few crashes, and trade agreements failing for no apparent reason.
[/list]

[h1]Summary:[/h1]
Overall, Total War: Medieval II is one of the best Total War games in the franchise, and still stocks up well against modern strategy games. If you love the medieval period and strategy games, I see no reason for why you should not pick this game up.

[h1]Rating: 9/10[/h1]
