I don't quite know what to make of this game. Tactically, the game is brilliant, as usual for Total War. The battles are majestic and make sense for the most part, and you actually do have to use what would amount to standard medieval tactics to win these engagements. On the strategic level, this game is horrible. The AI, no matter what difficulty setting you have it turned to, seems to be permanently set to 'Syphilitic Bipolar Nero.' What makes the AI in this game so hard to beat on the campaign map is that it is utterly unpredictable. For example, in one campaign I was the only faction to join and successfully complete the Crusade the Pope called for. I built numerous churches and used a whole lot of missionaries to bludgeon my faith into nearby territories like a bunch of Jehova's Witnesses on crack/cocaine. What did this get me? I was excomunicated and wiped off the map by less pious kingdoms. Other factions will attack for no reason, refuse to settle a conflict EVEN THOUGH they are about to be wiped out, and just generally behave like 5-year olds. There are better medieval strategy games than this. 4/10.

Great game and the best of all the Total War series for me personally, partly because of the time period and partly because of it being the first Total War game I ever bought. It has some issues now in terms of poor wide screen support and stuff like difficulty of mod installing for steam version, but its still a great and addictive game. Over the years communnity around it made it only better with lots of amazing mods like LotR themed Third Age:Total War and Warhammer fantasy themed Age Of Warhammer:Total War(which is btw without doubt is one of the reasons we get Warhammer:Total War now). I played hundreds of hours of this game and never got tired of it, and I could tell you hell of a lot of stories what happened within it in that time, but it would take too long. So just know that like any good game, this one allows you to come up with stories of your own while having a great time playing and enjoying most of its aspects.

This is an amazing game right here. If youre into strategic games, then this game is perfect for you. Its like a more advanced type of the game R.I.S.K. The way you can pick from different civilizations and conquer all the others is awesome. The managing of your economy, military, and building production is spot on. Even the battling system is great. You can either auto- simulate the battle ( in case you just want it over with quickly), or use your strategic mind to conquer the battlefield by either losing less men or winning an out matched battle. The seige part of the game is nice too because when you're attacking or defending, it seems pretty fair. It is a pain on how other civilizations will ask you to become allies and the 2 turns later start attacking you. The ship battling part of the game seems a little unfair because those are the only battles where you have to auto- simulate. Over all the graphics of the game are good for its time, the battling system is good, diplomacy system is a little iffy, challenges the mind, and you actually get a good history lesson for the most part.

Although rather dated in graphics, the campaign of mideval total war 2 makes up for it in unit size, and storyline. A great base for modders to create there dreams based on the models of mideval 2, in all medieval 2 is a great addition to any total war collection

My honest opinion:

The AI is what really stands out. It's just as competent in battle as Attila's (the most recent TW title) is, and does well in the campaign, too.

The tactical (battle) part of the game has aged incredibly well, all things considered. The combat mechanics are robust, and abilities are important (though a bit 'busy' in terms of interface, and fire-at-will is not always enabled by default on units that are meant to only fight at range). The asymetry in rosters means that combat can really vary a good deal, yet the balance feels just right.

The strategic (campaign) part of the game aged less well. It's certainly playable, and it, too, feels balanced yet complex, but I'd be lying if I said the user-interface was all that good. As campaign UI goes, it's somewhat cluttered IMO, though I'd argue it's probably better than N:TW's was.

In technical stuff, it's really, really stable, something that inexplicably was not the case in Empire and N:TW... in those games, I seemed to get sound glitches on the campaign screen, crash during battles, and so forth pretty much every campaign, forcing constant saving to be ready. Here, though, the game never seems to glitch up or break down.

In artistic stuff, the game does quite well. For the era it was made in, the unit cards are good, and the unit models are surprisingly detailed when you zoom all the way in. The music is great, too. And the voice-over is, as always, the one mixed-bag (aside from the campaign UI, which was mentioned above). Voice-over work is terrible for units, but acceptable for in-game advisor and narration of pre-battle stuff (in historical battles, etc.).

Overall, is it worth it for $20.00? Well, without mods I could see arguements that $20.00 is too high... but bear in mind how long the game has existed and how many people made mods for it, and it becomes evident that there will be plenty of mods to wade through and try.

So, I marginally recommend it. A decade ago, I'd say to pick it up in a heart-beat... today, it's still just as good, but should really be a bit cheaper given that you will want to get the Kingdoms expansion as well and, hey, it's a pretty old title now (both it and the ex-pack).

On sale, though, it's a no-brainer: pick it up.

This game is such a great concept. A no brainer, really. So whats the problem with every game in this franchise? The A.I. is also a no brainer. There is no challenge short of the lazy, overwhelm the player situation. Which is still hard since I just fought one of my armys ( around 1k troops) againts three seperate armies with 2x my numbers. I wish I could say it was because I made some impossible move that won the day. (it WAS a tough fight, toughest I have seen so far) I didn't do anything smart. I did the only thing I could do to win. Pelted the A.I from far away until they gave me no choice but to engage them. once routed, I pulled my forces back, remorfed my lines and repeated. 2 other armys form into this and it becomes more of a timing game.

Right after this, I go to defend a castle under siege. The problem? EVERY TIME the computer attacks my castles, they just sit there. 100% of the time I had to go after them. At best, I can send out 1 calvalry unit to gode them into doing something, but that rarely works. They siege my castle, I have to leave the castle and go after them. yay...

I would sum up the Total War fanchise as follows: great ideas, HORRIBLE execution. NONE of it matters if the computer can't at least attack you during THEIR invasion of your territory. Everything else could be prefection, but with an A.I. that does little more then shuffle it's troops around, it wouldn't matter. I hate to say it, but stay clear of the entire franchise until a new game is released that shows an A.I. I couldn't trick into drowning itself. :(

I started with Rome: Total War and it was a great game. You picked an empire to control and used diplomacy, force, and cunning to grow. You manage armies, cities, and special units (spys/diplomats) in order to conquor Europe and surrounding areas.

What Medieval II: Total War did was took Rome: Total War and made it even better. With the same mechanics and the addition of converting cities to forts and vice-versa the gameplay becomes even better. New units, new Factions, and a new map gave this series a well deserved title.

I myself consider Medieval II: Total War to be the best game in the entire Total War franchise because instead of dumbing down the game (which is becoming rampant in the game industry) they took what they had and improved upon it instead.

I recommend you buy this game if you are an intelligent person who enjoys to plan things out and act upon them with patience and coordination.

Total War is a long running franchise made by CA (Creative Assembly.) This franchise is known for the tactical and wide scale gameplay. For those who are not familiar with total war it works like this. The campaign plays like a grand strategy, you have build, recruit, run politics, diplomacy, and warfare each and every turn until you win. When your army engages an enemy are it is brought to more of an RTS setting where you control your army to either annhiliate, defend, or route your enemy. Multiplayer is all about the RTS setting, however, there are ways to play multiplayer campaigns, sadly they are hard to setup. 

Pros
 
-Realistic combat: There is friendly fire, moral levels (enemies, allys, and your army will route if moral is too low), and realistic counter units.

-In depth strategy both multiplayer and single player

-Many factions to choose from

-Looks great for being an older game

-Has historical battles that you can play

-Provides hours of entertainment

Cons

-Can be very difficult to understand

-Pathfinding bugs

-Lacks naval battles

-Units will sometimes ignore your orders, even if they don't have the bonus effect "Will charge without order"

An epic game set in an epic era, medieval II is a title different from other total war games. Its beautiful graphics in combination with the inspiring music makes you feel the excitement to play it. The diplomacy is very realistic, the battles are just epic and the options on developing your empire are endless. Make sure to buy the DLC ''Kingdoms'' for a complete adventure!

I love this game, Medieval 2 Total War in my opinion is the best Total War game to date, Rome Total War polished, and I enjoy the medieval era more than the Roman era. Objectively speaking there is an undeniable quantity of value in this game, before I downloaded mods I had about 200 hours. The vanilla version of this game is excellent. I could even play the campaign mode of the vanilla version after playing the campaign mode of these mods. Battles in this game are the best it will ever be and with multiple medieval eras from early to high to late where you have musket men and cannons. I could have an army of Mongolian cavalry fight an army of French pikemen and musket men. Possibilities in the battles are endless! Also, battles require tactical positioning, flanking, planning and using your brain in general. If you dont like to use your brain, than dont buy this game. If you do, however, you will find very interesting and creative ways to defeat your enemies. When to attack the enemy or hold position and send spearmen to the front, when you should retreat or hold fast. There is just so much fun to have in battles. 
The Campaign mode has no story, like every other Total War game, based on the situation of your nation and other nations, plans and ambitions, you make your own story. Be the king of England and defeat the French once and for all, forge an empire of 2 land masses. Play as Byzantium and retake lost lands and lost lands of the Roman empire. When it comes to recruitment and construction it is balanced. Recruitment pools determine how many units you can recruit per turn and how long you must wait until you can recruit another one of the same unit. This prevents large and massive armies of heavy infantry running all over the place. Diplomacy feels real as in the medieval times there were no phones to call other leaders. Countries had to send a diplomat and wait for a response. Diplomacy is not as in depth as it could be, but this game is focused around war and military. Keep that in mind when you play the campaign mode. Trade, alliances, embargos, vassals, military access, the basics are all there. Events happen in the campaign mode throughout such as the Mongolian invasion, the discovery of gunpowder and the new world, and yes, this game includes the plague.
Overall, unless you are too stupid to use your brain in coordination and deep thought, you will enjoy this game and get your moneys worth without a doubt. Even at full retail price I would still find my moneys worth. Go buy it on sale if you are still sceptical, I did it, too.
I give this game a full 10/10!
AWESOME

Second best Total War title to date, second only to Rome 1. Only thing that makes it worse is the Castle/City feature, where each settlement is divided into two categories: Castles and Cities. Castles are obviously hard to attack, having up to 3 layers of walls, and recruit much better units. They are poor for getting money or raising population, you can't even set taxes to the castles. Cities recruit worse units (though depending on your faction sometimes the city parts are better than their castle counterparts, Italian Spear Milita and Venetian/Genoean Crossbowmen being examples of this) but are so much better for economy. Most of the time your armies will be composed of units that can only be recruited in castles, but if you take a city with it and lose a lot of troops there is no way to replenish them unless you send them to another castle. 

That is literally my only gripe with this game. Graphics still kind of hold up, even 9 (holy shit this game is 9 years old?!?!) years later. Massive scale armies are often seen, the AI isn't entirely stupid and can be logical in their choices after you think hard enough. There is a stereotype (much like Civ V) that the AI will randomly attack you for no reason, but there are always logical reasons. Either they see you as weak and easy pickings, you are attacking (and beating) one of their allies, or you've taken lands that they wanted. If you really want to avoid war with a certain faction, just avoid those three things. 

The game can be challenging at times, often times you will think you've won a war and then suddenly they have a full army besieging your capital, that carefully hid in the forests so you couldn't see them. The economy isn't as challenging as I'd like it to be, you can simply raise taxes as high as you can without having the happiness go below 100% (Yea for some reason the happiness can go well over 100%, it's weird) and don't garrison your cities with expensive units. As long as you're using your armies to conquer cities you'll never go into the red. 

The game is challenging and interesting, no two campaigns will ever be the same. A lot of things are predictable, such as for me Milan always seems to be a huge power that gobbles up France and the Holy Roman Empire with ease, and Egypt always ends up winning in the east unless the Mongols decide to head that direction (they always beeline straight for Poland/Hungary/Russia in my games and get destroyed by knights). There are in game events such as the Mongol invasion, the Black Death, the Timurid invasion, Gunpowder being invented, and you can even travel to the New World late in the game. You will quickly learn to love and hate some factions, personally I hate fighting any italian faction just because their Italian Spear Militia are rediculous and their crossbowmen do waaay too much damage without taking much in return. 

Overall the game is a 9,9/10 for me. It's my second favorite strategy game of all time, and there is a still active modding community that can spice up your games should you ever get bored of the same map/factions. Definetly worth the 20$, but you'll often find it on sale for much less. The DLC is definetly worth at least a try, it adds 4 new campaigns (different maps and factions, it doesn't add anything to the main game they're basically 4 smaller standalone games) which are pretty fun but a tad bit small and limited, which is to be expected given how small the regions are. If you liked any other Total War game or are interested in buying one to see if you do like it, definetly buy either this one or Rome 1 first.

The only annoying parts of the game for me, is having to deal with the Pope and his contant demans and nagging, but you get used to it and just send your least favorite generals off to die in the crusandes and not conquor the world for a few turns because the French attacked me first and aparently god is against a counter attack.... that and of course the older controls from a while back like the arrow keys instead of WASD, setting your units into groups can sometimes end them up in awkward and strange formations, and a slight lack of detail has to why a settlement is pissed even though the public order is at 100%.  

For beginners, I would suggest you play as England, for the cool people I would suggest scotland because of the OP highlander infantry, or if you really want a challange, the Holy Roman Empire

As i hope you can all see from the hours spent playing i rather enjoyed this game. If you enjoy playing strategy games that are based heavily on long term victories or are a fan of any others in the seiries i would like to strongly suggest this game. 

Highlights:
-Massive race/team diversity which i beleive for any strategy game is vital
-long very open campaign (you dont need to follow the rules 100% though following them may help) that has for me a very good replay value as each faction has a different goal set of units and starting position
-has  variety of difficulty as with the easy campaign i find it fun to sweep your oponents off the board 
-though you can be extremely overpowered in this there are also forces in play that will hold you back such as plague, public disorder, rebelions and the obvious other factions
-another thing to balance out the game is the religion factor which i felt deserves its own minor section to talk about due to the fact that it has enough elements to absorb the other factors such as the 5 religious groups "Christianity, Orthadox, Islam, Pagan, Heretic" you also much apease the pope as he will not favour a warmongerer and may excamunicate you if you are seen as an enemy of your fellow christians (i have yet to check out the islamic factions which only adds to the replay factor as i have only played 1/3rd of the factions in the game)
-unit background; each unit has its own description and amount per unit and they can receive better armour and experience
-i find it has a good level of complication as it isnt insanely all over the place leaving new players in the dust as they watch their whole faction tumbe but it gets more interesting as the game goes on so the player gets a chance to learn rather than be crushed under what they must know to even play


Downfalls:
-while i love the challenge added by the pope in this game he tends to become annoying and is very very biased against you, unless you play as a very religious lord, which can have you tearing out your hair due to the constant deterance of you making any progress at the threat of excommunication and in extremes a crusade upon one of your large cities/castles
-the relationships with other factions tends to become hostile at every turn with groups of 4 factions allying and all attacking you unprevoked even if you try to become friends with them, the best strategy i have for this is ally those far away for a long lasting aliance.

Overall: rating would be 10/10 because there were so many things that made me love this game which i'd say is easily the best total war game i own and the fact that i had to sit here and think before u could actualy find something tht was worth puttin as a downfall to this game i would gladly recomend this game to a friend and wish that they would make a third edition with multiplayer campaign.

This is my favorite PC game, bar none.  I  have to add a disclaimer. However, I bought the game on Steam with my new computer (CD would not install again) and, not only is this game not supported in Workshop, they have made it very tedious, if not impossible to install mods, primarily by removing the start menu and adding a Steam version start menu. Medieval 2: Total War is a highpoint of the Total War series. It is certainly the longest supported and one of the most highly modded of the Total War games. 
On a surface level it's an empire management game requiring economic management of cities and regions. On a secondary level it's a diplomacy game, requiring careful decision making regarding allies and opponents as well as currying favour with the powers that be i.e. the Papacy and thirdly it still blends in the faster paced action of the tactical battles that allows one to actively witness and control sieges and battle upon the open field. 
As an older game the graphics are poor but not terrible, due to the usually zoomed out perspective, that doesn't show up poor unit models. It's challenging and has only the barest introduction for new players, requiring learning through trial and error, (which is more effective), and has a UI that contains as little or as much detail as you like, depending on how far through the menus you progress, something newer games tend to try to oversimplify and thus lack detail. 

Medieval 2: TW is more than likely going to be around for a long time yet, with it's continuing active player base, and it is that more than any review online that speaks for the quality of this game.

This is the magnum opus of Creative Assembly's work and unfortunately, as of lately, the last good game they made. Since 2006, I have possibly spent over 1000+ hours playing this game with many campaigns under my belt. I usually quit after a while because the game got very tedious micromanagement wise, but focusing just on conquering territories, upgrading military units and battles, I beat my very first campaign ever in a total war game on 11/26/2015. This game is one of the best PC games ever made which is astounding for the shit that has been trodded out from CA lately, I wonder how such a great company could have let a brand dissipate into what it is now. Do not buy Rome 2, Empire * (The engine works for skirmishing and line battles, I spent 300+ hours in this game, but I still wouldn't reccomend buying it), Shogun 2, Atilla, Napoleon Total War or any of the DLC they push out for these games. Rome Total War uses the same engine and follows the same formula but really, Medieval 2 is where it's at (I reccomend buying Rome Total War). With tons of mods ranging from Third Age (LOTR mod), Call of Warhammer to Stainless Steel 6.4, this game will be more than worth the reduced price it's offered for now.

My favorite of all TW games, I've found the AI works best with campaign difficulty set to Hard (this prevents AI from stacking tons of siege weapons) and battles set to Very Hard. There are plenty of mods but not integrated to steam workshop like the newer TW games, but worth giving a try. 

It's essentially Civ without map tiles, and battles are fought on landscapes generated mirroring the world map (i.e. If you are near/on a mountain or forest, that battlefield is going to have steep slopes or heavy foliage respectively) which works well, as most open field battles never feel the same. Sieges of towns and cities share similar layouts, however there is the opportunity to siege settlements a variety of ways: ladders, siege ram, siege towers, Spy infiltration, various siege units i.e Trebuchets, Catapults, Ballistae, Cannons.

Short Review

This is a fun game. Much better than the first one. I love the middle ages units (we need a Fantasy Total War game). There are only two things I dislike about this game: 1. The Pope always intervenes so you cannot wipe anyone out. 2. The Mongols are way too tough.

I still like the game. You can build up your cities, recruit troops and fight the battles on the battlefield where you can control all of the troops, and it is a cool empire building game. Europe, however, is getting really boring to me to fight in. Unlike Shogun the original Total War, it seems that the AI troops do not always run and hide when vastly outnumbered.

Anyway, Medieval II is a little older but a really decent game.

Its cheap , and the stories it creates through gameplay. All I have to do is write about a battle I had in my latest Campaign as France.

So I was fighting a battle against the English, these bastards had to gual to stab me in the back while I was off fighting the Moor's in Spain, they laid siege to Paris. What I did was raise a small army of elite soldiers coupled with peseants and drove back there full stack army. I chased them back towards there motherland, then they decided to send ANOTHER army to back them up that was roughly half a stack, I shrugged since the combined force I had gotten from Paris was about 1 and a half stacks of troops, not only that I had feudal knights and armored swordsmen.

So I started the battle and decimated the first enemy wave, not even the english Billmen could not stop my swordsmen charge, and my feudal knights broke whatever resistance was left. I had taken a decent amount of casualties, my feudal knights were a bit poorly managed and took alot of casualties and my peseants took a beating. So I reform and prepare to face the 2nd english army, the full one. What I had realized is that this full army was not a pushover, it was composed of fuedal knights, lowbowmen and even armoured swordsmen, AND EVEN ARTILLERY. I quickly matched his front line, charged and flanked with cavalry, his artillery killed over 100 men before I managed to hit it with one of my feudal knights, then I turn them unto the enemy flank just in the knick of time to prevent my men from routing, I have my general rally as well to make sure my men chase the enemy down. Once back on the campaign map, I ransom the men I captured back to england for 7,500 gold (which is alot at turn 45)

other things; Fuck the pope if you have more than 10 regions, unlike Crusader Kings 2 there is no official way to fight factions that are christian as a christian, even if enemies are the agressor they get a free pass to fuck shit up on you while you will get commands from the pope with threat of excommunication, which is pretty bad place to be in btw.

Also, this is a great mod platform. There is a LORD OF THE RINGS MOD that is amazing, as well as a Game of Thrones mod, and many more total conversions as well as basic modifications like overhauls to the game.

My favorite game of all time, and one of the best, if not THE best, Total War titles.

It doesn't have the improved politics, economy, replenishemnt, and public order systems of the later titles, but it M2 has it where it counts, visceral battles, free-form campaigns, amazing soundtrack, and a lot of personality that the later titles have lost. Before I had the steam version I logged 600 hours on this game, and that was WITHOUT mods. The major strength is that you can pretty much play the campaigns any way you want with minimal interference from the "story" , unlike Napoleon, R2, and Attila. You create your own history instead of being pushed into following actual history.

The AI might be a bit dumb and it has its fair sure of bugs and glitches, but there's no DLC.

Supposedly the latest steam version doesn't let you use certain mods, hasn't been an issue for me. I'd recommend two mods that I always use: Retrofit (takes kindoms features into the M2 grand campaign) and Crimson Tide (lots more blood and dirt).

I amass a small force of horse archers to distract one of the armies. I camp a steep hill and manage to win the battle. Confused at my victory, i conjoin the remaining horse archers with my main army, and decimate the venetians. after that i declare total war against all other countries, and eventually achieve victory.

For example I have a small group 800 which contains mostly archers and spearmen while the enemy has a army of 1600 or so with calvary and some other random troops.  i know i can't win so i try to kill as much as i can or else my castle might be in danger if they lay siege later on. I shall write this review, as a review of the mod 'Rage of the Dark Gods', which is a Warhammer fantasy mod, which should be getting more attention because you don't have to pay 40 just to play and extra race.

-Playing as Dwarves
-Wipe out Orcs
-Pouring everything into attacking Chaos Dwarves
-Sudden Beastmen horde
-Lose both western settlements before I can recruit to defend them enough

I actually owned this game on disk before I owned it on steam, and have about double the time played as my steam account says, So I actually have >500 hours in this game.

This is the pinnacle of the total war series. With the kingdoms expansion the game has hundreds of hours of replayability. With the extensive mod support, the game hundreds more hours of replayability. The Third Age Total war mod is by some considered the best Lord of the Rings game in existence - and it's only a mod.

This game had soul in a way later games did not always successfully recreate. The battles were longest in this iteration, really helping you get immersed in the bloody nature of medieval warfare. While not without flaws, most problems with medieval are problems that still exist with current iterations of total war, such as questionable AI capabilities and occasional frustrations with certain commands (such as people not climbing up ladders automatically in sieges, or cavalry stopping their charge at the last second).

Overall, this game is polished, deep, varied, highly replayable, highly moddable, and still looks quite nice with the graphics jerked up (considering it's been 9 years). If you are a fan of total war and have yet to play this installment, you're crazy. If you're looking to try total war, this is an excellent game to start with.

Medieval II: Total War is one of the three best Total War games, the other two being the original Rome: Total War and Total War: Shogun 2. M2TW improved on the mechanics of its predeccesor RTW as well as introducing its own, slightly better visuals (2006), bigger battles, more complex diplomacy, improved siege battles, town management and religion.

The campaign starts in the year 1080 AD, and as in all Total War games you must expand and maintain the faction of your choice and build a mighty empire! There are only five factions to choose from though (England, Scotland, France, Holy Roman Empire, Venice, Spain) it might be possible to unlock more factions by completing the game, but I wouldn't know because i've never managed to complete a campaign, the shame...
Obviously it is wise to establish an alliance with one or more of your neighbours, before anyone starts eyeing up your lands.
The diplomacy in M2TW is much more complex than in previous games, if you have a bad reputation with a faction they won't give you the time of day. However, if you have built up relations with them then they will be highly unlikely to betray their most trusted ally (unlike RTW when your Gallic allies invade you on your 40th aniversary...)

Religon plays a larger role than it did it in RTW Barbarian Invasion, The Pope will keep an eye on all the factions, and you will receive missions from him like you do from the Senate in RTW (you also receive missions from the home team, the Council of Nobles). These missions range from build a chapel in X settlement, recruit a priest in Y settlement, to the pope launching a crusade, where you are required to send a crusading army to the specified settlement, usually somewhere near Jerusalem, or Jerusalem itself. Its quite jarring to be going along nice and easy expanding into eastern Europe to then suddenly have to sail an army to the other side of the known world not knowing what enemy forces await you there, and even if it is a successfull crusade, the Muslim forces might retaliate with a Jihad to retake the land. What ensues is basically the movie Kingdom Of Heaven.

New agents include the priest who converts the population of the settlement he is stationed in, to his religion, the Merchant who can be sent to resources on the map to trade them (Total War just became Monopoly), princesses who can be used as diplomats, or you can marry them off to a genaral to ensure his loyalty, or to someone in another faction to cement an alliance. Also assassination video's are back in this game (yay!).

It's also possible to be excommunicated from The Church if you upset The Pope too much, leaving you fair game for invasions from other factons. When The Pope dies however, the slate is wiped clean and you even have a chance to influence who the next pope is. Each christian faction has one or more cardinals who vote on who the next pope will be
so you can influence your cardinal's decision. In one play through were I played as England, I always did what The Pope asked (Conquer Egypt) I was awarded many cardinals, which means that whoever I chose was almost guaranteed to be elected. If you vote for a Pope who becomes elected you're in his good books before you start, choose poorly and The Pope will be most dissapointed with you. It makes you feel like you are part of a huge power struggle over the control of the Holy Land.

In addition to regular settlements you can convert a town into a castle, which is a lot easier to defend and allows you to train advanced infantry (Knights!!!). However, castles produce half the amount of income as regular settlements so you have to get the balance right so you are making enough money for your cities to support the armies being supplied by the castles.

Castle sieges are more difficult than regular city sieges, towards the latter half of the campagin castle defences are so high that more often than not it is literally impossible to get past a castles walls without losing half your army. Siege towers and the like are so easily reduced to matchwood that sending them up against anything but a wooden wall is a suicide mission. Meaning catapults aren't just optional, they are required while taking a citadel.

The acctual RTS side of the game is very similar to RTW, the Ai is slightly better than in RTW but will still regularly do something silly, espesially during siege battles (Units facing the wrong way while being hit by volley after volley of arrows, to name one of the more severe, though rare, cases). For some reason the cavalry charges in M2TW don't feel as powerfull as they did in RTW, neither do archers who do less damage and are less accurate than in the previous game (if you have about five units of archers firing at the same target they tend to eventually get the job done).

M2TW Isn't as glitchy as it could have been (certanly not as glitched as newer Total War titles) but occasionally bugs occur ranging from mild to severe, one time a unit from my reinforcements got stuck outside the map on a piece of scenery. Sometimes during sieges it can be extremely clunky to move units on walls, they completely stop responding when going into a tower. One time I broke through a gate with a Ram, "once more into the breach", I ordered my knights, and instead of using the gate (which was ajar and unguarded) they ran to a pair of ladders on the wall next to them and started to ascend while spear infantry positioned themselves in the gateway blocking the entrance. During the campaign I also managed to exploit a major mistake on the part of the Scottish Ai, they left their settlement
Inverness completley empty of soldiers. I just sailed round landed a small battalion and walked through the front door.
These major glitches were few and far between (for me at least). The most common problems in this game are path finding issues during siege battles. For the most part the AI is just fine, (you want to see some real messed up AI play Empire or Rome 2)

The reason why Medieval 2: Total War is so good is that it improves on everything that Rome: Total War did and introduces some of its own mechanics that add even more depth to an already deep strategy game. The Total War series is my favourite strategy series of all time and Medieval 2 Total War is one of the best of this series. I'm surprised that a game this old runs so well on a modern computer, it runs perfectly, (by contrast Total War: Shogun 2 crashes whenever I turn on V-Sync). If you like strategy games, or have never played strategy games and are looking to give them a try, this game is one of the best in RTS.

Perhaps the best of the "classic" Total War games. Units and siege tactics are well-balanced -- requiring more strategic finesse than many other titles in the franchise. Each faction feels suitably unique, with numerous exclusive units and stat buffs. Players will definitely have to change their approach if they want to play as a different faction. 

The expansions breathe additional life into an already versatile game, putting you in smaller cut-throat maps with new specialized factions. Each expansion features a unique region and time period, which makes them all stand out from each other and the main game.

There's also a number of fun mods for it, which can extend the life of the game even more. Highly recommended.

The best instalment in the Total War franchise by far.

can i recommend a game where the devs has focused on mainly historic theme and feeling and forgotten all about balancing and general balanced gameplay? yes and no.

When this game performs at it's best, you'll feel like a midieval commander taunting banter at your foes while you cavalry tramples them to death.

Grand Campaign:
like most total war games, the grand campaign is pretty straight forward. you have the tactical turn based map with figures representing armies, moving arround doing what you command them to. the build menu isn't too diffrerent if you played Rome Total war.

what annoys me however is that there are a huge lack of political statistics. you never know who is on the edge to being agressive towards you because all you get is a welcomed enemy, or neutral. doesn't really tell you alot.

another problem is that once you begun building up the begining of your empire, you would have to deal with the fact that 60% of your neighbourghs will almost instantly be hostile towards you, either by sending a ton of agents or simply entering an all out war with you.

so now you are locked in a massive war that forces you to stay defensive for 50 turns and not expand in any way. if just one of your armies move the slightest amount towards an enemy stronghold, then they will just completely ignore the danger you put them in and attack you city. this will ultimately lead you in loop where you are stuck reclaiming and taking cities and using all of your Florins (the currecny ingame) to replenish your troops.

the worst part about these wars is that a lot of the times where you ahve the advantages in unit type, strenght and numbers it can still lead to some of the nastiest possibilities you can get. expect an army of 240 knights, 80 militia and 45 archers wot win against 400 spear militia, 100 knights and a bombard? NOPE

you have the stronger units that counters the enemy in every way, but for some reason that game won't allow you to have fun and win the battles in a fair way. the reason why is simply due to the fact that some of these engages magicly halves your army so instead of having an attacking army of 350-400 you suddenly only have 250. this happened regularly and the worst part was the aftermath. because a defending army in the city was joined in, i automaticly lost the city after. this wouldn't have been so bad if the amount of troops i lost was under half of my army, but yet for some reason half of the half that didn't die was mysteriesly dispanded instead of going into the castle again.

this wasn't just a one time fluke. it happened many times and not only for sieges. 

on top of these bullshit battles you also run in to the fact that the enemies tend to get high end units atleast 30 turns before you do. which means that when you just got longbowmen as the brits, you are already fighting feudal knights which absolutely wreck everything you can muster at this point.


now we get into multiplayer:
in short a huge dislike from me about the multiplayer battles you can have.

remember how broken a pike wall was in the first Rome total war? double that and you have a musket army or a crossbow army. unless you place your entire army furthest back you can, you will get attacked just after your spawn due to their overly high range. not only does crossbows have an incredible range (even outranging longbows) but also a decent firering speed, ammo capacity, accuracy and worst of all a cheap price. i made a high tech army of knights on foot and cavalry and a decent amount of cannon fodder and had almost 1000 more men that my friend (oponent) had.

what he had was unfortunately 4 squads of militia crossbows. all i could see the first 2 minutes was piles after piles of dead knights and cannon fodder whilst i desperately tried to rush his crossbows to minimize damage. but when my army was locked in melee with his entire army it was too late. his crossbows had done the job and weakened my squads immensely.

TL:DR
Don't ever invest in this game if you want a decent game to play with and against friends and can't handle rage inducing bullshit.


Authers note:
This game has done what is impossible for 99% of all my games. 
it made me utterly violent to my environment out of pure rage over it's bullshit.

I got this game a while back and I recently decided to play again as England. First I married my prince to the French princess. I knew they would betray me later but I figured I could atleast conquer the British Isles before I had to deal with them. I conquered scotland and soon the British Isles were mine. I had built tons of markets mines and merchants and after a while my economy was booming. I spent my money on a huge invasion force and sent it to Denmark. It was going well until the HRE attacked me. I allied with Poland since they were also warring with the HRE and Denmark, and I was able to conquer Denmark and together we beat the HRE back to a few settlements in Italy. I had been expanding too fast though, and the war had put a signifigant strain on my economy. Since I couldn't keep my cities in Germany happy I gave them to Poland. Then Milan attacked me so I beat them back too, but that war was alot more costly and I lost tons of men and some of my best generals. I decided to send my new king back to London since his traits were really good and he just married his new wife (which was also his cousin, ew) and I wanted to make sure he didn't get killed before he had an heir. On his way back he was ambushed by my backstabbing French allies and killed. Then the Polish betrayed me, despite the fact that I had helped them build an empire for them.  With all my best generals dead, I lost all my territory in Europe, and I then deleted my save in a fit of rage.

10/10 would build an empire and then watch it burn to the ground again

p.s Never trust the French, in fact never trust anyone, everyone wants to kill you. No matter what you do eventually everyone will gang up on you.

I want to preface this review by saying that this is my first total war game ever AND my first review ever. I was contemplating between entering the Total War franchise with Attila or this. I think I chose correctly. Now, onto the review.

Amazing game when it works. Utterly frusterating when it doesn't. 

First, The Bad: (Refering primarily to campaign but some things are applicable in Multiplayer too)
1. Ai can be utterly moronic at some times. Blatantly avoiding any sort of conflcit in open field battles if they dont outnumber you 2-1 or have a massive missle cav force.
2. Sieges are annoying as hell on bad days.
                                 1. Sallying  out breaks the Ai and they will just sit there letting you take pot shots at them.                   
                                 2. The Ai will try to destroy your entire city, making the city basically worthless, before charging in.
                                 3. Charging archers up ladders onto walls first. Need I say more?
                                 4. Archers are glitchy as hell on the walls. Refusing to move, refusing to fire, etc.
                                 5. Finally, any kind of combat inside the walls can get super fldgety and frustrating;
                                 6. Finally, the most annoying thing of all is, you can solve most of this using small unit sizes. Boring
3. If you make an ally or allies in campaign. Be prepared to get it thrown in your face no matter what is currently happening. Ive literally seen the Ai betray and mass attack my borders after I finally saved them from a massive military insurrection into their territory.  Marrying princessess into their faction will certainly help with this but there is no guarantee. 
4. Pathfinding, both inside and outside of sieges can screw you at any point. I've literally used 2 groups of knights to target a crossbow unit. Instead they pulled a complete 180 and charged straight into a pike unit. That basically lost me that battle as I didn't have much cav to begin with. 
5. Pope excommunicating cimulator. 10/10 (Although I will admit, it can be fucking hilarious.)
Warning: this is not a complete list, just things that I notice on a REGULAR basis. Other odd stuff does occur.

Now, The Good: 
EVERYTHING ELSE!! Despite everything annoying and wonky about this game. I cannot deny how much fun I've had. It's hilarious to watch as Christian factions eliminate each other while on crusade only to ultimately fail that crusade because they killed each other off. Combat (when its working properly and troops aren't refusing to take orders) gets FREAKING EPIC. Watching the carnage of a really good battle unfold in front of you gets your blood pumping. Despite all the grievances I have with this game, they also make this game hilariously funny. Being able to take out around 2000 men with a group of 80 knights leaves you feeling accomplished despite the fact that its primarily the fault of crappy Ai. Other times you'll be hiding behind the 1% of your walls that remain in a siege and be crapping your pants trying to cover all the breach points. Mongol and Timurid invasions add insane moments, especially if you are based in the middle east or Russia. I've had times where I took a city as a crusader and had to fortify insanely fast to prepare for a massive mongol invasion. Barely holding out against around 10,000 mongol cavalry with barely a handful of men as they pounded my walls with rockets and trebuchets.  Ultimately, I highly recommend this game to anyone who is willing to look past the (at times) terrible Ai and frusterating campaign moments. However, a word of caution to those who like strategy. This game will suck your life away. I've literally played for 6 hours straight some times. If you have the self control and the time. Buy this game immediately.

I know, at the time of this review I've only spent 15 hours in the game so I dont know every aspect inside and out. I will say this: Ive been a strategy fan all my life, from Chess to Star craft, and From Command and Conquer to Warhammer ... at least I thought I had been a fan of strategy. Now I'm sure youver heard of the civilizations ... welll total lays similarly to that ... only with all the missing pieces. From massive set piece battles, to choosing who your princess will mary this game allows you to take control of a faction in history and remold its history with your own skill (Granted my skill is terrible right now). pushing aside the short attention spans of this call of duty generation, this game forces you to think, puts you in tough situations, and throws curve balls at you when you least expect it. But if you are sound of mind, patience, and strategy you will prevail. Thats the beuty of this game ... there is no obsticle you cant overcome if you take a moment to think. Anyone who thinks they like strategy should buy this game. For its price now its a steel. 9/10 solid.

Well, my first review critized the AI but after a long endgame run I realized that the AI indeed does have stuff...that you dont have, like experienced or armored soldiers in the first turns but I've realized that this is not too much of a deal, these soldiers are usually not too "good" (in later turns you barely notice it anymore) and the AI does make their mistakes too, especially every now and then in sieges they once attacked me with too less siege stuff that I burned and so they failed. I take it now that the AI has small benefits (could be a little annoying at the start though) that balance their behavior in battle and I got over it.

A great game that I have poured over 100s of hours into. There are plenty of options as to how you want to raise your kingdom to be the greatest of all time. WIll your king be an honourable man, one who releases all his prisoners? Or a dreadful man, whose subjects follow him not out of loyalty, but fear? Will you cement a lasting alliance with the kingdom on your borders by marrying off your young princess to their prince, or will you slaughter them, burning their towns and villages and killing all their lords? Although the game lacks extreme political intrigue, there is enough there to keep you playing for a loong time. You can use covert ops (such as assassins and spies) to eliminate the lords and ladies of the enemy, weakening their forces before you ride in, killing everyone. There is so much to do in this game, and the RTS combat is fantastic. True strategy is necessary to win on the field of battle. A competent commander will triumph over the greatest of odds if his enemies blunder about like fools. There is also a great deal of diversity throughout the units for each faction. And, despite how old this game is, I assure you, the multiplayer community is very much alive and well. A must buy for TW fans, and strategy fans in general.

Medieval 2: Total War is one of the best games from the Total War series. The game itself is really in-depth, and the strategy is so immersive and complex. Even the campaign map has hidden strategies for managing the diplomacy of your kingdom, which makes the seemingly uncalled for attacks from neighboring nations look a lot less random. The battlefields and units are designed very well and the whole game looks very polished. Battle strategies can be somewhat complex, but once you get the hang of them you will feel like a 5 star general. Not to mention the fact that you can even modify the game to play as the papal states, which has influence over most European factions. I haven't tried any big mods for this game yet, but I've heard about many of them, so it's nice to know that there are options out there in the unlikely event that I ever get bored with the main game. If you're looking to buy anything on Steam, this is a game you should seriously consider adding to your library. Happy warmongering!

It was cheap
The strategy part is fun

Con's
Unit placement is impossible. I literally timed how long it took me to get one unit to accept the placement. I gave up!
Placing Archers unit on walls makes the archers shoot up into the air instead of down at the enemy.
Moving units down from the walls is impossible. See Unit placement issues above.

Cavalry units that are discribed as ruling the battlefield gets owned by peasants.
Placing stakes in front of your own units to protect from enemy cavalry is great until you have to move your own cavalry. No matter how much space there is around the stakes. They go right through it I die.
The automated battle option is completely random.
Screen randomly decides to get stuck moving in one direction all the god danm time. unable to move the camera back save & load is what you'll be doing most of.

Even though this version pales in comparison to the game-play of the original, there aren't many good choices out there for this particular type of turn-based/real-time strategy/tactics/builder game. There are some obvious weaknesses that one would think simply playing the game would have revealed to the developers, such as having to open three menus and then alphabetizing the final list to be able to check on various non-military agents such as merchants and assassins, then, depending on what you do seeing the the list close and having to start from the beginning to check on your next agent. And since these agents are often spread across the entirety of Europe, North Africa, and the Near East, this is a constant headache.
Additionally, your view of the action on the tactical level is VERY restricted, as zooming in does so on an arc, and there isn't any way to pan up or down. Additionally, you can't view very far away from your troops. I understand the need for realism to restrict your view, but with the arching zoom its very hard to point at a spot you want your troops to go to if there are trees or buildings in the way. The view in EVERY Total War game after the original Shogun Total War and Medieval Total War has been awful when compared to those original games. They had their issues, but were so much more enjoyable and easy to play then the versions that came after. 
There are guides that tell you little bits of advice, but no way to bring up previous instructions. This would only occasionally be helpful because most of the help is of the simplistic, Protect your archers from cavalry with spearmen type. So what was the button to push to make (whatever) happen?
There are also lists that seem to be simply text, with no indication you could click on a heading (such as a raised button) that are fairly disorganized without doing so. This is just lazy programing.
There is also no way to prioritize what gets built first, so if you have a project at one city or fortress that you want to make sure gets started, you have to delete every item from both queues (armies and structures) at every other city or fortress.  And if you have 15 or 20 other cities or fortresses this is very time consuming. Again, something that should have easily been noticed by the developers if they played the game for 15 or twenty hours.
But, unfortunately, this is still one of the best series available for this type of game. It's just so frustrating that with a little bit of effort it could have been so much better.

The best part of this game was the blend of different playable styles. As someone who has played (but not owned) all of the total war games, the stand out aspect of Medival II is that playing as the Sicilians is compleately different from playing as the english, which is in turn different from the egyptians. Aaother thing that iIpersonaly found brilliant was that nothing was too overpowered (albit Pavise Crossbow Militia) and that almost every nation had a playable unit roster (if not a very diverse one).

In short:
+Good replayability
+Good unit balance
+Varying ways to play within a faction 

And thats on top of all the other great things TW is know for like diplomacy (LOLOLOLOLOL noooooo.....)

I bought this game a year ago whilst it was on sale and I thought, "hey, this might be a cute little strategy game to play on my down time!" I was wrong...

It took me a few weeks to learns how to play, which is fine by me because I like my games to have a little bit of depth to them and this was my first total war (which is bittersweet, because that's like being a virgin and having sex with a pornstar, only to have the rest of your experiences wanting). Anyways, I loaded up the game and started a new campaign as Scotland on very hard difficulty. I managed to conquer the British Isles in the name of Mel Gibson, which was good because my economy was sky rocketing. After a few years in game I had built up five full stacked armies of knights, armoured footmen, and archers. It was time to invade Normandy to liberate France from the HRE. I studied Allied WWII invasion plans for a while before I actually comitted to my attack. So I declared war on the factions inhabiting the Italian penisula and invaded mainland Europe on two fronts. Whilst I was fighting battle after battle, I got Russia to ally with me and attack the countries to the east of HRE. After a while, Russia and I completely obliterated the mainland. However, Russia wanted more land. A few turns later Russia declared war on me and we fought tooth and nail to secure our newly conquered lands. Russia was winning for a while, but then everything changed when the Mongols attack. We were both weak from fighting a mock WWII so the Mongols just steamrolled Russia. I tried to ally with the mighty Khan, but he refused me. In my weakened state, the factions of Iberia declared war on me and invaded the British Isles while the Mogols savaged my holdings in the mainland. Despite my best effort, Spain, Portugal, and the Mongols defeated my glorious empire. In the end, I failed my people, my God, and most importantly Mel Gibson.

11/10 would fight a medieval WWII again.

An outstanding game even in 7/2/2015 this game is amazing this is one of those games that can stand the test of time. What to expect: Massive battles enmass of melee units of a high varity From Peasent's to noble Knight's down to the very archer's to screen the field. But this is not all this game has to offer. I'd say that it has a very high mass of building's that can be built leaving endless hours of fun. And if you are the Historical type they have multiple challenging Historical battles. This game also supports multiplayer which I found quite fun. Though like every game it has it's share of bugs and it's bad sides. The lack of update's and fixes to the game were rarely seen. (Seige does need abit of help.) You may encounter a bug or two at most but the rest of the game makes up for that factor. Lastly this game share's many cinematics from spy's infiltraiting areas to assassin's assassinating the Pope himself. I myself found these quite interesting and satisfing to watch. When it comes down to it I at most give this game a 8 out of 10 This game was an amazing experience but it shares it's bugs and it's disadvantages (such as Horsemen bug and them sometimes not holding down their lances) But all in all a good game definitely worth the buy and play through.

One thing I learned from Medevial Total War: Never trust your allies.

I know what your thinking. You love them, you guys have a great relationship, you fought a mutual enemy with them! How could they turn on you?

If your ally has no room to expand, he's about to attack you.
If you have been at peace for too long, he's about to attack you.
If you are allied with Milan, Milan's about to attack you.

10/10 would crush all my allies again.

I had played it a long time ago. I was recently confined to an older machine, and, being unable to play a newer TW game, I bought it on steam to replay. I was very disappointed to find it in this sorry state. At its heart, this game is as good a TW game as any, but at the same time it is thoroughly broken. I remembered this game being far from perfect, but I didn't remember it being nearly unplayable.

There are many things I could mention, from disappearing units to the inexcusable lack of colour coordination of the menus. But the one thing that will really send you looking for a different TW title is the pathfinding. There's no way I can list all the things that go wrong. If you can think of it, it happens here. Ignoring commands? Sure. Spontaneously cancelling orders? Of course. Long ant-lines when turning corners? Always. How about a unit splitting into two parts that move at different speeds? How about one bugged guy sprinting in place causing your entire unit to become tired? You didn't think of that did you? Play this game and you'll learn all about broken pathfinding. Every decision you make needs to be explained to your units an average of 3 times, and, once it's working, you don't touch the unit or you'll ruin everything.

I am going to compare this game to Rome: Total War, an older entry of the series.

Improvements I instantly notice:

Naval combat feels very rewarding! It is still autocalculated, but 2 ships will go up against 1 and you will probably win. 6 ship can go against 5 enemy ships, and you might just win a heroic victory with 0 losses! 

Instead of the SPQR for Roman Factions, you have a Pope for the many different Catholic factions! This is a good addition in my opinion, as now more factions feel fleshed out. 

Graphics are better here and there, but the way my settings are, I don't really notice major differences. Not that the graphics hold anything back!

Pre-battle speeches feel nice and Medieval-like! Though they are slightly repetitive, they're still a joy to listen to. 

There is no balance issues that I can see, but the Byzantines/Turks and the Holy Roman Empire seem to have it easier early on when they're played by AI. 

Crusades are a nice new addition as well! 

For the most part, the Campaign map feels the same. However, a key difference is that you can swap a settlement between being a Castle or a Town. Castles offer military power, whilst Towns offer economic power. The choice is yours!

Agent system feels a lot more immersive.

There are tons of cinematics! It feels like an achievement just to have a Spy take a look at a few stray enemy units.

MP is still kicking, but Rome 1's MP is also alive. 

It is also only worth $20, with a very cheap DLC! That is a complete steal for a game like this. That said, Rome 1 is cheaper.

Probably one of the best things this game has is the fact that the map is more immersive! There was historical events in Rome 1 like volcanoes and floods, but now you can witness the spawn of the Mongols, or contact Aztecs when you have been confined to Europe all this time!

10/10

Would marry off my daughters to Genghis Khan again!

Once upon a time, I had carved out a worthy empire in northern Germany, and Scandanavia, and was steadily working up to a war againist the HRE, until they finally struck and began to attack. By then, I was having horrible money issues, due to poor upkeep, and an insane abundance of generals. I had an army far superior to the HRE's but they had immense numbers, I carved my way through atleast 3 armies before my own was reduced to less than a hundred and I was forced to retreat. But, with no cash to rebuild a defence I decided it was time to leave behind the dozen generals and the deadly enemy I had made for a much more peaceful living. My ally, Venice gladly traded Tripoli to me for all my cities. In no time, I was able to stablize myself with just 2 generals, all the rest died in a horrible accident with the English navy. However, I had no room to expand and was forced to battle Sicily. It was suprisingly easy after I had taken Tunis. But the Mongols had begun to capture every city they could. They wanted Tripoli too, so I easily gave it to them, their navies and armies scared me. But before I left, I renamed the city to Mongoliassholia. Now, in Tunis I built up my economy and made up enough money to get 3 Carracks to sail me to Sicily and Sardinia, which I easily conquered as the Sicilians somehow lost their entire forces defending Tunis. After much conquering, I had Corsica, Florence too, and was well on my way to finish off Sicily off east. When Portugal, and Milan decided I was in the way of their expansion. By then Germany, Egypt, and the Turks had been destroyed. Scotland reduced to Ireland, the Netherlands, and a city in the Baltics somehow. Portugal had made Spain and the Moors into vassals. Russia had been reduced to their original size, by the Timurids. The Mongols stretched out from Tripoli, to the Ukraine. Venice, once a power thanks to me had been too stretched out, and France, had managed to move all the way out to Poland, and Hungary, and were steadily taking out the rest of Venice in Europe, and eagerly awaiting to finish the ones off in Scandanavia. They wouldn't attack me though, we were in good standing. Now, as my eagar axemen, and sword-bearers are ready to invade Bologna, the Mongols come knocking again, and the max turns are reached. This is where I ended my game. Sandwiched between enemies. My allies, far gone. The moral of the story is use condoms, so your generals don't make 20 god damn children.

Medieval II: Total war is a fun game. In Medieval 2 total war, you control an empire you choose, and you get to run settlements, recruit units, assassinate enemies, spy on enemies (Or your allies if you want >:) ) and more! You  also get to control your units in the battle.  You'll feel what they feel. . .  The catapults launching flaming rocks at you, the trebuchets pounding your enemies. . . The charge of your horses into your foes. . . You get to decide! It's also fun to defend castles. If you get a big enough castle, you get to defend it from the walls (If you want) By that I mean you can place archers on the walls and your foes have to either use siege towers or ladders to go over the walls, or use a battering ram to bash down your gates. Have your archers fire flaming arrows and set fire to their battering ram!
It's a really fun, action-packed game. For more action, get the expansion pack - Medieval 2 total war kingdoms.
This is easily my favorite Total War game.

This game is amazing, one of my favorites. Lots of cool factions, events that shake up the campaign (the Black Death, for example), lots of cool units, and much more. Settlements are divided between castles and cities which make the game more interesting and fun.There are a lot of little details that go a long way to making the game interesting and giving it some character. For example, after a battle, if you have prisoners you can decide whether you want to release them, execute them, or attempt to ransom them. When you hover the cursor over each choice, you will have one of the prisoners saying things depending on what you are looking at. If you hover over the "release" option, they'll praise you and say nice things, but if you hover over the "execute" option, they franticly beg for their lives. Enemy armies will also say things depending on your relations with them. If you are neutral, they'll have a respectful tone, but if you're enemies, they yell at and insult you. There are also these little videos for your spies and assassins when they act, though the  assassin videos are better, even when they fail. I had an assassin try to kill a guy, and he failed when his target hit him in the face with a door. You'll most likely be playing as a Catholic faction, so just a warning, the pope can be a little annoying, and obviously, the AI isn't perfect but this game is still awesome.

So yes, I recommend this game. I recommend it a lot.
Also, the most hilarious thing that has ever happened to me in this game? The pope in my Venice campaign is secretly female. I got a good laugh at that one.

First off, this is a SUPERB game. However, be careful buying it in any pack because Kingdoms is apparently NOT included. I purchased the Total War complete pack and CA/SEGA decided to make it so that any games you already own, you do not get a second copy of (to give to a friend, etc). No discount. I wanted about 6 titles I didn't have anymore so I thought, "OK, that's irritating, but I'll give it a go." I already had Med II but it was alright because I hate patching since they don't have the official patch up anymore. When Kingdoms was listed as DLC for another $12.00 I was unamused. I'll simply reinstall my old DVD copy and patch it up. 

PROS: At least there's a million amazing mods for Med II, back when modding was the name of the game and CA wasn't just a dough monger looking to get another $2 here and $10 there.

My favourite and most played of the Total War series, with probably closer to 400 hours, before I bought again on Steam.

A stand out element is the music  I have been known to boot up into the main menu, just to savour the fantastic score, I believe entitled Time And Again, accompanied with the crashing of thunder and lightning, and watching the silhouetted troops march by.

Part of the reason Medieval II (and Kingdoms) is my favourite, is likely because I just have not invested the time in the newer incarnations (the following 2 just didnt grab me), but undoubtedly the combat style of the era is much more to my taste.

All in all a really great game, with more than enough to keep you enjoying well beyond the purchase price. 

Fully recommended.

"To crush your enemies, to see them driven before you, and to hear the lamentations of their women." This is the essence of the Total War series. This is a game where you lead a fledgling nation and turn them into a glorious Reich that will conquer all of Medieval Europe. 

The gameplay has two parts: a turn based map where you deal with politics and move troops around, and the battles which are real time fast paced and fun. There's a ton of strategy involved in both and it captures medieval combat and politics perfectly. Lead crusades, or Jihads, conquer Europe, lead the Holy Roman Empire in glorious Teutonic conquest. It's really fun!
Command your vast army and lay siege to giant castles. Or order them to join a crusade.

Really fun game, only problem is if you're sending people to attack a wall with a siege tower/ladders/etc, if the wall is hit, they stop in their tracks. Makes it a big problem when they have lots of archers and you're charging. Really love the game, especially the Holy Roman Empire.

Medieval 2 is easily my favourite in the Total War series. It is epic and grand and rich in variation. In the beginning you try to hold together diplomacy with the Catholic states and then total war erupts. Just when things are getting better the mongols invade, and then the Timurids in order to throw a few curve balls and keep things interesting. The ending of the game is - as well - truly magnificent and turns everything you knew upside down in a final epic battle combined with world exploration.

The graphics are really good even today and the units, cities and maps are excellent. The only complaint I have would be with the Merchants... oh why were they even there...?

+ Graphics
+ Units
+ Diplomacy (and missions)
+ Campaign map & RTS

- Merchants

Played this game since its release in 2006, bought a digital copy via steam when my old CD stopped working.

You'll like this game if you like history. It certainly isn't "perfectly accurate" (is anything?), but it tries a lot harder than most games. At least, at the outset. The point of this series is to screw with history. I once played as the Almoravids of al-Andalus and crossed the Atlantic, converting the Americas to Islam. I once played as the Byzantine Empire and transplanted the entire dynasty to sub-Saharan Africa, watching as the rest of the world was eclipsed by the Mongol tide.

The other great thing about this game is the mods. The best ones I know of are Third Age, Rage of the Dark Gods, and Hyrule. You can find one to suit almost any fancy. I just got done ravaging the Shire and Rivendell as Isengard.

Seriously, pick up this game if you have $20 to spare. You won't be disappointed.

On a scale from Moors to the Timurids/Mongols, how great of a conqueror do you think you are? How about on a scale of the HRE to Milan, how great of a defender? Storm across Europe, crushing your foes, betrothing daughters, sons, and generals alike, assassinate enemy priests or family members, become the homeland of the pope, send waves of men on crusades, or jihads, forcing your religious fervor on to your foes, create massive armies to defend what you have taken from others, create powerful alliances and enemies, spurring total war. 

Those are just a few things that you can do. Of course, that is if all goes as planned. Cities rioting, being besieged, angry rebels and neighbors, excommunication, the black death. In one game, I had the Holy Roman Empire get exiled four times, and even a crusade, to vanquish the heretics. My assassins almost never get a successful attempt on lives or buildings unless its something to do with religion. During crusades, men desert simply because you waited one turn so you could bring in reinforcements. 

The DLC is nice, though not a fan of Teutonic. Britannia is alright, but can only win as Ireland. Wales I can never muster a big enough force, and if I do England seems to divert every soldier ever to come and challenge me. Had one where in two turns the whole of Scotland succumbed to riots and was eliminated. Crusades is alright, minus the fact everything is so far apart and thinly stretched. Americas is, well, awful. Haven't played as Apaches yet, but as both Mayans and Aztecs I managed to pull some stunning victories over Spain, until they got reinforcements and blasted me to oblivion. So I played as Spain and its too easy, even on hard. You can have 100 men and you will still have the upper hand over 500 natives. 

The game is amazing for when it was made and what not, just a few kinks in the rope, but its fun. Even when you get slaughtered. 9/10 would definitely send shirtless men with sticks to kill Spaniards in metal again and again.

Even 9 years later, Medieval II Total War is still the best strategy game out there.  A huge amount of different factions and hundreds of different units means that each faction will have their own battlefield strategy.  On top of that, little details like the weather and elevation can come into play, not to mention how tired your own units are.  Despite all that complexity, the user interface is very simple and straightforward-even a novice can master the game's mechanics in as little as an hour of gameplay.  And if you somehow manage to exhaust the main campaign, the modding world has kept this game very much alive, with new mods always in the pipeline.

Medieval II is the first Total War Title that I was introduced to, and it flat out blew me away. The size of the map makes the number of different areas one can battle in simply staggering (you're not progressing in your campaign the way you would in say... Warhammer: Mark of Chaos, you make it up as you go). The family trees and generals end up giving your factions a real personality and very distinctive features (woe betide you if madness or infertility strikes). Battles are stupidly fun, although they will lack the graphic detail of the later Total War titles. That being said, the units are pleasant to look at and have unique appearances and appeals between factions (something I found horribly sad about Rome II: variety? sure! accuracy? sure! horrifically ugly units and often without beards. It's like watching 5th graders stab each other). There is a staggering amount of variety in most of the factions recruiting pools which just makes for interesting viewing and battles. 
I bought this game the first time on disc, the second time on a disc when I lost the first one, and the third time on Steam. Yes. Three times. It was that good.

Don't know why I haven't gotten around to recommending this game yet since I've been playing it on and off for years, but, quite simply, Medieval 2 is a masterpiece of grand strategy.  I am a big fan of the Total War series, and I can say without question that this game has the best diplomacy and politics of any TW and the best mods for any TW game.  Whether you simply want a more refined experience in the form of mods such as Stainless Steel or a total conversion that puts you centerstage in the War of the Ring with Third Age TW, the Medieval 2 modding scene has much to offer.  Truly one of the highlights of the series and if you're a fan of the genre or just ancient history in general, buying this game is a no-brainer.  Do it now!

(p.s. be sure to get Kingdoms as well)

The total War Franchise should take a look at this game and rethink what they have been releasing because this one had it right.

Definately has to be one of the best strategy games I have ever played. 
First of all, the gameplay offers a massive choice of nations and units each with their own traits. 17 different factions on top of long and short campaigns give a lot of room for different story paths and immense replayability. The mix of battles, diplomacy, family traits and strategy AI create a truly realistic and immersive game that offers an infinate number of choices to your next move, although the turn-based elements often feel oversimplified. It does have a solid real time combat foundation, but the AI is either really good or really bad depending on the difficulty setting. There is no middle ground. If you are new to real time strategy games, this one has a pretty steep learning curve. Even seasoned players may feel overwhelmed.
One campaign can take days, even months of play time. However, sometimes the game can become a bit taxing to less motivated players (not that I'm complaining) and the AI during battles can often glitch. Whilst these glitches are mostly minor, they nevertheless break your immerson in the game and can be quite annoying when your soldiers glitch about instead of doing as they're told. Despite all its weaknesses, Med 2 is still a briliantly crafted game, its strategy mixed in with impressive graphics and cinematic music will keep you wound up in the Medieval age for thousands of hours.

It's one of CA's best (Total War) games. It beats Empire, it beats Napoleon (which was rather a pile of garbage so that wasn't hard) and it beats Shogun2. I still like Medieval 2 better than anything that came after it.

TURN 7
-Milan declares war on me, and sends ONLY TWO FAMILY MEMBERS into my territory
-I kill the generals
-The HRE declares war on me
-Pope loses Rome to Milan (Who declared war on him)
-Milan and HRE stacks now reduce me to Tunis
-Trade my last city and my wealth to England in exchange for Dublin
-Form a new empire there, killing Scotland and forcing England back to Europe.

END RESULT:
Sicilian Empire holding Britain (Later Denmark and Scandinavia were taken)
Pope became a belligerent and began a war on every living thing
Mongolian and Timuriud armies strech all the way to France
Franco-Sicilian alliance repels the invaders and liberates Europe
France backstabs me and takes Dublin+ London
Retreat to Denmark
Pope takes Aarhus

11/10 will play as British Sicily again

I played this on CD to the point that the disk stopped working. I don't have an hour total, but I can assure you I spent a good two or three years putting about as much time into this as I did my full time job.

Probably the last really well thought out Total War game, and one of the least buggy. There is no stupidly awkward city management system (Empire), most of the factions are reasonably well balanced (with the exception of the Italian States, who are crushingly overpowered in a player's hands - still better than pretty well all the other total war games out there), and things move at a pace that doesn't feel to relaxed or too rushed (shogun, napolean).

It's not a masterpiece by any means, but now that I revisit them, I don't think any of the Total War games really are. It is a pretty fun game though, and certainly worth getting if you've are looking to get into the series.

Edit: When I say "the least buggy", I'm just refering to the Steam versions. Rome:TW on CD, from like a decade ago, remains stable as a fucking rock resting on the surface of a giant steel cube with the gravitational pull of a black hole. There is also a 6 billion ton weight sitting on top of the rock. I've been told the Steam version doesn't work that well, but haven't had to try it despite having lost my Rome CD recently, because Rome is from an era where devs depended on human decency and CD codes as DRM.
