A long time ago, I played the DVD version and loved it (particularly the Crusades and Teutonic expansions). Long lost so I picked up the Steam Medieval II: Total War package including all the expansions on sale. So far, I've played over 150 hours. Obviously, if I've committed so much of my spare time to playing a game I can hardly not recommend it. On sale, it's one heck of a value. However, overall, I find it a bit frustrating and though I have started many games, I've never finished a single one.

The really good news is that MTW II and all it's expansions are terrific at differentiating the factions. There are a lot of clever ideas and thought that's gone into making each faction unique and interesting.  Game graphics really hold up considering the age of the game. No complaints there. Lots of historic detail to revel in. Massive battles never really get old.

The bad news is the campaign AI is poorly balanced between factions. A few are easy to play (which can be corrected by upping the difficulty) but many are ridiculously difficult even in easy campaign mode. To make matters worse, the diplomacy is pretty much awful. Generally creating an alliance greatly increases the odds of being attacked by a faction a few turns down the road. The campaign script is pretty rote. After about 25 turns the first faction attacks. Make any headway and the 2nd attacks. Keep up your progress and the 3rd one attacks. Of course, the attackers diplomacy remains "mixed" or "reliable" while the victim of attacks - that'd be the only human in the room - drops to "despicable." Really?

To give the AI a fighting chance, the human player starts off in the basement of development. It takes a very, very, very long time to build an interesting fighting force. Meanwhile, getting pounded by an increasing number of factions who seem capable of pumping out better, larger armies delays development even longer. Money management requires applying every penny each turn to development and maintaining troops. Losing just 1 city while getting piled on by the AI factions and my house of cards can quickly collapse. 

There are a lot of interesting side characters: priests, assassins, spies, merchants, and diplomats. Unfortunately, they're spoiled by the aforementioned issues. Diplomats are important but crippled by poor diplomacy AI. Merchants are horribly balanced. There may be a way to strengthen them I'm missing but mine tend to get killed quickly by rival merchants. I can count on 1 hand (with fingers left over) the number of times my merchant survived an attack. Newly created assassins, by contrast, are equally pathetic but can be slowly built up over time by killing, for example, rebel captains. Priests similarly are weak in killing heretics with no way of building them up I can see so I tend to use assassins for this task. Still, priests are useful to build up religion in a region I control though their ability to foment rebellion in regions held by rival factions is a lot weaker than I expected. With rare exception, priests are about useless to this task.

With the game being so old I have little hope for a patch to rebalance or improve the AI. So MTW II is what it is. A game that's fun to fiddle with but never really finish, IMHO.

I give MTW II 6.5 out of 10. Above average but I'm really disappointed in the Steam version. There's so much potential to a great concept being lost. I recall the DVD versions being a lot more fun. Strange.

If you're going to play an RTS, then play this one.
Huge scale battles, intelligent AI, and a rather fun campaign that you will either dominate or be dominated in - usually both.
Get beat down into submission and backed into a corner...then come out guns - er, swords - blazing and hold on just that little bit longer...and then be destroyed by the next attacking force because you made enemies with everyone. 
Only one thing to complain about: WHERE'S MEDIEVAL 3?!

(ignore the playtime, I played over 200 hours of this easy before I got it on Steam)

Resource management is the devil. I've believed that for a long time, because it's a ball and chain wrapped around RTSs that basically dictates "he who micromanages faster, wins."

What sets the Total War series apart is that all preparation for battle is done in the turn based stage. If you get caught off-guard or overwhelmed, it's based on your shortcomings as a strategic and tactical player, not who can mine vespene gas faster. 

That being said, Medieval II is still probably the strongest out of all the Total War titles. There is a huge pool of traits that give your generals character (whereas Empire had like, what, 10?), very diverse countries and units, and probably the most satisfying of the Total War battlescapes.

Of course, this also comes with the things Total War is notorious for: suicidal AI (i have one province and your army outnumbers mine 20:1, I DECLARE WAR) and backstabbing-for-no-reason AI (I'm going to break the alliance we signed one turn ago).

Still, best in the series. Highly highly recommend.

My Medieval 2 Campaign as Milan:
-Start campaign
-Have Milan and Genoa, making tons of money
-Ok, ally with Venice
-No nearby rebels, what to do...
-Venice attacks Genoa for ABSOLUTELY no reason
-Kill Venetian faction leader
-March huge army to Venice, Venice falls
-Take Zagreb, Ragusa, and Durazzo from Venetianse
-Crusade called on Cairo
-Pope thinks I am a threat to Catholicism and demands Duke Puccio joins the crusade on Cairo
-Join Crusade
-Exterminate Cairo
-France excommunicated for having 8 heretics in their borders and 12% Catholicism in Paris region
-Pope takes Marseille, makes it their capital
-A new threat in the East? Shouldn't affect me...
-Trade Cairo for Rome

And then it all went South...

-I own Milan, Genoa, Venice, Bern, Florence, Staufen, Innsbruck, Vienna, Thesslonica, Durazzo, Corinth, Ajaccio, Tripoli, and Nuremburg.
-France reconciled
-French declare war on me
-French attacks an army of 8 broken lances with their king ONLY
-French take Marseille from Pope
-France excommunicated
-Milan excommunicated
-Mongols come out of nowhere and take Corinth, Constantinople, Durazzo, and Thessalonica
-Black Plague breaks out
-Kills off 2/3 of my empires population
-Cairo rebels
-Pope is homeless
-HRE declares war
-HRE takes Staufen and Bern
-Armies crippled Borders shrinking, economy failing
-Use what little I have left to buy a city off of the Moors
-Italian Penninsula falls

End Result

-Milan has become a one city faction based in Timbuktu
-France is a bunch of heretic witches with magic sticks
-Africa now speaks Italian.

And I didn't even bring up the Timurids, and their armoured elephants with cannons on their backs!

The successor to the classic Rome: Total War, Medieval II: Total War is a fun game that introduces new concepts and deals with a period of time from shortly after the Norman Conquest of England to the Age of Discovery. Among other events that will be affecting you in this time period are the Mongols showing up, gunpowder being introduced, the Black Death arriving and killing most of your population (don't worry it does the same to everybody), the Timurids following their Mongol ancestors, and then the beginning of the Age of Discovery. Castles and Cities develop in two separate ways, and produce different units.

If playing a Catholic nation, you have to deal with the Pope. He can make or break your nation, so keep an eye on your approval rating with him. After a victory, most of the factions are then unlocked. They are also unlocked individually if you happen to be the one to land the killing blow.

Side note: If you do unlock all the nations, three are the Moors, Egypt, and the Turks. Do take care of your volume at that time, because when you click a unit, move them, or attack with them, they do have a slight vocalization. Which at times could make people nervous (about killing infidels and the like). Some who hear you play may also get a bit nervous when you play the Holy Roman Empire (or the First Reich).

This game is a true masterpiece. Im going to start this off with the factions. You start with only five to choose from, but when you beat the game as one you unlock all of the other nations as well. Though there is not a ton of difference between them, there are some nice variations. Each has there own special units, strenghts and weaknesses in their armies and of course, different rivals and allies. The combat is well done with many different types of units such as infantry, calvalry, archers and artillery. The generals are a nice addition as well, as they can use abilities to bolster your troops morale, though if they die your troops morale will plummet. There are two types of battles, assulting a city, castle, citadel etc. and open battle on many different terrain types. If you are playing as a christian kingdom you will have to stay in the popes favor or else he may excommunicate you or even call a crusade on you. The only weaknesses with this game is it`s diplomacy, only usefull for trade and limeted npc interactions with each other.

very brilliantly done Total War game, set just after the Battle of Hastings you take charge of one of the races present in Europe or the Middle East and use armies of troops, political backstabbing or literal backstabbing to become the top dog in the known world. 

each race has its own unique units and look and are based on actual units and peoples from the time, from the English Longbowmen to the German Zweihander and the Turkish Naffatun (early grenade) thrower, all are present and all existed, and later in game muskets and cannons become available, and even the Aztecs and the New World become available for exploration.

there is also religions like the previous games, who will give you missions to complete and send you or members of the royal family on Crusades or Jihads depending on religion. 

a fun game for fans of the Total War series and any history gaming fans out there.

A little context: I was a Rome Total War 1 die hard. Great game.  I bought Rome Total War 2 at release.  Played through all the patches.  Did not like the game one bit.  I missed a lot of the old game: family tree, dynamic traits and retinues, diplomats, priests, the ability to build roads for crying out loud.  I missed all that.  So I bought Medieval 2 Total War.  

My review is basically a comparison between this game and RTW2:

I became immediately immersed in this game.  I actually care about the characters and how they develop and grow, it feels more real.  RTW2 is a terrible game.  Playing this game made me realize just how bad RTW2 really is.  It looks pretty but it has no guts.  It's amazing how older games are so much better than these new ones. Just mindblasting.

Bottom line: if this game goes on sale, buy it.  Not worth the full price, just because it's a bit dated in the graphics, but at 30%+ off it's a steal.

M2TW is a fun cheap game, that will cause you to stay up much to late telling yourself "just one more turn". The game runs well on nearly any PC and its unbelivably well-priced for how entertaining and detailed it is. Now, I am sure someone could argue that there are better RTS games out currently, but considering the release date of this game and its price it is definitely worth the buy. I would say my favorite part of the game is how many variables and details are incorporated in the logistics involved in the campaign (such as financial, military, domestic, diplomatic, and geopolitical elements). Every time I play through a campaign I learn something different.

Basically, if you want an addictive and engaging RTS to play, and you want to spend as little cash as possible I would absolutely get this game.

This is the game that hooked me on the Total War series.

This game is damn well near perfect. Sure it has a few bugs, but the game has been out since 2006 you can easily find a mod to fix any unresolved bugs or gameplay issues. And speaking of mods, Medieval II: Total War has the best overhaul mods I've ever seen, let alone played. Sadly buying the game on Steam complicates modding since there is no Steam Workshop for the game. For instance my favorite overhaul mod, Third Age: Total War (a Tolkien-inspired mod), refuses to launch no matter what I do.

As for the game itself, I cannot praise it enough. While not eye-candy like Shogun II or Rome II, the gameplay (both in campaign and in battle) was the best of the original Total War games. After Medieval II, Creative Assembly begins a gameplay transformation that peaks in Rome II. Essentially this game perfects what CA started in their previous games (Rome, Shogun and Medieval).

The question is ultimately: Should I buy it? Well there's a free demo, but the Gold Edition (or rather the Medieval II: Total War Collection) is worth full price. I'm not sure I have the right words to describe it, but "yes, more Total War please" will suffice.

The game is acutally OK, its not too bad, its just really realy dated... bug-wise.
It seems that everything sega touches is either buggy or broken. The game has serious pathfinding problems, and the units respond strangely on the battlefield. All-in-all the battles aren't worth it, its just very predictable or downright broken.

All the other aspects are ok, the graphics the sound, the presentation, its a big brand game, but it doesn't deliver really. The game pretends to be big, but its actually really, really small. And there aren't that many countries to play with, even if you count the entire map. 
It reminds me of Lords of the Realm 3 and how that sucked big time, but maybe I'm just spoiled by Paradox Interactive. 
The campain map is limiting in most ways, and the gameplay its self either has things that dont realy work for it, or that you can simply completely ignore.
Maybe if this was all there was to it, ok, it could have been good... But we have Civilization 4, Europa Universalis 4 and many other real grand strategy games out there.
Heck even Zeus: Master of Olympus is better than this.

so yeah i'm sure by my title you can guess where i stand on my opinion of the game. Now before i begin i will say that i have played many games of this category. for instance there is nearly all the total war titles and europa univeralis 4, hearts of iron 3. So i am not unfamiliar with this (and for those who are you will find it is VERY easy to get into). Pretty much everything about this game is perfect i mean the gameplay when you command your troops in battle is so immersive and spotless it is hard to find a complaint. Not to mention this game is weirdly more advanced and realistic compared to later total war game, like empire total war and napoleon or even the newest rome 2.


 I mean you actually have to have your diplomats move and not just be lazy and click a button and open up the diplomatic menu. Not to mention the soldiers actually act like people! now if you haven't noticed the troops from shogun 2 and rome 2 DESPERATLEY need to take notes from this MASTERPIECE of a game. the troops in Medieval 2 move so fluently it is unreal, in rome 2 they feel like bricks with legs, shogun 2 (and empire and napoleon) are slightly better with this which adds to my earlier topic of how earlier games are better than the new ones. empire and napoleon makes more sense with how they soldiers move though because of the timeline, shogun 2 kinda does because it does have a couple gun regiments. but rome 2 i have no idea.


And another thing is that Medieval 2 is not arcady like rome 2 and empire napoleon and shogun 2. in rome 2 there is a timer in the fortress in a siege so if you just have one dude step in that stupid circle you will win in 2min it is crazy, now i know there is one in Medieval 2 but considering it is in they WAY back of the fortress it is not even there. another thing is the maps are very different and unique and are just generally much better than what i've seen in rome 2. (by the way if you are wondering why i am comparing so much to rome 2 it is because it is the newest game of the total war series and this just goes to show that pretty graphics can only take you so far, because that is all rome 2 is to me) 


Also the gameplay in the battles in Medieval 2 are so much more stratigic and are just generally perfect in everyway possible, unlike rome 2. Now the whole point of the total war games is to have an easy political view game and a very complicated and stratigic battling system in between. THAT IS WHAT A TOTAL WAR GAME IS SUPPOSED TO BE LIKE. (which is why Medieval 2 is so amazing) in rome 2 the battling system is so horride and awful it makes me want to puke, and the diplomatic gameplay just.....i can't even describe my disgust with that, in Medieval 2 it is just so perfect and amazing that my only explanation for how good it is, is probably that a god crafted Medival 2. 


Now i could go on and on about how Medieval 2 is the best total war game i've played. Like the music is so amazing and inspiring and immersive. Medieval 2 also is SUPER IMMERSIVE AND PERFECT IN NEARLY EVERY WAY POSSIBLE! now i could talk for the rest of my life on how good this game is, but i am pretty sure that whoever read this long probably got the idea already, so yeah Medieval 2 is 10/10 in my book

Medieval II: Total War is the best total war game I've played, though I've only played the more recent ones. Still, there are countless hours of fun in here, and if you like strategy games there's absolutely no reason not to pick this up. 

Still, there are problems with the game. It's pretty old, and while I have few complaints about the graphics (kinda unfair to rag on those), I did have some problems making it run on Windows 8.1 - so keep that in mind. There are also quite a few things that could improved; the campaign goals are a bit ridiculous, though that doesn't mean that it's all that hard to beat the campaign. The AI - while it has moments of brilliance - is pretty bad in general: on the battlefield it'll often charge forward with little thought (though this seems to happen less late game, for some reason), and on the campaign map in can be incredibly stubborn (unless you have an enourmous advantage), attack you for no discernable reason (sometimes accepting peace the turn after with no battles fought) and in general it's just incredibly hit and miss. The ship battles are also basically non-existent, and there's an annoying lack of control, but who ever liked ship battles anyway, so that's a minor point. 

The unit variety is also somewhat lacking, though it isn't all that bad - the selection is okay, but your armies will often look alike, and you'll find yourself just building the same army again and again. Of course as you grow larger, you'll encounter enemies with completely different units, but it happens fairly late in the campaign. It's sad because the game actually includes quite a few more units, but they're only "unlocked" very late game where you're already totally dominating. Talking about selection, you have a choice of annoyingly few factions when first starting the campaign - you have to beat it to unlock minor factions.

I have more minor complaints, but the good news is that mostly everything can be fixed with the huge number of mods made for this game. 

Overall, I'd love a MD III: TW - where they don't fuck up as they did with Rome II - where they incorporate the good stuff they made for the new games (tech tree, mini settlements), but drop the stuff like mo-cap and whatnot. I could talk for awhile about what shouldn't be included, but anyhow: I wholeheartedly recommend this game, and you should buy it even if it isn't on sale. It's probably the game I've had the most fun with. It's easy to get into, and it's entertaining throughtout - I have a few nitpicks, but yeah, there's nothing majorly wrong with this game in my opinion. Music's great as well.

After playing 25 hours of Medieval II Total War I decided to write a review. My comments may be a little lengthy so for those not inclined to read further I will say  Buy this great game now!  . 

If you are reading onward I ought to say Im a relative noob when it comes to Total War games. I bought Napoleon TW about 2.5 years ago and Empire TW roughly 2 years ago and have clocked 80 hours in Napoleon TW and about 220 hours in Empire TW. Completely enjoyed my hours playing each of these games, having led the 95th Rifles successfully across Spain in Napoleon TW and captured all of North America 1st as the Brits and then again as the French in Empire TW. Lots of great battles along the way too! 

So when I saw the Medieval II TW Collection on sale for 75% off I decided I would buy it and see what it was like. Had read several good reviews of it and really couldnt beat the price anyways. Once it installed I was off and running, err galloping into the game. Very quickly I began to really enjoy the experience. One really cant tell its an 8 year old game. It runs well, plays great, and the battles are the usual TW standard I am used too.  If I had of known it was this good I would have bought it long before now. But as stated above Im fairly new to the world of TW gaming. I keep meaning to take screenshots during battles but keep forgetting to snap the pics once the action starts. Have to work on that!

My recommendation for this game is 9/10. More than one review I read about Medieval II Total War called it the best Total War game of all time. Im not able to state that myself but with 25 hours into the game so far I will say for anyone who likes Medieval period warfare this is the game for you. Nothing like making the right command, having your archers switch to fire arrows, only to see your enemys attacking siege tower go up in flames a few min later after some concentrated archery. Or standing on the walls of Rennes after a French attack with the battlements covered by bodies of both the attackers and my defenders. There is a pic of that in my content posts. The full price for the Collection of this game is $25 US. Well worth it if you want some great gaming now. If you feel like waiting, this game will be on sale in both the Steam Thanksgiving Sale and the Christmas / NYs Sales happening in the next 3 months. Hit the right days and youll be able to get a fantastic deal. Hope you have found my comments useful and they have helped you decide to buy this ever interesting game!

Probably the hardest and most fun Total War Game I've played. Medieval II does a great job with preserving a lot of the the really unique, interesting aspects of the original, such as the interplay with the Pope and your own world conquest initiative, a very complex and intense economic system, along with unique and important characters and agents (such as the new "merchant" unit who can buy out rival merchants or just make you money per turn, depending on the resource they are stationed on. This allows for both "attacking" economies and "defensive" economies!)

My problem is there are a couple of things that, while accurate, aren't really that fun to be on the receiving end of (inquistors... oh my god screw you,) and some of the base options of the game suck unless you fix it (trust me, do not have settlements go under auto-manage if you don't have a general stationed there. It makes the game way harder but also kills a lot of the fun!) Plus, while the myriad of units are really cool, and by really cool I mean incredibly awesome, early combat is extremely static (spearman stand in front of archers, archers shoot, cavalry flank, repeat for victory.)

Besides these minor pitfalls, the dozens of amazing parts of this game completely dominate and make this easily a must-have in your library if you love any of the Civilization style games, any RTS game such as Age of Empires, or if you liked any of the other Total War games, you need to play Medieval II. Heck, grab this and see if you might like those other titles!

A great TW Game, with very good grahics, good campaign map, and many other cool features. Gameplay is easy, and simple, with little experience in other TW games needed, though it does help to have a knowledge of TW games in general when playing *any* Total War game. Diplomacy is greatly improved, giving   the feture of seeing what the proposal's strength is(a HUGE plus, when compared to Empire's rather un-responsive AI Diplo), and the Campaign Map is of excellent quality(obviously not Rome II quality, as i is some years older, but still very good, and very detailed) Battles are great, with a good UI allowing full control of the battlefield, and immersive maps that truly do the game justice. Again, the graphics here are great, and very detailed in the city/castle making. Another big plus is the inclusion of the Family Tree, later removed, which is great for viewing whom is within an ever growing family, and who should be king(a great plus over having to kill off the un-desired heir in the previous Medieval: Total War XD).
I cant give this game enough positive reviews, and have yet to come across anytihg negative.

This day is called the feast of Crispian:
He that outlives this day, and comes safe home,
Will stand a tip-toe when the day is named,
And rouse him at the name of Crispian.
He that shall live this day, and see old age,
Will yearly on the vigil feast his neighbours,
And say 'To-morrow is Saint Crispian:'
Then will he strip his sleeve and show his scars.
And say 'These wounds I had on Crispin's day.'
Old men forget: yet all shall be forgot,
But he'll remember with advantages
What feats he did that day: then shall our names.
Familiar in his mouth as household words
Harry the king, Bedford and Exeter,
Warwick and Talbot, Salisbury and Gloucester,
Be in their flowing cups freshly remember'd.
This story shall the good man teach his son;
And Crispin Crispian shall ne'er go by,
From this day to the ending of the world,
But we in it shall be remember'd;
We few, we happy few, we band of brothers;
For he to-day that sheds his blood with me
Shall be my brother; be he ne'er so vile,
This day shall gentle his condition:
And gentlemen in England now a-bed
Shall think themselves accursed they were not here,
And hold their manhoods cheap whiles any speaks
That fought with us upon Saint Crispin's day.
-Shakespeare Henry V

Let me start by saying I am [i]not[/i] easily impressed. I think my several "Not Recommended" reviews are a testament to that. That being said, Medieval II: Total War is one of those games that really knocks my socks off.

What sticks out first to me is the level of detail put into the battle system. The idea of different units having morale levels that go up and down depending on events going on around them is amazing. It seems apparent that someone on the dev team thumbed through a military strategy guide too. Leaving a route for an enemy to escape to encourage them to flee rather than fight to the death is something touched on in the opening sections of [i]De Re Militari[/i], and such a tactic is encouraged in the game as surrounded enemies who try routing will instead fight to the death or until they manage to break through the encirclement.

Another thing I like is the level of detail put into unit animations. Considering the time this was developed I find it rather impressive. I knocked a guy off a wall with an explosive cannon shot and could hear him scream while he fell to his death. That was a couple days ago and it's still stuck in my head.

The music is great. It can get repetitive, but it's got that blood-pumping feel to it that mimics the gameplay perfectly. I don't know what more I can say about it. If you haven't heard it, go check it out on Youtube or something, assuming the copyright Jews haven't taken it down yet.

Like I said, I'm not easily impressed. If Medieval II: Total War can elicit a positive response from me, that's a pretty good indicator that its creators did something right.

576 hours on record and I still have so much try on this game. It is in my opinion the ultimate strategy game and best of the Total War series. The main menu music and background instantly give you a taste of the grand scale and epic setting. Even compared to Rome 2 it is visually stunning and will run great on most newer systems, although I remember when it first came out it was brutally demanding of graphics power. One aspect that sets this game out from the others in the series is the religion factor. Yes, the other games have it also, but not to the lenghts of this game. Sending a massive crusading army across Europe and into the Middle East, and than being met by an opposing Jihad force is simply stunning. Than depending on the outcome of the crusade you will either be greatly rewarded by the church for victory, or for failure you may be excommunicated and cast as an enemy to the Christiandom! Another unique feature is the guilds. While their effects and purpose are hard to see at first, they will progressively become more helpful to your nation and will lead to some awesome and elite troops specific to different factions. For example, England can develop a woodsmen guild in Nottingham and once it reaches a certain level, you can recruit Sherwood archers that can camoflauge in the woods and have tremendous range. The powerful Knights Templar are another guild specific to Christian Nations, while eastern nations have the Hashassins guild. If there is one thing that frustrates me during combat, it is that sometimes archers don't fire directly at the enemy when there on walls, but it just takes some practice mastering their line of sight and taking advantage of their range. I also wish there were more historical battles as they provide some awesome scenerios and challenging battles. I recommend going through atleat one play through as the vanilla game, and than trying out the VAST amounts of full and partial mods that have been made for this game. You can even try your own costumizations to the script and combinations of different modification until you find the perfect balance for you. All in all, this a game for the ages and is better than 99% of the garbage that comes out nowadays.

An essential for any Historical Strategy/Battle fan. 17 unique factions, over 100 regions to conquer and an incredibly immersive soundtrack make M2: TW a vast improvement over Rome - soldier appearances are randomised, world events (the plague, the Mongol invasion etc.) can shatter the status quo, and the ability to choose between cities (financial strongholds) and castles (troop factories) adds a new level of decision-making when capturing a settlement.
While Papal favour and politics sound boring on paper, they quickly brings the most Machiavellian tencancies to light; calling crusades to draw away neighbouring armies before invading, flooding regions with agents to destabilise the government and rigging the vote for the Pope with the aid of gold and/or assassinations.
As with all Total War games, infantry occasionally have difficulty navigating onto and off of walls, but aside from that, Medieval 2: Total War is one of the best games in the series, and (in my opinion), the genre.
The war of the ages, packing historical facts and political decisions which will change the gameplay through and through changing what happens each time you playthrough.

A very fun game which can be about as challenging as you want it to be.

The strategy on the world map is very important, and logistics are by far the deepest part of it. Not hard to get into, mind you, but it takes some time to master. The battle tactics are much more difficult to become skilled at, but the game gives you incentives to do so, and it feels rewarding and exhillarating when you do. And if over-arching strategy is more your thing, and you find the battles themselves either not to your liking or too difficult, you can always just auto-resolve, and this game has an auto-resolve that actually favors the player rather than the AI like in most games. 

Excellent replayability, as there is a wide variance in unit type and viable playstyles between factions, not to mention you begin in different situations, with different neighbors, regions, and money.

If I had to mention a few cons, the diplomacy is broken. If you favor expansion, expect all of your neighbors to very quickly declare war on you, and they will very rarely make peace for anything. And even if they do, it won't last. Allies do not function properly (at all, really), and the Pope imposes debilitating penalties to your nation by demanding you not fight any other Catholic nation, even if those nations are the aggressors against you. The pathfinding for units is very bad, the enemy's battle AI, while efficient and skilled at what it is meant to do, is not overly intelligent, and understanding how to get infantry to attack properly is a nightmare.

Overall, though, it is a very good game that was quite lovingly made, with attention to detail and good voice-acting and music, even if there isn't that MUCH of those. Bugs are few, and it really makes you feel like a medieval administrator/warlord. Good stuff.

Let's start off gameplay, the gameplay is the best i've seen in the Total War series, you can battle with over 15+ factions. (More if you use mods or edit the games programming). And a wonderful gameplay experience. You can use a variety of units based on real life units. (Ex. Highland Pikemen...My favorite Scotland unit.) and not just the Campaign or Custom battling experience, you have a chance to face off with Historical battles, battles that are designed and developed to show the real life experience.

Multiplayer - I don't like how it's setup, wishing it was more like Empire Total Wars where you can just set a username and start playing, but on here you have to make an account at some site... Campaign - The campaign at first you get 5 factions. There is a Short and Long campaign mode, and you can play and do certain objectives, depending the faction. Certain factions have to take over certain regions, and certain factions have to have a certain amount of regions. For newer players to the Campaign area, you can adjust the settings of AI managing. For example you can set it to AI manage the entire game where you can only move and command troops...take over cities..etc Or you can manage only recruitment or building or both and let the computer handle taxes. My first run at campaign I managed everything and succeeded until I got to a certain amount of Regions then I lost control. But it's easier to let the computer do it first, then watch and see what it builds and recruits..etc. Also if you are non-patient and like to get through the movements of the AI you can switch the + type thing off and skip the AI movements. If you are a hardcore gamer, I do suggest you try the campaign.


Single Player - Custom Battles... My least favorite kinda... I like the idea of playing from each faction and free battling, but I really don't like not being able to have seige battles or having scenarios in that field. Otherwise it's self-explanitory really you just pick out certain units for each and every team, then you battle. Only a handful of maps, all the factions already unlocked, and tons of units. 

The overall review, the game is great and addicting. I don't play a lot but if I'm already at 10 hours it's addicting. Some other players played for over 1000+ hours. Pretty sad right? No hell nah! Hehe.

Medieval II: Total War is the most engaging and interesting nation-builder I've ever played. This is the last Total War game to NOT implement technology research, which makes it more fast-paced and straight forward than its successors. The game takes place in the lands surrounding the Mediterranean and a portion of the Americas. If you like Civilization, you'll love ME2, because the pace is steadier, the locationsare real, and the map isn't based on square/hexagonal textures. All of the factions, units, events, and gameplay aspects pertain to actual history. This game taught me more about medieval history, warfare, and tactics than  Middle School and High School ever could.

Medieval II Total War is a RTS (real time sratergy) of sorts that lets you play as one of the medieval super powers of that age, each with their own strengths and weaknesses.

For example France has the best knights in the game but suffers when it comes to infantry whether they be archers or spear men. But England has worse knights but better foot soldiers.

When starting the game the player has a number of options (besides the options menu and quiting the game of course). I have not covered  multiplayer in this review as I have no idea if any of the public servers work as I have never tried any of them,  but the single player,  oh boy i can tell you,  that it is good.

First off the game gives you a custom battle mode. So, if you ever wondered what it would be like to have an army of nothing but peasants charge a fully equipped renaissance castle filled to the brim with archers with flaming arows, now you can find out!

Then there's the campaign which might be confusing to some, but I suggest either looking up some hints and tips on the forums or replaying the tutorial. The campaign also has diplomacy, and very good diplomacy at that. And the best part is, the A.I does make deals with you that are in your favour, such as giving you gold or line of sight to where they live if you ally with them. As well as that there are spies for taking a peek at what your foes are doing and how big a force they have, as well as assasins for when you just need to go all stabby, stabby on that certain duke or king.

Even though the graphics are not up to date whith what todays graphics are, they still look good even if you zoom right in on people's faces.
That, and the way a castle looks when you bring its walls down with everyone on top falling through the new hole you just made, is awsome.

The game also involves a lot of strategy. I can tell. And even if you sort of suck at it, like I do, you can still have a lot of fun witth this game. Basic tactics (allthough not as good) can still win you the game, at least against the medium A.I. as charging your entire hourse-back army down a hill to smash into your foe's unprotected rear is a tactic.

Also, this game handles flaming projectiles really well, as hitting your enemy's peasants feels really satisfying, as well as making you really glad that you are not one of  those poor fools. This goes for catapults and trebuchets as well, exept bigger and much more deadly ones. You can also make enemy siege weapons burn down, which makes you feel like such a troll to the stupid A.I.  As you say "nope!" as your archers burn down an entire siege tower and the men who were just using it are forced to use ladders, only to be poked to death by your spear-men, now waiting at the top for them.

So, all in all, I give it a 9/10 as there are some things that bug me a little, such as 1 guy with a leather shield blocking 10 arrows at once or a knight in full plate-mail bursting into flames at the first fire arrow.

This is the last pre-warscape CA Total War game, and really the last that could be successfully modded extensively.  This latter piece of the puzzle matters because some of the community dating back to when the game originallly released went to a lot of trouble to make mods, such as Stainless Steel and the total conversion for Lord of the Rings: Third Age.

For me, the charm of Medieval 2 though is really centered around the game itself, the time period is so well suited for the style of game play that CA makes with the turn based stragegy map combined with the real time tactical battles that the result is just endless amounts of fantastic game play.

This and Shogun 2 are for me the two best games CA has ever created.  Thumbs way up.

Medieval II: Total War is probably my personal favorite entry in the Total War franchise. This is partially due to my love of the time period, partially due to my previous obsession with the original Medieval: Total War (if they added that to Steam, I'd snap it up in a heartbeat), but largely because it managed to find the perfect balance between complexity and simplicity when it comes to campaign options - a balance which later entries in the series have tried to reproduce but often fall to one side or the other in attempting.

Like all Total War games, Medieval II features a turn-based strategy map where the player manages their armies and cities, and a real-time tactical battlefield where they play out combat against opponents' armies. Medieval II covers the medieval period of Europe (and includes northern Africa and portions of the Middle East), allowing your faction to attempt to conquer the entirety of the western world of the time.

It's fantastic and an enormous timesink. The graphics hold up surprisingly well for a game that was almost released a decade ago, in large part because the spectacle is so based on the massive numbers in the armies instead of incredible detail on the individual units.

Medieval II is a wonderful game, and I heartily recommend it to any strategy fans.

Following the huge success that was Rome, developers Creative Assembly turned their talents to a 'remake' of Medieval: Total War. All that made Rome TW great was included in this one: a detailed campaign map, zooming in close to your troops during battle, generals with personalilty and characteristics (which makes for amusing pre-battle speeches!), vast, credibly sized cities....

Furthermore, a couple of differences helped put Medieval 2 on par and, at times, above Rome. A new graphics engine replaced the 'technicolor' effect of Rome, doing justice to the metallic effect of armour and ever sharpening detail; Medieval 2 appears darker, gritty, alongside a menacing atmosphere. Whilst Diplomats play their usual role, Assassin's also return - and, true to the feedback of TW fans, those enjoyable 'mission' videos (sadly lacking in Rome) have reappeared so you can follow their success or failure. 

This is a world of religious beliefs; Priests are instrumental in spreading the godly influence of your faction: use them to either assauge dissident elements in your own provinces, or send them into rival lands and provoke rebellions! However, beware of pushing your luck when attacking 'fellow' Christian factions - dismissing the Pope's (a new gameplay mechanic) warning to cease hostilities will eventually excommunicate you, declaring your people heretical, thus making you fair game for rival factions. Death of a Pope and voting in a new one will have profound effect upon your fortunes - so hope you haven't too many 'unfriendly' rivals in the College of Cardinals. You will also be given the opportunity to prove your piety when requested to take part in a Crusade (Christian) or Jihad (Muslim). Embarking for a heretical target earns you gratitude from the Pope (always handy) and you can share in the loot of a successful venture.  

Gunpowder also found its niche in warfare during this period. As you progress and develop building tech trees, more powerful cannon can be recruited and utilized to deadly effect - especially during sieges. Crude types of 'handgun' first appeared during the high stage of medieval times, introducing a new infantry unit. As before, certain buildings can help cities expand, recruit quality units, maintain populace contentment, and improve on trade. 

Many nobles and wealthy knights captured by a victorious foe were seen as worthy ransoms. In victory, you'll also be presented the option of either 'releasing', 'slaughtering', or 'ransoming' captured enemy units. Your choice will affect the 'chivalry' or 'dread' aspects of the general who won the battle, whilst moulding the attitude of rival factions: carefully weigh decisions in face of considering peace negotiations with that faction in the future. 

There are some fascinating 'events' - such as inventions, scientific discoveries, the arts, newfound philosophies, and political incidents - marking your progress through the ever developing Medieval 2. Gunpowder is one, while another key moment is much more terrible: the Black Death! As population levels drastically drop, so too does trade and industrial output, affecting finances, reducing city garrisons to a literally skeleton force. If you manage to survive the plague's deathly scourge, then it's time for rebirth and rebuild. Indeed, it makes you wonder how our ancestors did it in reality. One other key moment is discovering the New World - although a much more elaborate  and longer campaign in this idea unfolds in the Kingdoms expansion - but in the main game you'll have to be content with conquering a few areas which represent the Americas. Although one of very few negative points, it's still fun taking an army across the vast Atlantic in a mad race to be the first to make a landfall! 

Medieval 2: Total War is often regarded one of the best in the series, capitalizing on Rome's design and success, whilst presenting some excellent new gameplay features alongside a revamped engine. Certainly, I've made several returns (each time starting a campaign from scratch with a different faction) and saw it through to the bitter end...hours of scheming and battling fun to be had here!

Medieval 2 is the first game in the Total War series that I have purchased, but after watching many gameplay videos on Youtube and various other sites, I had very high expectations for the game. Within less than an hour, all of my expectations were met. Medieval 2 has a fairly straight forward learning curve, and is very forgiving to those who are new to the game. With both skirmishes and a grand campaign, there is plenty to do, with many different factions to choose from, each with their own unique units and specialties. With a fantastic engine and good graphics, the game feels very realistic. The campaign is very deep, with many different agents and battles, making you come up with new strategy's every time you play. Beating the campaign unlocks the rest of the factions to play as, with you only starting with five. Overall I would rate this game as an 8/10, as there are some minor bugs.

One of the finest RTS games I have played and probably my only real favourite in the Total War series.  

Within this game you start off as one of the monarchies of the medieval era, England, France, Spain etc, inhabiting the West with the Turks, Egyptians, the Moors etc controlling most of the Eastern regions.  And I use control loosely, for this game is about constant strife, border control and damning your so called allies to your own religious hierarchies.  

The gameplay itself is split into two halves.  One half is the typical RTS strategic combat, where two armies with varied units, face each other on the battlefield to determine a victor!  In this part of the game, there is a Rock Paper Scissors style of strategy, with Spears besting Knights, Knights besting Archers and Archers besting Spears, though as your own technology expands and your coffers grow larger, more diverse units will be available to you.
The AI can be a little stupid at times, often forgetting your commands or taking an insanely longer route than it needs to travel to reach it's destination.  So some micromanagement is needed there.  


The second part of the gameplay is entirely Turn-Based.  
You begin with a selection of territories relevant to your faction's Monarchy, you also have your own Royal Family who each have their own needs and quirks which affect your overall strategy.  And in this phase of the game you'll be charged with building your resources, exploring the world, and interacting with your neighbours.  

Honestly I find this part of the game to actually be rather interesting, it's always fun to approach your neighbours with peace offerings and treaties, only to plan treachery for when the time is right.  And there are numerous and inventive ways you can attempt to accomplish this through, in a very Game of Thrones style of diplomacy if you're familiar with the subject matter.

I found this to be the better of the Total War series.  Others will have their preferences to Rome, Shogun or maybe even the Napoleonic Wars, but if you have any doubts of either, just do your research.  I hope my review will help contribute to that.

Put simply, Medieval II: Total War is, while not perfect, one of the best strategy games available for PC. Medieval 2 combines large-scale battles with an overarching grand strategy-esque campaign map. It's complete with a large number of factions, an evolving campaign map, diplomacy, and intrigue.


The campaign can best be described as Grand strategy lite (This isn't a knock on the game, as I'll explain). Expanding your state and managing your cities, economy, diplomacy, agents, family members and armies is an involving process and ultimatly more important than the battles themselves, but is also accesable enough for almost anyone to get into. If you have even glancing knowledge of games like Civilization, you will be able to jump right in with little trouble. The campaign (at most difficulties) thus comes off as well balanced, as its easy to get into but requires some serious time to master. 

Religion also plays a big part in the campaign, as Catholic factions have to deal with the tremendous power of the church and the pope, who can direct policy with almost every action he takes, and even call crusades and excommunicate factions. Islamic factions can call Jihads to rapidly conquer problem locations. Religion adds an interesting dynamic to the game, as a settlement bordering a nation of a different religion might start to experience unrest as competing ideologies debate in the streets. Religion gives an interesting interconnecting feeling to factions who, politically and millitarily might be at odds with one another but share the same faith, or might share competing faiths but similar goals. 

The large battles are likley to be what drives most people to try out the game though, and for good reason. They are absolutly massive and very entartaining to watch (though, up close, some of the animations can look a bit silly) and require skill to win. After building up forces on the campain map and moving them into position, 2 (or more armies) clash, zooming in the camera from the tactical campaign view to the ground to command the action. The map for the battle, however, is not pre made- it's generated from the terrain on the campaign map. Every building, farm, and mountain is present. When in battle you have to take into account unit type, terrain, exhaustion and even weather.

However, the battle map puts into sharp vision one of the games biggest problems: the AI. Its by no means an issue that makes the game unlpayable, but when the gods of randomness decide for the problem to rear its ugly head, it can be pretty unnerving. Sometimes in battle the AI can be outright genious, only to become completly idiotic in the next battle. On the Campaign map, factions sometimes will try to assault heavily guarded fortresses with armies composesed of 2 archers. Like I stated before, its not always the case, but its common enough for it to be a problem worth noting. 

However, the game is insanley moddable, which can fix the problem outright in itself. Have another problem with the game? think its not tolkein-esque enough? download the Third Age: Total War mod. Hate the AI or think the campain map is too small? (Which, spoiler alert: its pretty fucking huge to begin with) Download Stainless Steel. The moddability is another contributing factor to another huge plus in the games favor: Its almost infinite replayability. Outside of mods, no two campaigns will be the same.

In the end, this is a fantastic game that almost any fan of strategy will adore.

TL;DR: Buy it, its pretty fantastic.

I've played Shogun TW, Medieval TW, Medieval 2 TW, Empire TW and Shogun 2 TW and this game by far is the best of them all. It's one of the best strategy games I've ever played. I'm speaking from a strictly SP POV though. The game is pretty old now but it still looks quite nice with the settings turned up.

I've never been able to figure out diplomacy in this game so I always just end up making a lot of enemies and crushing them by brute force. I'm not sure if that's my play style or a flaw in the game's diplomacy system though.

The AI is decently intelligent both on the campaign map and on the battlefield.

I absolutely hate and despise naval battles in all TW games after this one. It's one of the main reasons I haven't been able to enjoy any newer TW titles. Naval battles in Medieval 2 are simple. You build a fleet and all battles are auto resolved. Easy, fast and out of the way so you can concentrate on the really fun stuff - land battles and expansion. I don't know if I'm alone in thinking that naval battles are trash and have ruined the newer TW games, but you definitely don't have to worry about that in this game.

There are a lot of factions you can play and they all have small differences but you can generalize all of them into 4 super factions that share a lot of similar traits and units: western Europe, eastern Europe, north Africa and middle east. Playing through the campaign as different factions is fun and rewarding.

The bottom line is this game is pretty amazing and you should definitely give it a try.

If you love the time period and liked Rome Total War then this game is for you.  I was not that happy with the game until I learned how to effectively charge knights. In Rome Total War you simply double clicked on what you wanted dead. In Medieval ll  you have to keep your formation in line before attacking. This is accomplished be judging the ground between you and the enemy unit you want to decimate.  When you are at a run with your knights and they are formed up in line hit the attack order (Double click).  Hitting them head on is a must (unless they are pike men then hit them from the back) spearmen don't stand a chance when a formed charge hits them. The diplomacy in  this game is involved and steeped in history. The different agents can help you do things like cement alliances with marriage or steal money from other nations with merchants.  The pope has impact on your decisions when you are a catholic nation. The crusades are very fun and a good mini quest which will help you groom princes to become better kings. The family tree adds a personnel touch which makes you actually care about your generals. The availability of mods also makes this a great game for instance if you get tired of the same old game then you can download something like Stainless steel mod which overhauls the entire game.

Medieval II Total War is a good game, a fun game. But when put beside it's predecessors, it's also a very small game. I am not talking about size here, or even the scope of the game but more it's advancement over the previous installment. It's that same question you always have to ask yourself every time a franchise you enjoy comes out with a new installment.

Should I get the new one or just replay the old one? In the case of Medieval II the answer is, you might as well go play another campaign in Rome.

While Medieval by itself is a great game that promises hours of entertainment it doesn't really do anything that you couldn't already do in Rome. Most of the new features are minor in nature or simply cosmetic the lack of advancement is instantly noticeable when you realize that Medieval even managed to bring over a few bugs from Rome that were never quite fixed.

For the newcomers to the series, Medieval II Total War is a mix between a real time strategy game and a turn based grand strategy game. The turn based aspect focuses mainly on empire management, improving your cities, raising and moving armies and conducting diplomacy with other factions. This area has traditionally been the weak spot of Total War games and Medieval makes no changes there. The system is clunky and bugged, the AI is completely worthless and the diplomacy might as well not have been included. Anything the grand strategy aspect of Total War tries to do has already been done a thousand times better in pretty much every other grand strategy game.

But then again, you don't buy a Total War game for the cerebral strategy. You buy it for the guts and glory of the the real time battles where armies clash and legion perish all for the hope of victory and while the satisfaction you get from a successful maneuver is still present so is the complete lack of any sort of intelligence on the part of your opponents. As with all other Total War games, the AI is incapable of doing anything beyond the classic attack move with no concern for formation, flanking or skirmishing leading to almost every battle being a cakewalk unless you are terribly outnumbered.

Graphically the series still impress although the uniformity with your units is beginning to show, the sounds work well enough that you are never taken out of the action and the soundtrack is acceptable most of the time.

All in all Medieval II is a good and fun game that you can spend hundreds of hours in easily. Should you buy it still comes down to that same question however. If you have never played a Total War game I would always recommend you get the newest in the series. Medieval II is still an advancement over Rome, albeit a very minor one. If you already own Rome however then there is little new for you here and you would probably be better off saving your money for further down the line when another installment in the series comes along with a more profound leap in mechanics and technology.

My personal favorite in the Total War series. Medieval 2 gains a lot by being set in a time and place that is more or less easily recognizable to westerners. 

Assuming you start the game as the default English or French, you'll be mostly battling accross Europe with late game forays into northern Africa, western Russia, and the Middle East. Your units will, for the most part, also be familiar and easily understood. Even a casual student of medieval European history will understand why charging a spear wall with calvary is a bad idea, or why you don't use tight formations to advance into arrow or catapult fire. The game's medieval atmosphere is further boosted by a provocative musical score, accurate sound effects, and nation-themed voice dialogue. 

Gamplay in Medieval II, like any Total War game, is dividied between the strategic global campaign map and tactical maps where battles are played out. 

The strategic gameplay is solid, and players will be required to juggle tax income, religion, unrest, noble desires, and public health with the logistical demands of supporting your armies between battles. While the game lacks the research tech tree introduced in Empire, technology pacing is present through city building. As you build and upgrade your stables, archery ranges, and barracks you'll gain access to new troop types while smithies, jousting fields, and swordsmen guilds will enhance the equipment and quality of troops. 

Tactical gameplay is fantastic with players having strong control over formations, positioning, and abilities. Complexity is added in with morale and stamina mechanics, both of which are easily understood and implemented in a way that makes sense. 

The few faults that do exist in the tactical gameplay only emerge when directly comparing the game to more recent Total Wars, like Shogun 2 or Rome 2. Combat and unit cohesion in Medieval 2 can feel more rigid and unresponsive than its successors, but never enough to seriously impede gameplay.

I love this game, it's the pinnacle of the Total War series for me.

The original games look horrifically primitive in comparison to the more modern ones, and the new ones have some weird limitations. I like  the eccentricities of this version, like if you're playing one of the Catholic factions you're subject to the whims of the AI pope. If you defy him, your king gets excommunicated leading to unruly towns and potential disaster. However, if you've trained a coterie of assassins on bandit leaders... well it's a completely different story. Then you can send these assassins to kill pope after pope and automatically get reconciled... I'm going straight to Hull. Or maybe just Grimsby. At least it's fun solo without the online Scunthorpes

Then there's all the guilds, and the two story ... well they're not twists exactly but when the Mongols and then the Timurids turn up in the East you had better be ready, and have very large amies guarding every bridge choke point in Asia Minor, plus gunpowder turrets on all your cities. Actually you're going to get spanked and spend quite a while pushing them back...

There is the element where a quick burst of conquest at the beginning sets you up wonderfully to steamroll your neighbours, but the faction balance plus the religious faction element makes it much more challenging

I think I have to try and win as the Russians & Byzantnes on the highest difficulty...

9/10 but try a demo if you've never played one of the others, it's sort of it's own genre

A good mix of turn-based and real-time strategy, although the turn-based elements often feel oversimplified. It does have a solid real time combat foundation, but the AI is either really good or really bad depending on the difficulty setting--there is no middle ground. If you are new to real time strategy games, this one has a pretty steep learning curve. Even seasoned players may feel overwhelmed. 17 different factions on top of long and short campaigns give a lot of room for different story paths and immense replayability. One campaign can take days, even months of play time.

Being the 4'th game in the Total War franchise Medieval II Total War kicks in with new graphical options and fancy brand new options. As always improving upon the previous games and switching the time periods, take control of one of the 17 kingdoms and lead them to conquest!

Very involved.  Follows Rome: Total War very well, but with the added bonus of knights.  Also, new interesting dynamic with the Pope and the Papal States apply subtle yet definite pressure on the player to give more attention to the political aspects of the game.  Basically, this game is awesome.

This is an excellent game with enough factions to keep you entertained for endless hours.  I've played the campaign as England, France, Spain, Holy Roman Empire, Byzantine, Egypt and more.  Each gives a new angle to the game.  On top of that you get a great modding community that has then gone on to improve the base game and create new challenging scenarios.

The map is always Europe and nothren africa and a litle of the middle east. You can not be in Finland and nothren Norway and Sweden.

It is nice and simple task.. To eliminate the enemy throug out strategy. You have a Navy and a Army. You also have a king, so you may control your nation and of course a prince and the rest of the royal family.

A terrific Total War Game. he good thing about the game is that it doesn't require a excellent system to play like most games, and it still has good graphics. In the game, you can play as one nation out of many, like England, Spain, Venice, Spain, etc. But in order to unlock more, you must beat the game on one of the games first 6 nations. It also has a good timeline, every turn equals 2 years, Real world events even come into play, Mass making of paper in the West, Mongols Invading, And discovering Gunpowder. And as you progress you unlock more units to use. A very good game for stradegists, but may be quite hard for new players.
The graphics and gameplay fall between Empire and Rome, just as the game did chronologically. That said, either one of those is probably a better choice unless you really like medieval stuff.
